Primary_Text: He followed her with his eyes.
Translated_Text: He followed her with his eyes.
Comment: This "visual following" is a distinct polysemic meaning.

Translated_Text: Can you help?

Primary_Text: The rain washed away all the leaves away.
Translated_Text: The rain washed away all the leaves away.
Comment: This is a distinct meaning of wash, only possible with "water" subjects such as rain, river, tears, etc. It normally requires some kind of locational expression.

Primary_Text: I generally wash the delicate items by hand.
Translated_Text: I generally wash the delicate items by hand.

Primary_Text: Have you washed behind your ears?
Translated_Text: Have you washed behind your ears?
We touched.
We talked for hours.

Primary_Text: She talked at me for hours.
Translated_Text: She talked at me for hours.
Comment: Notice that a topic phrase with about is unacceptable in this construction, e.g. ?She talked at me about it for hours.

Primary_Text: The road follows the river for ten kilometers or so.
Translated_Text: The road follows the river for ten kilometers or so.

Primary_Text: It won't help to talk to him when he's drunk.
Translated_Text: It won't help to talk to him when he's drunk.

Primary_Text: Antibiotics won't help to prevent an ear infection.
Translated_Text: Antibiotics won't help to prevent an ear infection.

Primary_Text: Feeling sorry for yourself won't help.
Translated_Text: Feeling sorry for yourself won't help.

Primary_Text: Let me help you with those those bags.
Translated_Text: Let me help you with those those bags.

Primary_Text: Can you help me with my homework?
Translated_Text: Can you help me with my homework?
Comment: help with - is this an alternation? It's pretty common, with "activity" nouns such as housework, chores, investigation.

Primary_Text: Persil washes well and it's not too expensive.
Translated_Text: Persil washes well and it's not too expensive.
Comment: Persil is a brand of washing detergent.

Primary_Text: Cotton/polyester fabric washes well and requires little or no ironing.
Translated_Text: Cotton/polyester fabric washes well and requires little or no ironing.
I'm scared of his temper.

Primary_Text: I am afraid for my children.
Translated_Text: I am afraid for my children.

Primary_Text: I was afraid to mention to him.
Translated_Text: I was afraid to mention to him.

Primary_Text: He was afraid for his daughter's life.
Translated_Text: He was afraid for his daughter's life.

Primary_Text: She feared him for his temper.
Translated_Text: She feared him for his temper.
She feared his temper.
Comment: This looks like it could be a candidate for what Levin (1993: 74) calls the "Attribute Object" alternation, but it does quite fit the bill as the putative alternate (*She feared the temper in him) is not acceptable. Preferable to see it as a variant of She feared him for his temper.

Translated_Text: This stuff really smells.
Comment: Implies that it 'smells bad'.

Primary_Text: I was still eating lunch when he arrived.
Translated_Text: I was still eating lunch when he arrived.
Comment: Though both are superficially transitive, expressions like eat lunch, eat dinner, etc. belong to a different construction type to eat an apple, etc.

Translated_Text: He stole my bike.
Comment: This doesn't sit well as a "possessor ascension" version of He stole the bike from me, because the former sentence implies real ownership, whereas the latter only requires temporary possession, e.g. I had borrowed my sister's bike and while I had someone stole it from me.

Primary_Text: The child stole cookies from the cookie jar.
Translated_Text: The child stole cookies from the cookie jar.

Primary_Text: He stole the old lady's money.
Translated_Text: He stole the old lady's money.

Primary_Text: The thief stole money from the old lady.
Translated_Text: The thief stole money from the old lady.

Primary_Text: We got a loan from the bank.
Translated_Text: We got a loan from the bank.

Primary_Text: He got a prize for the best undergraduate essay in his year.
Translated_Text: He got a prize for the best undergraduate essay in his year.

Primary_Text: I got an email from Christina today.
Translated_Text: I got an email from Christina today.

Primary_Text: I got a new bike for Christmas.
Translated_Text: I got a new bike for Christmas.

Primary_Text: What kind of wood makes the strongest walking stick?
Translated_Text: What kind of wood makes the strongest walking stick?

Primary_Text: Merino wool makes great socks and stuff.
Translated_Text: Merino wool makes great socks and stuff.

Primary_Text: The first thing to do is to make a fire.
Translated_Text: The first thing to do is to make a fire.

Primary_Text: Did you make it or buy it?
Translated_Text: Did you make it or buy it?

Primary_Text: It's best to get one that's made in Japan, the ones made in China are not as good.
Translated_Text: It's best to get one that's made in Japan, the ones made in China are not as good.

Primary_Text: My girlfriend made me a scarf.
Translated_Text: My girlfriend made me a scarf.

Primary_Text: Will you make me a cup of coffee sweetheart?
Translated_Text: Will you make me a cup of coffee sweetheart?

Primary_Text: In America they make ethanol from corn, in Brazil they make it from sugarcane.
Translated_Text: In America they make ethanol from corn, in Brazil they make it from sugarcane.

Primary_Text: How to make old bottles into lamps and vases.
Translated_Text: How to make old bottles into lamps and vases.

Primary_Text: You can easily make old jeans into shorts.
Translated_Text: You can easily make old jeans into shorts.

Primary_Text: She made the flour, eggs and milk into biscuits.
Translated_Text: She made the flour, eggs and milk into biscuits.

Primary_Text: She made biscuits out of rice flour.
Translated_Text: She made biscuits out of rice flour.

Primary_Text: He made a shelter out of branches and leaves.
Translated_Text: He made a shelter out of branches and leaves.

Primary_Text: A taxi can take four passengers at a time.
Translated_Text: A taxi can take four passengers at a time.

Primary_Text: He brought his racquet and sports shoes with him.
Translated_Text: He brought his racquet and sports shoes with him.

Primary_Text: He brought his brother with him.
Translated_Text: He brought his brother with him.

Primary_Text: In the morning they brought him fresh clothes and a hearty breakfast.
Translated_Text: In the morning they brought him fresh clothes and a hearty breakfast.
The girl brought me flowers.

Primary_Text: The child brought the money to me.
Translated_Text: The child brought the money to me.
She brought them to me.

Primary_Text: He ran at me with his fists raised.
Translated_Text: He ran at me with his fists raised.
I want you.
Comment: This is a formula (i.e. with a direct object designating a person). It probably represents a specialised meaning of want.

Primary_Text: I want a lift into town.
Translated_Text: I want a lift into town.
I want an icecream.

Primary_Text: She wants to know what you think about it.
Translated_Text: She wants to know what you think about it.

Primary_Text: I want you to wait here.
Translated_Text: I want you to wait here.
I want to go home.
She boiled the pot dry.
She boiled the water.
The water's boiling.

Primary_Text: Modern humans first appeared in Africa.
Translated_Text: Modern humans first appeared in Africa.

Primary_Text: This story first appeared in Le Monde.
Translated_Text: This story first appeared in Le Monde.
Comment: This is specialised "text-related" meaning; roughly, to appear in print, as opposed to appear in a place.

Primary_Text: All of a sudden her fairy Godmother appeared in front of her.
Translated_Text: All of a sudden her fairy Godmother appeared in front of her.
Don't cry for me Argentina.
Comment: A well-known line from a song, but illustrative of the "cry for" alternation.

Primary_Text: There's no point crying about it.
Translated_Text: There's no point crying about it.
"Get out now!", he cried.
Comment: This is a distinct "speech related" polysemic meaning.

Primary_Text: Tony Blair said he cried for the victims of the Iraq war.
Translated_Text: Tony Blair said he cried for the victims of the Iraq war.

Primary_Text: He abused my wife and made her cry.
Translated_Text: He abused my wife and made her cry.

Primary_Text: The first day he left home I cried my eyes out.
Translated_Text: The first day he left home I cried my eyes out.
She cried like a baby.

Primary_Text: I couldn't sleep because the baby was crying.
Translated_Text: I couldn't sleep because the baby was crying.

Primary_Text: He fell to his knees and wept.
Translated_Text: He fell to his knees and wept.

Primary_Text: I looked at her again but I still didn't recognise her.
Translated_Text: I looked at her again but I still didn't recognise her.
Look at me.

Primary_Text: Your problem is that you never listen.
Translated_Text: Your problem is that you never listen.
Comment: This is a distinct "speech related" meaning, not a purely "auditory" listen.

Translated_Text: Listen! Can you hear it?

Primary_Text: They listened patiently to the opening speeches.
Translated_Text: They listened patiently to the opening speeches.
Listen to me carefully.

Primary_Text: I didn't hear about it till yesterday.
Translated_Text: I didn't hear about it till yesterday.
Comment: This is a distinct meaning from purely "auditory" HEAR, cf. hear that ... .

Primary_Text: I heard that you got a new job.
Translated_Text: I heard that you got a new job.
Comment: This is a distinct meaning from purely "auditory" HEAR.

Translated_Text: I heard her snoring.

Primary_Text: I heard a loud bang in the car park.
Translated_Text: I heard a loud bang in the car park.
I heard shouting outside.

Primary_Text: I have a burning pain when I urinate.
Translated_Text: I have a burning pain when I urinate.

Primary_Text: She had a stabbing pain in her back.
Translated_Text: She had a stabbing pain in her back.

Primary_Text: I had a pain in my back.
Translated_Text: I had a pain in my back.
She hurt herself.
She hurt her foot.
It hurts!

Primary_Text: My neck hurts when I turn my head.
Translated_Text: My neck hurts when I turn my head.

Primary_Text: It must have fallen out of my pocket.
Translated_Text: It must have fallen out of my pocket.

Primary_Text: My i-pod fell into the water.
Translated_Text: My i-pod fell into the water.

Primary_Text: Apprarently the child fell from the balcony.
Translated_Text: Apprarently the child fell from the balcony.

Primary_Text: He slipped and fell into the pool.
Translated_Text: He slipped and fell into the pool.

Primary_Text: She fell down and hurt herself.
Translated_Text: She fell down and hurt herself.

Primary_Text: I felt hungry all the time.
Translated_Text: I felt hungry all the time.

Primary_Text: I wasn't hungry but I ate anyway.
Translated_Text: I wasn't hungry but I ate anyway.
The baby is hungry.

Primary_Text: The sun dried out the ground.
Translated_Text: The sun dried out the ground.

Primary_Text: I dried the clothes in the clothes-drier.
Translated_Text: I dried the clothes in the clothes-drier.

Primary_Text: The ground dried out after a day or so.
Translated_Text: The ground dried out after a day or so.
The clothes are dry.
It made me feel sick.

Primary_Text: I feel sick when I think about it.
Translated_Text: I feel sick when I think about it.

Primary_Text: I felt sick after lunch and wondered if the food was OK.
Translated_Text: I felt sick after lunch and wondered if the food was OK.

Primary_Text: I was too sick to go to work all last week.
Translated_Text: I was too sick to go to work all last week.

Primary_Text: I felt sad for some reason.
Translated_Text: I felt sad for some reason.
Comment: More "experiencer focussed" than be sad, and (relatedly) more at home with a 1SG subject.

Primary_Text: The little girl was sad because she'd lost her kitten.
Translated_Text: The little girl was sad because she'd lost her kitten.
I feel cold.
Comment: With the verb feel, the effect is more "experiencer focussed".

Translated_Text: My main meal was cold.
Comment: A secondary meaning.

Translated_Text: It was cold outside.
Comment: This is a secondary polysemic meaning of cold, used in relation to places and ambient conditions.

Translated_Text: I'm cold.

Primary_Text: The road went through the forest.
Translated_Text: The road went through the forest.
Comment: Go has a second polysemic meaning with an inanimate "path" subject.

Translated_Text: Go home!
Comment: Past-verbal home could be considered a realisation of an allative NP (esp. since go to home is ungrammatical), but it has some additional construction-specific semantics (go to your home(s) and go home appear to have subtly different meanings).

Translated_Text: We went three kilometres.
Comment: The post verbal expression is an "extent complement", not a direct object.

Primary_Text: The women went to the market every day.
Translated_Text: The women went to the market every day.

Primary_Text: I want you to sit down with him and talk it through.
Translated_Text: I want you to sit down with him and talk it through.
Comment: This is probably a distinct meaning of sit down, associated with the comitative valency extension. In this sense one can also sit down together.

Primary_Text: The children sat down on the bench and waited.
Translated_Text: The children sat down on the bench and waited.
He ran a marathon.
I ran ten kilometres yesterday.
Comment: The post verbal phrase is an "extent complement", not a syntactic direct object

Primary_Text: Phil used to run to and from work.
Translated_Text: Phil used to run to and from work.
The horse is running.
When did you leave?

Primary_Text: My wife left me for another man.
Translated_Text: My wife left me for another man.
Comment: This is a distinct polysemic sense of 'leave'.

Translated_Text: They left me there.
Comment: Is this an alternation or a different lexical sense of leave, i.e. 'to leave someone somewhere'? I'm inclined to think the latter.

Translated_Text: The boy left the village.
I sat the baby up.
Comment: Could be viewed as a coded alternation of Induced Stance, cf. She stood it up, She lay it down, She sat him down.

Primary_Text: The children sat on the floor.
Translated_Text: The children sat on the floor.

Primary_Text: The kids were screaming for icecream.
Translated_Text: The kids were screaming for icecream.

Primary_Text: She screamed at him to get out of her room.
Translated_Text: She screamed at him to get out of her room.
She screamed at me.
She screamed in fear.
This man is a hunter.
Their boat sunk on them.
We sank their boat.
The boat sank.
I rolled a smoke.
Comment: This is a specialised sense of roll as a verb of production, specifically for cigarettes.

Primary_Text: I rolled up the sleeping bag.
Translated_Text: I rolled up the sleeping bag.
Comment: This is the verb roll up, distinct from roll (either intransitive or transitive).

Primary_Text: The child rolled the ball down the hill.
Translated_Text: The child rolled the ball down the hill.

Primary_Text: The ball rolled across the floor.
Translated_Text: The ball rolled across the floor.

Primary_Text: I asked him to help me fill out the form.
Translated_Text: I asked him to help me fill out the form.

Primary_Text: I asked for help with filling out the form.
Translated_Text: I asked for help with filling out the form.
Comment: Other common complement nouns, aside from help, include permission, (an) explanation, directions.

Primary_Text: The boy asked his parents for money.
Translated_Text: The boy asked his parents for money.

Primary_Text: My little sister told on me.
Translated_Text: My little sister told on me.
He told me about it.
She told me to go.

Primary_Text: He could never tell a joke properly, the timing was always wrong.
Translated_Text: He could never tell a joke properly, the timing was always wrong.

Primary_Text: She told me a funny story.
Translated_Text: She told me a funny story.

Primary_Text: The children named their new puppies Bonnie, Mitzy, and Ben.
Translated_Text: The children named their new puppies Bonnie, Mitzy, and Ben.

Primary_Text: Some call it ganja, some call it weed, some call it marijuana.
Translated_Text: Some call it ganja, some call it weed, some call it marijuana.

Primary_Text: In German it's called 'das Auto', in English it's a 'car'.
Translated_Text: In German it's called 'das Auto', in English it's a 'car'.
This place is called Armidale.

Primary_Text: The children used to call me Uncle.
Translated_Text: The children used to call me Uncle.
They called him a fool.
They called the baby Anna.

Primary_Text: I like that you can get a refund if you're not satisfied.
Translated_Text: I like that you can get a refund if you're not satisfied.
Comment: I suspect that like taking a that-complement originated in American English but it is certainly spreading. I sometimes hear it now in spoken Australian English.

Primary_Text: I liked her for her sense of humour.
Translated_Text: I liked her for her sense of humour.
Roger likes playing tennis.
Pete really likes his PS3.
I'm scared of him.
He scares me sometimes.
His temper frightens me.
He was frightened of snakes.

Primary_Text: Oh my God, don't do that, you frightened me!
Translated_Text: Oh my God, don't do that, you frightened me!

Primary_Text: It turned out he was afraid of heights.
Translated_Text: It turned out he was afraid of heights.
I'm afraid of spiders.
He feared for his life.
He feared for her safety.

Primary_Text: Americans generally fear the Muslim Brotherhood.
Translated_Text: Americans generally fear the Muslim Brotherhood.
Comment: The verb to fear is not particularly common (cf. be afraid); generally the object is an abstract noun.

Translated_Text: His eyes blinked involuntarily.

Primary_Text: Coming out into the sunshine, I blinked a few times before I could see properly.
Translated_Text: Coming out into the sunshine, I blinked a few times before I could see properly.

Primary_Text: Coughing, sneezing and wheezing all symptoms of several dog diseases.
Translated_Text: Coughing, sneezing and wheezing all symptoms of several dog diseases.
She had a nasty cough.
Comment: This is not an instance of the have-a-VP(INF) construction. In the example, cough is a simple noun.

Translated_Text: I coughed up blood.
Comment: an instance of cough up

Primary_Text: I couldn't sleep, I was coughing all night.
Translated_Text: I couldn't sleep, I was coughing all night.

Primary_Text: At the time I was living in Armidale.
Translated_Text: At the time I was living in Armidale.
They live near the river.
They live in town.
She played me a sonata.
Comment: This is Benefactive alternation of play (i.e. play a musical instrument).

Translated_Text: She played a sonata.
Comment: This is a Cognate Object alternation of play (i.e. 'playing a musical instrument').

Translated_Text: She plays the guitar.
Comment: This is a distinct polysemic meaning of play (i.e. 'playing a musical instrument').

Translated_Text: They were playing tennis.
Comment: Any game name can be the post-verbal object, or the word game.

Primary_Text: The children were playing nicely together.
Translated_Text: The children were playing nicely together.

Primary_Text: The children were playing in the garden.
Translated_Text: The children were playing in the garden.
He taught geography and science.

Primary_Text: He was teaching a class on semantics.
Translated_Text: He was teaching a class on semantics.
She taught me about business.

Primary_Text: She taught him how to swim.
Translated_Text: She taught him how to swim.

Primary_Text: Every day the old lady taught a new song to one of the girls.
Translated_Text: Every day the old lady taught a new song to one of the girls.

Primary_Text: My grandmother taught me this song.
Translated_Text: My grandmother taught me this song.
His bum was showing.
Her bra strap was showing.

Primary_Text: She showed me where it was.
Translated_Text: She showed me where it was.

Primary_Text: The girls showed their teacher the pictures.
Translated_Text: The girls showed their teacher the pictures.

Primary_Text: The girls showed the pictures to their teacher.
Translated_Text: The girls showed the pictures to their teacher.
He took it with him.
Comment: Unclear whether this represents a distinct meaning ('take with one') and/or an alternation.

Translated_Text: He took her the money.

Primary_Text: I took the parcel over to him.
Translated_Text: I took the parcel over to him.

Primary_Text: He took the money from the drawer.
Translated_Text: He took the money from the drawer.
She hid her face.
Comment: Unclear whether this represents an alternation (body-part related) and/or a distinct use of hide.

Primary_Text: The child hid from his mother.
Translated_Text: The child hid from his mother.

Primary_Text: He hid it under the bed.
Translated_Text: He hid it under the bed.
Comment: Arguably hide necessarily implies a locus, i.e. 'one hides something somewhere'. It might be better to define this as the basic frame.

Primary_Text: The boy hid the frog from his mother.
Translated_Text: The boy hid the frog from his mother.
The soup is still cooking.
She cooked him a meal.

Primary_Text: She walked in while I was cooking.
Translated_Text: She walked in while I was cooking.
The men cooked the meat.

Primary_Text: He ground his knee into my back.
Translated_Text: He ground his knee into my back.
Comment: A different meaning to the primary 'grind P with I' meaning.

Primary_Text: She ground her hips against him.
Translated_Text: She ground her hips against him.
Comment: This is a distinct meaning from the 'grind P with I' meaning.

Translated_Text: He ground it into flour.

Primary_Text: The women ground the seeds with a mortar and pestle.
Translated_Text: The women ground the seeds with a mortar and pestle.

Primary_Text: I pushed my way through the crowd.
Translated_Text: I pushed my way through the crowd.
I pushed through the crowd.
Comment: I believe that this is an extended meaning, related to the way-construction.

Translated_Text: I pushed against the door.
Comment: This could be seen as an analogue of the Conative construction: it implies that force was applied via contact, but with it stops short of implying that there was any consequence movement.

Primary_Text: I tried to push him over but he was too strong.
Translated_Text: I tried to push him over but he was too strong.

Primary_Text: They managed to push it down the driveway and onto the street.
Translated_Text: They managed to push it down the driveway and onto the street.

Primary_Text: He pushed her into the water.
Translated_Text: He pushed her into the water.

Primary_Text: She dug a lot of potatoes yesterday.
Translated_Text: She dug a lot of potatoes yesterday.

Primary_Text: They dug their way out (of the wreckage).
Translated_Text: They dug their way out (of the wreckage).

Primary_Text: They dug through the top layer of sediment.
Translated_Text: They dug through the top layer of sediment.

Primary_Text: She's digging a new garden bed.
Translated_Text: She's digging a new garden bed.
He dug a hole.
Comment: Other comparable "objects" are: tunnel, well, grave, ditch, trench.

Translated_Text: She was digging for potatoes.

Primary_Text: She was digging in the garden.
Translated_Text: She was digging in the garden.

Primary_Text: He wiped the tears from his eyes.
Translated_Text: He wiped the tears from his eyes.
He wiped his eyes/face/hands.
She wiped the table.

Primary_Text: She wiped the crumbs off the table.
Translated_Text: She wiped the crumbs off the table.

Primary_Text: I covered my eyes with my hands.
Translated_Text: I covered my eyes with my hands.

Primary_Text: Her face was covered with freckles.
Translated_Text: Her face was covered with freckles.
Comment: Expressions like these (describing the appearance of a surface, without implying any prior movement event) are probably best regarded as lexicalised. Formally they are parallel to Ambitransitive, but even in the active voice a sentence like Freckles covered her face does not imply an event of covering (unlike, for example, Snow covered the ground).

Translated_Text: Snow covered the ground.

Primary_Text: The woman covered her son with a blanket.
Translated_Text: The woman covered her son with a blanket.

Primary_Text: They loaded her into the ambulance.
Translated_Text: They loaded her into the ambulance.

Primary_Text: He loaded the truck with hay.
Translated_Text: He loaded the truck with hay.

Primary_Text: The farmer loaded the hay onto the truck.
Translated_Text: The farmer loaded the hay onto the truck.
The water filled the glass.

Primary_Text: She filled the glass with water.
Translated_Text: She filled the glass with water.

Primary_Text: I tied the ribbon into a bow.
Translated_Text: I tied the ribbon into a bow.

Primary_Text: He tied the rope onto the branch.
Translated_Text: He tied the rope onto the branch.

Primary_Text: He tied the rope around the tree.
Translated_Text: He tied the rope around the tree.
They tied him down.
He tied a reef knot.

Primary_Text: He tied the horse to the tree with a rope.
Translated_Text: He tied the horse to the tree with a rope.

Primary_Text: He could pour a perfect beer.
Translated_Text: He could pour a perfect beer.

Primary_Text: He poured the water into the glass.
Translated_Text: He poured the water into the glass.
My hands peeled.

Primary_Text: The skin on my hands is peeling off.
Translated_Text: The skin on my hands is peeling off.
Her skin was peeling.

Primary_Text: He peeled the bark off the stick.
Translated_Text: He peeled the bark off the stick.

Primary_Text: I peeled the potatoes with that new Swiss vegetable peeler.
Translated_Text: I peeled the potatoes with that new Swiss vegetable peeler.

Primary_Text: She cut the meat into three pieces.
Translated_Text: She cut the meat into three pieces.

Primary_Text: The team built the old lady a new house.
Translated_Text: The team built the old lady a new house.

Primary_Text: They built the model out of plywood and plastic.
Translated_Text: They built the model out of plywood and plastic.

Primary_Text: He broke his arm playing football.
Translated_Text: He broke his arm playing football.
Comment: This is a distinct, polysemic meaning of break.

Translated_Text: Glass breaks easily.
The hammer broke the window.
The window broke.

Primary_Text: He broke the chocolate into several pieces.
Translated_Text: He broke the chocolate into several pieces.

Primary_Text: He broke the twig off the branch.
Translated_Text: He broke the twig off the branch.
Comment: It is debatable whether this deserves to be seen as an instance of an alternation. The argument in favour is connected with the fact that without the off-phrase the verb would depict a different action, i.e. breaking a twig (if it is acceptable at all) depicts a different event type from breaking a twig off a branch.

Primary_Text: I accidentally broke the knob off.
Translated_Text: I accidentally broke the knob off.

Primary_Text: He broke the glass with a hammer.
Translated_Text: He broke the glass with a hammer.
Comment: Break is (a) highly polysemous and (b) occurs in a large number of fixed and semi-fixed expressions with "abstract" objects, e.g. break the law, break a promise, break a record, break the ice, break the silence. In frequency terms, the agentive meaning is probably not the most common.

Primary_Text: He beat his fists against the wall.
Translated_Text: He beat his fists against the wall.
Comment: Most examples are with a body-part, especially head and fists (against the wall).

Primary_Text: He beat the poor dog with a stick.
Translated_Text: He beat the poor dog with a stick.

Primary_Text: This racquet doesn't hit properly. If you tighten the strings it will hit better.
Translated_Text: This racquet doesn't hit properly. If you tighten the strings it will hit better.

Primary_Text: He hit the stick against the fence.
Translated_Text: He hit the stick against the fence.

Primary_Text: He hit wildly at the snake.
Translated_Text: He hit wildly at the snake.

Primary_Text: I hit my head on the roof.
Translated_Text: I hit my head on the roof.

Primary_Text: I hit myself on the head.
Translated_Text: I hit myself on the head.
Comment: The "locus of contact" PP is optional.

Primary_Text: He hit him in the face.
Translated_Text: He hit him in the face.

Primary_Text: The boy hit the snake with a stick.
Translated_Text: The boy hit the snake with a stick.

Primary_Text: The curtains and floor were touching.
Translated_Text: The curtains and floor were touching.

Primary_Text: The curtains were touching the floor.
Translated_Text: The curtains were touching the floor.
Comment: This is a distinct meaning from agentive 'touch'. Arguably it is semantically simpler, because it involves "pure contact", without any action or causation.

Primary_Text: She touched him on the shoulder.
Translated_Text: She touched him on the shoulder.

Primary_Text: The boy touched the snake with a stick.
Translated_Text: The boy touched the snake with a stick.
She sings beautifully.
The boy sang a song.
He had a shave.

Primary_Text: He shaved with a cut thoat razor for the first time that day.
Translated_Text: He shaved with a cut thoat razor for the first time that day.
He shaved his beard.

Primary_Text: I washed and dressed with special care.
Translated_Text: I washed and dressed with special care.
She dressed slowly.
The mother dressed her daughter.

Primary_Text: I was washing up when the guests arrived.
Translated_Text: I was washing up when the guests arrived.
Comment: Wash up is a distinct verb from wash.

Primary_Text: I had my first wash in a week.
Translated_Text: I had my first wash in a week.

Primary_Text: I hadn't washed in a week.
Translated_Text: I hadn't washed in a week.
The mother washed the baby.

Primary_Text: I helped myself to a beer.
Translated_Text: I helped myself to a beer.
Comment: One could see this as a specialised subject-specific benefactive, but since it is restricted to a single verb, and it always refers to acquiring or consuming, it is better to say there is a lexical expression to help oneself (to).

Primary_Text: I helped the boys to fix their bikes.
Translated_Text: I helped the boys to fix their bikes.

Primary_Text: The boys followed the path all the way to the river.
Translated_Text: The boys followed the path all the way to the river.
Comment: With a path as direct object, the verb follow has a different meaning to when it has a human (or animate) direct object.

Primary_Text: The boys followed the girls to the river.
Translated_Text: The boys followed the girls to the river.
They met (up) at the river.

Primary_Text: The men met the boys at the river.
Translated_Text: The men met the boys at the river.

Primary_Text: She hugged him close to her.
Translated_Text: She hugged him close to her.
They hugged each other tight.
They searched me (for drugs).

Primary_Text: They searched the house (for the women).
Translated_Text: They searched the house (for the women).
Comment: If a locus (locational argument) appears, then the 'for-phrase' can be omitted

Primary_Text: The men searched for the women.
Translated_Text: The men searched for the women.
Obesity can kill.
He killed himself.
Thou shalt not kill.
Comment: With an Omitted Object, the identity of the object is understood to be 'people' in a generic sense.

Primary_Text: The man killed the snake with a stick.
Translated_Text: The man killed the snake with a stick.

Primary_Text: She tore the page up into tiny pieces.
Translated_Text: She tore the page up into tiny pieces.

Primary_Text: She tore the poster down (off the wall).
Translated_Text: She tore the poster down (off the wall).

Primary_Text: The girl tore the page from the book.
Translated_Text: The girl tore the page from the book.
She sent her grandmother flowers.

Primary_Text: The girl sent flowers to her grandmother in hospital.
Translated_Text: The girl sent flowers to her grandmother in hospital.

Primary_Text: We give regularly to Doctors Without Frontiers.
Translated_Text: We give regularly to Doctors Without Frontiers.

Primary_Text: We couldn't afford to give any more.
Translated_Text: We couldn't afford to give any more.

Primary_Text: We gave the children the books.
Translated_Text: We gave the children the books.

Primary_Text: We gave the books to the children.
Translated_Text: We gave the books to the children.

Primary_Text: The horse jumped the fence and got away.
Translated_Text: The horse jumped the fence and got away.
Comment: This construction is found also with swim and climb, but not with walk and run. I have dubbed it Locative Promotion, thinking that it is akin to a Locative applicative.

Primary_Text: The girl jumped over the puddle.
Translated_Text: The girl jumped over the puddle.
I jumped for joy.
She thought it over.
Comment: an instance of a verbal expression 'to think something over'.

Primary_Text: I had a long think about it.
Translated_Text: I had a long think about it.
I thought, "Gee, that's strange".

Primary_Text: I think that the library is still open.
Translated_Text: I think that the library is still open.

Primary_Text: I was thinking about my mother yesterday.
Translated_Text: I was thinking about my mother yesterday.

Primary_Text: I didn't know how to do it.
Translated_Text: I didn't know how to do it.

Primary_Text: I knew that he was at home.
Translated_Text: I knew that he was at home.
He knows calculus.

Primary_Text: He knows a lot about gardening.
Translated_Text: He knows a lot about gardening.
I don't know her well.
My computer died on me.

Primary_Text: He almost died in the flood waters.
Translated_Text: He almost died in the flood waters.
Comment: Cf. He died in a hail of bullets. This is probably a distinct construction in which the in-phrase indicates a physical cause, not a location as such.

Primary_Text: He died when he was sixteen.
Translated_Text: He died when he was sixteen.

Primary_Text: This stuff smells like dead fish.
Translated_Text: This stuff smells like dead fish.
The food smelled good (to me).
The bear smelled the boy.

Primary_Text: Her words said yes, but her face said no.
Translated_Text: Her words said yes, but her face said no.

Primary_Text: She said her prayers every night.
Translated_Text: She said her prayers every night.
Don't say that word.
Comment: To say words is a distinct and highly specific combinatorial frame for the verb say, although from a grammatical point of view words is simply a noun. Presumably the say words option licenses extended cognate object uses such as saying prayers.

Primary_Text: He said that he had to go.
Translated_Text: He said that he had to go.

Primary_Text: He said, "Sorry, I have to leave early".
Translated_Text: He said, "Sorry, I have to leave early".
They said "no" to me.
Comment: This is no direct quotation, since only a narrow range of formulaic responses (yes, no, and (perhaps) maybe) can appear. It is more like a de-locutive frame.

Translated_Text: She said something to me.
They shouted their support.
They shouted the answer.

Primary_Text: He shouted that he was alright.
Translated_Text: He shouted that he was alright.

Primary_Text: "Get out, I never want to see you again", she shouted.
Translated_Text: "Get out, I never want to see you again", she shouted.
Don't shout!

Primary_Text: The mother was shouting at the children.
Translated_Text: The mother was shouting at the children.

Primary_Text: I'm seeing a girl from work.
Translated_Text: I'm seeing a girl from work.
Comment: This is a distinct meaning from visual SEE.

Translated_Text: I'm seeing him this afternoon.
Comment: This is a distinct meaning from visual SEE.

Translated_Text: I see what you mean.
Comment: This is a distinct meaning from visual SEE.

Translated_Text: I saw them going.
I saw them go.

Primary_Text: I saw that they were gone.
Translated_Text: I saw that they were gone.
I can't see.

Primary_Text: He saw the bear by the river bank.
Translated_Text: He saw the bear by the river bank.
Look! Over there!
He looks like my brother.

Primary_Text: I got a good look at him.
Translated_Text: I got a good look at him.

Primary_Text: I had a look at it.
Translated_Text: I had a look at it.
The girl looked good (to me).

Primary_Text: She threw herself out of a window.
Translated_Text: She threw herself out of a window.
Comment: This usage, with a reflexive pronoun, is a polysemic extension.

Translated_Text: They threw eggs at me.

Primary_Text: The boy threw her the ball.
Translated_Text: The boy threw her the ball.

Primary_Text: The boy threw the ball through the window.
Translated_Text: The boy threw the ball through the window.

Primary_Text: He put the phone down (way, back).
Translated_Text: He put the phone down (way, back).

Primary_Text: She put the cup on the table.
Translated_Text: She put the cup on the table.

Primary_Text: One B-52 carries 29,700 kilos of bombs.
Translated_Text: One B-52 carries 29,700 kilos of bombs.

Primary_Text: The flood waters carried her away.
Translated_Text: The flood waters carried her away.
Comment: With a "natural force" subject, the meaning of carry is a polysemic extension of the primary sense of carry.

Translated_Text: He was carrying a weapon.

Primary_Text: She carried lip balm with her at all times.
Translated_Text: She carried lip balm with her at all times.

Primary_Text: He carried it on his back.
Translated_Text: He carried it on his back.

Primary_Text: The men carried the gear to camp.
Translated_Text: The men carried the gear to camp.
I climbed up/down/over/in.
Comment: With a directional particle, the verb can apply to any established object, e.g. a tree, a fence, the back of a truck - so this is not the same as the regular Omitted Object alternation with climb, which implies 'climbing (up)' (e.g. 'climbing (up) a mountain').

Translated_Text: We climbed ten kilometres.
They climbed for hours.
The boy climbed the tree.

Primary_Text: They talked me into doing it.
Translated_Text: They talked me into doing it.
Comment: This is an 'into-resultative' construction implying interpersonal manipulation, cf. they tricked me into doing it, they scared me into doing it, she pressured him into doing it. What is particularly notable when talk appears in this construction is that the addressee appears as post-verbal object, then normally this is impossible (cf. *They talked me).

Primary_Text: We had a good long talk about it.
Translated_Text: We had a good long talk about it.

Primary_Text: I talked to him about his problem for quite a while.
Translated_Text: I talked to him about his problem for quite a while.

Primary_Text: We had a good laugh about it later.
Translated_Text: We had a good laugh about it later.
They laughed at me.
The children laughed and laughed.
The fire burnt over 4000 hectares.
Comment: Uses like these, i.e. with a place or a place-extent complement, may deserve to be recognised as a distinct valency frame.

Primary_Text: This material will cut nicely if handled properly.
Translated_Text: This material will cut nicely if handled properly.

Primary_Text: A good knife cuts well, offers a good grip, and isn't too heavy to hold.
Translated_Text: A good knife cuts well, offers a good grip, and isn't too heavy to hold.

Primary_Text: A shard of glass cut his hand.
Translated_Text: A shard of glass cut his hand.

Primary_Text: He cut his face while shaving.
Translated_Text: He cut his face while shaving.

Primary_Text: She cut herself on the finger.
Translated_Text: She cut herself on the finger.

Primary_Text: Cut the onion with a sharp knife.
Translated_Text: Cut the onion with a sharp knife.

Primary_Text: I haven't had a hug in months.
Translated_Text: I haven't had a hug in months.
They hugged and kissed.

Primary_Text: She hugged her little sister and kissed her on the head.
Translated_Text: She hugged her little sister and kissed her on the head.

Primary_Text: The fire burnt her house down.
Translated_Text: The fire burnt her house down.
Comment: Fire has the status of a "cognate subject" for the verb burn. Thus, from a semantic point of view, examples like this one are quite different from transitive use of burn with a human agentive subject.

Primary_Text: I burnt myself on the hand.
Translated_Text: I burnt myself on the hand.
Comment: Implies an accidental outcome.

Primary_Text: I burnt the papers in the backyard.
Translated_Text: I burnt the papers in the backyard.

Primary_Text: Kindling burns well but it doesn't last long.
Translated_Text: Kindling burns well but it doesn't last long.

Primary_Text: Her house is burning down around her.
Translated_Text: Her house is burning down around her.

Primary_Text: The fire burnt the house down.
Translated_Text: The fire burnt the house down.
The fire burnt for hours.
It's raining.

Primary_Text: He used to eat at the cafe.
Translated_Text: He used to eat at the cafe.

Primary_Text: He was still eating when I arrived.
Translated_Text: He was still eating when I arrived.

Primary_Text: I ate too much for lunch.
Translated_Text: I ate too much for lunch.
I make the man cover the child with a blanket.
Comment: INST vs. ALL are both possible in both derived and underived contexts
Translation_Other: Yo hago al hombre cubrir el niño con la cobija.

Translated_Text: I make the boy ask the man for money. / Yo hago al joven pedir dinero al hombre.
I make the boy give the book to the teacher.
Translation_Other: Yo hago al joven dar el libro al meastro.

Translated_Text: I make the man dress the child with clothes.
Translation_Other: Yo hago al hombre vestir mi hijo con ropa.

Primary_Text: Wájpike ó píkyootsóhi ájɨ mɨ́ɨ́né pañévu.
Translated_Text: I make the man put the palmleafs in the canoe.
Translation_Other: Yo hago al hombre poner las hojas en la canoa.

Primary_Text: Wájpike ó cáhpíñutsóhi nújpakyo váásó pañévu.
Translated_Text: I make the man fill the glass with water.
Translation_Other: Yo hago al hombre llenar el vaso con agua.

Translated_Text: I make the boy take the book to the teacher.
Comment: '... take the book from the teacher.' would be expressed analogously, except that ABL instead of ALL would be used.
Translation_Other: Yo hago al niño traer el libro al meastro.

Translated_Text: I make the boy send the book to the teacher.
Translation_Other: Yo hago al niño mandar el libro al maestro.

Primary_Text: Tsɨ́ɨ́méneke ó wááotsóhi íwatájcojɨ téhí pañévu.
Translated_Text: I make the child throw his hat into the water.
Translation_Other: Yo hago al joven llevar el libro al meastro.

Translated_Text: I make the boy bring the book to the teacher.
Translation_Other: Yo hago al joven llevar el libro al meastro.

Translated_Text: The man frightened the boy.
What are you laughing about/at?
Lit. The thunderstorm rained.
The boy asked the man for money.
My brother pushed me.
He killed himself.
The knife cuts the bread.
They helped each other.
I dig for barbasco root.
The man hunted the deer.
My brother will be a wood worker.
I dress my children with clothes.
The man called the boy a slow one.
The water is already boiling.
We teach the children the work.
The grandmother cooks the meat.
The child threw his hat into the water.
I hear the bell ring.
I shaved my beard.
I am wiping dust off my foot.
I grind peppers with a mortar.
I put my book on the table.
You give me the leftovers.
You have already shown my child his blood.

Primary_Text: Botsíi píívyéébeke ú táúmeíhí mémájchotá dooráábeke.
Translated_Text: You ask the creator for fish of our nutrition.
I am dry.
My house is burning.
The steamship sank in the harbour of Iquitos.
Comment: ADL marked NP is an adjunct

Translated_Text: The trunk rolled into the river.
The girl feels sad.
The boys are playing with the ball.
The man shouted at the boy.
Comment: almost certainly contains ihjyu 'mouth', from which ihjyu-va (mouth-VBZ-have) 'speak' is also derived, but not certain how exactly. -cunu usually derives intransitive verbs, which does not match the fact that ihjyúcunú takes direct objects

Translated_Text: I laugh.
You left the village.
I go to my house.
The old man sits on the signal drum.
She blinks.
We peel manioc.
The boy tore the page from the book.
The man built the house with palm leaves.
My brother is shouting at me.
I dress my children with clothes.
I think about my brothers.
The dog smells the meat.
The children are hugging the mothers.
The woman made the man eat bread.
I eat deer.
The glass is full of water.
Comment: -wahpé-tsó = full-CAUS; derivations from this root with forms from the transMult system that are attested are: -0, i.e. wahpe 'be full' (intransitive), -cunu, i.e. wahpécunu 'be full' (intrans(mult-sing?)

Translated_Text: The child has covered himself with a blanket.
Comment: possibly cobííjya-ri is possible

Translated_Text: The child was covered with a blanket.
Comment: * cobííjya-vu

Translated_Text: The man covered the child with a blanket.
The men covered each other with a blanket.
The man covered himself with a blanket.
The man covered himself with a blanket.
The woman made the man cover the child with a blanket.
Comment: possibly walle wájpiikyé wátájcotsó tsɨ́ɨ́ménedívú cobííjyavu is also possible

Translated_Text: It rained.
The boy was hungry.
The boy froze (lit. The boy was cold).
The man fell (on the ground).
The man died.
My arm hurts (me).
The boy appeared on the path.
The boy sang (a song).
The boy lived (in the village).
The boy went (from the village).
The boy came (to the village).
The child jumped (on the floor).
Comment: below-LOC is not an argument by any definition

Translated_Text: The child ran (on the floor).
Comment: below-LOC is not an argument by any definition

Translated_Text: The man sat (on the floor).
The man sat down (on the floor).
The man climbed (up) the hill.
The man coughed.
The man washed himself.
The man washed the child.
The man dressed the child.
The man ate the bread.
The man helped the girl.
The man followed the girl.
The man met (lit. saw) the girl.
The man married the girl.
The man hunted.
The man searched for the boy.
The boy liked the man.
The boy feared the man.
The man frightened the boy.
The man looked at the boy.
The man saw the boy.
The man remembered the boy.
The man knew the boy.
The man talked to the boy about work.
The boy asked the man for money.
The man told a story to the boy.
The man said to the boy: "no".
The man called the boy a fool.
The man built the house with palm leaves.
The boy broke the window with the stone.
The boy killed the snake with the stick.
The boy beat the snake with the stick.
The boy hit the snake with the stick .
The boy touched the snake with the stick.
The boy cut the bread with the knife.
The boy hid the book from the teacher.
Comment: CHECK

Translated_Text: The boy stole the book from the teacher.
Comment: CHECK

Translated_Text: The boy took the book from the teacher.
Comment: CHECK

Translated_Text: The boy showed the book to the teacher.
Comment: CHECK

Translated_Text: The boy gave the book to the teacher.
The boy sent the book to school.
The boy sent the book to the teacher .
The boy carried the book to school.
The boy carried the book to the teacher.
The boy brought the book to the teacher.
The boy threw the stone into the window.
The man put the book on the table.
The man poured the water into the glass .
The man tied the horse to the tree.
Comment: CHECK

Translated_Text: The man loaded the hay on the canoe (lit. The man put palm leaves into the canoe).
The man filled the glass with water.
The man covered the child with the blanket.

Primary_Text: Kithang masà-thaksir kithang=pe ruuma daalang=ka see=le lorang=le mlaayu=dering arà-oomong=si.
Translated_Text: We have to think whether you and I speak in Malay in our home(s).

Primary_Text: Karang kithang marà-thaksir kithang=nang Allah draapa=so prentha pada=yang kaasi aada.
Translated_Text: Now let's think how many rules Allah has given to us.

Primary_Text: Haraam=yang arà-diyath haraamyang arà-dinggar haraam=yang arà-oomong haraam=yang arà-thaksir.
Translated_Text: They are watching forbidden things, they are looking at forbidden things, they are saying forbidden things and they are thinking forbidden things.

Primary_Text: Aajuthyang sangkeluppas hathu polludering Rose-red buurungnang supuukul.
Translated_Text: Rose-Red beat the bird with a stick until it let go off the dwarf.
I am a fisherman.
The bear frightened me.
The woman is digging for potatoes.
The girl wiped dirt off the table.

Primary_Text: Prompang biiji pada lumpangle aalulederi aràgiiling.
Translated_Text: The woman grinds the seeds with mortar and pestle.
The house is burning.
I am sad.
The child is playing.
My hand hurts.
The child left the village.
The boy went away from the village. / The boy left the village.
The man is sitting on the ground.
The monkey climbed on top of the tree.
The man coughed.

Primary_Text: Oorang klaapa pada trucknang nyaangkath thaaro.
Translated_Text: The men loaded coconuts on the truck.

Primary_Text: Oorang potti pada paasarnang nyaangkath baapi.
Translated_Text: The man carried the boxes to the market.

Primary_Text: Aanak klaaki incayangpe ummaderi koodokyang susbuuniking.
Translated_Text: The boy hid the frog from his mother.
The boy peels the banana (skin).

Primary_Text: Aanak klaaki hatthu kaayudering uularnang aràthìkkam.
Translated_Text: The boy touches the snake with a stick. / The boy pokes at the snake with a stick.
The man built a house from wood.

Primary_Text: Ummabaapa pada aanaknang Anna katha naama nyathaaro.
Translated_Text: The parents called their child Anna.
The woman shouts at the children.
The child follows the mother.
The mother dressed her child.
The bear smells the child.
The mother hugs her child.

Primary_Text: Incayang ini Seelongka anàaada lakuan baathu asàcaari.
Translated_Text: He looked for the valuble stones which existed in this Ceylon. / He looked for gems from Ceylon.
The man got up and looked for his hats.

Primary_Text: Baayenang goorengnang blaakang ini santhamyang itthunang thuwang.
Translated_Text: After frying (it) well, add this coconutmilk to it.

Primary_Text: Itthu bambuyang giini angkathapa, pullang aràthoolak.
Translated_Text: Having lifted that bamboo like this, slowly push it (back).
Comment: the undergoer NP is dropped

Primary_Text: Boat hatthuka thaaro abbis itthu queenyang nyathoolak aayernang.
Translated_Text: Having put her into the boat, (they) pushed the queen into the water.
The Titanic sank.

Primary_Text: Siini, Andare atthas lompath lompath aràthàthaawa.
Translated_Text: Here, he laughed violently about Andare.
I am very sick now.

Primary_Text: Seppe oorang pada see saapa katha thàràthaau.
Translated_Text: My folks did not know who I was.
I do not know his father's name.
I can't tell (you) that.
There is no work that I would not know.
I know everything about tailoring.
They feared what they saw.

Primary_Text: Punnu mlaayu oorangnangle cinggala màblaajar thàràsuuka.
Translated_Text: Many Malay people did not like to learn Sinhala. / Many people did not want to learn Sinhala.
We did not want to go abroad.
We want to have a look.
I tear the book to pieces.
Comment: The vector verb thaaro is used to express violent action

Translated_Text: Boil it well in water!
Then we cook it.

Primary_Text: Baapa derangpe kubbongka hatthu pohong nyapoothong.
Translated_Text: Father cut a tree in their garden.
Then we will cut your neck.

Primary_Text: Derang hathu papaayayang asàpoothongapa papaayaka suumbu hatthu kalthaaro.
Translated_Text: When they cut open a papaya and put a wick into it.
They went to another country.

Primary_Text: Itthusubbath derangpada jaalang aràgijja, butthul ruuma padayang aràpiccakang.
Translated_Text: There for they are making streets, they are demolishing good houses. / Therefore, they construct streets and good houses are getting demolished.
You can break those things to pieces like this.

Primary_Text: Hathyang aarika Snow-whitele Rose-redle laapang piingirka, berry kapangpiccakang, bissar hathu buurung derangpe atthasdering suthìrbang.
Translated_Text: The other day, when Snow-White and Rose-Red were picking (=breaking) berries, a big bird flew over them.
Comment: picakang is normally used for breaking events, but it is also the normal verb to refer to collecting berries

Translated_Text: When we meet we speak in Malay.
Sebastian speaks Malay.
The dwarf wept in fear.
Bring it to a boil in water.
They want land.

Primary_Text: Itthusubbathjo incayangnang maau, ini Sri Lankan Malay màblaajar maau.
Translated_Text: Therefore he wants, he wants to learn this Sri Lanka Malay.
And Andare died like a king.
These two army captains did not die.

Primary_Text: Kithangpe sudari padanang makanan màmaasak aada.
Translated_Text: Our sisters had to prepare food.
Have you (already) eaten Satay, Sebastian?

Primary_Text: Itthunang blaakang Andare guula thiikarka asalompath "luppe muuluthkale paasir, seppe muuluthkale paasir" katha biilang biilang baayenang baapale aanakle guula sumaakang.
Translated_Text: After that, Andare jumped on the mat and saying "There is sand in your mouth, there is sand in my mouth" father and son ate sugar.
After having looked at a man, I can tailor (something) for him.

Primary_Text: Hathu haari puthrinang Andarepe biiniyang màdiyathnang hathu sukahan sudhaathang.
Translated_Text: One day, the queen got the desire to see Andare's wife.

Primary_Text: Thakuthannang derang pada hathu thumpathnang nyalaari.
Translated_Text: Out of fear, they ran to a place.

Primary_Text: Itthu haarikajo aanak pompang duuwanang hathu duuri pohongnang puuthi, paanjang jeenggothyang anàkànàdaapath kìnna hathu kiccil jillek Aajuth hatthu=yang sukuthumung.
Translated_Text: On that day the two girls saw a small ugly dwarf who had got stuck to a thorn tree with his long white beard.

Primary_Text: Blaakangjo incayang anàkuthumung moonyeth pada thoppi asàambel pohong atthaska aràmaayeng.
Translated_Text: After that, he saw that the monkeys had taken the hats and were playing in the tree top.
Comment: the complement is a sentence, not an NP, so the accusative is not used here

Translated_Text: This one is such that it is made with custard powder.

Primary_Text: Goppe aanak pada uuwang godang aràkiiring.
Translated_Text: My children send me money.

Primary_Text: Itthu thumpathyang incayang giithujo awuliyanangjo sukaasi.
Translated_Text: That place, he gave it to the saint in that manner.
My father gave him gold.

Primary_Text: Buruanpe kuulith incayangpe kaaki baawaka jaatho suaada!
Translated_Text: The bear's hide had fallen to his feet!

Primary_Text: Skarang biini aràiinngath puthri thuuli katha; Puthri aràiinngath biini thuuli katha.
Translated_Text: Now the wife thinks that the queen is deaf and the queen thinks that the wife is deaf.

Primary_Text: Bannyak haaridering saapayangke thàràencokang katha anàiinngath Andare.
Translated_Text: Andare thought that he had not taken anybody for a fool for many days.
They think of him all the time. / They commemorate him all the time.
Comment:
Third person plulral is used with singular reference here
The commemorators are dropped
maana X=le is the universal quantifier

Primary_Text: See aràiingath Malaysia kalthraa Indonesiape hatthujo athiaada.
Translated_Text: I think that there would have been one from Malaysia or otherwise Indonesia.

Primary_Text: Itthusubbath see iingath moderate islamizationka maràpii.
Translated_Text: Because of that I think we should go towards moderate islamization. / Therefore I think we should strive for moderate islamization.
Grind pepper and salt in a grinding stone.

Primary_Text: Sooreka, Snow-whitele Rose-redle derangpe umma samma appi dìkkathka aràduuduk ambel.
Translated_Text: In the evenings, Snow-White and Rose-Red used to sit down close to the fire together with their mother.
Comment: The nonpast form conveys habitual here; it is used regadless of the time reference to the past

Translated_Text: They live in Hambantota.

Primary_Text: Suda itthu oorang padale Seelongka aràduuduk.
Translated_Text: So these people also live in Ceylon.
They heard a familiar voice.
After hearing this talk...

Primary_Text: Andare ruumanang asàpii biininang subiilang "puthrinang kuuping aràdinggar kuurang" katha.
Translated_Text: After Andare went to his house, he told his wife: The queen hears little with her ears. / Andare went home and told his wife that the queen did not hear very well.
He got a job at HSBC.

Primary_Text: Itthunang blaakang sedang Oman navyka job hatthu anàdaapath.
Translated_Text: After that I got a job at the Oman Navy.

Primary_Text: Freedomyang màdaapathnang kithangnang bannyak caape aada.
Translated_Text: We have worked hard to get our freedom.

Primary_Text: 26452 votes incayangnang anàdaapath; itthunangle incayangnangle inni thumpath thàràdaapath.
Translated_Text: He got 26452 votes but nevertheless he did not get a seat (in parliament).
He steals all the people's goods.

Primary_Text: Dee aràcuuri baaye kaaya oorang padadering kaaya oorangderingjo aràcuuri.
Translated_Text: He steals from the rich men, it is from the rich that he steals.

Primary_Text: Hathu mliida birrasyang asàcuuci aayer màwadinji sumpang.
Translated_Text: Wash one measure of rice and reserve water to strain.

Primary_Text: Aanak raajape perkathahanyang Snow-whitenangle Rose-rednangle sukahandering supunnu hathu hidopan suthunjiking.
Translated_Text: The princes words showed a place which filled Snow White and Rose Red with delight.
We show our faces a little here.

Primary_Text: Bahasa mlaayupe habaran padayang caari apa...
Translated_Text: After having looked for/found news of the Malay language...

Primary_Text: Suda puthrile biinile aràcaanda haarile sudhaathang.
Translated_Text: Thus came the day when the wife and the queen were to meet.
I want to meet Andare's wife.

Primary_Text: Skarang maana aarile atthu atthu oorangyang aràbuunung.
Translated_Text: Now people are getting killed every day one by one.
Comment: the reciprocal meaning cited in Nordhoff (2009) is unlikely

Primary_Text: "Lorangpe guuna thàràsampe! hathyang skali bannyak masàaapith!" Aajuth subutharak.
Translated_Text: "Your respect is insufficient! Next time you must be more careful" the dwarf screamed.

Primary_Text: Biini itthu subladering aràbitharak; puthri inni subladering aràbitharak.
Translated_Text: The wife screamed from that side and the queen screamed from this side.
X told him too: "Come to the religion". / X told him too that he should convert to our religion.

Primary_Text: Andare ruumanang asapii biininang subiilang "puthrinang kuuping aradìnngar kuurang" katha.
Translated_Text: Andare went home and said to his wife "The queen hears little with her ears". / Andare went home and said to his wife that the queen did not hear well.

Primary_Text: Cinggala raajanang derang pada banthu aada.
Translated_Text: They helped the Sinhalese king.

Primary_Text: Spaaru oorang pada biini padayang asàambel supii.
Translated_Text: Some men took wives and left. / Some men married and left.

Primary_Text: Derangpe umma derangnang jaithanle, jaarong pukurjanle suaajar.
Translated_Text: Their mother taught them sewing and needle work.
They send me money.

Primary_Text: Spaaru oorang pada biini padale baawa aada.
Translated_Text: Some men had brought also their wives. / Some men had also brought their wives.

Primary_Text: Incayangpe kepaalaka anàaada thoppidering moonyeth padanang subuwang puukul.
Translated_Text: (He) violently threw the hat which was on his head at the monkeys. / He took the hat from his head and threw it violently at the monkeys.
Comment: puukul is a vector verb for "intensive/violent realization". The brackets show the complex NP modified by a relative clause

Translated_Text: So I ask Allah for grace. / So I pray to Allah.
When they put a wick in the papaw.

Primary_Text: Skarang Sri Lankapele islam pada muuka aràthuuthup.
Translated_Text: Now also the Muslims of Sri Lanka cover their faces.
The water is boiling.
The ship sank.
I want a new car.
I heard the news.
Mother cooks rice.
The child screams.
The grandfather teaches Tamil to the child.
The child sits on the chair.
The father pushes the child outside.
Father took the cat from grandfather.
Father is a hunter.
I am going home.
This wood is dry.
It is raining.
I am hungry.
I am feeling cold.
The stone falls down.
Grandfather died.
Tony died.
The child is singing.
The rabbit is jumping.
The child is running.
The father washes the child.
The child is eating the mango.
The child helps the father.
The father saw the child.
I know that man.
Grandfather talks to the child about the war.
I asked my father for the car.
The child said "Goodbye" to the father.
The child breaks the window with a stone.
The man kills the enemy with a rifle.
The man kills the enemy with the rifle.
The father hits the child with the stick.
The chlid cuts the mango with the knife.
The child tears the page from the book.
The thief steals the horse from the rich man.
The man shows the foot to the woman.
The man gives the pig to the child.
The father sends the child to Colombo.
Father brings the car to the house.
The child throws the ball at the wicket.
The man puts the glass on the table.
The man ties the enemy to the tree.
The child pours water into the glass.
The child fills the glass with water.
Women cover their faces with cloth.
Father makes a house out of wood. / Father makes a wooden house.
The woman is advising something.
The woman was told something.
The woman is being told something.
It can be said to that woman.
Comment: If you are waiting for news, the woman can be informed in your place so that she can inform you later.

Translated_Text: He told the child to say it (=something) (to someone else).
I am saying the hour to the woman for you (i.e. in your place).
The clothes were dried.
Clothes can be dried.
It burns.
My house is burned.
My house was burned.
The garbage can be burned.

Primary_Text: Ju ili uusi jamutta sankoata beetaria.
Translated_Text: The child is burning the garbage for the woman.
Someone was sunken in the mud.
Mud is a place for sinking.
I sank myself in the mud for the child.
The stone was rolled.
There certainly is a place to roll down.
The stone can roll.
The child is rolling for the woman.
There is hungriness in that house.
Here is certainly a place to be hungry.
There is sadness in my home.
Here is certainly a place to be sad.
It is OK to play with the baby.
The ball was played.
One can play with the dog.
You are playing with the child of the woman.
Here is certainly a place to die.
(S)he is dying for the woman.
It is cold. / It feels cold.
Here is certainly a place to feel cold.
Pain can be felt in the stomach.
The joke was laughed about.
Here is a good place to laugh.
He is laughing because of the woman.
He is laughing at his woman.
Someone has sat on the bench. / The bank has already been sat on.
That bank is a place to sit on.
The man sits in order to ambush the woman.
He sits in order to ambush me.
Vicam is a place to live in happily.
This (here) is a good place to live in.
The child is leaving something.
The child was left.
The child is being left.
The dog can be left.
Jesus is leaving for Melquiades.
Comment: Melquiades was supposed to leave the place but Jesus will go away in his place.

Translated_Text: I am leaving (this place) for you.
Those songs were sung.

Primary_Text: Jume bwiikam bwiikwa im maalata betchi'ibo.
Translated_Text: The songs are being sung for my mother.
The songs can be sung.
I am singing for someone.
People ran far away. (lit. It was run far away.)
The race can be run.
I am running the race. / I am running in the race.
I am running for someone (i.e. in his place).
The mountain was climbed. / The climbed mountain.
The mountain was climbed.
The man climbs the mountain. / The man is doing mountain-climbing.
The tree can be climbed up.
Comment: It is also possible to say: Ju juupat aa ja'amutu, using the locative marker on the subject.

Translated_Text: I got into the car.

Primary_Text: Ju ili uusi ju'upat a ja'amuria.
Translated_Text: The child climbed up the tree.
Maria was coughed at.
There is coughing in the house (i.e. Someone has a cough in the house.). / It is coughed in the house.
Here is a good place to cough.
I am coughing at Maria.
The dust makes you cough.
Cough in my place.
The blinked eyes.
The eyes were blinked.
The eyes can be blinked.
Comment: Note: if you got something in the eye, for instance.

Translated_Text: I am blinking my eyes at Juan.
I blink for someone else.

Primary_Text: Nim team chachairi im maala betchi'ibo...
Translated_Text: My name shouted by my mother...
My name is being shouted. / My name was shouted.
That can not be shouted!
The man shouts at someone for the child (in his place).
The mask is already asked for.
Comment: as in a layaway system

Translated_Text: The money was asked for. / The money was required.
The money can be asked for (as a loan).
Maria sees people. / Maria is able to see.
The house was seen.
See the beans for me (in my place).
Comment: The subject might be omitted. It is understood that it is a command.

Translated_Text: The house has been looked at.
The house has been looked at. / The house is being looked at.
The mountain can be looked at well. / The mountain is easy to see.
Juan is looking into the house.
Comment: It is implied that Juan is outside the house and he is looking into the house.

Translated_Text: I am looking at something.
Comment: The meaning is not 'I am looking for something'.

Translated_Text: Juan is looking at the sheet.
The child was hugged.
The pillow can be hugged. / The pillow is huggable.
Juan made Maria hug the child.
Juan hugs the child for Maria. / Juan greets Maria by hugging the child.
Comment: 'Juan greets Maria by hugging the child', as in: 'Give her my regards!'

Translated_Text: Juan is eating.
I am eating meat.
I am eating the chicken's thigh.
I ate the apple for my mother (in her place).
I am loading.
Comment: This is an intransitive construction (cf. *ne puatom yee pu'akta).

Translated_Text: The adobe has been loaded onto the car.
The child can be lifted. / The child can be carried.
I am loading.
The stomach is being filled with food. \ lit. He is filing his stomach with food.
The basin is being filled.
The water was filled in.
The jar can be filled with water.
The table filled.
Comment: Intransitive version of the verb tapunia. Probably the basic form is tapuna and tapunia is the derived transitive form.

Translated_Text: The man filled the glass at the woman('s place).

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta baasota tapuniaria.
Translated_Text: The man is filling the glass for the woman.
The child was covered with the sheet.
The child can be covered with the blanket.
He covered it in the pot.

Primary_Text: Ili uusi beemeta jamutta ili uusita pattariak.
Translated_Text: The girl covered the child on behalf of the woman.
Translation_Other: La muchacha cubrió al niño por la mujer.

Translated_Text: Pour something there.
Translation_Other: Poner algo de una forma.

Translated_Text: Water was poured in the pot.
Water was poured.
Water can be poured in the pot.
Pour some water on the dish for the dog.
My mom seats the people.
The books are placed on the table.
The books were put on the table.
The table can be set.
I put the books to Maria on the table.
I made Maria put the keys in the purse.
I put the keys in the bag for Maria.
The water is put there.
Put it into the water. / Let it soak.

Primary_Text: U baaso kaa tu'isi aa manatu.
Translated_Text: The glass can not be placed well. / The glass is not suitable.
I put the books on the table. / I placed the books on the table.
I made Juan put the pot on the table.
I put the glass on the table for Juan.
I put him the glass on the table. / I put the glass on the table for him.
The Paskome ties (people).
Comment: yee suma means 'to acquire a compromise'.

Translated_Text: My hands are tied.
The horse can be tied.
Comment: cf. U kaba'i aa tu'isi sumatu, 'The horse is easy to tie'.

Translated_Text: The man made Juan tie the horse.

Primary_Text: U yoeme Joanta kaba'ita jupau sumaria.
Translated_Text: The man tied Juan's horse to the tree.
Juan throws (somebody) far away.
Comment: It is an intransitive version of the verb using the transitive form, i.e. watta.

Translated_Text: The tree's leaves were thrown.
The leaves were thrown.
He is throwing off his clothes. / He is getting undressed.
Put the tortillas in the nest.
Leaves fell down.

Primary_Text: U jamut ili uusim sankoata mekka wattatua.
Translated_Text: The woman made the children throw the garbage far away.

Primary_Text: Ili uusim jamutta sankoata mekka wattaria.
Translated_Text: The children throw the garbage far away to the woman.
Comment: cf. Ili uusim jamutta sankoa mekka watta, 'The children throw the garbage of the woman far away'.

Translated_Text: Juan is carrying someone.
The water has been carried to Hermosillo.
Comment: cf. U ba'a Peesiou toiri bu'u, 'The water in Hermosillo is too much'.

Translated_Text: The water is carried to Potam.
Beans can be carried in the pot.
I am carrying something.
Comment: cf. Inepo jita toja.

Translated_Text: Juan made Maria carry Pedro the books.
Juan brought the books of Pedro to Maria. / Juan carried Pedro's books to Maria.
Juan carried the books to Maria (in behalf of) Pedro.
Translation_Other: Juan le llevó los libros a María en lugar de (llevarlos) Pedro.

Translated_Text: Juan carried Pedro the books to the library.
Juan sends something to someone.
Comment: Juan jita itou bittua, 'Juan sends us something'.

Translated_Text: The letter has been sent. / The sent letter.
The letter was sent there.
Flowers can be sent.
Juan sent Pedro's documents to Potam.
The clothes will be given to the people on Sunday.
He was given a clothes.
Flowers can be given.
Comment: Maria sewam aa maktu, 'As for Maria, they/you can give her flowers'.

Translated_Text: Give the boy the books on my behalf.
Juan showed something.
Comment: It is also possible to say: Juan ume monom yee bittuak, 'Juan showed some images'.

Translated_Text: The book that was shown to you.
Translation_Other: El libro que te fue mostrado.

Translated_Text: Your were shown the book.
Translation_Other: A ti te fue mostrado el libro.

Primary_Text: U yoeme ili uusita librompo monom bittuak.
Translated_Text: The man showed the child the images from the book.

Primary_Text: U yoeme ili uusita jiosiam jamutta bittuak.
Translated_Text: The man showed the woman the child's book.
Comment: It is not possible to use the applicative -ria unless the verbal root bit-ria is used.

Primary_Text: U yoeme ili uusita jiosiam bittuak.
Translated_Text: The man showed a book to the child.
Maria is hiding (someone).
I found the hidden money.
I found the money that was hidden.
Earrings can be hidden.
Translation_Other: Los aretes se pueden esconder.

Translated_Text: Maria hid (herself) at Juan's (place/house).
Maria hid the book at Juan's (place).
Translation_Other: María escondió el libro donde está Juan.

Translated_Text: Juan is peeling (something).
I ate the peeled orange.
The orange was peeled.
You're peeling.
The orange can be peeled.
I made you peel the orange for me.
Peel the orange for me.
I burned the torn pages of the book.
Translation_Other: Quemé las páginas trozadas del libro.

Translated_Text: The blouse was torn.
My clothes are tearing.
The blouse can be torn.
Maria's blouse tore.
I tore one page from the book. / I tore one page off of the book.
The taken money. / The money (has been) taken.
The money was taken.
The money can be taken. / The money can be grabbed/stolen.
Juan went to Maria('s place) (to ask) for money \ lit. Juan took money from Maria (i.e. Maria's place).
Juan took Maria's money. / Juan took the money (that was) on Maria.

Primary_Text: U jamut Mariata ili uusita nu'utuak.
Translated_Text: The woman made Maria carry the child. / The woman made Maria take the child (in her arms).
You took money from Maria.
Water is cut off.
Water was cut off.
The cable can be cut.
He cut himself with the knife.
The rope is cut.
I cut my brother's bread.
I cut my brother the hair.
Their hands are touched.
Their hands were touched.
Juan is touching them the hands. / Juan is holding their hands.
Lift my skirt (lit. Lift me the skirt!)!
Comment: Because my skirt is falling down. The possessor of the skirt is not expressed.

Translated_Text: Juan hits people.
Translation_Other: Juan choca con la gente.

Translated_Text: The table is beaten.
Comment: -i is a phonological variant of -ri.

Translated_Text: The table was beaten.
Juan slammed the door.
Translation_Other: Juan se golpeó con la puerta.

Translated_Text: The woman made the man crash the car.
The man is moving the car for the woman.

Primary_Text: U yoeme jamutta puetau mesata tastaria.
Translated_Text: The man beats the table of the woman against the door.
I hit people.
The dog had been hit.
The dog was hit.
I hit my/the hand with the door.
The dog can be hit.

Primary_Text: U yoeme chu'uta ili uusitau bebak.
Translated_Text: The man sent the dog to bite the child.
Translation_Other: El hombre mandó al perro para que mordiera al niño.

Primary_Text: U yoeme ili uusita chu'u bebriak.
Translated_Text: The man hit the dog of the child.
Comment: An equivalent expression does not use the applicative morpheme: U yoeme ili uusita chu'u bebak.

Primary_Text: U yoeme ili uusita chu'uta bebriak.
Translated_Text: The man hit the dog for the child.
Comment: kom beb-ria-k (down hit-app-pfvl) means 'to frighten'.

Translated_Text: Juan kills (people).
The rabbit is dead. / The rabbit was killed.
The rabbit is being killed.
The cow can be killed.
Juan made me kill the cow.
Juan killed a cow for me.
Juan broke something.
Translation_Other: Juan hizo algo.

Translated_Text: The glass is broken.
The window of the house got broken.
The window of the house broke.
Melquiades broke the eyeglasses of Jesus.
Juan broke the window of the house.
Juan is taking pictures.
Comment: 'to take pictures' is the only meaning that yaa 'make' expresses when yee 'people' accompanies it.

Translated_Text: The house is being made.
Meat can be made. / Meat can be prepared/cooked.
Juan names the people.
Comment: Usually Juan uses nicknames for naming the people.

Translated_Text: Juan calls me Pepe.
Comment: Pepe is a nickname used with people whose name is José.

Primary_Text: U yoeme jamutta ili uusim teuwaria.
Translated_Text: The man called the children of the woman.
Juan talked about the story.
Juan talked about a (specific part of the) story.
The story is already told.
The story has already been told.
I made you talk to Maria.
Juan is meeting people.
The snake is being followed. / The snake is being haunted.
The woman followed the child of the man.
Comment: Here the applicative introduces a possessor instead of a beneficiary.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta ili uusita jajariak.
Translated_Text: The man followed the woman for the child.
Comment: Typical situation: the child asked the man to follow the woman.

Translated_Text: The women were helped.
Maria is helping the woman for the man.
The legs are already shaved.
The hair is already shaved.
The hair is being shaved.
Hair does not shave well.
I shaved on my head. / I shaved my own head.
Juan shaved his head.
The woman shaved the man.
The woman made the man shave his head.
Comment: The possessor is not expressed.

Translated_Text: Maria dresses the people. / Maria is a dressmaker. / Maria sews.
The child was dressed.
Clothes dress well.

Primary_Text: U jamut ili uusita o'outa a'anariak.
Translated_Text: The woman dressed the child for the man.
Comment: The man asked the woman to dress the child. The man is the beneficiary of the event.

Primary_Text: U jamut ili uusita baato betchi'ibo a'anak.
Translated_Text: The woman dressed the child for the baptism. / The woman dressed the child in order to attend the baptism.
The dishes were washed.
Juan made the child wash the car.
Maria is washing the corn leaves for Juan.
Comment: sanaba beea means 'corn leaves'; beea means 'husk or skin' while the word sanaba has not been registered by itself. We are glossing the words sanaba beea as 'corn_leaf', even though it acquires a plural (collective) meaning when it is used.

Translated_Text: The searched for dog. / The dog was searched.
The dog was searched for too much.
I am searching for something on the dog.
The man is searching for the boy for Juan. / The man is searching for Juan for the boy.
Something is thought.
The man is thinking (of doing) something. / The man pretends to do something.
I know someone/people.
The known people. / The known things.
Comment: It is equivalent to say: 'acquaintances'.

Translated_Text: It can be known.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta uusita ta'aria.
Translated_Text: The man knows the woman's child.
Maria is liked so that she will be Juan's (girlfriend).
Comment: The sense of the sentence is that someone, probably the parents, consider Maria a good girl to start a relationship with Juan.

Translated_Text: Maria is likeable (for someone). / Maria allows (someone) to woo her.
Maria likes the woman's skirt.
Comment: It does not mean 'Maria likes the skirt for the woman' as in 'Maria liked the skirt in order to give it as a gift to the woman

Translated_Text: The man frightened people.
Someone is scared because of the dog (lit. The fearsome dog (causes someone to be scared).).
Maria is feeling fear (because of the people).
Comment: 'people' is the stimulus of Maria's fear but it is not an obligatory argument of the verb since it is possible to say Maria majae with the same meaning: 'Maria is feeling fear'.

Translated_Text: The flower was smelled.
The flower can be smelled.
The smelled flower. / The flower was smelled.

Primary_Text: U ili uusi chu'uta wakasta juktatua.
Translated_Text: The child makes the dog smell the cow.
Translation_Other: El niño hace que el perro huela a la vaca.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta wepul bwiikam bwiiktuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman sing a song.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta pueplopo jo'atuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman live in the town.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka ili uusita cheptituak.
Translated_Text: The man made the child jump.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka ili uusita pisopo buibuitituak.
Translated_Text: The man made the child run on the floor.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta betuk bwiapo yejtetuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman sit down on the floor.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta kauta ja'amutuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman climb up the hill.
The man made the woman cough.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta uka ili uusita a'anatuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman dress the child.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamuta paanim bwa'atuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman eat the bread.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta uusi beemeta aniatuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman help the girl.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta uusi beemeta jajatuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman follow the girl.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta uusi beemetamak emo nau teutuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman meet the girl.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta uusita jariutuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman search for the child.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta o'outa tu'urituak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman like (the other) male.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta o'outa majaetuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman fear the (other) man.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta uusita gomtatuak.
