Translated_Text: The man made the woman to frighten the boy.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta uusita bitchutuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman see the boy.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta uusita ta'atuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman know the child.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta uusitau jamutta betana a eteuriatuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman tell the boy about the girl.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta o'outa tomita betchi'ibo a'autuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman ask the male for money.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uusi beemetau etejoita teuwak.
Translated_Text: The man told a story to the girl.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta uusi beemetat chachaaetuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman shout at the girl.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta uusi beemetau kaita teuwatuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman say nothing to the girl.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka uusi beemeta uusitau kaa suak ti jiutuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the girl name the boy a dumb.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka uusita karisaamita yaatuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the boy build a house of adobe.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka uusita karita saamimmea yaatuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the boy build a house with adobe.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka uusita bentaanata tetae jamtatuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the boy break the window with a stone.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka uusita bakotta kutae me'etuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the boy kill the snake with a stick.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka uusita bakotta kutae bebtuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the boy hit the snake with a stick.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka uusita bakotta kutae bwistuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the boy touch the snake with the stick.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka uusita nabasommea panim chuktatuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the boy cut the bread with a knife.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka uusi beemeta mesapo jaimachirata tu'utetuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the girl wipe the dirt from the table.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka uusi beemeta librom jiosiota siutatuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman tear the page from the book.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka uusi beemeta maejtrata librom essotuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the girl hide the book from the teacher.
Translation_Other: El hombre hizo que la muchacha le escondiera el libro a la maestra.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka uusi beemeta librom maejtrata bittuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the girl show the book to the teacher.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka uusi beemeta maejtrota liprom maktuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the girl give the teacher the book.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka uusi beemeta maejtratau liprom bittuatebok.
Translated_Text: The man made the girl send the book to the teacher.

Primary_Text: U yoeme jamutta baasopo ba'am to'otuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman pour the water into the glass.

Primary_Text: U yoeme jamutta karopo pajata pu'aktatuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman load the hay on the car.

Primary_Text: U yoeme jamutta uka baasota ba'ammea tapuniatuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman fill the glass with water.

Primary_Text: U yoeme jamutta uka ili uusita pisammea paktatuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman cover the boy with the blanket.
The soldier runs towards the mountain.

Primary_Text: In maala in jakamak binwa etejo.
Translated_Text: My mom is talking to my aunt for long.
Gentlemen, I want to tell you (...).
Comment: Many of the Yaqui narratives begin with these words of introduction.

Translated_Text: I frightened the dogs. \ lit. I made the dogs to fear.
Translation_Other: Hago que los perros tengan miedo.

Translated_Text: Juan made a cement house.
Juan made a house by using wood. / Juan built a house out of wood.
The ceiling is made of earth.

Primary_Text: U jamut bwiata bweje papaam jariwakai.
Translated_Text: The woman is digging the ground looking for potatoes.
The woman is digging looking for potatoes.
Women wash early (in the morning) in the river.
Comment: The verb form changes from baksia into paksia because of the prefixation of the ji('i)- intransitivizer morpheme.

Translated_Text: I knew Juan. / I met Juan.
Juan says he is coming.
The man is talking too much.
Comment: The sense of the example is that the man is telling something that he is not supposed to tell anybody.

Translated_Text: Juan killed the dog with a stone.
Juan is cutting firewood.

Primary_Text: U ili uusi jamut jiosiam maejtrotau nu'upak.
Translated_Text: The little girl brought the book to the teacher.
Those oranges are falling down.
I threw the litter far away.
The firewood does not burn well.
We are peeling the corns.
I will plow the ground (lit. I will shave the ground (in order to sow something).).
Comment: This example is included in order to provide a typical transitive form of the coding frame 1 2-acc V but this coding frame involves a meaning extension from SHAVE to PLOW.

Translated_Text: Juan made Maria show drawings to Peter.
The boat sank.
(His) Grandfather does not hear.
Comment: It does not mean 'His grandfather is deaf'. For expressing that, there is another lexical item (adjective: nakapit).

Translated_Text: Food is already cooked.
The meat is cooking too much.
My mother is cooking the meat.
Beans cook well.
The rock rolls. / The rock is rolling.
I am rolling the rock. / I roll the rock.
Carlos tore off his shirt.
I made fun of Juan.
Juan stole money from Maria.
Juan stole money from the house.
I blinked.
The dog frightened the man.

Primary_Text: U ili uusi chu'uta kutae beebak.
Translated_Text: The child hit the dog with a stick.

Primary_Text: U ta'a kaa tu'isi jita wawaacha.
Translated_Text: The sun does not dry well.
The clothes are dry.
The sun dries the flowers (for someone).
The horse is sinking in the mud.
Running caused Juan to be hungry.
I am feeling sad because of my dog.
Comment: The dog is the cause for being sad, e.g. He died.

Translated_Text: Maria made Juan sad.
The man let the woman die.
Comment: It implies that the man did not do anything to help the woman, e.g. She was sick and he did not cure her.

Translated_Text: Maria is dying for her children.
Comment: The children are the malefactees of the event muucha.

Translated_Text: The wind causes (everybody) to feel cold.
The wind caused me to feel cold.
Something caused me to feel cold.
The food made me feel pain in the stomach. / The food caused my tummy to ache.
Juan is screaming at Maria.
Maria is making Melquiades laugh. / Maria makes Melquiades laugh.
Comment: The related verb form atbwa 'make fun (of somebody)' is the transitive (non-causative) form of the aache 'laugh' verb.

Translated_Text: Melquiades is laughing at Maria.
They laughed at someone here.
Comment: passive

Translated_Text: Juan lives. / Juan has a house.
Melquiades left by bus.
Melquiades left Hermosillo.
Melquiades left towards Vicam.
Juan went with Maria.
Juan left.
Juan is playing.
Juan made Maria play.
Juan played a game.
I jumped over the cow's dung.
Comment: It is implied that I jumped over the dung in order to not step on it.

Translated_Text: I stepped into the cow's dung.
Comment: It is implied that the dung is all over the foot.

Translated_Text: I blinked (my eyes) at Juan.
Juan blinked at me.
The car is being loaded with hay.
Carry my child for me.
Comment: The first person singular is the benefactee.

Translated_Text: The storm caused the town to be covered in drizzling.
The town is covered with water (lit. The town is filled with water.).

Primary_Text: U jamut ili uusita soto'ita tapuniatuak.
Translated_Text: The woman made the child fill the pot.

Primary_Text: U ili uusi achaiwata betchi'ibo au pattak.
Translated_Text: The child covered himself for the father.
Comment: It is not possible to say this sentence using the applicative marker instead of the betchi'ibo postposition.

Translated_Text: The child is already covered with the sheet.
Cover the child with the sheets!
Comment: This is an imperative sentence.

Translated_Text: The woman is covering herself with the shawl.

Primary_Text: Goi ili jamuchim tutukabeak in jo'apo to'e.
Translated_Text: Yesterday, two girls stayed at my home (to sleep). \ lit. Two little girls yesterday laid at my home.
Comment: The verb requires a plural subject in this case.

Translated_Text: Pour some water on the jar.

Primary_Text: I pichel kaa tu'isi jita yeu toto'a.
Translated_Text: This jar does not pour well.

Primary_Text: I wikia kaa tu'isi jita susuma.
Translated_Text: This rope does not tie well.
Juan tied the horse to the tree with a rope.
Juan tied the horse with a rope.
Juan knotted his tie.
Juan carried the book(s).
Someone was given a book.
Maria has been given a book.
Juan gives a lot (of things) to the library.
I gave away the books.
Comment: The verb miika means 'to give something as a present'. It has the same coding frame, though.
Translation_Other: Regalé libros

Primary_Text: Ne librom Juanta makak Mariata betchi'ibo.
Translated_Text: I gave Juan the book for Maria.
Juan is a deer-hunter.
Maria hid from Juan.
Maria hid.
Comment: It is not sure whether the verbs esso and euse are related by an equipollent relation.

Translated_Text: Maria hid the book from Juan.
I tore one page from the book.
Take Maria's money!
Comment: This example is a command.

Translated_Text: Those knives cut well.
Juan is touching himself.
Juan is touching something.
Juan and Maria are touching each other.
The table was beaten.
Juan built me a house.
Speak to me. / Tell me (something).
I shaved (myself) for the feast.
Juan dresses well.
Juan is washing himself.
I climbed to the fifth floor.
I climb the stairs.
Comment: The locative marker can be replaced by a plural marker if the verb displays the participle marker.

Translated_Text: The dog is smelling somebody. / The dog is sniffing.
Juan looks at himself in the mirror.
The dog's name is Tobi.
The dog was named Tobi.
Juan spoke to Maria. / Juan told something to Maria.
Juan is shouting. / Juan is screaming.
I asked for money from my mother.

Primary_Text: Ne tomita a'awak nim maalata betchi'ibo.
Translated_Text: I asked for money from my mother.

Primary_Text: U ili uusi unna tomita a'awa.
Translated_Text: The child asks for a lot of money.

Primary_Text: U ili uusi achaiwatau tomita a'aula.
Translated_Text: The child asked money from his father.
Juan realized something by himself.
Juan and Maria met each other.
Juan helped me to paint.

Primary_Text: I saabu kaa tu'isi jita babaksia.
Translated_Text: This soap does not wash well.
My car is washed.
My car does not wash well.

Primary_Text: Ume yoemem siime karipo jita jariwa.
Translated_Text: The men searched all the house.
That is what I think.
Juan is thinking (sexually) of Maria. / Juan is having sex with Maria.
Comment: The verb's meaning is shifting to 'feel'.

Translated_Text: The stuff/person is known.
Maria has been liked.
Comment: Maria tu'ulila is also possible.

Translated_Text: I frightened Juan for Maria.
I got frightened because of Juan.
Translation_Other: Por culpa de Juan me asusté.

Translated_Text: The people are scared. / Someone frightened the people.
Translation_Other: (Alguien) asustó (a la gente).

Translated_Text: The man got scared of the dog.
Maria has been afraid.
Maria is afraid.
Comment: We used the verb 'to be afraid' as the intransitive counterpart of the meaning FEAR.

Translated_Text: The mountain is not well-seen. / The mountain is not easy to see.
Juan looks good.
Juan sees the child.
The apple is gone (lit. The apple is eaten.).
Maria is being hugged.
This food is easy to eat (lit. This cow (meat) is easy to eat.).
The apple is gone.
Comment: Lit. 'The apple was eaten' but without using a passive marker.

Translated_Text: Juan is eating.
Comment: could also be analyzed as incorporated undetermined object jita

Translated_Text: I put the glass there.
Comment: The place where the object is placed can be dropped. It can be determined by the context.

Translated_Text: The man washed (himself).
Maria teaches (people).
The dog is smelling (something).
The man shaved his head.
The man shaved himself.
The wind caused it to rain.
Juan and Maria met (lit. Juan and Maria knew each other.).
Juan and Maria met each other.
Maria has liked people/someone.
I know Hermosillo (lit. I know about Hermosillo.).
Juan killed himself.
Maria is hugging around.
Juan and Maria hugged each other.

Primary_Text: U ili uusi kutae yee bebak.
Translated_Text: The child hit (people) with a stick.
Juan is playing soccer.
Comment: The word pelotam can not be singular in Yaqui.

Translated_Text: Maria is singing. / Maria sings.
Juan beat (at) the table.
Juan beat the table.
Juan talked.
Juan can not see.
Juan ran two kilometers.
The woman shouted at the little child.
Maria showed drawings (to people).
The child asked for a lot.
Juan chases (people).
That helps.
The man shaved (something).
These sheets do not cover (people).
I am feeling pain in my head (lit. I am feeling head-pain.).
Comment: It is also used to express: 'I have a headache'.

Translated_Text: Juan is washing his hands.
Peel the skin off the orange.
Tiburcio is freezing the grilled beef.
Juan coughed on me.
Juan sank the boat.
Maria seated the child on the bench.
The shirt is tearing off.
The man got frightened.
The house is burning.
The glass broke.
Maria teaches (people) English.
Comment: lingo/ringo is a word used to refer to foreigners, specifically people from the United States, but it has extended its uses to every foreigner.

Translated_Text: Juan is a hunter.
The mesquite is drying.
Juan is drying the clothes.
Juan is feeling sad.
I am playing (with a toy) car.
The dog is dying.
The woman screamed.
Melquiades left. / Melquiades has gone.
The cow jumps over the fence.
I jump.
The man sits on the log.
Juan ran.
I coughed.
I am loading cases onto the car.
My mom is carrying the child.
Juan takes the money from Maria. \ lit. Juan money-takes from Maria.
Juan took the money.
Juan built a house.
Juan talked to Maria.
Juan met Maria.
He is getting dressed.
The woman is dressing the child.
The man is fearing. / The man is afraid.
The man fears the dog. / The man is afraid of the dog.
Juan is looking at the child.
The dogs are smelling themselves.
The dog is smelling/sniffing Maria.
Juan made a table.
The woman is digging the ground.
Juan went to the market.
Juan washed the car.
I helped Maria.
The man saw the child.
The man knows the child.
He said 'no' to me.
He is saying the time/hour for the woman (in her place).
What is the man saying ?
Maria sat down on the floor.
Juan broke the window with a stone.
Juan killed the dog.
Juan took the books to the library.
He is wiping the car.
Maria showed drawings to Juan.
I sent the book to Maria.
I am freezing (lit. I am feeling very cold.).
Juan gave Maria a book.
Comment: This construction allows the occurrence of two accusative markers. In this case, one of the participants is marked with the plural -m, which can not appear together with the accusative marker, i.e. *ta-m ~ *-m-ta.

Translated_Text: Somebody brought me flowers.
He is covering the pot.
I am filling the deposit with water.
I am filling the jar.
Juan tied the horse to the tree.
Juan burned the house.
Juan is hearing Maria.
Maria is cooking beans.
The man thinks.
Juan rolls the ball.
Juan pushed Maria into the water.
It is raining.
Juan lives in Hermosillo (lit. Juan is housed in Hermosillo.).
Maria is singing songs.
They are eating beans.
The cowboy is following the horse.
I tore one page from the book.
The men are looking for the child.
Maria likes Juan.
Melquiades laughs. / Melquiades is laughing.
I am feeling pain in my hand. / My hand is hurting.
I blinked my eyes.
Juan climbed.

Primary_Text: U ili uusi achaiwatau tomita a'awak.
Translated_Text: The little child asked money from his father.

Primary_Text: U ili uusi jamut eteorita neu etejok.
Translated_Text: The little girl told me a story.
My mother is screaming out for the dog. / My mother is calling the dog.
Comment: It might be "shouting at the dog" but not necessarily.

Translated_Text: Maria hid the book.
Comment: The plural marker can not co-occur with the accusative marker.

Translated_Text: I put the glass on the table.
The little child hit the dog.
Juan is touching Maria.
Translation_Other: Juan agarró a María.

Translated_Text: We are making the house.
The man is digging.
The woman goes to the party.
The small man is washing himself (his hands) in the river.
Marta is washing the corn leaf.
I'm going to see my relative in town.
I know Maria.
The man is talking.
My son says that he is hungry.
The man is saying something to the woman.
The woman is sitting on the field.
Juan broke the mirror.
Juan is killing the snake on the field.
Manuel cuts the meat.
The man beats the wall angrily.
Comment: The verb chona means 'to hit something with the hand'.

Translated_Text: The woman is cleaning the baby.
The woman is cleaning her house.
The woman shows the man the grilled meat.
I am sending Juan to Potam.
While I was on the field, I felt cold.
The man gave the woman a horse.
The cowboy brings a deer.
I threw the water on the table.

Primary_Text: U jamut ili uusita pisammea patta.
Translated_Text: The woman covers the child with a blanket.
I am filling the pot with water.
The woman pours water in the pot.
The woman ties the dog.
Manuel's house burned.
I peeled an orange.
I am shaving (myself).
My brother is sinking the car in the mud.
The boy does not hear his mother.
The food is boiling.
Juan does not think. \ lit. Juan think nothing.
Comment: The expression kaita is a reduction of the phrase ka jita, which means 'no something'. It is used as an answer to express 'nothing'.

Translated_Text: The horse collided with the man. / The horse ran into the man.
He is grinding corn.
It is raining in Vicam. / It is raining over there in Vicam.
My brother lives in Vicam.
My grandmother sings to me.
The woman follows the man.
I am searching for my dog.
The little boy is afraid.
The cat frightens the little boy.
I like Diana.
I like the big house.
Juan always laughs.
Lola is feeling much pain in her stomach.
The woman blinks too much.
The child is hungry.
The children are climbing at the tree.
The child is afraid of the dog.
To whom are you talking?

Primary_Text: Ili uusi jamut ili uusita tejwa ...
Translated_Text: The girl says to the boy...
Whom are you shouting at?
My girlfriend's name is Alma.
Comment: 'to name' is a verb in Yaqui but the translation to English employs a copula.

Translated_Text: Do not hit the pot with the stick!
I hid the money.
You are stealing money.
Juan hugged Maria.
Juan is eating an apple.
I am putting the pot on the table.
The man is touching the woman.
Ask Maria for John.
Maria is asking for Juan.
I want some beef.
The coyote weeps on the scrub.
My mother grinds beans.
I am rolling the stone.
Juan cooked the meat.
The man carries some meat.
The child fell into the mud.

Primary_Text: Ili uusita ne ania aakim a yojta.
Translated_Text: I help the child to get down the pitahaya.
I got a job.
Juan wants pop corn.
Maria is crying.

Primary_Text: Ili uusim wasapo bwia rebejkoam mojta.
Translated_Text: The children are crumbling some clods.
The man is thinking.
Juan broke the table.
The table broke.
Maria fell.
Juan appeared.
Maria is sick.
The deer bled.
Juan took Maria there.
Juan went to the market.
These oranges don't peel well.
Juan knocked the table.
Juan knocked the table (lit. Juan knocked on the table.).
The man is searching the bag.
The girl got dressed (lit. The little girl caused herself to be dressed.).
Maria gets dressed quickly.
Juan broke the table on me.
Juan threw a stone.
Juan threw me a stone.
Throw one peso to the pool.
I drain the pool of the water.
The pool has been emptied.
The pool is being emptied.
The woman covered (herself) with the shawl.
The woman covered herself with the shawl.

Primary_Text: U ili uusi jaibu au jintuala.
Translated_Text: The little child is already covered.
The woman covered (herself).
Comment: jintek means 'to cover with a blanket or a shawl'.

Translated_Text: Juan went over there.
Juan lives (lit. Juan is alive.).
Juan lived (for) fifty years.
I live with my heart.
Melquiades is laughing at Maria.
Juan is laughing (at somebody).
The soup is cold.
The soup burns (people).
Juan burned the house.
The sun is heating the ground.
The ground is heating up.
The snake peeled off.
Comment: The meaning of weche in this example has changed into an idiomatic one, meaning PEEL OFF instead of FALL.

Translated_Text: You know how to ride a bike.
The wattle is broken.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta ili uusita ubbatuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman wash the child.

Primary_Text: U yoeme uka jamutta pisou kom wettuak.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman fall down to the floor.
What do you want to cover her with?
It's not dry yet.
Brad helped Erni cook breakfast.
My little sister asked me for money. /Lit. From me was asked for money by my little sister.
Comment: Lit: From me was asked for money by my little sister.

Translated_Text: Nadia was brought a gift by Erni.
I sent the letters for Erni.
The dog was killed.
We discussed that issue.
Tessa was robbed.
Dalan got scared.
Nadia wants to meet Tomo tomorrow.
Hillary climbed Mt. Everest.
The children are playing.
Dalan shaved his moustache.
Dalan skinned the chicken.
Nadia pealed a mango.
Singgih listened to that song endlessly.
I call her mom.
I am called Tom. / I was called by Tom.
The house is burning.
Betty likes Padang food.
Ririn asked Tessa for money.
Comment: ke, ama, dari are all licit prepositions

Translated_Text: Nadia said it would be best if we go.
Erni broke my pen.
Dalan showed me his hand.
Dalan loaded his things into the car.
Dalan filled the car (with gas).
The fire is burning.
Adam is cold.
Dalan's mother just died.
Dalan is singing.
Betty went to the market.
Dalan bathes his grandmother.
Nadia dresses her child.
Erni helped Dalan.
I followed Dalan.
Dalan frightened Erni.
Erni broke my heart.
Dalan killed the lights.
Adam cut the cake.
Nadia tears her clothes.
Betty hid the wallet in the cupboard.
Adam stole a dog.
Betty sent me money.
Dalan tied his hair.
Erni covers her head with a headscarf.
Nadia cut the mango.
Tim got chocolate(s).
Tessa stole the money.
Tom takes a motorcycle.
Erni appears in a soap opera.
His girlfriend smelled his body odor.
Vitto wants (some) meatballs.
Nadia is thinking.
Erni took the money.
The boss got the receipt.
Erni was pushing the car.
Dalan skinned the chicken.
Nadia is peeling a mango.
Erni was doing her homework.
Dalan was laughing.
Dalan was hugging his girlfriend.
Singgih heard someone's voice.
The farmer grinds the rice.
The worker dug the grave.
Erni cooks noodles.
Nadia called (for) the doctor.
Erni held her child's hand.
The maid washes the clothes.
Her head appeared (from the window). / Her head was sticking out.
Erni is jumping (up and down).
Comment: Specifically vertical jumping.

Translated_Text: Dalan climbed the betel tree.
Erni helps her mother.
Dalan is happy.
Ririn asked for money.
Erni told Tom the plan for the outing.
Tom is talking.
Erni broke her ruler.
Comment: Accidental reading.

Translated_Text: Nadia killed the dog.
Dalan hit the dog.
Jono plugged in the cable.

Primary_Text: Tessa nyuri duitnya dari dompet Betty.
Translated_Text: Tessa stole money from Betty's wallet.

Primary_Text: Anaknya nunjukin hasil ujiannya ke ortunya.
Translated_Text: The child showed her test results to her parents.
Erni went into the classroom.
Dalan helped Nadia with her homework.

Primary_Text: Jono bicara ama Betty soal gajinya.
Translated_Text: Jono talked to Betty about her salary.
Nadia cut the mango with a knife.
Dalan wiped the table.
The car's full.
I'm sad.
Dalan is a hunter.
The item of clothing is dry.
The ship sank.
Tessa turned on the lights.
The ball rolled.
His/her eye blinked.
The child is hungry.
The air is cold.
The cellphone fell.
Tom is sick.
Tessa appeared from within the cave.
I live in Jakarta.
Dalan sang a dangdut song.
Tom jumped.
Dalan is running.
Erni is sitting on the floor.
Dalan coughs.
Dalan bathes.
Nadia is wearing shoes.
I ate bread.
I attended an outing.
Dalan met Tom.
Erni looked for her book.
Erni likes chocolate.
Dalan was afraid of a cockroach.
Dalan saw a ghost.
Erni knew John's wife.

Primary_Text: Dalan cerita ke Erni soal rencana pernikahannya.
Translated_Text: Dalan told Erni about his wedding plan.

Primary_Text: Nadia bilang ke Dalan dia udah pergi.
Translated_Text: Nadia told Dalan she already left.
Dalan built a house.
The glass broke.
The cat died.
Erni hit the table.
Dalan touched his girlfriend.
Nadia tore the paper.
Betty hid in the cupboard.
Dalan stole some money.

Primary_Text: Erni dapet kado dari Pak John.
Translated_Text: Erni got a gift from John.
I brought the basin.
Erni poured the water into the glass.
Nadia filled the earthen pitcher with water.
Tomo shouted.
Dalan left.
The water is boiling.
Dalan found (some) money.
Dalan was taught literature by Erni.
Erni teaches math.
Erni shaved Dalan's moustache.
My bag got carried away (accidentally).
Tim got rained on.
Tim got herpes from his girlfriend.
John got his laptop from Bangkok.
I put the book on the table (for someone).
Comment: Benefactive. Iterative readings available.

Translated_Text: John put the book on the table.
I put the car in the garage.
I threw a rock to Tim.
I put the laptop down for John.
Dalan sent a letter for his mom.
I hit Tim with stones.
Tim closed the door with a stick.
Dalan's mommy cut him some mango.
The motorbike was put in the garage by the guard.
I poured her some water.
Betty sent me letters.
Nadia was given a gift by her boyfriend.
Dalan was told by Nadia about the FPI.
I gave him a book.
The water was poured out (by) me.
Dalan broke the glass.
Erni covered the food.
The wallet was stolen (by) her.
I tied my hair.
I threw a stone.
Nadia was called.
Betty is hiding.
I go.
It's raining.
Erni's crying.
Tessa is helping Erni with her homework.
Tomo's building some rooms for rent.
Nadia's grilling fish.

Primary_Text: Dalan ngambil duit dari dompet Betty.
Translated_Text: Dalan took money from Betty's wallet.
The cat was killed (accidentally).
My wallet was stolen.

Primary_Text: Gue ngajarin bahasa inggris ke dia.
Translated_Text: I teach her English.
I teach her English.
I brought a book for her.
I brought her a book.
I gave a book to him.
I gave him a book.
The door was closed by Erni.
Erni covered the food.
The door is closed.
Erni closes the door.
Erni closes the door.
The child hid behind the tree.
Bit by bit, the student's sense of self died away.

Primary_Text: Geu namuga Marye euhaeseo kajireul jallyeotta.
Translated_Text: The branch of that tree was cut by Mary.
Comment: O'Grady (1991: 72) gives this highly unnatural and questionable example to argue that in a possessor ascension construction the bearer of the role changes from the former possessum to the possessor, and accordingly, only the possessor in a possessor ascension construction can become the subject of a corresponding passive construction. Note therefore the (from a Indoeuropean perspective) rather strange coding pattern with NOM-postpos_adjunct-ACC V, which I would reject here.

Translated_Text: Mari was given a truly valuable opportuniy.
Comment: This example is supposed to show the interaction between the double accusative marking alternation that pertains to this verb and the changes of marking that occur in passivised sentences such as above. Both ACC cases seem to be changed into NOM here.

Translated_Text: He killed thirty people.
One cooks the soup for thirty more minutes.

Primary_Text: Sumineun migugeseo sibnyeoneul saldaga hangugeuro dorawatta.
Translated_Text: Sumi lived in the States for ten years and came back to Korea.
Original_Orthography: 수미는 미국에서 십년을 살다가 한국으로 돌아왔다.

Translated_Text: I went to the market today.

Primary_Text: Niga joajilkkabwa naega neol ilbureo museowohaneun geoya.
Translated_Text: I'm being afraid of you on purpose because I might start liking you, you know [and I musn't do that].
Comment: As opposed to base forms, experiencer verbs in hada-constructions can imply volitionality, as the co-occurrence with the word ilbureo 'on purpose' suggests.
Original_Orthography: 니가 좋아질까봐 내가 널 일부러 무서워하는 거야.

Primary_Text: Gipeun sarangdo haebogo, ttoneun, daege apado mani haebogo geuraeseo...
Translated_Text: ...I had the chance to be deeply in love and also be in deep pain, so...
Comment: Found at the beginning of Episode 21 of a Korean series called 시크릿 가든, 'Secret Garden' (the Hangeul title are English words), where the actress replies to a question about her impressions about shooting this series. This example has been found to be relevant because it suggests that the emotion/sensation verb and hada in a hada-construction might not be that tightly bound, and contrary to my intuition, it seems to be a periphrastic construction where two morphemes can occur in non-adjacent positions in syntax.
Original_Orthography: ...깊은 사랑도 해보고, 또는, 대게 아파도 많이 해보고 그래서...

Primary_Text: Seonguga sumireul Cheolsuege seonmureul juge haetta.
Translated_Text: Soung-U made Sumi give a gift to Cheolsu.
Comment:
Although I do find this example a bit strange, I am assuming that it is due to an acceptability, rather than grammaticality issue.
I am not sure whether Sumi could be marked with nominative case, although I would reject Sumi being marked with dative case.
Note that one would make a little pause after the second constituent.
Original_Orthography: 성우가 수미를 철수에게 선물을 주게 했다.

Primary_Text: ?Ya neo nal geu kareul jom chajajwo jamkkan?
Translated_Text: Hey can you just look for the knife you told me about for me?
Comment: I am not sure whether a double accusative coding pattern is possible for benefactive constructions.
Original_Orthography: ?야 너 날 그 칼을 좀 찾아줘, 잠깐!

Primary_Text: Eomma na i gyul jom kkajwo, na jigeum himi eobseo.
Translated_Text: Mum, can you peel this tangerine for me? I just don't have the energy to do that right now.
Original_Orthography: 엄마 나 이 귤 좀 까줘, 나 지금 힘이 없어.

Translated_Text: Please, would you sit down around here?
Comment:
Clearly, there is a benefactive meaning implied here, and the imperative implies that the speaker is the potential beneficiary, although syntactically, no argument is added here.

The locative argument can be marked with directional case for reasons of politeness. (To give you a gist, compare Just sit somewhere around there or Just sit on the black chair over there).
Translation_Other: Wenn die Herrschaften sich hier niederlassen würden?

Translated_Text: How nice would it be if it rained (for us)?
Comment: An example where a verb is combined with juda 'give' to a complex predicate, although no overt syntactic argument seems to be added, although it is semantically implied.
Translation_Other: Wie schön wär's, wenn es mal endlich für uns Regen gäbe.

Translated_Text: He put his hand on his chest and swore an oath.
This church has been built out of wood.
The father built a house for his son.

Primary_Text: Eoje bam geu sasiri on gukminege allyeojyeotta.
Translated_Text: That fact went public yesterday.
Original_Orthography: 어제 밤 그 사실이 온 국민에게 알려졌다.

Translated_Text: Sumi told her family the happy news.

Primary_Text: Tteonamyeon andwenikka yael gyesok geogie anja ikke hae!
Translated_Text: He can't leave, so make him stay sat the whole time!
Original_Orthography: 떠나면 안 되니까 얠 계속 앉아 있게 해!
Translation_Other: Er darf nicht weggehen, bring ihn also dazu, dort sitzen zu bleiben!

Translated_Text: The children made fun of Cheolsu.
Cheolsu was playing with his friend in the patio.
The child perceived a weird sound coming from far away.
Comment: I am not sure whether a double nominative construction would be grammatical, since my own judgment varies from time to time.

Translated_Text: The teacher taught the students German.
My presentation was moved back.
Comment: This example has been taken from Naver on-line dictionary of which the content has been provided by the National Institute for the Korean Language. URL: http://endic.naver.com/krenEntry.nhn?sLn=en&entryId=0a9a00fd4b5e4845b754434e7a1f8ae1&query=%EB%B0%80%EB%A6%AC%EB%8B%A4 [accessed 2014-03-04]

Translated_Text: We put the cupboard by the windowside by pushing it there.
Comment: The locative case may be licensed through the joint predication with noh- 'put'.

Primary_Text: Achime ireonatteoni jeongwone jandiga imi kkakkyeo isseotta.
Translated_Text: When I got up in the morning the grass in my backyard had already been cut.
Original_Orthography: 아침에 일어났더니 저원에 잔디가 이미 깎여 있었다.

Primary_Text: Yeonpilkkakkireul sseumyeon yeonpiri hwolssin deo ppalli kkakkajinda.
Translated_Text: If you use a pencil sharpener, you can sharpen pencils much quicker.
Original_Orthography: 연필깎이를 쓰면 연필이 훨씬 더 빨리 깎아진다.

Translated_Text: Peel this apple.
Comment: A more colloquial example. Note that the prescriptively favoured form would be kkakka here and not kkakkeo. Since case marking is missing, only the word order clarifies that neo is the subject here and sagwa the object.

Primary_Text: Eomma i hobagi kkeopjjiri yeong an kkajine!
Translated_Text: Mum, this pumpkin skin just doesn't want to come off!
Comment: This example is not as naturalistic as it could be, since one would usually drop the nominative marking on the first noun, which in turn would make it difficult to distinguish between a nominal compound and two adjacent, but independent nouns.
Original_Orthography: 엄마 이 호박이 껍질이 영 안 까지네!
Translation_Other: Mama, die Schale vom Kürbis hier lässt sich einfach nicht schälen!

Translated_Text: I grazed my knee yesterday when I fell over.
First, you have to peel the skin off the apple.
I grazed my knee yesterday when I fell over.
Comment: Impressionistically, I would claim that the ji-periphrasis sounds less stilted than the morphological passive. See ex. 286.

Translated_Text: The farmer dug the roots out of the ground.

Primary_Text: Yojeum biga deol waseo ttangi jal an pajinda.
Translated_Text: It is hard to dig the ground since it's been raining little.
Original_Orthography: 요즘 비가 덜 와서 땅이 잘 안 파진다.

Primary_Text: Achime ireonatteoni jeongwone keun gudeongiga payeo isseotta.
Translated_Text: He had just got up in the morning when he saw that someone had dug a big hole in his garden.
Original_Orthography: 아침에 일어났더니 정원에 큰 구덩이가 파여 있었다.

Primary_Text: Geuneun myeot sigan dongan michidorog ttangeul patta.
Translated_Text: He dug the ground for hours and hours as though he went crazy.
Original_Orthography: 그는 몇 시간 동안 미치도록 땅을 팠다.

Translated_Text: [when looking for something with one's arm in a location one cannot see]: He could feel something soft touching his hand./He inadvertedly grabbed something soft.
Translation_Other: Er spürte etwas weiches an seiner Hand. / Er ertastete irgendetwas weiches.

Translated_Text: Intended meaning: I made Mia laugh on the street.
Comment: Very questionable and awkward example given in Sohn (1999: 376). The alternation value for LAUGH for the morphological causative has been checked as 'marginal', since the usage of the periphrastic causative seems much more natural to me.
Original_Orthography: nay ka Mia lul kil eyse wus-ky-ess-ta

Translated_Text: Cheolsu was very sad about the death of his friend.

Primary_Text: Keompyuteoga ppareul surog peijiga deo ppalli chajajinda.
Translated_Text: The faster the computer, the quicker one can find the web pages.
Original_Orthography: 컴퓨터가 빠를 수록 페이지가 더 빨리 찾아진다.

Translated_Text: The father looked for/found the toy for his child.
Comment: This example is certainly ambiguous, and could also be seen as a biclausal structure where the two verbs head spearate clausal domains.

Translated_Text: The child screamed.
Comment: The meaning of jireu- is unknown to me, please refer to the comment field of the corresponding verb layout.

Translated_Text: I am dedicating this piece to you.
Comment: See comment in verb layout.

Primary_Text: Kkeudeobneun oeroumi nae maeumeul chubge handa.
Translated_Text: The endless loneliness makes my heart feel cold.
Comment: Since I was not entirely sure about the possiblity of such an example I constructed this after a disussion found on the internet (Nate). See http://ask.nate.com/qna/view.html?n=12006643 [accessed 2014-03-03].
Original_Orthography: 끝없는 외로움이 내 마음을 춥게 한다.

Primary_Text: Naneun i bangi chuwoseo jameul mot jagesseo.
Translated_Text: I think I can't sleep because this room is so cold.
Original_Orthography: 나 이 방이 추워서 잠을 못 자겠어.

Primary_Text: Juineun uriege aju bangaun gisaegeul natanaetta.
Translated_Text: The owner presented us his joy of seeing us (on his face).
Comment:
This sentence can be found as an example in the Naver on-line dictionary. The (diachronically?) causative form of natanada 'APPEAR'
is used with rather abstract nouns and I am not sure whether this verb is often used in colloquial language as opposed to, let's say, byeojuda 'SHOW visually'. URL: http://krdic.naver.com/detail.nhn?docid=6727400 [accessed 2014-03-03] Note that what has been glossed as 'welcoming' here is a verb, bangabda that describes the feeling of joy when someone meets somebody else.
Original_Orthography: 주인은 우리에게 아주 반가운 기색을 나타냈다.
Translation_Other: Der Gutsherr begegnete uns mit einem Ausdruck des Willkommenheissens.

Translated_Text: The god rescued/resuscitated that child.

Primary_Text: Sini baekseongdeureul geu maeureseo salge hayeotta.
Translated_Text: The god made his people live in that village.
Original_Orthography: 신이 백성들을 그 마을에서 살게 하였다.

Primary_Text: Geudeureun maeureseo haengbokan insaengeul salgo isseotta.
Translated_Text: They were living a happy life in the village.
Original_Orthography: 그들은 마을에서 행복한 인생을 살고 있었다.

Primary_Text: Eommaneun jeonyeogmada aiege norae(reul) bulleo jusyeotta.
Translated_Text: Every night the mother sang her child a song.
Comment: The accusative marking seems to be optional here, which is why the benefactive coding frame could be regarded NOM-DAT rather than NOM-ACC-DAT.
Original_Orthography: 엄마는 저녁마다 아이에게 노래를 불러 주셨다.

Translated_Text: Our grandmother used to sing all day long.
Original_Orthography: 우리 할머니는 하루 종일 노래 부르셨다.

Primary_Text: Kkujunhi cheryeogeul kiumyeon deo jal dallyeojinda.
Translated_Text: If one works on one's stamina continuously, one can run much more easily.
Original_Orthography: 꾸준히 체력을 키우면 더 잘 잘려진다.

Primary_Text: Oneul naega jeon koseureul dallyeogajigo eomcheong pigonhada.
Translated_Text: I've run the whole course today and am really, really tired.
Original_Orthography: 내가 오늘 전 코스를 달려가지고 엄청 피곤하다.

Primary_Text: Naega oneul chong sip kiromiteoreul dallyeotta.
Translated_Text: In total I ran 10 kilometres today.
The monkey climbs on the tree without any effort.

Primary_Text: Maneun saramdeuri beoseureul tago Seoraksane deungsanhareo gatta.
Translated_Text: Many people went on a bus to the Seorak mountains to go hiking.
Original_Orthography: 많은 사람들이 버스를 타고 서락산에 등산하러 갔다.

Translated_Text: Many people have boarded the ship.

Primary_Text: Neo bab meokki jeone gaseo ssiseo!
Translated_Text: Go wash before we eat!

Primary_Text: Sajeong sajeongeul haedo mari an meokine.
Translated_Text: Really, no matter how much I explain my reasons to him, no matter I beg him, my words just do not reach him.
Original_Orthography: 사정 사정을 해도 말이 안 먹히네.

Primary_Text: I sangwange geuraedo babi meogeojinya, meogeojyeo, i jasiga?
Translated_Text: So you still can eat despite the situation were in, you bastard?
Original_Orthography: 이 상황에 그래도 밥이 먹어지냐, 먹어져, 이 자식아?
Translation_Other: Sag mal du Sack, du kriegst immer noch etwas runter, in dieser Situation?

Primary_Text: Urineun eoje bam gyesok yaegihadaga jam deureotta.
Translated_Text: Yesterday we fell asleep after talking to each other for hours.
Original_Orthography: 우리는 어제 밤 계속 애기 하다가 잠 들었다.

Translated_Text: The father beat up his son with a stick./The father punished his son through beating.
Comment: Whether double accusative marking is possible here, is unclear. As an alternative suggestion, it might be that either the instrument or the patient can be marked with accusative, and whether their occurence is mutually exclusive in the case of an overtly accusative-marked instrument should be tested.

Translated_Text: Cheolsu gave Sumi a slap in the face.
Comment: Not sure whether this example is grammatical.

Translated_Text: The mother cut the meat for her child.
The mother wiped the child's mouth (for it).
Comment:
Another example where a verb combines with juda 'GIVE' to a complex predicate to implicate benefactive meaning, although
the verbal valency does not seem to be altered, since there is no dative-marked benefactive argument here.

Translated_Text: Supposedly: (somebody) made the children wipe off the spilled water.
Comment: This entry has been found in the Naver on-line dictionary for Korean of which the content have been provided by the National Institute for the Korean Language. Being a prescriptive source, I have included this example as an inspiration for further research, although in actual non-corpus-planning usage this constructions sounds ungrammatical to me. Since this example cannot be supported by my intuition, I checked the corresponding alternation value as 'marginally'. Whether this form is in actual use I dare to doubt. URL: http://krdic.naver.com/detail.nhn?docid=8516700 [accessed 2014-03-04]

Translated_Text: The glass had not been cleaned properly.
Comment:
Whether the morphological passive is still widely used in spoken language is unclear, although it does not sound ungrammatical as the causative form of this verb in ex. 250. For more, see the entry in Naver dictionary:
http://krdic.naver.com/detail.nhn?docid=8516600 [accessed 2014-03-04]

Primary_Text: Eomma, yeogi meonjiga jal an ttakkajyeo!
Translated_Text: Mum, the dust here doesn't really get wiped off properly!
Comment: The colloquial form as indicated in the verb layout comment of WIPE has been given here. (구어체) gueoche has been added as a comment to the primary text here which means 'colloquial language'.
Original_Orthography: 엄마 여기 먼지가 잘 안 딲아져! (구어체)

Translated_Text: As I had walked all day long, my shoes were all torn.
Comment: This usage of periphrastic passive with jjijda 'TEAR' seems much more natural to me than in ex. 246.
Original_Orthography: 하루 종일 걸었더니 신발이 다 찢어졌다.

Translated_Text: My cloths got caught in barbed wire and got torn.
Comment: As ex. 245, this example has been found in the Naver on-line dictionary. Similar to ex. 245, I have not come across this form so far, although my intuition tells me that morphologically this passive form could be formed, whereas the causative form does not sound grammatical. Impressionistically I would say that his form has been replaced by the periphrastic passive in spoken usage, but this should be checked.

Translated_Text: He tore off some scrap for his younger sibling to make dolls.
Comment: This sentence has been found in the Naver on-line dictionary (content provided by the National Institute of the Korean Language). I personally have never heard of this verb form before, and it is questionable whether such a form could still be in use in spoken (and written?) language. Moreover, the case frame shown in this example is peculiar, since as opposed to other morphological causatives in Korean, the causative here adds a beneficiary (and not a causee) to the verbal valency without the employment of a juda-periphrasis as in a "normal" benefactive alternation. The alternation value has been checked as 'marginally' here. This sentence has nevertheless been included to spark some future research. URL: http://krdic.naver.com/detail.nhn?docid=36523000 [accessed 2014-03-02]

Primary_Text: Iyagi sogeneun eonjena jinsiri sumgyeojyeo itta.
Translated_Text: There is always truth hidden inside stories.
Original_Orthography: 이야기 속에는 언제나 진실이 숨겨 있다.

Primary_Text: I jasigi gami nae apeseo geu sasireul sumgyeo?
Translated_Text: So that bastard really dared to hide that fact from me?
Original_Orthography: 이 자식이 감히 내 앞에서 그 사실을 숨겨?
Translation_Other: Dieser Typ wagt es also tatsaechlich, das vor mir zu verheimlichen?

Primary_Text: Geuege dasi han beon gihoega jueojyeotta.
Translated_Text: He had been given/granted another opportunity.
Comment: See comment on verb layout.
Original_Orthography: 그에게 다시 한 번 기회가 주어졌다.

Primary_Text: Neo yaereul wae don dallago hal ttaemada doneul jwo, wae?
Translated_Text: Why the hell do you give him money every time he asks for it? Why?
Comment: This example has been created to show a double accusative case frame occuring with juda 'give', as it could be used in colloquial speech. The accusative-marked recipient here is yael 'this child.ACC' and doneul 'money.ACC'. It might be that depending on the speaker one might consider this example ungrammatical, preferring the usage of yaehante 'this child.DAT' here.
Original_Orthography: 너 얘를 왜 돈 달라고 할 때마다 돈을 줘, 왜?

Translated_Text: The child sent a gift to his friend.

Primary_Text: Aiga uri jibe seonmureul gajyeo watta.
Translated_Text: The child brought a gift to our house.
Comment: Dative case is only possible with animate recipients.

Translated_Text: The child brought me a present.
A dark sauce was on the food.

Primary_Text: Geuneun nameun eumsigeul dwaejideurege bueo jueotta.
Translated_Text: He poured the remaining food in front of his pigs.
Original_Orthography: 그는 남은 음식을 돼지들에게 부어 주었다.

Translated_Text: For the last time he checked whether his shoelaces had been tied correctly.
Comment: neunji seems to be a nominaliser that is used to create sentential complements, and the whole constituent can take on case marking as shown above.

Translated_Text: The father of the child tied his shoelaces for him.
Many things had been loaded onto the car.
She filled water into the glass.
The lungs got full with water.
Comment: For some reason that is not clear to me, a constituent order where the nominative NP comes first and the locative NP comes second sounds awkward, although for verbs such as salda 'LIVE' it works fine. With salda however, there is an agent NP which precedes the locational NP, whereas here mul-i is not an agent, and the question that arises is whether the thematic role linking plays a role in the order of constituents here.

Primary_Text: Aiga umsigi sanghaji anke geureuse ttukkeongeul deopeotta.
Translated_Text: The child put a lid on the bowl to keep the food from getting bad.
Original_Orthography: 아이가 음식이 상하지 않게 그릇에 뚜껑을 덮었다.

Translated_Text: A bear took a stone and broke the glass.
Comment: A more natural example than ex. 86 or 191, where the instrument is expressed in an embedded clause as the argument of another predicate.

Translated_Text: Hey watch out, the meat is catching fire!/getting burned!
The lungs were filled with water.
Comment: This sentence has been found as a Daum blog entry in what appears to be a poem about a woman that has drowned. See here: http://blog.daum.net/benefitesr/16 [accessed 2014-02-25]

Primary_Text: Daeum nal achime jib ape sseuregiga deonjyeo jyeo isseotta.
Translated_Text: The next morning rubbish was dropped in front of his house.
Original_Orthography: 다음날 아침에 집 앞에 쓰레기가 던져져 있었다.

Translated_Text: The student threw a ball to the child.
Father build a house using stones.
The mother shouted at the children.
Comment: The meaning of the verb jireu- is not clear.

Translated_Text: The mother undressed the child.
We pushed the cupboard towards the window.

Primary_Text: Geuneun jasinae silsuro gieobe keun sonaereul angyeotta.
Translated_Text: Through his own mistake he caused his business a whole lot of damage.
Comment: Another example where the morphological causative of a verb brings along unpredictable changes in meaning. The causative form of anda 'hug' is often used with words relating to pain or damage, and might have been partly collocationalised. Note that inanimate nouns cannot be marked with dative case in Korean, but are marked with locative instead. As mentioned, much more common than the above form seems to be a complex predicate made of anda 'hug' and juda 'give'.
Original_Orthography: 그는 자신의 실수로 기업에 큰 손해를 안겼다.

Translated_Text: My father grabbed my brother under his arms to help him get in the car. / lit. My younger brother was grabbed by my father under his arms and got in the car.
Comment: This sentence was found on Naver's on-line dictionary of which the contents have been provided by the National Institute of Korean Language. See: http://krdic.naver.com/detail.nhn?docid=25023100 [accessed 2014-02-21]

Primary_Text: Naneun eolleun ttwieonaga eomeoniwa budungkyeoankko ureotta.
Translated_Text: I hurried outside and ran into my mom's arms and cried.
Comment: This sentence was found on Naver's on-line dictionary of which the contents have been provided by the National Institute of Korean Language. Although it does not sound ungrammatical in principle, whether such a construction is actually used in spoken language I am not sure. Cf. here: http://krdic.naver.com/detail.nhn?docid=17508300 [accessed 2014-02-21]
Original_Orthography: 나는 얼른 뛰어나가 어머니와 부둥켜안고 울었다.

Primary_Text: Eommaneun naege dallyeowa nareul budungkyeo anatta.
Translated_Text: Mother ran towards me and hugged me with her whole body.
Original_Orthography: 엄마는 내게 달려와 나를 부둥켜 안았다.
Translation_Other: Meine Mutter kam auf mich zugerannt und nahm mich zu sich in eine tragende Umarmung.

Translated_Text: Thomas hugged Anna by dragging her towards him.
Translation_Other: Thomas zog Anna zu sich heran und umarmte sie./Thomas nahm Anna in seine Arme.

Translated_Text: Thomas embraced Anna.
Thomas hugged Anna.
Thomas and Anna accidentally met again.
Comment: Word order of NPs from ex. 121 to show that the comitative marked argument does not seem to be embedded into the NP of the nominative-marked argument, speaking for a 'true' reciprocal alternation as opposed to ex. 124.

Primary_Text: Geu aiga nareul (*naega) seonsaengnim irago bulleotta.
Translated_Text: That child called me seonsaengnim. / That child used the title saensaengnim to me.
Comment: This sentence has been taken from Sohn (1999: 325, ex. 105 in original numbering), and the glossing has been adapted to the purposes of this database. It is shown here since as Sohn (1999: 325) mentions, "when quoting verbs mean 'call, name, entitle, think, believe', etc. and the quotative clause predicate is a copula, the quoting verbs may need a direct object". This is not a very enlightening statement, although what I understand from this is that for NAME, the syntactic expression of the named object can only be marked with accusative case, and accordingly this may show that it is always part of the main clause and cannot appear as the overt subject of the embedded clause, as is possible in cases where verbs such as THINK take a sentential complement (see Sohn 1999: 325 for an example).
Original_Orthography: ku ai ka na lul/*ka sensayng-nim i-la ko pull-ess-ta

Primary_Text: Eommaga [aiga gyesok ana dalla haeseo] aireul ana jwotta.
Translated_Text: The mother, with her child constantly begging for a hug, gave the child a hug.
Comment: This is an example as it is commonly used in colloquial usage. The verb anda is commonly used together with the verb juda without affecting the verb's valency. The embedded clause is included here to provide a context where it is made clear that the action of hugging is carried out for the benefit of someone else, and as a help, syntactic brackets have been given here. The element dal- which has been glossed as give.IMP.REFL is a peculiar case where the verb stem of ju- 'give' seems to be suppleted by a diachronically unrelated verb stem dal- (or da- in some cases), for which Sohn (1999:384/ 385) uses the term 'reflexive benefactive auxiliary'. It is used in requests where the participant requesting some benefactory action is semantically coreferential with the beneficiary participant, hence the gloss REFL. I cannot think of a corresponding independent form of this verb in Korean, and since I do not know why it sometimes occurs as dal- and sometimes as da-, I just followed Sohn's analysis of the stem as dal- (Sohn 1999: 385, Sohn himself does not explain the diachronic background of this construction). Note that ha-seo do-CONV means 'say' here.
Original_Orthography: 어머니가 아이가 계속 안아 달라 해서 아이를 안아 줬다.

Translated_Text: The mother dressed her child.
Comment: In ex.42/43 it has been noted that when os and ibda occur adjacently without case-marking on os, there are some interesting phonological changes that normally only apply to compounding processes. Even more interestingly, here ai 'child' cannot be marked with dative case as in ex. 118, and accusative marking is the only option (although this should be tested on a larger set of consultants than n=1).

Translated_Text: The cat came up the tree.
The cat climbed up the tree.
My sister showed me some music.

Primary_Text: Naega aideurege jaeminneun iyagireul deullyeotteoni neomu joahanda.
Translated_Text: As I told the children my story, they really liked it.
Comment: Sentence taken from naver online dictionary (contents by National Institute for Korean Language, cf.http://krdic.naver.com/detail.nhn?docid=10859800 [accessed 2014-02-18]). Although acknowledged by prescriptive sources, this kind of usage without the benefactive juda is highly unnatural in spoken usage, and almost sounds ungrammatical. The author actually had to check the existence of this verb form without juda, since it is so seldomly used in spoken language.
Original_Orthography: 내가 아이들에게 재미있는 이야기를 들렸더니 너무 좋아한다.

Translated_Text: Soung-U was listening to music.

Primary_Text: ?Dodugi dongsaengege geunyeoae jigabeseo doneul humchyeo jwotta.
Translated_Text: The thief stole money from her wallet for his younger brother.
Comment: Whether this is a grammatical example for the benefactive alternation applied on humchida I do not know - it does sound somehow right, but as mentioned, a construction as in ex. 203 may be preferable.
Original_Orthography: ?도둑이 동생에게 그녀의 지갑에서 돈을 훔쳐 줬다.

Primary_Text: Dodugi (*dongsaengege) geunyeoae jigabeseo doneul humchyeoda (gatta) jwotta.
Translated_Text: The thief stole some money from the girl's wallet to give it to his younger brother/for his younger brother.
Comment: As mentioned, whether a benefactive alternatiion applies to this verb is not clear. Instead, one might prefer a construction with an embedded clause which literally means 'steal and give'. Admittedly, the difference to the benefactive example of this verb is not very clear, which is why ga-ss-da go-PST-CONV is given in parentheses here: As opposed to the benefactive example, gatta may appear between the two verbs which modifies the meaning of juda 'give' to gattajuda 'bring something to somebody/take something to somebody'. Still, I do not know the reason why this construction is preferred over a benefactive construction, possibly because the full development of a fully productive benefactive alternation is ongoing. Furthermore, the dative marking of the beneficiary sounds ungrammatical (and at best unacceptable), another possibility would be a postpositional phrase, thus dongsaeng-eul wihaeseo brother-ACC for 'for the brother'.
Original_Orthography: 도둑이 (동생에게?) 그녀의 지갑에서 돈을 훔쳐다 (갔다) 줬다.

Translated_Text: The thief stole money from her (and came here).
The thief stole money from her wallet.
The thief stole money (away) from her.

Primary_Text: Geunyeoneun mentodeul apeseo jasinmanmanan moseubeul boyeotta.
Translated_Text: She presented herself to her mentors with overflowing confidence (lit. she showed an appearance of full confidence in front of her mentors).
Comment: Sentence constructed after on-line article published by REVIEWSTAR, for source see Kim (2012).

Primary_Text: Gunyeon jeon B.ga naege gwansim boyeotta!
Translated_Text: Twenty years ago B. showed me her interest!
Comment: Appears as headline in an online article by the Munhwa Broadcasting Company (MBC). Names and years have been changed/masked because of possible copyright issues.Two remarks can be made here: Firstly, it is typical for this verb to occur with a more abstract theme argument (instead of, say, 'show a book'), and secondly, it does not seem to be usual in spoken usage (as confirmed by two other consultants). Instead, the benefactive form, boyeojuda, seems more natural. For the source, see Kim (2010) in the references section.
Original_Orthography: ㅅ, 20년 전 ㅂ가 나에게 관심 보였다!

Primary_Text: Kim seonsuneun eoje gyeonggijangeseo chameuro nollaun sillyeogeul boyeotta.
Translated_Text: Yesterday in the arena, Kim displayed his exceptional skills.
Original_Orthography: 김 선수는 어제 경기장에서 참으로 놀라운 실력을 보였다.

Primary_Text: Neo na ballo gyesok manjyeo, wae!?
Translated_Text: Why are you grabbing me with your foot all the time?
Original_Orthography: 너 나 발로 계속 만져, 왜?

Translated_Text: The woman cut the bread with a knife/using a knife. / The woman took a knife and cut the bread.
Comment: More natural than ex. 93.

Translated_Text: The heroes put all their forces together and crushed the enemy.
The child threw a stick and hit the/a snake.
Did you push me/touch me just now?
Comment: Here, chida means 'touch someone pushing him or her, with a very quick and strong movement in order to provoke his anger'.

Translated_Text: Discomposure caused by polar bear breaking zoo's security glass.
Comment:
Title of an online newspaper article (from news1 Korea) where one can see that the instrument appears with instrumental case marking.
cf. comments on this verb's coding frame: Interestingly, the instrumental case marked argument appears nowhere again in the article which suggests it may not be that common in more fluent speech/writing; instead an embedded clause is used to talk about the instrument used in te event. Online newspaper titles arguably have to be kept short, and this may be why one did not use a dependent clause construction. For source, see reference (Seo 2012).

Translated_Text: Did you just follow me until here?
Translation_Other: Bist du mir sogar bis hierher nachgelaufen?

Primary_Text: Eomeoniga aireul jagi gangajireul meogyoksikige haetta.
Translated_Text: The mother made her child bath his/her dog.
Comment: The reflexive noun can have either the causer or the causee as an antecedent, although here one would tend to interpret the dog as belonging to the child (probably for extra-linguistic reasons). As mentioned for some other examples with a periphrastic causative, I would rather say that from an impressionistic perspective accusative marking on ai 'child' sounds most natural, although one could imagine nominative marking here, with dative marking rejected as a possibility.
Original_Orthography: 어머니가 아이를 자기 강아지를 목욕시키게 했다.

Translated_Text: Quickly, shave your beard!
Comment: Similarly to many other examples, suyeom and kkakk- seem to be one prosodic unit in this case, and it would be more natural to use an adverbial in such a construction and not in one where suyeom is marked with accusative case. Note that the -eo ending is typically spoken, and in written usage it would be -a.

Translated_Text: The child had a bad cough.
Comment: In this example, gichim appears separate from its 'light verb', and it is marked for case. This might be due to the modifier simhan 'bad' that modifies gichim adnominally. Compare this with ex. 37, where simha- 'be bad' appears in its adverbial form.

Translated_Text: I'm afraid of you./I find you frightening.
Comment: This kind of example sounds more natural than those normally discussed in the literature where both arguments are overtly marked with nominative case markers. Note that there is no prosodic break between any constituent of the sentence above, particularly between the two personal pronouns.

Translated_Text: I am afraid of tigers.
Comment: This sentence can be found in Yeon (2003: 42). It must be said that this DAT-NOM construction with experiencer verbs in Korean has been discussed quite a few times in the literature (see O'Grady 1991 or Yeon 2003 for references), but I doubt its acceptability in both written and spoken usage. This is not to say that DAT-NOM experiencer patterns in Korean should generally be impossible, but especially wit FEAR it sounds very unnatural. Cf. comment in verb layout.
Translation_Other: Ich finde Tiger furchterregend./Mir machen Tiger Angst.

Primary_Text: Na baega gopaseo jugeul geo gata.
Translated_Text: I think I'm dying of hunger. / I am so hungry I think I'm dying.
Comment: This is an example where BE HUNGRY is used in a construction where bae 'belly' as the element still identifiable as a lexcial item is marked with nominative case marking, but the meaning of the verb is not clear to me. In this construction (in natural spoken usage), the experiencer argument is not overtly marked for case, and I don't know if it ever would be. -ga in Korean seems to have some properties of a (nominative) focus marker which is why in spoken usage it is probably not used in information-structurally unmarked contexts. However, this is an issue that needs to be further explored, and linguistic treatments of Korean tend to use this marker over-excessively irrespective of its information-structural function.

Primary_Text: Geuneun eumageul deureumyeonseo maeumeul jogeum garaanchyeotta.
Translated_Text: He settled down a bit while listening to music.
Original_Orthography: 그는 음악을 들으면서 마음을 조금 가라앉혔다.

Primary_Text: Gunini silsuro baereul sumyeon araero garaanchigo maratta.
Translated_Text: The soldier ended up sinking the boat on the ground.
Comment: Sentence constructed after dictionary enry: http://krdic.naver.com/detail.nhn?docid=99200 [last accessed 2014-02-25] The contents for this dictionary have been provided by the National Institute of the Korean Language.
Original_Orthography: 군인이 실수로 배를 수면 아래로 가라앉히고 말았다

Translated_Text: A god set the house on fire and let it burn down.
Comment: Similarly to ex. 180, the word for fire may occur with ta- as a (at least) prosody unit.

Translated_Text: The national treasure number one, the Sungnyemun [i.e. more widely known as Namdaemun in Seoul] has burned down.
Comment: To be found as the title of many online articles when the National Treasure no. 1 of South Korea, the Namdaemun gate in Seoul was demolished through fire. This construction is peculiar since the verb ta- already means burn - albeit rather meaning 'to be charring/char' - and as opposed to ex. 10, bul 'fire' occurs as a prosodic (and possibly syntactic) unit with the verb BURN, and the sole, overtly marked argument is the burning object.

Translated_Text: I dried my hair.
Translation_Other: Ich habe mir die Haare getrocknet.

Primary_Text: Neon ni gireul gago, nan ne gireul galteni sanggwan ma.
Translated_Text: You'll go your way and I'll go mine, so don't butt in.
Comment: An example where GO can appear with a way-argument (that is, a word that stands for the path of a motion) in accusative case. Such a construction is different from a 'true' Korean transitive construction since alternations such as passivisation (e.g., ji-passivisation) cannot apply (although this is rather solely based on my intuition than on a multiplicity of grammaticality judgments from different speakers).
Original_Orthography: 넌 니 길을 가고, 난 네 길을 갈테니 상관 마.

Translated_Text: I don't know why he's always making the kid(s) cry. / He always has to make the kid(s) cry. It really makes me wonder why...
Comment:
The part of the sentence `I don't know' is commonly dropped, as the complementizer presupposes such an expression. (consider in German:
-"Was hat er gefragt?/Was weiß er nicht?" - "Na, ob sie jemals wiederkommen wird.", or the German translation above. See Evans 2007 for more) Apart from that, the periphrastic causative tendentially implies that the child has been brought to tears mainly by somebody teasing it or making it unhappy rather than physically abusing it. However, the semantic differences between the periphrastic and morphological causative with CRY might not be that rigid as for verbs of which the semantics involve a higher affectedness of the patient and a more drastic change of state.
Translation_Other: Dass er immer sein(e) Kind(er) zum Weinen bringen muss (ist mir echt echt ein Rätsel)...

Translated_Text: Why are you always making the kid cry?
Comment: This version of the verb CRY with morphological causative rather implies that the child was teased or picked on more or less directly (by hitting it and the like). In spoken language, one happens to come across an echoing of the main verb in questions.
Translation_Other: Warum bringst du ständig das Kind zum Weinen?

Translated_Text: The lungs are/were filled with water.
Comment: See alternating coding frame in ex. 227.
Translation_Other: In den Lungen sammelte sich Wasser an/hat sich Wasser angesammelt.

Primary_Text: Susurhago nani nuni jal an kkamppagyeojyeotta.
Translated_Text: After my operation I couldn't blink my eyes anymore.
Original_Orthography: 수술하고 나니 눈이 잘 안 깜박여졌다.

Translated_Text: Fruit fell from the tree.
If one puts on running shoes, one can run well.
Comment: This is an example where formally, ttwi- 'run' is inflected for what seems like a periphrastic passive alternation, although the verb's meaning acquires some modal meaning. Interestingly, the expression of any grammatical (potentially nominative, -ga marked) subject is not possible here, which raises the question whether this rather an impersonal construction than a true passive as observed with transitive verbs. This is why the alternation value for this verb has been chosen as 'marginally'.

Translated_Text: The child frightened the man.
Comment: Cf. comments in verb layout: This is the presciptively accepted causative form of this verb in South Korea, although I doubt how many people actually use it in spoken, non-medial discourse instead of using nollae-ki-da, get_shocked-CAUS-DECL.

Translated_Text: The message can be sent, but it cannot be received.
Comment: The first half of the above example, Messejiga bonae jigineun hande sounds alright, although bada jiji anayo sounds rather awkward for some reason that maybe needs to be further explored.

Translated_Text: First, one peels the skin off the apple.

Primary_Text: Aiga eomma mollae gangajireul sumgyeo nwatta.
Translated_Text: The child hid the little dog somewhere without letting his mother know.
Comment:
This is a more natural version of a sentence with the verb sumgida where instead of expressing the participant from which something is hidden through dative case or marking with an ablative-like -eurobuteo, one uses quite a peculiar construction where a noun appears together with mollae 'without someone noticing', a word that formally resembles the stem form of moreuda 'not know', molla-, but where it is not sure what form mollae is, and accordingly, what syntactic category the noun plus mollae constituent belongs to.

Still, it seems that instead of expressing the participant from which something is hidden as an adjunct with some 'regular' oblique case marking, this possibly multiclausal structure is preferred.
Original_Orthography: 아이가 엄마 몰래 강아지를 숨겨 놨다.

Translated_Text: The child hid the lipstick from his mother.
The patient hid that fact from his doctor.
Comment: This coding pattern sounds rather awkward.

Translated_Text: I can't lift the barrel because it's too heavy.
Comment: The parentheses have been added to show that the nominative marking does not (forcibly) come from the intransitive verb mugeob- 'be heavy'. Although the ji-passive here leads to a modal meaning, syntactically the former object seems to be promoted to subject function. The agent cannot be expressed here.

Translated_Text: The woman carried the barrel to the field.
Comment: A source can only be expressed with CARRY if one builds a complex predicate together with gada 'GO'.

Translated_Text: The child carried the bag for its younger brother.
A child is carrying a bouquet.
The whole bed is covered with flowers.
Snow is covering the peek of the Halla Mountain. / The peek of Halla Mountain is covered in snow.
The whole patio was covered in snow.
Comment: example shows the ji-Passive (periphrastic) from the alternative coding frame 1-nom 2-acc 3-instr V

Translated_Text: A book was lying on the table.
Comment: When the morphological passive is used, the impression is stressed that a book is lying around alone on the table, and it is almost as though it appeared from nowhere, all of a sudden.
Translation_Other: Ein Buch lag ganz alleine auf dem Tisch herum.

Translated_Text: It is not easy to let go of longing.
A terryfying fact was revealed.
Comment: Periphrastic passive of the causative.

Translated_Text: He uncovered that fact.
Comment: This example has been included in the database to show how the lexicalisation of morphological causatives in Korean can correlate with quite drastical changes in meaning.

Translated_Text: The sun is bright.
The child took presents to his friend's house.
She is called the 'Madonna of Korea'.
Comment: Interestingly, several articles can be found on the net which use this construction. The name appears with instrumental case marking here, which apparently only works in the passive voice of bureuda 'call sb.'.

Translated_Text: He is called Jjangsuni by his relatives.
A tiger killed a person.
One of her fingers was cut off in an accident.
Father took off his jacket.
Mother peeled the tangerines.
Mother peeled a tangerine.

Primary_Text: Harabeojiga sonnyeottareul mureub wie ankke hasyeotta.
Translated_Text: The grandfather made his granddaughter sit on his lap (by talking to her, not by lifting her).
Original_Orthography: 할아버지가 손녀를 무릎 위에 앉게 했다.

Translated_Text: The grandfather put his granddaughter on his lap.
I stopped a/the person who was walking along the way.
Have you ever been to Machu Picchu?
Comment: An example where a directional argument is not marked with locative, but with accusative case.

Primary_Text: Jebal jom nal wihae seoureseo tteona jweo.
Translated_Text: Please, I'm begging you, leave Seoul.
Comment: wihae is a postposition that governs accusative case on its noun phrase. See the explanation for the benefactive alternation for more information.
Original_Orthography: 제발 좀 날 위해 서울에서 떠나 줘.

Primary_Text: Eoje geu chinguga uri jibeseo tteonatta.
Translated_Text: He (my friend I told you about) left our house yesterday/That friend of mine, he left yesterday.
The father threw a ball to his child.
The child threw the ball into the direction of the ocean.

Primary_Text: Neo igeo jom na daesin chaeksang wieda nwa jweo?
Translated_Text: Can you just put this on the table for me, please?
Comment: A beneficary argument can only be expressed in a postpositional phrase here.
Original_Orthography: 너 이거 좀 나 대신 책상 위에다 놓아 줘.

Translated_Text: (thinking about it intensively) Where did I put my glasses?
Translation_Other: Wo habe ich nur bloß meine Brille hingetan?

Translated_Text: (nodding somewhere) Push it in that direction.

Primary_Text: Eommaga gagudeul saieseo meonjireul dakka naetta.
Translated_Text: Mom wiped out the dust out of the spaces between the furniture.
Comment: A source argument only seems to be expressible if a complex predicate is built using ttakkda and naeda.

Translated_Text: Mother cleaned the table.
With this, the water boils quickly./With this you can boil water quickly.
Comment: The periphrastic passive of the causative.

Translated_Text: One makes the water boil using sunlight/solar power.
I boiled the water./It was me who boiled the water.
The child was crying all the time.
Father build a house out of stones.
Comment: For some reason, intuitively I would prefer a sentence with an embedded clause rather than an instrumental adjunct. Cf. ex. 224.

Translated_Text: The child's whole body was hurting.
Comment: Although I would not reject this example as ungrammatical, something about it does not sound readily acceptable. This might be due to the presence of the experiencer argument. Alternatively, an interesting idea comes from Yeon (2003: 66) where he states that "Korean grammar prohibits direct reporting of a third person's internal condition or feeling, and other means are provided.", and the fact that it is third and not first or second person here might contribute to the potential awkwardness of this example. If one does a search on Google, it seems very common however to use the construction without the experiencer argument, so just on momi apatta/apayo etc. meaning 'my whole body aches'.

Translated_Text: The mother shouted at the children.
Comment: The meaning of jireuda (jill- in the example above) is not known to me, as it always occurs with the word for 'sound' to express the meaning SHOUT or SCREAM.

Translated_Text: I like Kimchi.
Anna and Thomas hugged each other.
Comment: Although superficially one might assume that this looks like a reciprocal alternation, a detailed look might reveal that this is not the case here. The reciprocal seoro in Korean behaves similarly to a noun in that it can take various case markers, and although it denotes semantic reciprocity, I am not sure whether this holds syntactically, since the above case pattern is still NOM-ACC, and it would not sound grammatical to leave seororeul out here (although this needs to be tested on a corpus given that in Korean NPs can be dropped). Moreover, switching the order of anna-wa 'Anna-COM' and tomaseu-ga 'Thomas-NOM' as in a 'true' reciprocal alternation sentences results in ungrammaticality (*Thomaseuga Annawa seororeul kkyeoanatta, compare with ex. 213). This shows that the nominative case marker has its scope over the comitaitve marked NP, and the latter seems to be embedded in an NP headed by the noun tomaseu. Thus what I am trying to say here is that probably this construction, although semantically reciprocal, syntactically exhibits a 'normal', transitive NOM-ACC coding pattern.

Translated_Text: Hug me!
The mother hugged [her] child.
Comment: Whether the kki- is identical with kki- 'jam' in independent usage cannot be said for sure. Evans (2010: 176f.) describes the meaning of this verb as 'move into a tight-fitting configuration with something else' which would also apply to this context.

Translated_Text: Anna and Thomas met again accidentally.
The mother fed her child [some] fruit.
Comment: Both accusative and dative marking are possible, cannot say which one would be more appropriate. In colloquial usage, the pronunciation often has changed to meg- in a vowel fronting process (probably induced by the front, high causative morpheme vowel), which is why this verb form might be seen as being on the way of its lexicalisation to an autonomous lexeme.

Translated_Text: Mother made her child dress.
Comment: Although many sources claim that the causee can be marked with either dative, accusative or nominative case, I would by far prefer accusative case marking here.

Translated_Text: The mother dressed her child.
The child wanted toys.
Please accept this present for me.
The child got a present from his friends.
A man appeared in the forest.
The cat climbed on the tree. / The cat went up the tree.
The sportsman jumped 2.2 meters high.
The water is boiling.
The grandmother taught the child a song.
The teacher taught the pupils German.
The older sister showed her brother some music.
The child (inadvertedly) heard the sound of a bird (=a bird).
The women ground the beans with a big stone.
A thief stole her money (and went away).
A thief stole her money.

Primary_Text: Geuneun ppurireul chakkii wihae jeongweoneseo keun gumeongeul patta.
Translated_Text: He dug a hole in the garden in order to find the roots.
Original_Orthography: 그는 뿌리를 찾기 위해 정원에서 큰 구멍을 팠다.

Translated_Text: Mom poured the soy sauce into the pot.
The mother covered the child with a blanket (for it).

Primary_Text: Jeo eoje samchonhante sopo han sangjareul bonaesseoyo.
Translated_Text: I sent a parcel to my uncle yesterday. / I sent you a parcel yesterday, uncle.
Original_Orthography: 재가 어제 삼촌한테 소포 한 상자를 보냈어요.

Translated_Text: The grandmother gave the child some money.
The child showed the teacher a picture.
Comment: It is not sure whether this can actually count as a benefactive alternation of boida, see comment in the corresponding verb layout.

Primary_Text: Aiga chaegeseo jongi han jangeul jjijeonaetta.
Translated_Text: The child tore a page out of the book. / The child tore one page from the book and took it out.
Original_Orthography: 아이가 책에서 종이 한 장을 찢어냈다.

Translated_Text: Why are you ripping this?

Primary_Text: Geuneun chaeksang wie itteon chingu(ae) doneul jibeotta.
Translated_Text: He took his friend's money which was on the table.
Comment: Genitive marker optional.
Original_Orthography: 그는 책상 위에 있는 친구(의) 돈을 집었다.

Translated_Text: If you do [it] with this knife, the bread cuts well.
The woman cut the bread with a knife.
Comment: Note that ex. 195 sounds more natural than this sentence where the instrument is expressed as an instrumental case-marked adjunct.

Translated_Text: He touched her hand.
The boy hit the snake with a stick.
Comment: Expressing an instrumental adjunct with this verb somehow feels ungrammatical, maybe because the movement of HIT is different from English. For more information see comment on this verb in the verb layout.

Translated_Text: The child beat/hit the snake with a stick.
Wow, it breaks easily/often.
Comment: As opposed to kkaeda 'BREAK', kkaetteurida 'BREAK" does not seem to undergo periphrastic passive, although a quick Google search reveals that it does seem to be possible, at least from a formal/inflectional point of view. However, whereas the same sentence above would work for kkaeda, it does not with kkaetteurida as shown above, and this example has been included in this database to motivate further research.

Translated_Text: The child broke the glass with a stone.
Glass breaks easily.
The child broke the window with a stone.
She said "no" to me / She told me it wasn't true/the case.
She told me the truth.
Comment: As opposed to ex. 83 and 85, here the nominal component of the above light verb construction, mal 'speech', cannot be omitted. This restriction would hold even if there was an additional quotational element (e.g., ani-rago NEG-be:QUOT 'that it is not' that comes before sasireul) as in ex. 83 or 85.

Translated_Text: She told me I was good-looking.
Sumi told her son that she will/would be leaving tomorrow.
The parents called that child "Anna".
Did you just call me a fool? / Did you just say "fool" to me?
Comment: There is a construction that may have arisen from -rago mal=hada -QUOT speech=do, . Both forms are in use, although this form can be found frequently in colloquial usage, and only -rago hada can be used in the case of giving someone names or nicknames or titles.

Translated_Text: The son asked his parents for money.
The girl talked to the boy about the dog.

Primary_Text: Yeojaaineun sanaiwa gangajie daehaeseo yaegihago isseotta.
Translated_Text: The girl was talking with the boy about the dog.
Original_Orthography: 여자 아이는 사나이와 강아지에 대해서 얘기하고 있었다.

Translated_Text: You can see many things down from heaven. / Down from heaven, many things are visible.
The man saw a bear.
The boy looked at the girl.

Primary_Text: Neo jamkkan igeo naemsae (jom) mata bwa!
Translated_Text: Just check out this smell for a minute!
Comment: As you can see in this example from colloquial Korean, case markers are not used in this context and therefore not obligatory in spoken usage. The intervening particle jom shows that the word for smell, naemsae can be separated from the verb matda.
Original_Orthography: 너 잠깐 이거 냄새 좀 맡아 봐!

Translated_Text: The tiger smelled persons passing by.
The child frightened the man.
