Comment: This is the more widely used, although only covertly 'accepted' causative form of this verb. Cf. comments in verb layout.

Translated_Text: Look how the child got frightened because of the sound!
Comment: This is an example for the intransitive use of a form that has prescriptively been determined as the causative of an alleged intransitive form, nollada, and South Korean language polity is quite desperately trying to convince people of the incorrectness of this form (see Yi 2010).

Translated_Text: My older sister feared big animals.
My older sister fears big animals.
My older sister feared earthquakes.
Comment: The verb form is formally similar to other periphrastic constructions where an apparent converb-like form is combined with another 'light verb' such as hada 'do' above.

Translated_Text: My older sister feared earthquakes.
What kind of food do you like (much)?
I like you so much!
The child already knew that story.

Primary_Text: Geuneun imi geu sasireul algo isseotta.
Translated_Text: He already knew that fact.
Original_Orthography: 그는 이미 그 사실을 알고 있었다.

Primary_Text: Haksaengeun daeum nonmun jujereul saenggakago isseotta.
Translated_Text: The student was thinking about his next essay topic.

Primary_Text: Geuneun ol banghage daehaeseo saenggageul hago isseossda.
Translated_Text: He was thinking about his next holidays.
Original_Orthography: 그는 올 방학에 대해서 생각을 하고 있었다.

Translated_Text: The child was thinking about his grandmother.
The man was looking for money.
The mother took the child in her arms. / The mother hugged her child.

Primary_Text: Nampyeoneun anaewa geukjjang apeseo mannagiro haetta.
Translated_Text: The husband decided to meet his wife in front of the cinema.
Original_Orthography: 남편은 아내와 극장 앞에서 만나기로 했다.

Translated_Text: When are we meeting?
Yesterday I met with Soo-Young in town.
Yesterday I met Soo-Young in town.

Primary_Text: Eojae nan nae jeon namjachingureul mannatta.
Translated_Text: Yesterday I met my ex-boyfriend.
Original_Orthography: 어재 난 내 전 남자친구를 만났다.

Translated_Text: A chick is following its mother.
Father helped the child.
Comment: The present analysis that parallels that of a periphrastic benefactive alternation construction is questionable.

Translated_Text: The child ate the fruit.
Mom, did you wash my laundry using the wahing machine??
Comment: The instrumental adjunct is prosodically emphasised here.
Translation_Other: Mama, hast du etwa meine Kleidung in der Waschmaschine gewaschen??

Translated_Text: Quickly, wash your face!
Mother bathed her child.
Did you wash the fruit (we were about to eat)?
The child wash his hands.
Comment: Note that people tend not to pronounce the alveolar fricative [s] as tensed as actually indicated in the orthography.

Translated_Text: Have you put on your cloths already?
Comment: Note the difference in pronunciation (primary text field): The phonological process that occurs above normally applies to compounds where changes occur as word-internal processes (e.g., som 'cotton' + ibul 'duvet' = somnibul 'cotton duvet'). The diachronically motivated phonological 'change' pattern that is observed with the combination of os and ibda is so widely recognized that prescriptivists have included it in their regulations (see NIKL references), see comment in verb layout. As opposed to ex. 41, this phonological process suggests a greater boundness between the nominal and verbal elements here, which is why it is not sure whether os could be seen as an argument of the verb.

Translated_Text: Get dressed!
Comment: Note the difference in pronunciation (primary text field): The phonological process that occurs above normally applies to compounds where changes occur as word-internal processes (e.g., som 'cotton' + ibul 'duvet' = somnibul 'cotton duvet'). The diachronically motivated phonological 'change' pattern that is observed with the combination of os and ibda is so widely recognized that prescriptivists have included it in their regulations (see NIKL references), see comment in verb layout. As opposed to ex. 41, this phonological process suggests a greater boundness between the nominal and verbal elements here, which is why it is not sure whether os could be seen as an argument of the verb.

Translated_Text: The child put on his cloths. / The child dressed.
He shaved.
Comment: Not sure whether this verb could appear with the nominal element myeondo, 'shaving' being marked with accusative case and prosodically separate.

Translated_Text: He shaved his beard.
He blinked with his eyes.
The child coughed badly.
Comment: In this sentence, gichim and haetta seem to be a prosodic unit, thus the equals sign. Cf. with ex. 187.

Translated_Text: The horse ran.
He sat down on the bench.
The children were sitting on the floor.
The children were happily (i.e., because theywere happy) jumping up and down.
Grandmother sang a beautiful song.
I'm going to the market./I'm going for some grocery shopping.
Comment: As seen above, the locational argument of GO can occur without case marking. Prosodically, the locational argument and the verb seem to become one unit. Note the slight differences in translation.
Translation_Other: Ich geh' einkaufen.

Translated_Text: The madam went to the market.
Comment: GO with locative marking on its goal argument puts an emphasis on the intentions and motivations of the agent, whereas marking with directional -euro would put an emphasis on the direction of motion. (cf. ex. 29)

Translated_Text: The madam went to the market (to do something there).
Comment: GO with locative marking on its goal argument puts an emphasis on the intentions and motivations of the agent, whereas marking with directional -euro would put an emphasis on the direction of motion.

Translated_Text: The man/mister left the house for good.
I live in Germany.
I live in a city.
The children are playing.
The man/mister laughed.
The baby screamed.
My arm is hurting (me very much).
Comment: A somewhat accentuated meaning. In spoken usage it does not feel common to use a genitive form of the pronoun, nae 'my'.

Translated_Text: My arm hurts.
Comment: This is a construction I would say is more natural in spoken usage. The equals sign (actually a sign for clitics in the Leipzig Glossing Rules) has been used here to indicate that as opposed to constructions such as na pal-i apa 1SG arm-NOM hurt, the prosody of the arm=hurt unit changes drastically to that of a single word. It should be further investigated whether in this case a constituent could come between 'arm' and 'hurt' without instantiating nominative case marking on the stimulus with correlating prosodic separation, such as hypothetically na pal neomu apa 1SG arm too hurt 'My arm hurts so much.' If so, the equals sign would probably not be justified, at least from a syntactic perspective.

Translated_Text: I am cold.
My dog is dead. / My dog died.
Such stories are too sad for me. / Such stories are so sad.
Comment: yaegi is a colloquial form for iyagi 'story'

Translated_Text: Such stories are too sad for me.
Comment: yaegi is a colloquial form for iyagi 'story'

Translated_Text: I am sad.
I am hungry.
Comment: An overt nominative marker on the experiencer would sound awkward, and it is not clear to me why that would be so. Thus although nominative marking has been indicated in the coding frame, I am not sure about this.

Translated_Text: This man is a hunter.
The ball rolled down (along) the street.
Comment: People may tend to write the two verbs together, and prosodically it sounds like one unit. Maybe this is a hint towards an ongoing lexicalisation of this complex predicate.

Translated_Text: A ball rolled/was rolling.
A ship has sunk.
The house is burning on fire.
The ground has dried.
It has rained.
Comment: Nominative case marking (-ga) not obligatory (see general remarks in Yeon (2003: 22), possibly depends on information structural factors where it preferably occurs when it encodes new information.

Translated_Text: The children tied the branches to one another.
Comment: Example constructed after sentences found on: http://news.invil.org/article/PnArticleDetail.jsp?article_no=88613, 서로 서로 잘 묶어 놓은 복분자 가지들, seoroseoro jal mukk-eo noh-eun bokbunja gaji-deul, one_another well tie-CONV put-ATTR Rubus_coreanus branch-PL, 'The Rubus coreanus branches which have been carefully tied to another'; seoroseoro is not obligatory here, although without it it would only be clear from context that the branches have been tied to another.

Translated_Text: The soldier tied the horse to a tree.
My brother loaded the luggage on the car.
My older brother filled a glass for me.
Translation_Other: Mein älterer Bruder füllte mir mein Glas auf.

Translated_Text: My older brother filled the water into his glass.
The mother made the daughter cover herself with the blanket.
Comment: Several authors have discussed the possibility of marking the causee with different case particles. According to them, ttal- 'daughter' from above may take on nominative, dative or accusative marking, with an increasing degree of control on the causee by the causer (cf. Yeon 2003: 94/95, O'Grady 1991: 171ff.). The accusative case was chosen here according to the intuition of the author.

Translated_Text: Mother covered the dough with a kitchen towel.
Mother cooked all day long.
She made him hungry.
Translation_Other: Le hizo tener hambre.

Primary_Text: Tatīyá nyaʔne nu ntii tzaa tzayoʔō ítā ntoo nanaʔ wī niī lēʔ nu ntīlítiʔ ūʔ jiʔį̄.
Translated_Text: Every animal that wanted to go and go drink water from the mud, then they would sink there.
Translation_Other: Todos los animales que querían ir a tomar agua en el lodo, entonces se hundían allí.

Primary_Text: Ntuteę na jiʔį̄ lóʔō itzǫʔ na.
Translated_Text: We carry it with (on) our backs.
Translation_Other: Lo acarreamos con la espalda.

Translated_Text: My ancestors were hunters.
Translation_Other: Mis abuelos fueron campeadores.

Translated_Text: Juan is sinking in the mud.
Translation_Other: Juan se va sumiendo en el lodo.

Translated_Text: Juan is going to roll the stones.
Translation_Other: Juan va a echar a rodar las piedras.

Primary_Text: Ntekēkukwęʔ pīyúʔú jiʔį̄ nā keē tikwą lyaʔāá jiʔį̄ jwanāá.
Translated_Text: The little girl is making Juana smell the foul smelling flower.
Translation_Other: La nena está haciendo a Juana que huela la flor que huele mal.

Primary_Text: Jā saʔne nchakwiʔ nāáʔ tzáʔ wá nī.
Translated_Text: I have been talking about this for a long time now.
Translation_Other: Ya hace tiempo que estoy hablando sobre eso.

Primary_Text: Nkalōónaa ūʔ jiʔį̄ kinī wiʔ naa sensóklē.
Translated_Text: They named that bird mockingbird.
Translation_Other: Le nombraron al pájaro que se llama zenzontle.

Translated_Text: That man steals.
Translation_Other: Roba ese hombre.

Translated_Text: Long ago I heard it.
Translation_Other: Hace tiempo lo escuché.

Primary_Text: Nkwēkujyā na matrū skwelā jnā nkwítząá.
Translated_Text: The teacher set the kids to playing.
Translation_Other: El maestro los puso a jugar a los niños.

Primary_Text: Nkwēkuxáʔā pīyúʔú jį̄ jwanāá yaa kékū.
Translated_Text: The baby girl made Juana scream when they went to the water source.
Translation_Other: La nena hizo llorar a Juana cuando fueron al agua.

Primary_Text: Na kwaaʔaʔ nyāʔā ta yaku jiʔį̄ xikūnáʔa ūʔ xī ntoǫ lóʔō kichi jį̄ nchoō.
Translated_Text: The bear, you see, already ate his wife where she was standing with her quern grinding.
Translation_Other: El oso verás ya se comió a su mujer donde estaba moliendo con su metate.

Primary_Text: Nāxíʔi laaʔ nu kekūná ūʔ tī jį̄ nyatę̄.
Translated_Text: It is not the case that they make the people cry.
Translation_Other: No es así que le hagan llorar a la gente.

Translated_Text: They are going to dress her in that shirt.
Translation_Other: Van a vestirla con esa camisa a ella.

Primary_Text: Nkwēkūná jwāá jį̄ tyáʔā nkaláā nu ntijya niʔi.
Translated_Text: Juan made his sister cry because he took away her toy.
Translation_Other: Juan hizo llorar a su hermana porque le quitó su juguete.

Primary_Text: Tala ntii tzéʔā jį̄ na ítāá jwāá.
Translated_Text: Juan, he for sure wants the water.
Comment: The subject is postposed and extraclausal here.
Translation_Other: De por sí Juan quiere el agua.

Translated_Text: It will get shaved.
Comment: This is the intransitive, basic verb from which SHAVE is derived via the u-causative alternation.

Translated_Text: No one spoke to us.
Then they left and they went away.
Comment: The locations of the place of leaving and the goal of going are unexpressed and understood from the context of the text.

Primary_Text: Tyāá tī ntyūsé nuwę̄ʔ jiʔį́ nī.
Translated_Text: God will give that back to you now.
Don't be afraid.
There they made a hole in the ground.
Comment: kétū yuu is a complex nominal lexeme.

Translated_Text: There she turned around to look at them.
"Do not be frightened", he said.
Juan grabbed the plate.
Comment: This example shows the basic, transitive verb from which nk-y-ukwą̄ GET is derived via the Intransitive alternation.

Translated_Text: You are going to make a yoke.
Juan received the plate.
He is crying.
Juan will sink the wood.
Look for three names.
Translation_Other: Busquen tres nombres.

Translated_Text: Juan will drown the dog.

Primary_Text: Na jnēʔé ntukwęʔ xī nchaa na kwinaʔá.
Translated_Text: The dog smells where the deer is going.
Translation_Other: El perro huele donde pasó el venado.

Primary_Text: Nu nkātākǫ́ʔūʔ laaʔ nu jā tyāʔ ntūkwá tya kétū.
Translated_Text: Although they closed it off, the hole still exists.
Translation_Other: Aunque lo taparon todavía existe el hueco.

Translated_Text: It got dug.
Comment: This is the intransitive, basic verb from which DIG is derived via the u-causative alternation.

Translated_Text: She speaks slowly.
You will speak at the market.
And we went to that.
He will go to his house.
Comment: The subject is not coreferent with the owner of the house. If it were, the verb 'go to one's base' would be used and not this verb, which is 'go to a non-base'.

Translated_Text: The child left the village.
The air came out of the ball (the ball was punctured).
We are going to take him away.
Comment: This is a type of applicative related to the verb 'run'. Instead of using the verb 'leave' as an auxiliary, it has the u-causative prefix. It has the incorporated 'RN.with' like other applicatives.

Primary_Text: Chúʔ kūnáʔa ntijyalóʔō jnā walǭ nkānēʔé jį̄.
Translated_Text: The woman playing with the ball threw it.

Primary_Text: Na matrū skwelā ná nkasuʔū jnā nkwítzą lāká.
Translated_Text: The teacher did not teach the children yesterday.
It is getting peeled.
Comment: This is the basic intransitive verb from which PEEL is derived via the equipollent causative/intransitive alternation.

Primary_Text: Mariyā nteyūkéʔ súkwā lóʔō na ketǫʔó.
Translated_Text: María is cooking the food in the pot.
The stick broke.
Comment: This example shows the intransitive verb from which the transitive BREAK is derived via the u-causative alternation.

Translated_Text: The man is hidden.
Comment: This example illustrates the intransitive verb from which HUG (tr.) is derived.

Translated_Text: María hid the tortillas from Juan.
Comment: This can also mean 'María hid Juan's tortillas'.

Translated_Text: I didn't understand, but I think I now understand.
Comment: y-una means 'understand'.

Translated_Text: Juan prodded the donkey with a stick.

Primary_Text: Chu kíʔyū nkaʔnikiyaʔ jnā walǭ nchaa xaaʔ seʔę.
Translated_Text: The man kicked the ball and it went somewhere else.
Example_Type: Offered by speaker from visual stimulus

Primary_Text: Lee leerā ntiʔniūʔ lometā jų́ʔ to kiʔna kwaą̄.
Translated_Text: Like this they would hit their bottles on the edge of the loft.
Then, we would burn it there.
The fire is burning.
The house burned.
The old man is sad.
Example_Type: Offered by speaker from visual stimulus

Primary_Text: La kii ntāátīʔę́ʔ tyúʔoōʔ̨ tzūʔ jlyā.
Translated_Text: I think I'm leaving early tomorrow.
Comment: The verb THINK here has a clausal complement, so does not match the target coding frame. The verb LEAVE has an unexpressed locational NP.

Primary_Text: Niʔ kíʔyū nka-teę tza manzanā nanēʔ kweję.
Translated_Text: The man carried the apple in the bag.

Primary_Text: Ntuteęya yusę la to kelā lóʔō tzǫʔya.
Translated_Text: We carried sand from the river with our backs.
Comment: The sentence is in the context of talking about building houses, for which sand from the river is used to make cement. So the direction 'from' would be inferred through world knowledge about traditional work practices.

Primary_Text: Léē tzoʔō laa tzakarāyu kula tyāʔ ntyuʔu tánēʔ serlī nu laa nkaā saʔne tzéʔā.
Translated_Text: It is beautiful, he is the only old one that still dresses in the cloth pants as in the old days.
Comment: This example shows the less-transitive verb from which the verb for our meaning DRESS is derived.

Primary_Text: Nkaʔnetikatzǭ mariyā jnā ítā jā katana.
Translated_Text: Maria heated the water so we could bathe.
Comment: This sentence illustrates the basic verb from which WASH is derived.

Translated_Text: He is always afraid every night.
Comment: This example shows the verb FEAR in a derived adjectival form, used as a predicate.

Primary_Text: Niī nu ná nyaʔa jiʔį̄na ná kikwiʔ jnā maxi kākwári nkuteję̄.
Translated_Text: Now they don't see us, they don't speak to us, even when they pass close by.
Comment: There is no appropriate valency reducing alternation to link this example to. Note that Zenzontepec Chatino is a highly transitivizing language. There is only one alternation (the intransitive alternation) or maybe two (including the object/instrument incorporation alternation) valency reducing alternation(s), and only a few verbs undergo them.

Translated_Text: He plugged it in where it was (plugged) in.

Primary_Text: Tī kwēyáʔ estē ntuʔu ntāʔwé niī jā nu jnyaʔa tiʔiri ntii kétū yaką nchatasaʔą tī na na saaʔ tzoʔō.
Translated_Text: At the time that black sapotes were in season (on the tree ready for harvest) our ears would hurt when the mute parrots would all take off at once (it was loud).

Primary_Text: Nkyatzāʔą́ na xikaʔá lóʔō na ítāá.
Translated_Text: The cup was filled with water.
Comment:
intransitive (inchoative) of 'fill it'
periphrastic causative construction (not morphological, so no alternation)
Translation_Other: Se llenó el vaso con agua.

Translated_Text: He does not want that bread.
Translation_Other: No quiere ese pan.

Primary_Text: Chiīʔ tī ntii nuʔu kīkwīʔ jnyá.
Translated_Text: Young one, if you want to, govern.

Primary_Text: Nee nyāʔā tyāʔ n-toǫ nyaʔne jiʔį̄=ya tza túkwa nuwęʔ tī nu n-tāá.
Translated_Text: He says, you see, we still have animals, one or two of them, and this is what provides for us.

Primary_Text: Nkānaʔa niʔ kíʔyū jnā nkwítzą kíʔyūuʔ.
Translated_Text: The man saw the boy.

Primary_Text: Jwaā ntēwíī tzǫʔ na yaka jā kujlyā choʔo jā léē tikwą nyaʔa.
Translated_Text: Juan is cleaning off the tree in order to paint it with lime, because it looked very ugly.
He rolled it.

Primary_Text: Nkulāmisę̄ sūʔwá jwāá lō nu yakīʔyáyu lita.
Translated_Text: Juan's load rolled when he went to haul corn.
If the land caves in, we would go rolling.

Primary_Text: Nkatūkwá jiʔį̄ nanēʔ tzaka kichuwī kusǭ.
Translated_Text: He put them in an old basket.
Comment: 'load'

Primary_Text: Nkātūkwá niʔ kíʔyūú jnā nkutīí nanēʔ na karetāá.
Translated_Text: The man put (loaded) the hay into the cart.
Comment: This is the 'load the hay' example.
Translation_Other: El hombre metió la paja en la carreta.

Translated_Text: He shaved himself.
He is drying his clothes (in the sun).
Comment: The causative u-prefix is deleted by the ē of the aspect prefix. The transitivizer prefix /s-/ is palatalized [x] because of the following [i].
Example_Type: Offered by speaker from visual stimulus

Translated_Text: My throat dries up on me a lot.
Comment: -ii means 'feel' in this example.

Primary_Text: Tī ná keʔe choo jā kiwiti nu nku-chata=na.
Translated_Text: If it doesn't rain, the crop (what we planted) will dry out.
My mouth feels very dried out.
Comment: -ii means 'feel' and not 'want' in this example.

Translated_Text: The child is jumping on the ground.
Translation_Other: El niño está brincando en el suelo.

Translated_Text: They made the child jump.

Primary_Text: Jā nu ntekwaą̄ niʔ ntekwaą̄ niʔ ntekwaą̄ niʔ nkweʔeteʔę niʔ tyākwę́.
Translated_Text: And he jumped and jumped and jumped and fell down to the path.
Juan went to dig up tubers, so we could eat yesterday.

Primary_Text: Tāká kixę̄ʔ tāká kee tāká xī nkālúū tyā yuu.
Translated_Text: There are weeds, there are rocks, there are places where the water has eroded the ground.
They dug it.
Tomorrow I will take him again.

Primary_Text: Nkyalóʔō na nkwítzą kūnáʔaá jnā liwrūú jnīʔ matrū skwelāá.
Translated_Text: The child brought the book to the teacher.
Comment: This example contains the applicative of the verb 'come' rather than GO, but it works exactly the same for GO.

Primary_Text: Yakwiʔ nu kūnáʔa jyą́ʔ i nkātāá súkwā jį̄náʔ.
Translated_Text: The woman spoke to me and offered me food.

Primary_Text: Lēʔ tyāʔ yakwiʔ nu kūnáʔa jlyālá jį̄ na nkwítząaʔ lēʔ nakwę laaʔ "i wala tz-āā tī nī?"
Translated_Text: And the mean woman still spoke to the child, and she said to him, "And where are you going now?"
Then we turned around and left.

Primary_Text: Nchakwiʔ na lóʔō niʔ maxi xītzáʔrina.
Translated_Text: We are talking with the lord even if only in our language.
Comment: It seems like jiʔį̄ is used for 'talk to' and lóʔō is used more for 'talk with'. As in English, the difference is subtle and not always very clear. The latter functions like a reciprocal, but reciprocals are not marked in this way, and it more resembles comitative NPs, which are flagged by lóʔō.

Primary_Text: Tzoʔō ntakǫʔ ʔneyu ntekwā niī jā ntikwiʔyu jnā.
Translated_Text: He does very well because he talks to us.

Primary_Text: Kinikwę tyūú jiʔį̄ jwaā tzaa tya kitzę jlyū.
Translated_Text: Pedro is going to tell Juan to go to the city.
"And why are we going to take pine?", said the woman.
Comment: The goal is unexpressed but understood from the context.

Primary_Text: Lēʔ yakwiʔūʔ lóʔō na kweta kyaʔāaʔ "laaʔ ntētāką́ʔ kwaa yākwá" nakwę.
Translated_Text: Then they spoke to the Mixtecs, "that is what is happening to us there", they said.
Comment: It seems like jiʔį̄ is used for 'talk to' and lóʔō is used more for 'talk with'. As in English, the difference is subtle and not always very clear. The latter functions like a reciprocal, but reciprocals are not marked in this way, and it more resembles comitative NPs, which are flagged by lóʔō.

Primary_Text: I niī reē nyāʔā ntyukwā niʔ loō nto síyā ntūkwá niʔ lóʔō niʔ lóʔō xikūnáʔa niʔ.
Translated_Text: And the king was sitting there, he was sitting on his chair with her, with his woman.

Primary_Text: "Tyūkwá kitzę ti wą ná akwāʔ kūlíji jwą̄ tī luwiʔ" nakwę.
Translated_Text: "It will be in your village, and it will never be lacking for you all then", he said.
Comment: This is the intransitive basic verb root from which nkā-tūkwá POUR/LOAD is derived via the u-causative alternation.

Translated_Text: The child climbed up on the table.

Primary_Text: Nchósaʔą na wīchíí nto yakaá tatīyá tzáą̄.
Translated_Text: The cat climbs up into that tree every day.

Primary_Text: Ntyáyulaʔ na nkwítząá ntzuʔu nto tyáā tatīyá tzáą̄.
Translated_Text: The children always get cold from being in the water every day.
I'm shaking from cold.

Primary_Text: Nkawanā na nkwítzą kūnáʔaá jnā liwrūú jnīʔ matrū skwelāá.
Translated_Text: The girl stole the book from the teacher.
They (nonspec.) stole the book from the teacher (the teacher's book).
Juan did not steal the tortillas.

Primary_Text: Na nyatę̄ nyāʔā nkawanāų́ʔ jnā jnā soʔni jnā soʔni jiʔį̄ų́ʔ.
Translated_Text: Those people, you see, they stole the, the shell, their shell.

Primary_Text: Ntákwī nchaaūʔ wiʔ nī lēʔ nu nkwētyūkwá nu ntikwiʔya chíjyą̄ʔ.
Translated_Text: When they were going and passing there, what we call a cardinal sat down.
Here we will sit, and we are going to give a story.
He sat down on the floor.
The man sat down.
The man sat down on the ground.
They made his arm hurt.
Translation_Other: Le hicieron doler el brazo.

Primary_Text: Lēʔ lóʔō na yaka nu ntuʔu yaāʔ ntekutzęyu jnā lyūkēʔę́ ntyákwikāʔá nu wiʔ.
Translated_Text: Then, with the stick that he had in his hand, he was scaring the flies that flew also, that one.

Primary_Text: Nkūkúti na yuú jā léē léē nkwiʔe choo.
Translated_Text: The earth became soft because it rained very hard.
It looks like it is going to rain again.

Primary_Text: Nkutyejnā ntiʔe choo kunu suwe ʔne lēʔ nkutyejnā ntulaʔaūʔ jnā keeʔ lōʔ kwitīʔyú.
Translated_Text: Then it started to sprinkle a little bit, and they began to break the rock with lightning.

Primary_Text: Nkwityātyūkwá niʔ kíʔyūú jį̄ chúʔ kūnáʔaá.
Translated_Text: The man helped the woman.
The man followed the woman.
He was already hungry when he arrived.

Primary_Text: Lō nu ntiʔyā tiʔēę́ʔ tiʔi ntii tīkéę̄ʔ.
Translated_Text: When I breathe, my chest hurts.

Primary_Text: Léē tiʔi nanēʔą́ʔ lō nu nchuteʔą̄ʔ.
Translated_Text: My stomach hurts a lot when I am hungry.

Primary_Text: Tiʔi nanēʔą́ʔ lō nu ntyayakoǭʔ chaja.
Translated_Text: My stomach hurts after I eat.
Translation_Other: Me duele el estómago después de haber comido.

Translated_Text: My whole head hurts.

Primary_Text: Tiʔi tatīyá tzáą̄ lō nu nchatasaʔąą̄ʔ.
Translated_Text: I'm in pain every day when I get up.
My heart hurts.

Primary_Text: Kutza nkaʔne jyą́ʔ nkū-túʔu lyātá ná tula ʔne=ą̄ʔ chaa=ą̄ʔ jā k-aja=ą̄ʔ xī tāká=ą̄ʔ.
Translated_Text: It was difficult for me to make my ditch (for the ditch to come out), but there is nothing for me to do. I better just go, so I may die in my own land (where I live).

Primary_Text: Tyúʔu na kiiʔí jnā ketǫʔó jā ta nkūkéʔ na súkwā.
Translated_Text: The fire is going to be taken from the pot because the food is done cooking.
Comment: Literal translation: 'The fire will leave the pot because the food is already cooked.'

Primary_Text: Ná ntyōtíʔya wala ntētúʔu tejeʔ nu ntakuya nī.
Translated_Text: We don't know where the salt we eat now comes from.
"Let's go", they said.
He is sad, and he is getting sick.
Example_Type: Offered by speaker from visual stimulus

Primary_Text: Jā n-tzaʔą=yu ná tzoʔō ntz-uʔu tza rúʔ nte-tāką́ʔ=yu lō tī tu nch-ā-kitza túkwi rúʔ kitza nte-ʔne.
Translated_Text: Because his animal spirit is not well that is why this is happening to him, if he is sick with whatever illness.

Primary_Text: Tī tu tyātyūkwā jyą́ʔ nyāʔā kisoǭʔ jį́.
Translated_Text: If you help me, I will pay you.
They are accompanying and carrying the one who is sick.
Example_Type: Offered by speaker from visual stimulus

Primary_Text: Jā nu nu tyātyūkwá tī na chii laʔā tī nu tza jnyāʔá lēʔ nu joʔō laa nī nakwę.
Translated_Text: That this elder helps us if it is true that he is a saint, he said.
We will accompany him because he is humble.

Primary_Text: Ná nīkwę̄ tu nāáʔ ntákwēę̄ʔ kyaʔa jā jiʔį́ tyaʔą-la-saʔą tza liya nu tāá.
Translated_Text: Don't say that it is my fault if he goes after you once he gives it to you.
She liked the oranges.

Primary_Text: Ná nchatoǫtīʔyu jā tikwą ntikwiʔ nyatę̄ jiʔį̄yu xī nchakā jūntáá.
Translated_Text: He does not like it because the people were talking bad to him where they were having the meeting.

Primary_Text: Jwāá ná yatoǫtīʔ jnā lúkwīí nu nkātáą̄ʔ jiʔį̄yu.
Translated_Text: Juan did not like the mezcal I gave him.

Primary_Text: Jwaā yanāʔā jnā wurū tī ná nteyatiʔ.
Translated_Text: Juan! Go and look at the donkey to see that it is not coming untied.
Why are they following me?
He hugs her.
He hugs her and kisses her lips.
I think it would be good to hug her.
Comment: the verb -ii 'want', means 'think' or 'feel' here

Primary_Text: Ná ʔnē tī laaʔ nu tyōǭ chuʔuxīīʔ tī yaka wala ntoǫ mītą́ʔ.
Translated_Text: Do not do that, that standing there and hugging the logs where the support posts are.
He went running because he went late.
Example_Type: Offered by speaker from visual stimulus

Translated_Text: He made the child run.
Translation_Other: Le hizo correr al niño.

Translated_Text: The boy ran on the ground.
Translation_Other: El niño corrió en el suelo.

Primary_Text: Naʔā nchuwintoo jwaā jā tiʔi ntooyu.
Translated_Text: Juan does not blink anymore because his eye hurts.

Primary_Text: Nkātēję́ na nkwítząá jnā keé tya nto bentanāá.
Translated_Text: The child threw the rock through the window.
Comment: 'The child (sent) caused the rock to pass through the window.'
Translation_Other: el niño aventó la piedra por la ventana

Primary_Text: Laaʔ tī tu walari kukwą̄ kee kūnēʔé jį̄.
Translated_Text: They can grab rocks and throw them wherever.

Primary_Text: Tzanēʔéjnáʔą̄ʔ jį́ nto kiiʔ nyāʔā chu xīyáʔri tikwą ntikwiʔjnyáʔā jyą́ʔ nakwę niʔ kwetāʔaʔ jnā kweeʔeʔ.
Translated_Text: "I am going to throw you in the fire, you'll see, you little one, because you insult me", said the fox to the crab.

Primary_Text: "Jā na kūʔwíí nkaʔne lō jiʔį́" nakwę lēʔ nkānēʔéūʔ jnuwę̄ʔ naneʔē.
Translated_Text: "That drunk there did this to you", he said, and they threw him in the jail.

Primary_Text: Kusuʔōǫ́ʔ jnā nkwítzą kūnáʔa jnīʔ kíʔyōǫ́ʔ.
Translated_Text: I will show the girls to my son.
Comment: 'show'

Translated_Text: I will teach you Zapotec.
She teaches him English.

Primary_Text: Nkasuʔūúʔ jnā liwrūú jnīʔ matrū skwelā.
Translated_Text: The book was shown to the teacher.
Comment: The agent is the 3rd person nonspecific, like 'they showed the book to the teacher'.

Primary_Text: Nkasuʔū na nkwítząá tzaka lakaʔ nkyánā jyą́ʔ.
Translated_Text: The child showed me a wilted leaf.
Translation_Other: el niño me mostró una hoja marchitada

Translated_Text: Juan does not want to shuck the corn.
This one takes away their job we say.
I will take (her) from him.

Primary_Text: Ntikwiʔtzáʔ ų́ʔwá jnā yuu nu nkāláą̄ wá.
Translated_Text: They are reclaiming the land that we took (from them).

Primary_Text: "Nkāyūkéʔ tīké ntē nī" nakwęūʔ jį̄ nyáʔaūʔ "jā kakuna."
Translated_Text: "Cook this liver", they told their mother, "so that we may eat."

Primary_Text: Jwāá ntēxūʔú yane na kwetuú jā kākéʔ.
Translated_Text: Juan is cutting the chicken's neck so that it can be cooked.
He got cut in two places on his hand.
Comment: This is the intransitive verb form of CUT, from which the transitive form is derived.
Example_Type: Offered by speaker from visual stimulus

Translated_Text: The man cut himself with his machete (by accident).
Comment:
unintentional, low agentivity
This is the less-transitive verb from which the u-causative form is derived. If it had the u-causative prefix, it would be nkā-xūʔú instead of nkū-xūʔú.

Translated_Text: We used to cut the weeds and we would plant the corn.

Primary_Text: Ta nkāxūʔúūʔ jnā ya nkítā tī niī.
Translated_Text: They have cut the elephant's ear tree now.
Translation_Other: Ya cortaron el guanacastle ahora.

Primary_Text: Nkūxūʔú na cha-jlyāá lóʔō na kuchilūú.
Translated_Text: The bread was cut with the knife.
Comment: This is the intransitive verb from which the transitive verb CUT is derived.
Translation_Other: se cortó el pan con el cuchillo

Primary_Text: Nkāxūʔú na nkwítząá jnā chajlyāá lóʔō kuchilū.
Translated_Text: The child cut the bread with the knife.
Translation_Other: El niño cortó el pan con cuchillo.

Translated_Text: He is holding her arm.
Comment: TOUCH in this case means 'hold'.
Example_Type: Offered by speaker from visual stimulus

Primary_Text: Lēʔ nchuʔukāchíʔ jā nu na nkwítzą ntilaʔ kee jā titǭ nkalaʔaūʔ jiʔį̄.
Translated_Text: They (the jugs) get hidden there, because the children grab rocks and they have broken several (of the jugs).
Comment: verb nti-laʔ means 'grab' here instead of 'touch' or 'hold'

Primary_Text: Ntāáūʔ ītzáʔ ntunaą maxi ná nkānaʔaą̄ʔ jį̄ ná yujweę̄ʔ jiʔį̄ ná yalaʔą̄ʔ jį̄.
Translated_Text: They talk about it and we listen, but I never saw it, I never killed it, I never touched it.
Translation_Other: Lo platican y lo escuchamos aunque no lo vi, no lo maté ni lo tenté.

Primary_Text: Na nkwítząá yalaʔ jnā kwénāá lóʔō na ya látīí.
Translated_Text: The child touched the snake with the stick.
Translation_Other: El niño tentó la culebra con la vara.

Primary_Text: Ntekēkutzę xāláą̄ʔ jyą́ʔ nu ntēráyakaūʔ jyą́ʔ.
Translated_Text: My dreams about people hitting me with a stick are frightening me.
Comment: instrument, or theme, incorporated

Primary_Text: Nkārá na nkwítząá jnā kwénāá lóʔō na ya látīí.
Translated_Text: The boy hit the snake with the stick.

Primary_Text: Ch-uʔu ntzukwāʔ jiʔį̄ jwaā=V́ la kii.
Translated_Text: Tomorrow Juan's corn will be planted.
Comment: This example shows the basic intransitive verb from which PUT/POUR is derived.

Translated_Text: We built granaries where the ears of corn were put.
Comment: This example shows the basic intransitive verb from which PUT/POUR is derived.

Primary_Text: Luwiʔ nkātāká nāáʔ ta tāká nyatę̄ ntē luwiʔ.
Translated_Text: At that time I was born. There were already people here at that time.
Comment: This example shows the verb in completive aspect, where in this instance it means 'was born', and the root also appears in a more-basic adjectival (but still derived) form with stative-like aspect meaning 'exist', 'live', where it illustrates the coding frame.

Primary_Text: Wī tī nuwęʔ wī chiīʔ wala=rā nk-ā=tāká wiʔ?
Translated_Text: And him, young one, where did he live?

Primary_Text: Nāxíʔi tu tijyuʔ tākáą nteēri tāká nkwítzą ntujwiʔ jį̄.
Translated_Text: We don't live far, right here lives a kid who sells them.
Comment: 2 instances of the verb 'live' in this example

Primary_Text: Kwitūsúʔwą kwítī kixę̄ʔ tatīyá nu nchuʔuntoo lákwiʔwą.
Translated_Text: Grab herbal medicine, everything you know yourselves.

Primary_Text: La niī nyaʔayu nakwę chuʔuntooyu jiʔį̄ nyatę̄ tāká ntē nakwę.
Translated_Text: "Now he will see", he said, "he will meet the people that live here", he said.
Translation_Other: "Ahora va a ver" dijo "va a conocer a la gente que vive aquí" dijo.

Translated_Text: I did/made it with my machete.
"You are going to make a plow", he said.
The woman was making what he was going to eat.
Translation_Other: La mujer estaba haciendo lo que iba (él) a comer.

Primary_Text: Tzáʔ jlyā nkajnyā jį̄. Tatīyá tī ų́ʔwá tzáʔ jlyā nkajnyāúʔ jų́ʔ.
Translated_Text: He made himself mestizo (non-Chatino). They all turned mestizo.
Translation_Other: Se hizo mestizo. Todos ellos se hicieron mestizos.

Primary_Text: Nu liwrū kujnyāyu jiʔį̄ kitzę nu laa nkyuʔu laaʔ saʔne jiʔį̄ to neʔe jiʔį̄ to laa.
Translated_Text: The book he is going to make for the village is like the one there was long before in the house of the church.
Comment: This example was included just to provide another example of the verb. It does have an added benefactive NP, but I did not include that process as one of the alternations because it seems too productive, basically unrestricted, and therefore of less interest for determining verb classes based on alternations as aimed for in the project.

Translated_Text: The house was built with grass.
Comment: This example shows the intransitive form of 'to build', which uses a different verb root (is suppletive) and thus does not show an alternation.

Primary_Text: Nkajnyā chu kíʔyūú jnā niʔií lóʔō lítúu.
Translated_Text: The man built the house with adobe.
Translation_Other: El hombre construyó la casa con adobe.

Translated_Text: The other one, you see, he is sad.
Example_Type: Offered by speaker from visual stimulus

Translated_Text: We are going to mess with him and see where we end up.

Primary_Text: Jā xī kāchíʔ tyeʔę lēʔ ná kiʔniūʔ kee jiʔį̄ nu jā na nkwítzą ntijya.
Translated_Text: Where it is hidden it will be, then they will not throw rocks at it, because children play.
Comment: this verb means 'hit by throwing'

Primary_Text: Nāxíʔi tī loō kijyana tī saʔne.
Translated_Text: It is not the case that we played that way long ago.

Primary_Text: Nkāxáʔālóʔō niʔ kíʔyūú jnā nkwítzą kūnáʔaá.
Translated_Text: The man screamed at the girl.

Primary_Text: Kixaʔaą̄ʔ jyū chaąyu tya nteē nakwę jā kunayu.
Translated_Text: I am going to call him so that he comes here and listens.

Primary_Text: Wī chu lyāʔ jnyá ntixaʔakāʔáūʔ jnā.
Translated_Text: And the authorities call on us also.

Primary_Text: Ntyáxáʔā saaʔ choō jlyū tuʔwari nyaʔa tza laaʔ wiʔ nkā.
Translated_Text: The parrots would begin to cry, friend, and thick they looked when gathered together there before (when they lifted off to fly).

Primary_Text: La wiʔ yatēyá luwiʔ lēʔ nkāxáʔā nakwę lákwiʔ tzéʔā wá nī jā yākwá ntixaʔa.
Translated_Text: She went to stand there then, and then she screamed, they say, it is right there itself where she screamed.
Comment: This example has 2 instances of the verb 'scream'.

Translated_Text: Juan laughed at him.

Primary_Text: "Tukwi nu chu kekuxiti jiʔį̄ jniʔ kūnáʔaą̄ʔ" nakwę, "lēʔ yūwíʔ saʔąyu lóʔō" nakwę.
Translated_Text: "Whoever makes my daughter laugh", he said, "he will marry her", he said.

Primary_Text: Tzáʔ wiʔ niī lēʔ nkaxiti tī jniʔ kūnáʔa na reēʔ.
Translated_Text: That is why the king's daughter laughed.
She got him to dance.
During the year, one goes to dance, one goes.
Gathered together, they are singing.
Example_Type: Offered by speaker from visual stimulus

Translated_Text: The child sang a song.
Translation_Other: El niño cantó una canción.

Translated_Text: The boy sang.
He boiled it.
Comment: There is an unexpressed pronominal object.

Primary_Text: Tza liya nu nkwityalákwi niī nyāʔā lēʔ lēʔ nchatákwī teę tī luwiʔ.
Translated_Text: Once it has stopped boiling, you see, it ends up still then.

Primary_Text: Jā tyejnā kīlákwi tī luwiʔ tza lō tī tu kiiʔ ntuʔu.
Translated_Text: It is going to start boiling then, as if there were fire in it.
Then I asked for the jugs.
Comment: There is no known unexpressed askee object here.

Translated_Text: We will not ask the people for it (money).
Comment: object 'money' unexpressed
Translation_Other: No se lo vamos a pedir a la gente.

Primary_Text: Nkwiiya ʔnekwēyáʔya laaʔ laaʔ tī nu jā nt-ū-nána=ūʔ jiʔį̄=ya.
Translated_Text: We wanted to try to do so, because they were asking us for it.
Comment: 'ask for' has unexpressed specific object (mezcal)

Primary_Text: Lēʔ nu tíʔnyo tzúna nyájā nuwęʔ niī nakwę ntyejnā ntūnána tzaka nyatę̄ jiʔį̄.
Translated_Text: At the age of eighteen it was that a person began asking for her (to marry).
Comment: This is a lexicalized special sense of the word, where 'ask for her' means 'ask for her in marriage'. The askee NP is understood as the girl's family.

Translated_Text: They (nonspec.) asked the man for the money.
Comment: This can mean: 'they asked for [the man's money]'

Primary_Text: Nkānána nā nkwítząá jnē jnīʔ kíʔyū.
Translated_Text: The child asked the man for money.
Translation_Other: El chamaco pidió dinero al hombre.

Translated_Text: He is always thinking.
She is always thinking of you.
Comment: jiʔī with low tone on final syllable is 3rd person jiʔį́ with high tone on final syllable is 2SG.

Primary_Text: Laaʔ laa ntzuʔuntoo tī nāáʔ jiʔį̄ na chiiʔ.
Translated_Text: And so it is that I knew that man.

Primary_Text: Kuweri tzoʔō tzoʔō lēʔ kōʔó=ǫ jiʔį̄ tza tasā xīyáʔ=ri.
Translated_Text: It gets ground very fine and then one drinks just a small cup.
Comment: This example illustrates the intransitive counterpart verb of the transitive verb 'grind'. The verb pair is suppletive and not related derivationally.
Translation_Other: Se muele bien bien y uno toma una taza chiquita.

Primary_Text: Tzalóʔō nāáʔ kichi. Tyūkwáxikǭǫ́ʔ jiʔį̄ tzūʔ lātzá jā kóō. Chāʔą̄ jiʔį̄. Kóō.
Translated_Text: I will take the quern. I'll carry it on my shoulder in the morning because you will grind. You will wash it. You will grind.

Primary_Text: Kii nī kōóūʔ jnū wá nī kakuna.
Translated_Text: Tomorrow they are going to grind it so that we can eat.
Translation_Other: Mañana lo van a moler eso para que comamos.

Translated_Text: She bathed the baby.
Translation_Other: Baño al nene.

Primary_Text: Nkwēkata na nkwítzą kūnáʔaá jnā piīʔ kūnáʔaá.
Translated_Text: The girl washed the baby girl.
Translation_Other: La muchacha baño a la niña.

Primary_Text: Kekataūʔ jnīʔ joʔō i kekutūʔúūʔ sateʔ.
Translated_Text: They are going to bathe the saint and dress him.
Translation_Other: Van a bañar al santo y lo van a vestir.

Primary_Text: Lyakwā ntekutzę jiʔį́ nakwę niʔ joʔō kwitzaā jiʔį̄ nyáʔa niʔ.
Translated_Text: "Why does it scare you?", the sun asked his mother.

Primary_Text: Nkwēkutzę niʔ kíʔyūú jnā nkwítzą kíʔyūú.
Translated_Text: The man frightened the boy.
Translation_Other: El hombre espantó al chamaco.

Primary_Text: Komō telā nyaʔa i loxę̄ʔrúʔ wisāʔ nteyutzę na nyatę̄eʔ.
Translated_Text: As it was nighttime and in the forest, therefore the person was afraid.
"Look here!", he said.

Primary_Text: Yutzę na nkwítzą kíʔyūú jiʔį̄ niʔ kíʔyūú.
Translated_Text: The boy feared the man.
Translation_Other: El chamaco tuvo miedo del hombre.

Primary_Text: Wī nuwęʔ kīlyóūʔ nkwiyūʔ pero ná nkyajā.
Translated_Text: And it was that one that they wanted to copy, but it didn't appear./Lit: 'And it was that one they wanted to take out again, but it was not found.'
Translation_Other: Y es ése ése que querían copiar pero no apareció.

Primary_Text: Wiʔ niī lēʔ nu nkyajā tī nuwęʔ jyū.
Translated_Text: Then there it was that she found him.

Primary_Text: Nkujwī na liwrūú jnīʔ matrū skwelā.
Translated_Text: The teacher's book was gotten.
Comment: intransitive
Translation_Other: Se consiguió el libro de la maestra.

Primary_Text: Nkujwī tzáʔ kwēyáʔ tį̄ jā tzaą tiį̄.
Translated_Text: Permission is gotten, so let's go now.
Comment: intransitive
Original_Orthography: nku-jwi_ tza!7 kwe_ya!7 ti_ ni_ ja_ tzaa -a& ti_ ni_
Translation_Other: Se consiguió permiso, pues ahora sí vamos.

Translated_Text: So that was gotten.
Comment: intransitive
Translation_Other: Entonces se halló eso.

Translated_Text: From my mother I got it.
Translation_Other: De mi mamá lo conseguí.

Translated_Text: Where did you get that?
Original_Orthography: wala nku-jwi_ ti_ kwa7a& ji7i_& nuwe&7
Translation_Other: ¿Dónde consiguieron ustedes ése?

Primary_Text: Nkutayūná na nkwítząaʔ nakwę laaʔ juti jį̄ kwentā nu kājá lyoʔo.
Translated_Text: The girl began to cry because her father told her she was going to get a husband.
Original_Orthography: nku-ta=y-u_na! na nkwi!tza& -V7 nakwe& laa7 juti ji7i_& kwenta_ nu k-a_ja! lyo7o
Translation_Other: La muchacha empezó a llorar porque le dijo su padre que se iba a casar.

Primary_Text: Na kwénāá nkujwi lóʔō na ya látīí.
Translated_Text: The snake died by stick.
Original_Orthography: na kwe!na_ -V! nku-jwi lo!7o_ na ya la!ti_ -V!
Translation_Other: Se murió la culebra por vara.

Translated_Text: The man died.
Translation_Other: Se murió el hombre.

Translated_Text: Those who were churchwardens are dying.
Original_Orthography: tzaka tzaka nyate_& ja_ nu tzu_7 ntey-aja -u_7. ntey-aja nu chu n-kaa_ wiska_
Translation_Other: Están muriendo los que fueron fiscales.

Primary_Text: Nkujwi tą̄ na kwīchíiʔ nakwę lēʔ lēʔ telā wiʔ nkujwi tą̄ nyatę̄eʔ.
Translated_Text: The jaguar died, they say, and then that night the person died.
Original_Orthography: nku-jwi ti_ na na kwi_chi! -V7 nakwe& le_7 le_7 tela_ wi7 nku-jwi ti_ na nyate_& -V7
Translation_Other: Se murió el tigre y esa misma noche se murió la persona.

Primary_Text: Na kweta kyaʔāaʔ nkyaą nkayujwi jiʔį̄ na kwénāaʔ.
Translated_Text: The Mixtec came to kill the snake.
Original_Orthography: na kweta kya7a_ -V7 nk-yaa& nkay-ujwi ji7i_& na kwe!na_ -V7
Translation_Other: El mixteco vino para matar la culebra.

Primary_Text: Wī ntujwi tī kwa jnuwę̄ʔ lóʔō kētǫ́.
Translated_Text: We killed those with guns.
Original_Orthography: wi_ nt-ujwi ti_ kwa ji7i_& nuwe&7 lo!7o_ ke_to!&
Translation_Other: Nosotros matábamos a esos con armas.

Primary_Text: Jā tyánana nyatę̄ nu nu nu kujwi jnūwá nu tyána nyāʔā tula ʔnena jiʔį̄.
Translated_Text: Let's look for someone who will kill that one (snake) and who will look for, you see, what we are going to do.
Translation_Other: Que busquemos gente que la mate a ésa (culebra) y que busca, verás, lo que vamos a hacer.

Translated_Text: "I am going to go to look for him", he said.
Original_Orthography: le_7 nk-ya=ta=sa7a& ti_ luwi7 nakwe&. cha=tya!na -a_&7 ji7i_& -yu la7a_ nakwe&
Translation_Other: "Lo voy a ir a buscar a él", dijo.

Translated_Text: They (nonspecific) searched for the child.
Translation_Other: Se buscó al chamaco.

Primary_Text: Nkwītyána niʔ kíʔyūú jnā nkwítzą kíʔyūú.
Translated_Text: The man searched for the child.
Original_Orthography: nkwi-tya!na ni7 ki!7yu_ -V! ji7i_& na_ nkwi!tza& ki!7yu_ -V!
Translation_Other: El hombre buscó al chamaco.

Translated_Text: Send them here.
Comment: Pronominal object is unexpressed.
Translation_Other: Mándenlos aquí.

Primary_Text: Ná nkātēję̄ na jnē nu ntyākwī wiʔ jyą́ʔ.
Translated_Text: You did not send me that money you owe me.
Original_Orthography: na! nka-te_je_& na jne_ nu n-tya_kwi_ wi7 ji7i_& -a_&7
Translation_Other: No me mandaste el dinero que me debes.

Primary_Text: Nāxíʔi tī ta tu niī tu ntētēję́ya jį̄ xaaʔ seʔę.
Translated_Text: It is not as if we are already sending it out to other areas.
Original_Orthography: na xi!7i ti_ ta tu nii_ tu nte_-te_je!& -ya ji7i_& xaa7 se7e&
Translation_Other: No es que ya lo estamos transportando a otras partes.

Primary_Text: Nkā-tēję́ na nkwítzą kūnáʔaá jnā liwrūú jį̄ niʔ matrū skwelāá.
Translated_Text: The girl sent the book to the teacher.
Original_Orthography: nka_-te_je!& na nkwi!tza& ku_na!7a -V! ji7i_& na liwru_ -V! ji7i_& ni7 matru_ skwela_ -V!
Translation_Other: La niña mandó el libro al maestro.

Primary_Text: Nkātāá na nkwítzą kūnáʔaá jnā liwrūú jnīʔ matrū skwelāá.
Translated_Text: The girl gave the book to the teacher.
Original_Orthography: nka-_ta_a! na nkwi!tza& ku_na!7a -V! ji7i_& na liwru_ -V! ji7i_& ni7 matru skwela_ -V!
Translation_Other: La chamaca dio el libro al maestro.

Translated_Text: Juan poured water on the flowers.
Translation_Other: Juan le puso agua en las flores.

Primary_Text: Tzatūʔóǭʔ ítā jiʔį̄ maxi nāxíʔi tī kenaʔa.
Translated_Text: I will pour water on it even if not a lot.
Comment: The verb has an incorporated auxiliary 'go'
Original_Orthography: y-aa -a_&7 ya_kwa! lo!7o_ ti jo7o_ tza=tu_7u! -a_&7 i!ta_ ji7i_& maxi naxi!7i ti_ ke na7a&
Translation_Other: Le voy a echar agua aunque no sea mucho.

Translated_Text: She put salt in the broth.
Translation_Other: Puso sal en el caldo.

Primary_Text: Tyāʔná ka tī kwaʔą nyaʔa lyakwā nkatūkwáwą wiʔ?
Translated_Text: Too bad for you guys, why did you plant (corn) there?
Translation_Other: Pobre de ustedes ¿por qué sembraron allí?

Primary_Text: Kūtūkwá jnā lúkwīiʔ lō nu taʔa.
Translated_Text: They will pour the mezcal during the festival.
Original_Orthography: ka le_7 tyu_kwa! tu!kwa nyate_&. k-u_-tu_kwa! ji7i_& na lu!kwi_ -V7 lo_ nu ta7a
Translation_Other: Van a servir el mezcal durante la fiesta.

Primary_Text: Tza liya nu ta nkujwī xile ta ta nteyajā xile nu nchatzūʔ nyaʔa lēʔ kūtūkwáą ítā jiʔį̄.
Translated_Text: Once it has gotten strength and is getting stronger and we see it is rotting, then we pour water on it.
Original_Orthography: tza liya nu ta nku-jwi_ xile ta ntey-aja_ xile nu nch-atzu_7 nya7a le_7 k-u-tu_kwa! -a& i!ta_ ji7i_&
Translation_Other: Ya que halló fuerza ya está hallando fuerza ya que se ve que está pudriendo, le echamos agua.

Translated_Text: That one still had not been tied up.
Comment: Since I chose the intransitive verb as the basic form in the equipollent alternation, this example does not show any alternation or basic coding frame. It does show the intransitive verb pair of TIE.
Original_Orthography: wi!la_ ch-aka_&7 ti_ nu wi7. wi!la_ sukwa_ yaka ike ti_ nu wi7 ntikwi7 -a& ya nti-sukwa_ ke
Translation_Other: Todavía no se ha uncido ése.

Translated_Text: Juan tied up the dog.
Translation_Other: Amarró Juan el perro.

Translated_Text: They bandaged him in plaster.
Translation_Other: Lo vendaron con yeso.
Example_Type: Offered by speaker from visual stimulus

Primary_Text: ... lēʔ nkāxīką́ʔyu tī jiʔį̄ na torōoʔ.
Translated_Text: ... and then he tied up the bull.
Comment: The tying goal is optional. It is not removed via an alternation.
Original_Orthography: le_7 wi7 nii_ le_7 nkwi-tya=yaa_7 ti_ kosa_ nu ki_-ni_jnya! -yu le_7 nka-xi_ka!&7 -yu ti_ ji7i_& na toro_ -V7
Translation_Other: ... y entonces unció el toro.

Translated_Text: The horse was tied to the tree.
Original_Orthography: nk-ya_ka!&7 na kwayu_ -V! ji7i_& na_ yaka -V!

Primary_Text: Niʔ kíʔyūú nkāxīką́ʔ jnā kwayūú jnā yakaá.
Translated_Text: The man tied the horse to the tree.
Comment: The intended locational adjunct is flagged as an object. The agent is fronted before the verb.
Original_Orthography: ni7 ki!7yu_ -V! nka_-x-i_ka!&7 ji7i_& na kwayu_ -V! ji7i_& na yaka -V!
Translation_Other: El hombre amarró el caballo en el árbol.

Translated_Text: Fill the pot with water!
Original_Orthography: nka-7ne-cha!=tza7a& ji7i_& na keto&7 lo!7o_ i!ta_
Translation_Other: llena la olla con agua!

Primary_Text: Nkyākǫ́ʔ na nkwítząá lóʔō na tā kitząʔá.
Translated_Text: The child was covered up with the blanket.
Comment: This verb illustrates the basic intransitive verb from which COVER/CLOSE is derived.
Translation_Other: Fue cubierto el niño con la cobija.

Translated_Text: My nose feels like it got plugged up.
Comment: The verb -ii 'want', means 'feel' in this example. The example shows the basic intransitive verb from which COVER/CLOSE is derived.
Translation_Other: La nariz se siente que se me cerró.

Primary_Text: Nkyākǫ́ʔ kitząʔ ke nu kūnáʔa nu ntāá kwítī.
Translated_Text: The nurse's hair is covered up (with a cloth).
Comment: This example shows the basic intransitive verb from which COVER/CLOSE is derived.
Original_Orthography: nk-ya_ko!&7 kitza&7 ke nu kuna_7a!& nu n-ta_a! kwi!ti_
Translation_Other: Se cubrió el cabello de la enfermera.
Example_Type: Offered by speaker from visual stimulus

Translated_Text: The school was closed.
Comment: The example shows the basic intransitive verb from which COVER/CLOSE is derived.
Translation_Other: Se cerró la escuela.

Primary_Text: Nkātākǫ́ʔ nu nee joʔō kyaʔā kékū.
Translated_Text: He closed off the one called the god of nature.
Original_Orthography: nka-t-a_ko!&7 nu nee jo7o_ kya7a_ ke!ku_. nk-y-a_ko!&7=ntoo nu nee jo7o_ kya7a_ ke!ku_ kwenta_ nu nee nk-yaa& nu nee mpanjelisado_r nka_
Translation_Other: Tapó a aquel que le dicen dios de la naturaleza.

Translated_Text: They planned on closing it off (the place).
Translation_Other: Pensaron de taparlo (el lugar).

Translated_Text: He closed his eyes and walked out then.
Translation_Other: Cerró los ojos y salió para afuera entonces.

Primary_Text: Kutākǫ́ʔǫ jnā litaá jā ná nyaʔa xíkwą̄ jį̄.
Translated_Text: We are going to cover up the corn so that the sun does not see it.
Original_Orthography: k-u-t-ako_&7 -a& ji7i_& na lita -V! ja_ na! nya7a xi!kwa_& ji7i_&
Translation_Other: Vamos a tapar a la mazorca para que no lo vea el sol.

Translated_Text: The cloud is covering the moon.
Translation_Other: La nube está ocultando la luna.
Example_Type: Offered by speaker from visual stimulus

Primary_Text: Nkātākǫ́ʔ niʔ kíʔyūú jiʔį̄ na nkwítząá lóʔō na tā kitząʔá.
Translated_Text: The man covered the child with the blanket.
Original_Orthography: nka_-t-a_ko!&7 ni7 ki!7u_ -V! ji7i_& na nkwi!tza& -V! lo!7o_ na ta_ kitza&7 -V!
Translation_Other: El hombre cubrió al niño con la cobija.

Primary_Text: Chu kíʔyūuʔ nkaʔne tyátuuʔ nu kūnáʔaaʔ.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman cough.
Comment: This is a periphrastic causative, where the target verb is part of the complement clause following the verb nka-ʔne 'do'.
Translation_Other: El hombre hizo toser a la mujer.

Translated_Text: The man coughed.
Translation_Other: El hombre tosió.

Primary_Text: Na nkwítząá ntekēkaku chaja jiʔį̄ na jnēʔé.
Translated_Text: The kids are feeding tortillas to the dogs.
Original_Orthography: na nkwi!tza& -V! nte-k-e_=k-aku chaja ji7i_& na jne_7 -V!
Translation_Other: Los chamacos les están dando tortillas de comer a los perros.

Translated_Text: The time has arrived that we eat.
Translation_Other: Ha llegado la hora de comer.

Translated_Text: They are splitting (food) and eating.
The girl ate the bread.
Translation_Other: La muchacha comió el pan.

Translated_Text: The bread got eaten.
Translation_Other: Se comió el pan.

Primary_Text: Jwāá ná nkasatą jnā kwichīí jā cháku nūwá.
Translated_Text: Juan did not skin the rabbit for it to be eaten.
Original_Orthography: jwa_ -V! na! nka-s-ata& ji7i_& na kwichi_ -V! ja_ ch-a!ku nu_wa!

Primary_Text: Kii niī cháku na chajaá jā kenaʔa tī na chajaá ntōnēʔé.
Translated_Text: Tomorrow those tortillas will be eaten, because there are many of those tortillas piled up.
Original_Orthography: kii nii_ ch-a!ku na chaja -V! ja_ kena7a ti_ na chaja -V! n-to_=ne_7e!

Translated_Text: We eat it.
Translation_Other: Lo comemos.

Primary_Text: Nu chu Jwaā léē kenaʔa nkwītítzūʔ yaku yu nkutúkwā tuʔwa yu.
Translated_Text: Juan ate too much pineapple and his mouth got raw (chafed).
Original_Orthography: nu chu jwaa_ le!e_ kena7a& nkwi-ti!tz_u7 y-aku -yu nku-tu!kwa_ tu7wa -yu
Translation_Other: Juan comió demasiado piña y se escaldó la boca.

Primary_Text: Jwāá nkātāná yu yaku yu pastíyā.
Translated_Text: Juan got poisoned because he ate pills.
Comment: The target verb is in a dependent clause that is not overtly marked as dependent.
Translation_Other: Juan se envenenó porque comió pastillas.

Translated_Text: I did not eat eggs yesterday.
Comment: The subject is a pronominal clitic.
Translation_Other: Ayer no comí los huevos.

Primary_Text: Tsaą jā ta ntētāáʔ tī na nchuluwa jā ta nkūláā tínī.
Translated_Text: We are going to go because the soursops are cracking because they already came loose.
Comment:
This example shows the basic intransitive form from which the verb TEAR is derived.
This verb has a uniquely irregular equipollent alternation, with -u-s-Root for the transitive and -t-Root for the intransitive.
Original_Orthography: zaa -a& ja_ ta nte-t-a_a!7 ti_ na nchuluwa ja_ ta nku-la!a_ ti!ni_

Translated_Text: The child is tearing the tortilla.
Original_Orthography: na nkwi_tza!& -V! nte-sa_a!7 ji7i_& na chaja -V!

Translated_Text: The back of his clothes, he tore his clothes.
Original_Orthography: tzo&7 sate7 yu nkasa_a!7 sate7 yu

Translated_Text: I sent two letters.

Primary_Text: Ymam kiámb zéḡ wnan aba ymbate.
Translated_Text: He tied the pig to the tree with a rope.
Comment: Lack of case marking on 'rope' seems unusual and should be checked.

Translated_Text: They two are telling each other a story.
You two are telling me this story.
I'm touching him.
We say farewell to you.
He send me a letter in return.
I'll leave a sadness for you.
He told me to go inside.
You two love each other.
Give those two things (away)!
Give it here!
I am cutting the meat with a knife.
Those two men are fighting. (Could be hitting each other, or also fighting by other means).

Primary_Text: Yna pepa yép kunzn ombtes ym.
Translated_Text: The papers are dry inside the bag.
Ask Blag for a fish!
A man full of (overflowing with) spirit.
Comment: So far this is the only example of the middle verb apls, as a derived resultative from the infinitive apls, but it makes clear that the meaning is 'overflow, be full'.

Translated_Text: (S)he is afraid of me.

Primary_Text: Tende är gms brbr är yna bä dewernete, mnene är mrkp npser oynangéwelmän.
Translated_Text: A long time ago people used to hide here from headhunters (N2:125).
I remembered living in Arufi.
He sank the canoe.
Comment: This use of a- is so far unattested in other alternations of this type, i.e. there seems to be an alternation of olets vs alets but no base form.

Translated_Text: The canoe sank (with the heavy people).
They are shaving.
You will shave me.
The child is calling out.
They embraced.
I hugged her.
I am scraping the cassava.

Primary_Text: Yna powa Aesek kr modowa noyabte.
Translated_Text: After that, Isaac is showing off the dead bandicoot.
I'll think of you tomorrow.
Two men are building a house for themselves.

Primary_Text: Ymabem gowa sikma pip yapndt kstemne gowa noletnda.
Translated_Text: They filled the canoe completely to overflowing.

Primary_Text: Bmbem pitasan nne baba yapltat gowawan.
Translated_Text: You’ve loaded the canoe up completely (with enough).
Ḡma is loading the yams for/onto Ywal (i.e. into her yam-basket).
He loads himself up with yams.
I load myself up.
They're loaded up to go.
I loaded you up.

Primary_Text: Ynd bä naweretam gtäts Dimsisi är bende nne arns zi, geä gerengm, ynd yna powa nne bä narntam.
Translated_Text: We must wait to hear/get word that the Dimisisi people have begun their harvest, when we hear then we begin our own harvesting.

Primary_Text: Mnegta nowerete Nen Ym mersraes zi aba ygärngdam o yao.
Translated_Text: He is listening carefully to the recording to know whether we have translated the Nen correctly or not.
He can hear the sound of a flute.
He wants to stand up.
He wants to stand up.
I am learning Nen.
I'm teaching her my language.

Primary_Text: Ämb äräm tbe dene dnawapapte sarnḡ dene bä yangmbatang zḡngama.
Translated_Text: He was teaching us to tie the door post string of a yam house with string.
Two dogs are sniffing each other.
I smell you.
I sat it on the mat.
Sit on the mat!
That man is sitting.
We (two) rolled the log aside.

Primary_Text: Ynd yna yéb yanendn tande mitadmaepapn.
Translated_Text: I got this bag from my aunty.
He's about to go to sleep.

Primary_Text: Zimindi nnemne nne ämbs prta ykmangr yna sarnnḡ kunzn.
Translated_Text: Here are 36 of Jimmy's eating yams inside the yam house.
He put the cassava inside a black palm container.
We (two) pushed the log aside.
The two children are playing.
She / the two of them are scraping the skin off the yam.
God made the earth.
The boys are tying up Kamgo's fence.
We divorced (each other)/ left each other.
I've left my wife.

Primary_Text: Buder, ynd bende baskel yrgab tondn nnorndn.
Translated_Text: Friend, I left your bicycle by the river bank.
He's left/divorced his wife.
We two are laughing.
I'm going to the savannah to burn off.
The pains in my hand are hurting my whole body.

Primary_Text: Megdelinende mleg toge kérbér kitongäm yramte kapyép kunzn.
Translated_Text: Magdalen's little girl felt really cold inside the baby sling.
I'm feeling frightened.
The two of us dug the ground.
I cry.
The baby is crying.
You two are cooking for yourselves, cooking (for your own benefit).
He told me to cook the food.
You two cook food on the fire!

Primary_Text: Ynd wngm sambaks bä dizerngn totr.
Translated_Text: I'm going to burn the grassland today.
The fire flared up; it's caught fire.
Two pieces of charcoal are burning.
Bring the knife!
The water is boiling.
I feel sad.
My whole body is feeling sick.
I am hungry.
Binzawa named his child / passed on his name to his child.
Rain is falling, making a swishing noise.
In 2006 Wena fell down to the ground from up in a two-leaf tree.

Primary_Text: Ktktqébiwäm geä nzne, bm kr bä nm.
Translated_Text: If a taipan bites you, you will die.
An angel appeared to Mary.

Primary_Text: Kae gte endn awiya kipane widmatane kogamnete.
Translated_Text: Yesterday a cassowary suddenly appeared and passed to the other side of the road.

Primary_Text: Kae ämber toge má iparse niparnda endn.
Translated_Text: Yesterday a boy appeared on the road.

Primary_Text: Är togam mlegeita marirmarir angan aba yramte.
Translated_Text: The boy sang a love song for the girl.
The boy sang a song yesterday.
The boy lived in the village.
The children were playing, jumping.
I jumped onto the fence.

Primary_Text: Ynd gtets aba nlintan Dimsisi sambat.
Translated_Text: I ran all the way to Dimsisi village.

Primary_Text: Kae toge sombes äräm emzae ämiwan.
Translated_Text: The man sat the two children on the mat yesterday.
He was sitting on the mat (not long ago).
The man sat (down) on the mat yesterday.

Primary_Text: Äräm toge tarmbte lädawama kitara tqt.
Translated_Text: The man took the child up the ladder onto the balcony.
The man climbed the ladder (ascended by means of the ladder).
The man coughed.
The man washed/bathed yesterday.

Primary_Text: Yna mlegäm toge anu kae témbni.
Translated_Text: The girl washed the child yesterday.
The girl got dressed.
The girl dressed the child.
The bushfowl egg got broken.
I broke the coconut open.
It got hooked/tied.
I tied two ropes.
The starving dogs eat one another.
Comment: Note that because this is a large plural, which is coded by using the 3nsg undergoer prefix combined with the 3sg actor suffix, the middle prefix does not appear in this example, but the reciprocal diathesis is recoverable from the diathetic prefix wä-

Translated_Text: The child ate the yam.
I helped the old man climb the ladder.

Primary_Text: Är yna samban wgd weterser yngm.
Translated_Text: People in this village help each other.
Jesus, help me!
Friend, help me!
He is following behind.
The three children are following each other in a straight line.
The man followed the girl.

Primary_Text: Ynd tande ägmser äräba kiwinḡam déḡdéḡan wrng endn.
Translated_Text: I accidentally met my enemy on a bush track.
He and the girl will meet in secret on a forest path.

Primary_Text: Ymam mleg ybätnda wrng endn adwae.
Translated_Text: The man secretly met the girl in the forest path.

Primary_Text: Grmbo diya ele aba närte sermban.
Translated_Text: Grmbo went hunting for a deer in the night.

Primary_Text: Yna äräm trnze yande äprnḡsmne toge.
Translated_Text: The man looked in vain for his lost son.
I looked for the key in vain.

Primary_Text: Är togam angan räms mñteba yakate.
Translated_Text: That boy likes singing.
The boy likes/loves the girl.
I will think of you tomorrow.
I was thinking of something last year (it took me a long time to figure it out).

Primary_Text: Ynd yta ele sermban bba närtan, ämb yao nen yingowndn.
Translated_Text: I went out hunting last night, but didn't find anything.

Primary_Text: Yna äräm gasa brbrba wetst yapapnda.
Translated_Text: That man is going to frighten the crocodile.
Come(PL) and look at yourselves/each other!
I looked at the flower.
We saw each other last year.
I saw myself yesterday (e.g. a picture of myself).
We'll see each other again tomorrow.
You saw us yesterday.
I saw him yesterday.

Primary_Text: Ynd mete te nämtendn, bä bä ynm.
Translated_Text: I knew he would come.
I know how to beat/work sago.

Primary_Text: Yna är sombes bä ybenzos mete yären.
Translated_Text: Those two men know each other.

Primary_Text: Yna är bä mete ym yna toge.
Translated_Text: The man knows that boy.

Primary_Text: Ynd Idaba yémtandn, yande/yanzo dmab dgan ym, kkpan o wrngan ym.
Translated_Text: I asked Idaba where his wife was, in the garden or in the forest.
I told him to go.

Primary_Text: Är togaepap zi aba nowabte mlegändemne.
Translated_Text: The man talked to the boy about the girl.
He is talking.
He told (me) a story.
Shout out to Blag for fish!

Primary_Text: Blag ternang mnegta sesat osns yao bä guñpanga.
Translated_Text: Shout out/command to Blag not to miss/skip church.
Shout at Blag (e.g. not to do something)!
You shout out to Blag because of the fish!

Primary_Text: Yao ämb zi aba nowabtan mlegeipap.
Translated_Text: I didn't say anything to the girl.
The man built a paperbark house.
One step of the ladder broke.
This wood breaks easily.
I broke a step of the ladder.
The boy killed the snake.

Primary_Text: Yna är bä ym ymam kanam ygmenda.
Translated_Text: This is the man who killed the snake.
I got hit on the shoulder.
The child hit/beat the snake with a stick.
I am touching myself on the nose.
The two poles are touching each other.
The boy touched the snake with a stick.

Primary_Text: Är togam mleg toge tndan enzanda.
Translated_Text: The boy touched the girl on the hand.
I cut a piece of your meat for myself.
He got cut. / He cut himself.
Comment: Still need to check definitively that this is different from nawañpanda

Translated_Text: I got/cut on the leg.
The two of them are cutting themselves/each other.
Comment: Some unclarity about the formation of the RR of this verb, since notes also give bä nañpt and bä näñpt for 'they 2 are cutting each other'

Translated_Text: I cut (up) the animal meat.
I wiped the mud off the mat.
I wiped the mud with the bark.
This bag got torn.
This bag tore.
He tore the handle from the bag.
The children hid.
He was about to steal/hide the food.

Primary_Text: Yndbem ganzan kp tengernitam depi ärbende brbrmne.
Translated_Text: We hid the sacred stones from the foreigners / for fear of the foreigners.

Primary_Text: Yna samban ärm ybenzo-ybenzos nne yrnitat.
Translated_Text: In that village people steal each other's food.

Primary_Text: Är togam yrninda ämb ärände nne.
Translated_Text: The boy stole a man's food.
I can hear the sound of a bamboo flute.
A man is carrying a pig.
This child took my knife.

Primary_Text: Yna togam yadmaepapngama wagib ykapanda a yanenda.
Translated_Text: The child got/took the fish from his mother.
He showed the two of them one coconut.
He showed them the coconut.

Primary_Text: Ynd sombes ärbet ämbs wagib yawaraman.
Translated_Text: I gave the two men a fish.
I gave the three men a fish.
That man showed (him) two coconuts.
Comment: Check this with 1sg recipient - looks like U prefix is indexing theme, not recipient

Translated_Text: She showed the fish to the teacher / to him.
She gave the teacher the fish (and it reached him).
She gave me a fish.
She gave me a fish.
She gave a fish to him (to the teacher).
I sent him away (for being bad).
Comment: Looks like this is a double-V construction; needs checking.

Translated_Text: We used to send each other letters.
I sent him (a letter).
I've already sent the letter.
Comment: Given in the context of saying 'the letter's already been sent', so the P is fronted here for discourse reasons.

Translated_Text: I'm sending it now.

Primary_Text: Ynd ḡénzér kp tande anaipap yngatembandn.
Translated_Text: I send the money to my brother.
He will take the child to him/her.
He took me to Morehead in a truck.
Bring the child to me!
Comment: This would be in the context of asking someone to lead the child - if the child were to be carried, this would be expressed by Toge tapap tnrenza, i.e. using the verb renzas 'bring'

Translated_Text: I brought it for you.
I brought/carried the book to the teacher.

Primary_Text: Ynd ḡénzér kp tuwitan smasma tltan.
Translated_Text: I threw a stone at the goanna and missed.

Primary_Text: Ynd ḡénzér kp tuwitan smasma tnamtan.
Translated_Text: I threw a stone at the goanna and hit it.

Primary_Text: Ynd ḡénzér kp wenda benama tuwitan kunzt.
Translated_Text: I threw the stone inside, through the window.
It's pouring out of the cup.
Comment: Illustrates that this is a biaspectual verb.

Translated_Text: The water has poured out of the cup.
He's trying to carry all those yams.
He poured the water out of the cup.
Start tying it!
I'm tying up both his hands.
The cup is full of water.
Comment: apsere is decomposable into root ap, nominaliser s, plus suffix -ere, not yet fully understood.

Primary_Text: Kmboke marete ws nu(ngama) apst pitas ym.
Translated_Text: The broad-necked bottle is easy to fill.

Primary_Text: Kmboke rkrk ws geym nu(ngama) apst korkorp ym.
Translated_Text: The small-necked bottle is difficult to fill.
Comment: (The neck isn't enough to let the water in). Suggests presence of a middle form of the verb, aps 'to fill (up)', but so far no finite verb attested.

Translated_Text: The cup has been filled with water.
Comment: Passive use of waps 'to fill'

Translated_Text: I'm about to cover myself.
I filled the cup with water.
The man covered the child with the mat.

Primary_Text: Petrus ke ǃqhao gao ng aanki.
Translated_Text: Petrus smells something in the food.
You steal from us.

Primary_Text: ǀoba ke gaake ǂoo si boeksi.
Translated_Text: The child steals the man's book.
Comment: given when asked for 'The child steals the book from the man.'

Primary_Text: A ha ǁʼaa ha ku ng nǀng: "tyuin xae a ..."
Translated_Text: He goes and says to me "What is this ..."
He says: "Beat (him), beat (him)!"
The woman pushed Piet.

Primary_Text: ǀeeki ke xa ǂʼhaqa ǁʼaa Piet.
Translated_Text: The woman pushed Piet (away).

Primary_Text: ǁʼuin ǁʼannʼa ke, ǂoo soo ng stoelsi.
Translated_Text: Yesterday the man sat on the chair.

Primary_Text: A net see ng hui ng nǀa oom gǁain.
Translated_Text: You must come and help me with Uncle Hyena.

Primary_Text: Siia ki a, jong, a saa hui ng ng kunisi a.
Translated_Text: Come here, boy, come and help me with this car!
I get dressed.
I put my clothes on.

Primary_Text: Na ǁu xa ǁxaea ku xa nǁaa ki a.
Translated_Text: I don't know (that) he stays here.

Primary_Text: Gǀa ǁqxʼam? - ja, na ǁqxʼam, man.
Translated_Text: Are you washing? - Yes, I am washing, man!
Then he falls.
He falls on the ground.
He hears I tell the truth.

Primary_Text: Ng ka ǃaruke hng si ǁhaa.
Translated_Text: My legs, they will break.
He is afraid.
The child hides the book.

Primary_Text: ǀoba ke ǀʼhoo ǁhoo boeksi nǀa ǂoo gǂii nǀaa ki.
Translated_Text: The child hides the book so that the man doesn't see it.
Comment: given when asked for 'The child hides the book from the man.'

Translated_Text: The child hides the book.
The child tears the book's page.
Comment: given when asked for 'The child tears the page from the book.'

Translated_Text: They have torn my new seats.

Primary_Text: A hau ǀai ng tya ǀaake he ha xng ǂqaua.
Translated_Text: Then she takes (some of) the crushed berries.

Primary_Text: Gǀa dyee ng ǀai ng nǀng?
Translated_Text: How (=why) do you touch me?

Primary_Text: Nǁngǃui ǀai ǁhau hoedsi ng nǁaa nǀaa.
Translated_Text: The person takes the hat off his head.
(He) takes it with his mouth.
Comment: We regard the INST as an adjunct, therefore the coding frame is given as A V P.

Primary_Text: Kua ǀai ǁhau gao ng nǁngǃui nǀaa.
Translated_Text: He takes the thing off the person's head.
They take the shoes.
He pounds them.
Push the chair towards him.
Comment: This example is difficult to analyze: there is definitely a suffix -a 2SG.IMP but it is likely that there is also the BEN suffix -a. Therefore, we decided to regard this as A V V(path) P plus BEN construction here, but it also could be seen as an example for the direct object-oblique object -> DAT-direct object alternation?!

Translated_Text: Push the chair towards me.
Comment: This example is difficult to analyze: there is definitely a suffix -a 2SG.IMP but it is likely that there is also the BEN suffix -a. Therefore, we decided to regard this as A V V(path) P plus BEN construction here, but it also could be seen as an example for the direct object-oblique object -> DAT-direct object alternation?!

Translated_Text: The woman pushed Geelman away.
He breaks off (?a piece of) the thornbush.
Comment: It is unclear whether the reading is partitive or not.

Primary_Text: Ng si ku ng ǀʼhuunsi a xa ǁʼae ǃkxʼabesi.
Translated_Text: I will say to the Boer (that) you went to the cream.
Does he like hunting?
He got frightened.
Look at me, I don't have a sleeping mat.
Then we also steal milk.
Do you hear? / Are you listening to me?

Primary_Text: Saaa a saa tyuu ng Masehupu guuke.
Translated_Text: Come and come (and) hear about this Masehupu-things!
Comment: The speaker wants her daughter to come and listen about some stories that another speaker tells about a place called Masehupu.

Translated_Text: I listen.
Comment: In contexts like 'I am waiting (to hear) what you have to say'.

Translated_Text: I don't understand them.

Primary_Text: Na xng tyuua ku xng ǃqaan.
Translated_Text: I have heard (that) she has moved.

Primary_Text: Na ǁam xa noxoba nǀaa kike, a ng neti tyuu ng kike.
Translated_Text: I haven't seen them yet, I only hear(d) about them.
Petrus heard the bird.

Primary_Text: ʘoe ke ǃxama ng ǂqoa ǁaʼen.
Translated_Text: The meat cooks in the pot.
Comment: We regard the oblique as an adjunct here.

Translated_Text: She cooks.
I cook the meat.
The water boils.
The pot boils.
It is the blood (that) is boiling.

Primary_Text: Gunn ngke ǀuun ǁʼng ng ki ǁʼannʼa.
Translated_Text: These things boil out on this side there.
Comment: Used in a context where meat is boilt, and worm come out of the meat.

Translated_Text: He boils the meat.

Primary_Text: A hng nou gǀoe kxʼuu gǃaasi ng Janniejannie.
Translated_Text: Then they also turn Janniejannie into a servant. / Then they also make Janniejannie become a servant.

Primary_Text: ǂoo ke kxʼuu nǁng nǀa ǀhee.
Translated_Text: The man builds a house with/from grass.

Primary_Text: A ng sii ng kxʼuu koffie.
Translated_Text: Then I come (and) make coffee.
I make you (look like) a flower. / I turn you into a flower.
Comment: During the initiation ceremony, the young girl's face is painted, to make it look like a flower.

Translated_Text: She makes a small hut.

Primary_Text: ǀoba xa mhoo ǂxanisi ng ǂoo.
Translated_Text: The child got the book from the man.
Everybody gets (a piece) of it (the bread).

Primary_Text: ... maar a ǁala moo gao ki ng nǀng.
Translated_Text: ... but you won't get this thing from me.

Primary_Text: Ai, ou nooi, na ǂaoa ǃkhaa ʘuni.
Translated_Text: Ay, missis, I want a little bit of water!
I want you to come.

Primary_Text: Ng ǂao ng kxʼuua nya ǂoa.
Translated_Text: I want to make a sleeping mat for myself.
Comment: 'X wants to verb' must be expressed by the construction 'Subj want Subj-pronoun verb'.

Translated_Text: They came and searched us.

Primary_Text: ... want ǀʼhuunsi ǁu xa ǂxaqake si.
Translated_Text: ... because the white man did not want us.
... but I would like to see (it).
Comment: 'X wants to verb' must be expressed by the construction 'Subj want Subj-pronoun verb'.

Translated_Text: ... because we want to get rain.
We look for thornbush gum.
They cry.

Primary_Text: ǂoo ke gǃai ǁhooa ǂxanisi ng tafelsi.
Translated_Text: The man has put down the book onto the table.
He puts the dish down.

Primary_Text: ǂoo ke xng ǁhooa boeksi ng tafelsi.
Translated_Text: The man put the book on(to) the table.

Primary_Text: Ha ǀai ng piri dyoo, ha ǁhoo.
Translated_Text: He takes the goat's hide, he puts it down.
Comment: treated as an example with an overtly unexpressed P, thus A V P

Primary_Text: ǂoo ke nǃao kunisi nǀa ǀhee.
Translated_Text: The man loads the cart with grass.

Primary_Text: Ku ǀai mandjiesi, ku nǃao ng baisikelsi.
Translated_Text: He takes the basket, he loads it onto the cart.
He loads his cart (with s.th.).
Comment: This examples occurred spontaneously and convincingly in a text. Nevertheless, later, when the speakers where asked to judge the example, they said it "would be better" to have the oblique marker ng before kuni-si.

Translated_Text: He loads the basket (here: onto his bicycle).
The man loads tsamma melons onto the cart.
The man loaded the cart with tsamma melons.

Primary_Text: Hng sii hng ǃʼhaun ǁuruke, hng sii ng ǃʼhaun ka nǂoqno.
Translated_Text: They come (and) sit down on the road, they come (and) sit down in the shade.
The man sits down on the chair.
We go (and) land in Olifantshoek.
Comment: Used for a plane that lands.

Translated_Text: Sit down here!
Then we sat down.
It (the old age) makes me sick / be in pain.

Primary_Text: Ku ke xng kxʼuu ǀʼaa ku.
Translated_Text: He killed himself.
Comment: Note that there is a separate verb ǀhaa (alternative form ǀhii) 'kill'; the causative use of 'die' in this example might be due to the reflexive meaning of the clause.

Translated_Text: It has/is burnt.
I dry (them).
Comment: Note that in Nǀuu pronouns (especially for direct objects) are often overtly unexpressed when they can be inferred from the context. The above example is thus regarded as A CAUS V P, even though there is no P expressed overtly.

Primary_Text: Ng ǀʼii ǁhoo ng ǁʼuin nǀa ha ǁoo.
Translated_Text: I put it in the sun so that it can dry / become dry.
It looks like dry eggs (lit. It looks like eggs which are dry.).
They (the clothes) will become dry quickly (just now).
The dry oryx hide.
Comment: This is a relative construction: 'The oryx skin which has dried / which is dry ... .'

Translated_Text: I am not the hyena.
She is a small ghost.

Primary_Text: Kinn xainki ke kxʼuu aan kike.
Translated_Text: Their mother feeds them.

Primary_Text: ǁʼae nya ǁʼau, ǁʼae nya ǁʼau nǁoqoke.
Translated_Text: I go and dig, I go and dig out wild potatoes.

Primary_Text: ǂoo ke ǂqau kiin ng vloersi.
Translated_Text: The man falls on the floor.
The child hits the snake with the stick.
I cut steekgras.

Primary_Text: ǀoba ke ǀai preesi nǀa nǂona.
Translated_Text: The child cuts the bread with the knife.
I don't smell anything.

Primary_Text: Gǀa ǁu nǀai ku xa aan a ǃkxʼabesi?
Translated_Text: Don't you see he has eaten your cream?

Primary_Text: U saa, u ǂaqe nǁngǂee ngke he nǁaa ki a.
Translated_Text: You come, you look at the people who are here.
The man looks at the child.
Then I eat.
We ate seeds.
The man eats the bread.

Primary_Text: ǀoba ke ǂamʼin ǀaqasi nǀa ǃʼoqoke.
Translated_Text: The child beats the snake with a stick.
I will beat you.
The Boer beats hyena.

Primary_Text: ǀoba ke ǁhaa venstersi nǀa ǃao.
Translated_Text: The child breaks the window with the stone.

Primary_Text: ǀoba ke ǀhaa ǀaqasi nǀa ǃʼoqoke.
Translated_Text: The child kills the snake with a stick.

Primary_Text: Gǁain ke xa ǀhaa a gǂarusi.
Translated_Text: The hyena has killed your sheep.

Primary_Text: A si ǁhaa ng ka khiin.
Translated_Text: You will break my legs.

Primary_Text: Dya kxʼuu nǁng ng ki a.
Translated_Text: We build a house here.
Comment: The oblique is regarded as an adjunct here.

Translated_Text: They burn that bull.
The fire burns me.

Primary_Text: Na xng ǂʼhubia ng ǀkxʼaa ng ǀʼii.
Translated_Text: I have burnt my hand in the fire.
Comment: We are not sure whether the oblique should be regarded as an argument or an adjunct here.

Translated_Text: The animal hide burns.
The man is hungry.
He is sad (lit. His heart is not tasty/well.).
They are sad (lit. Their hearts are sore.).
Then we play 'jackal' (= the jackal's game).
Comment: The children play a game where one of the children plays the jackal and chases the other children.

Primary_Text: ǀʼhuu ke si kxʼuu ʘʼuiʼi ng.
Translated_Text: The cold will make me sick.
The child feels cold.
I feel cold.
I feel cold.

Primary_Text: U ke si ǀʼaa ng ǁqann!
Translated_Text: You will die of hunger!
Comment: We regard the oblique cause as an adjunct here so we treat this as an example of S V.

Translated_Text: You will die.

Primary_Text: Gǀa ǁu nǀai oom ǀʼArusi ǂao ha ǀʼaa?
Translated_Text: Don't you see that uncle ǀʼArusi wants to die?
I have pain. / I am sick.
Our knees are sore.
Your knees are sore.
He laughs at the hyena.

Primary_Text: Ki a ke si xng ng ǀʼhoa ng Klapin.
Translated_Text: This is how we lived at Klapin.
We come and settle at Klapin.
We live on a farm.

Primary_Text: Hng tsee hng nǀaa, nǁngǂee ka nǁaa.
Translated_Text: They come and see: the people are (stay) there.

Primary_Text: ǀoba ke ka nǁaa ng nǀng nǁng.
Translated_Text: The child stays (lives) at my house.

Primary_Text: ǀoba ke ka nǁaa ng nǁng.
Translated_Text: The child stays (lives) at my house.
They stay (live) at the cattle post.
I stayed (lived) in town.

Primary_Text: Gǃae meid-e ke nǁaa ki a.
Translated_Text: The springbok girls stay (live) here.
I stay (live) at Antjie's house.
He has left the town.
He goes away.
The people go to the springboks.
We go to town.
He goes to that country.
I don't go home?

Primary_Text: Ng ǁu ǂheeke ǂhuu, a ng ǂheeke.
Translated_Text: I don't sing well but I sing (nevertheless).
The child jumps (up and down, again and again).
