Comment: The ka is probably a pluractional marker here.

Translated_Text: Then he (the springbok) jumps.
He sits in front of the house (lit. by the house's mouth = by the door).
I am sitting here.
Today I stay at home (lit. Today I sit at home.).
Grandpa, why are you sitting (around here)?

Primary_Text: Ng ǂao ng ǃae ǃare ng gǀa.
Translated_Text: I want to pass you (running). / I want to overtake you (running).
We run a race.
We run a race.
Comment: The -a is unclear, I don't think that it has anything to do with valency change. It might be either the ?PFV suffix ('We ran a race') or the unclear (maybe phonetically only) -a which often is heard on ǃae.

Translated_Text: We (go and) run down the dune.
He (goes and) runs into the house.
Run to the shop!
He runs.
We go and climb (up) the dune.
They climb (up) the tree.
Climb up!
He climbs up again.
Comment: might be analyzed as alternation SV <-> A V P, or just as an A V P construction with an overtly unexpressed object

Translated_Text: Then he climbs up the dune.

Primary_Text: ǂoo ǀkxʼui ǂʼunn glassi nǀa ǃkhaa.
Translated_Text: The man fills the glass with water.
Look, my bag is full!
The bag is full.
The cup is full now.
It is full.
Comment: This construction normally requires the STAT marker -a on the verb, but in this example it occurs without it.

Translated_Text: The meat is full of fat.
The milk is full of fat. / The milk is full of cream, creamy, rich.
His hands are full.

Primary_Text: ǂoo ke ǂʼunna xabasi ng ǃkhaa.
Translated_Text: The man filled the glass with water.
It is full.
He fills the bucket with berries.
He fills the bucket.

Primary_Text: ǂoo ke kxʼuu ǂʼunn glassi ng ǃkhaa.
Translated_Text: The man fills the glass with water.
He fills the other basket.
I fill it (e.g. the pot).
Comment: The preferred version is clearly the one without the CAUS marker kxʼuu.

Translated_Text: The pot is full.
Comment: The -a is probably the PFV/STAT suffix which appears with many stative verbs. It is thus regarded as a TAM suffix and not as a valency changing suffix (therefore the alternation is classified as uncoded). While some speakers always use the -a suffix in this context ('be full'), some others never use it, and others have free variation.

Primary_Text: ǂoo ke ǂʼunna glassi nǀa ng ǃkhaa.
Translated_Text: The man has filled the glass with water.
I cover it with ashes.
I will cover your face.
We cover the house.
It is covered.
Comment: 'The house('s roof) is covered with grass, it is now waterproof.'

Translated_Text: She is covered with the animal hide.
She is covered with/by the animal hide.
I cover her with a blanket.

Primary_Text: Ku ǂhaun ǀʼeea ǃkhaa ng ǂqoa, of ku ǂhaun ǁʼnga kike ng ǂqoa?
Translated_Text: Did he pour the water into the pot, or did he pour it out of the pot?

Primary_Text: Si see si ǂhaun ki ng nǁng tyuu.
Translated_Text: We come and pour it (the soil) at (= in front of) the door.

Primary_Text: Kua ǃxaua ǁxaan, ku ǁʼaa ku aa ǂooa i.
Translated_Text: He carried the bag, he goes and gives it to the man.
Comment: This example was given by F when asked for 'He carried the sack to the man.' It is a nice example that 'animate goal location arguments' are treated in a number of different ways. Here, F avoids both the Benefactive and the V V(path) alternation and rather splits the event constructions into two subevents in two clauses.

Primary_Text: A ke si ǃxaua na (i) ǁxaan.
Translated_Text: You must carry that bag for me (e.g. because it is too heavy for me).
Comment: This is an example of the Benefactive alternation which is productive and completely regular and therefore not included as an alternation in the database.

Primary_Text: ǀoba ke ǃxau ǁʼaa ǂhunn ʘuun ng ǂoo.
Translated_Text: The child carries the little dog to the man.
You throw the ball to me.
Comment: This alternation is actually coded here (see the BEN suffix -a on the verb); alternatively, one could also regard this as an example of A V P plus the regular and productive benefactive?!

Translated_Text: You must throw the ball to me!
Comment: This alternation is actually coded here (see the BEN suffix -a on the verb); alternatively, one could also regard this as an example of A V P plus the regular and productive benefactive?!

Primary_Text: ǂoo ke xng ǂaqbekea venstersi nǀa ng ǃao.
Translated_Text: The man threw a stone into/at the window.
Comment: The translation is the sentence which was to be translated by the speaker. Literally this means 'The man threw the window with a stone.'

Translated_Text: I throw the ball.
I throw the tsamma melon on the floor.
I throw the tsamma melon against the wall (lit. house).

Primary_Text: Na si ǀae ǁʼaa u nǀa ng ǂxanisi ng ǀkxʼain.
Translated_Text: I will send you to town with a letter.
I will send you a letter.

Primary_Text: Na ǀae ǁʼaa u ng ǀkxʼain.
Translated_Text: I send you to town.

Primary_Text: ǂoo ke si ǀae ǀobaa i ǂxanisi.
Translated_Text: The man sends the book for/to the child.
They send me food.

Primary_Text: Na si ǀae u nǀa ǂxanisi u ǁʼae gǃari.
Translated_Text: I will send you to town with a letter. (lit. I will send you with a letter, you go to town).
Comment: very artificial example from elicitation

Primary_Text: Aaa sa ng gunn a xa ǀʼee ng ǃabu!
Translated_Text: Give us some of these things (that) you put into the bowl!
Translation_Other: Ou vir ons van daai goet wat jy in die skottel ingesit het!

Primary_Text: ... nou a hu gǀoe aa na ng gǀa aanki.
Translated_Text: ... now you must also give me some of your food.
He gives him something.
He shows us the goats.
She jumps to this side.

Primary_Text: ǀoba ke ǂhuun ǁhoe ng ǂʼhai.
Translated_Text: The child jumps down from the tree.

Primary_Text: A ha ǂkhuun, a ha hala.
Translated_Text: Then he jumps, then he shows off.
Pour coffee for me!
Comment: The benefactive construction (with the BEN suffix -a) is very productive and thus not regarded as an alternation here. But there was no other good example in the corpus for ǂhaun in the coding frame A V P/X.

Primary_Text: ǂoo ke ǂhaun ǀʼee ǃkhaa ng glassi.
Translated_Text: The man pours water into the glass.
We tie up the bag's opening.

Primary_Text: ǂoo ke ǁʼngke haansi ng ǂʼhai.
Translated_Text: The man ties the horse to the tree.
We are afraid of the jackal.
You frighten your horse.

Primary_Text: A ke si ǃxau ǁʼae ǁhaan a ng gǃari.
Translated_Text: You must carry this bag to town.
The man says the truth to us.

Primary_Text: A ǁu si suin, a ǀkxʼaea dya gǀuuki.
Translated_Text: You should not sit and be telling lies to us.

Primary_Text: A ng nǀng ǀaeki, na ǃʼhoeʼa a.
Translated_Text: You are my wife, I asked for you.

Primary_Text: ǂoo ke ǃʼhoeʼin mari ng ǂoo a ko.
Translated_Text: The man asks the other man for money.
The hare comes and meets the hyena.
The man must meet the girl.
The man followed the girl.

Primary_Text: Na si hui a, ng ǀʼhuunsi.
Translated_Text: I will help you, my boss.
The man helps the woman.
He helps me.
The woman dresses the child.

Primary_Text: A kama noxoba ǂaasinn a ng broekesi.
Translated_Text: You are still wearing trousers.
She wipes me off, (she) dresses me.

Primary_Text: Ng ǂao ng nǁaa ng ǃxaike.
Translated_Text: I want to put on my clothes.

Primary_Text: Ku xainki ke si ǂaasinn ku.
Translated_Text: His (the child's) mother will dress him (the child).
We search berries.

Primary_Text: Ng ǂʼain u si xuu kike nǀa kinn maar nǁaa ǃʼaun.
Translated_Text: I think you must let them stay on the land.

Primary_Text: Gǀa ǂʼainka, ng si ka ǃkxʼora nǀa a?
Translated_Text: You think that I will play with you?

Primary_Text: Ng nǁae ǂʼainka, ng nǁann si tsʼii.
Translated_Text: I think my stomach will ache.
She knows the things.
The man knows the woman.
I really know myself.
The child likes the man.
I like meat.
The man frightens the child.

Primary_Text: A ke si ǃxau tya ǁhaan.
Translated_Text: You must carry that bag.
We send you a letter.
They give him blankets.
He gives the letter to the Boer.
It rains (lit. The rain rains.).
It rains (lit. The rain rains.).
I laugh about them.
I laugh.
The man coughs.

Primary_Text: ǃxaeka na ka ǃkxʼora nǀa ha.
Translated_Text: In the morning, I play with him.
Comment: We treated this as an example for S V because we regard the COM/INST 'with him' as an adjunct.

Translated_Text: We play.
He will die.
The child sings a song.
The young men sing.
Mummy, we got money!

Primary_Text: ǀoba ke hoo ǂoo si boeksi.
Translated_Text: The child gets the man's book.
Comment: This example was given when asked for 'The child gets the book from the man'.

Translated_Text: The child fears the man.

Primary_Text: A a si ǁʼae ǃauka ng nǀng.
Translated_Text: And you should be afraid of me.

Primary_Text: ǂoo ke ǃauka ng ǂoo a ko.
Translated_Text: The man is afraid of the other man.
It is dry.
He shows me the way.
And then you wash yourself.
Comment: Reflexive use of the verb.

Translated_Text: The woman washes the child.
The boy brought his brother water. /lit. The boy came with water to his brother.
The girl was afraid.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen fürchtete sich.

Translated_Text: The boy left the house.
Translation_Other: Der Junge verließ das Haus.

Translated_Text: The man told to his friend, that he is ill.
Comment:
Alternative construction to ex. 12. Utterance introduced by the conjunction ʾinna 'that'.
Unmarked adjectives for gender are masculine.
Translation_Other: Der Mann sagte seinem Freund, dass er krank sei.

Translated_Text: The boy brought the book to the girl. / The boy run with the book to the girl.
Translation_Other: Der Junge brachte das Buch zu dem Mädchen. / Der Junge rannte mit dem Buch zu dem Mädchen.

Translated_Text: The boy brought the book to the girl. / The boy went with the book to the girl.
Translation_Other: Der Junge brachte das Buch zu dem Mädchen. /Der Junge ging mit dem Buch zu dem Mädchen.

Translated_Text: The boy came to the house.
Translation_Other: Der Junge kam zu dem Haus.

Translated_Text: The boy came to the girl.
Translation_Other: Der Junge kam zu dem Mädchen.

Translated_Text: The boy brought the book to the girl.
Translation_Other: Der Junge brachte das Buch zu dem Mädchen.

Translated_Text: The girl is not sick.
Comment: With the copula laysa the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen ist nicht krank.

Translated_Text: The girl will be sick.
Comment: With the copula kāna the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen wird krank sein.

Translated_Text: The girl was sick.
Comment: With the copula kāna the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen war krank.

Translated_Text: The girl is sick.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen ist krank.

Translated_Text: The boy is not sad.
Comment:
With the copula laysa the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Unmarked adjectives for gender are masculine.
Translation_Other: Der Junge ist nicht traurig.

Translated_Text: The boy will be sad.
Comment:
With the copula kāna the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Unmarked adjectives for gender are masculine.
Translation_Other: Der Junge wird traurig sein.

Translated_Text: The boy was sad.
Comment:
With the copula kāna the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Unmarked adjectives for gender are masculine.
Translation_Other: Der Junge war traurig.

Translated_Text: The boy is sad.
Comment: Unmarked adjectives for gender are masculine.
Translation_Other: Der Junge ist traurig.

Translated_Text: The clothes are not dry.
Comment:
HUM.PL nouns take F.SG agreement.
With the copula laysa the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Translation_Other: Die Kleider sind nicht trocken

Translated_Text: The clothes will be dry.
Comment:
HUM.PL nouns take F.SG agreement.
With the copula kāna the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Translation_Other: Die Kleider werden trocken sein.

Translated_Text: The clothes were dry.
Comment: HUM.PL nouns take F.SG agreement.
Translation_Other: Die Kleider waren trocken.

Translated_Text: The clothes are dry.
Comment:
HUM.PL nouns take F.SG agreement.
With the copula kāna the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Translation_Other: Die Kleider sind trocken.

Translated_Text: The girl is not hungry.
Comment:
With the copula laysa the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Unmarked adjectives for gender are masculine.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen ist nicht hungrig.

Translated_Text: The boy will be hungry.
Comment:
With the copula kāna the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Unmarked adjectives for gender are masculine.
Translation_Other: Der Junge wird hungrig sein.

Translated_Text: The boy was hungry.
Comment:
With the copula kāna the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Unmarked adjectives for gender are masculine.
Translation_Other: Der Junge war hungrig.

Translated_Text: The boy is hungry.
Comment: Unmarked adjectives for gender are masculine.
Translation_Other: Der Junge ist hungrig.

Translated_Text: The boy is not a hunter.
Comment: With the copula laysa the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Translation_Other: Der Junge ist kein Jäger.

Translated_Text: The boy will be a hunter.
Comment: With the copula kāna the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Translation_Other: Der Junge wird ein Jäger sein.

Translated_Text: The boy was a hunter.
Comment: With the copula kāna the predicate noun phrase is marked by the accusative case.
Translation_Other: Der Junge war ein Jäger.

Translated_Text: The boy is a hunter.
Translation_Other: Der Junge ist ein Jäger.

Translated_Text: The boy felt cold.
Translation_Other: Dem Jungen war kalt. (=Er fühlte die Kälte.)

Translated_Text: The thief stole from the woman.
Translation_Other: Der Dieb stahl von der Frau.

Translated_Text: The thief stole from the women.
Translation_Other: Der Dieb stahl von der Frau. / Der Dieb bestahl die Frau.

Translated_Text: The mother cooked all day.
Comment: kulla lyawmi 'all day' can be omitted
Translation_Other: Die Mutter kochte den ganzen Tag.

Translated_Text: The man stole in front of our eyes.
Comment: 'in front of our eyes' can be omitted.
Translation_Other: Der Man stahl vor unseren Augen.

Primary_Text: Yanbašu lwaladu ḥafratan baḥt̠an ʿan ḫātimihi.
Translated_Text: The boy dug (by hand) a ditch, looking for his ring.
Comment: ḥafratan 'trench.F.ACC' is omittable.
Original_Orthography: ينبش الولد حفرة بحثا عن خاتمه
Translation_Other: Der Junge grub (mit den Händen) einen Graben, nach seinem Ring suchend.

Translated_Text: The boy digs.
Translation_Other: Der Junge gräbt.

Translated_Text: The boy digs.
Translation_Other: Der Junge gräbt.

Translated_Text: The boy ate.
Translation_Other: Der Junge aß.

Translated_Text: The soup was cooked quickly.
Comment: Passive of cook sth. (stem I)
Translation_Other: Die Suppe wurde schnell gekocht.

Translated_Text: The two boys met.
Translation_Other: Die beiden Jungen haben sich getroffen.

Translated_Text: The waves crushed.
Translation_Other: Die Wellen schlugen aufeinander.

Translated_Text: The water poured on the ground.
Translation_Other: Das Wasser floss / ergoss sich auf den Boden.

Translated_Text: The rope tore.
Translation_Other: Das Seil zerriss.

Translated_Text: The soldiers fought each other.
Comment: stem VI = 'kill/fight each other' derived from stem III verb of the same root
Translation_Other: Die Soldaten bekämpften sich gegenseitig.

Translated_Text: The policeman requested the protester to follow him.
Comment: requestative causative
Translation_Other: Der Polizist forderte den Demonstranten auf ihm zu folgen.

Translated_Text: The boy knew about the girl.
Translation_Other: Der Junge wusste von dem Mädchen.

Translated_Text: The boy heard about the song.
Translation_Other: Der Junge hat von dem Lied gehört.

Translated_Text: The girl knew the results of the exam.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen kannte die Ergebnisse der Prüfung.

Translated_Text: The girl knew the results of the exam.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen kannte die Ergebnisse der Prüfung.

Translated_Text: The teacher showed the book to the children.
Comment: ʾarâ 'show' causative of raʾâ 'see'
Translation_Other: Der Lehrer zeigte das Buch den Kindern.

Translated_Text: Onion has been cut.
Comment: passive of 'cut sth.'
Translation_Other: Zwiebeln wurden geschnitten.

Translated_Text: A strange man appeared in the door.
Translation_Other: In der Tür erschien ein merkwürdiger Mann.

Translated_Text: The man said a nice word.
Translation_Other: Der Mann hat ein schönes Wort gesagt.

Translated_Text: The man shaved.
Comment: This construction without accusative object is only used, if it is known from the context what was shaved (head, beard etc.), or if the speaker wants to stress the action and the shaved thing/person is insignificant for the communicative purpose.
Translation_Other: Der Mann rasierte sich.

Translated_Text: Zaid shouted " 'Amr". / Zaid called 'Amr to help.
Comment:
Here CAUS has a transitivising function.
The derivation has irregular semantics.
Translation_Other: Zayd schrie: " 'Amr." / Zayd rief 'Amr zur Hilfe.

Translated_Text: My friend disappeared for a long time. / My friend is hidden for a long time. / My friend hides himself for a long time.
Translation_Other: Mein Freund verschwand für lange Zeit. / Mein Freund ist versteckt für lange Zeit. / Mein Freund hat sich für lange Zeit versteckt.

Translated_Text: The thief hid behind a wall.
Translation_Other: Der Dieb versteckte sich hinter einer Mauer.

Translated_Text: His skin peels off because of the dryness.
Translation_Other: Seine Haut schält sich wegen der Trockenheit.

Translated_Text: The boy peeled some scales off the fish.
Translation_Other: Der Junge schuppte Fischschuppen von dem Fisch ab.

Translated_Text: The boy was peeling the orange.
Translation_Other: Der Junge schälte die Orange.

Primary_Text: Nazzaʿa lmuʿallimu lwalada waraqatan min kitābihi.
Translated_Text: The teacher made the boy tear out a page from his book.
Comment: causative and intensive meaning of stem I
Original_Orthography: نزع المعلم الولد ورقة من كتابه
Translation_Other: Der Lehrer ließ den Jungen eine Seite aus seinem Buch ausreißen.

Translated_Text: The boy took the book from his friend.
Translation_Other: Der Junge nahm das Buch von seinem Freund.

Translated_Text: A pool arose out of rain.
Comment:
derived from stem II.
verb: get.INT
Translation_Other: Aus dem Regen ergab sich / sammelte sich eine Lache.

Translated_Text: The writer collected many awards.
Translation_Other: Der Schriftsteller erhielt viele Auszeichnungen.

Primary_Text: Ḥaṣalat albintu ʿalâ kitābin min ʾummihā.
Translated_Text: The girl got a book from her mother.
Original_Orthography: حصل البنت على كتاب من أمها
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen bekam ein Buch von ihrer Mutter.

Translated_Text: The company produced cell phones.
Comment: intensive meaning of make
Translation_Other: Die Firma produzierte Handys.

Translated_Text: The boy made a table out of the wood.
Translation_Other: Der Junge machte aus dem Holz einen Tisch.

Translated_Text: He pretended to be mad.
Comment: simulative meaning of 'appear'
Translation_Other: Er gab vor verrückt zu sein.

Translated_Text: He showed his identity card.
Comment: show = appear + CAUS
Translation_Other: Er zeigte seinen Ausweis.

Translated_Text: My friend wants to go abroad (lit. My friend wants the trip to abroad.).
Translation_Other: Mein Freund will ins Ausland reisen. (wörtl. Mein Freund will die Reise ins Ausland.)

Translated_Text: The boy let the book fall from the table.
Translation_Other: Der Junge ließ das Buch vom Tisch fallen.

Translated_Text: The boy fell from the wall.
Translation_Other: Der Junge fiel von der Mauer.

Translated_Text: He feigned crying in front of his father.
Translation_Other: Er tat vor seinem Vater so, als würde er weinen.

Translated_Text: He made his friend cry.
Translation_Other: Er brachte seinen Freund zum Weinen.

Translated_Text: The girl was crying in pain.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen weinte vor Schmerz.

Translated_Text: The mother cooked a delicious meal.
Translation_Other: Die Mutter kochte ein köstliches Essen.

Translated_Text: The boy let the girl listen to a song.
Translation_Other: Der Junge ließ das Mädchen einem Lied zuhören.

Translated_Text: The boy made the girl listen to a song.
Comment: causative and intensive meaning
Translation_Other: Der Junge ließ das Mädchen einem Lied zuhören / zwang das Mädchen einem Lied zuzuhören.

Translated_Text: The boy heard the song of his mother.
Translation_Other: Der Junge hörte das Lied seiner Mutter.

Primary_Text: Istaʿlama ṣṣuḥūfiyu min zamīlihi binatāʾiǧi lʾintiḫābāti.
Translated_Text: The journalist informed his colleague about the results of the elections.
Original_Orthography: استعلم الصحوفي من زميله بنتائج الأنتخابات
Translation_Other: Der Journalist informierte seinen Kollegen über die Ergebnisse der Wahlen.

Translated_Text: Umar pretended to be clever in front of Zayd.
Comment: derived from stem I of the same root with the meaning 'know'
Translation_Other: Umar spielte den Klugen vor Zayd (= Er täuschte Klugheit vor.).

Translated_Text: The student learned the lesson from the book.
Translation_Other: Der Student lernte die Lektion aus dem Buch.

Translated_Text: The journalist informed his colleague about the results of the elections.
Translation_Other: Der Journalist informierte seinen Kollegen über die Ergebnisse der Wahlen.

Translated_Text: The woman taught the girl a song.
Translation_Other: Die Frau brachte dem Mädchen ein Lied bei.

Translated_Text: The money was stolen.
Translation_Other: Das Geld wurde gestohlen.

Translated_Text: The thief stole the money from the woman.
Translation_Other: Der Dieb stahl das Geld von der Frau.

Translated_Text: The girl brought the book to the teacher.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen brachte das Buch zum Lehrer.

Translated_Text: The army was pushed out of Baghdad.
Translation_Other: Die Armee wurde aus Bagdad herausgedrängt.

Translated_Text: The travelers have been jostling at the door of the aircraft (= push each other).
Translation_Other: Die Reisenden haben vor der Tür des Flugzeuges gedrängelt (= schubsten einander).

Translated_Text: The boy pushed the girl into the lake.
Translation_Other: Der Junge schubste das Mädchen in den See.

Translated_Text: The trench was excavated.
Translation_Other: Der Graben wurde ausgegraben.

Primary_Text: Yaḥfaru lwaladu ḥafratan baḥt̠an ʿan ald̠ahabi.
Translated_Text: The boy digs a trench (searching) for gold.
Comment: ḥafratan 'trench.F.ACC' is omissible
Original_Orthography: يحفر الولد حفرة بحث عن الذهب
Translation_Other: Der Junge gräbt einen Graben, nach Gold suchend.

Translated_Text: The boy digs a trench.
Comment: without any instrument, i.e. with his hands or foot
Translation_Other: Der Junge gräbt einen Graben.

Translated_Text: The dog rubbed against the tree.
Comment: derived from stem II with the same meaning like the stem I verb masaḥa 'wipe, rub'
Translation_Other: Der Hund rieb sich an dem Baum.

Translated_Text: The girl (strongly) wiped her hands with the handkerchief.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen wischte sich ihre Hände (kräftig) mit dem Taschentuch ab.

Translated_Text: The girl wiped the dirt from the table.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen wischte den Schmutz von dem Tisch.

Translated_Text: The women ground the seeds with the pestle.
Translation_Other: Die Frauen zermahlten die Körner mit dem Stößel.

Translated_Text: He was burning with fear of the enemy.
Comment: alternative construction to ex. 156
Translation_Other: Er brannte vor Angst vor dem Feind.

Translated_Text: The army burned the ship of the enemy. (intensive).
Comment: derived from stem I 'burn sth.'
Translation_Other: Die Armee verbrannte das Schiff des Feindes. (intensive Bedeutung)

Translated_Text: The house is burning.
Comment: derived from ḥariqa (I) 'burn sth.'
Translation_Other: Das Haus brennt.

Translated_Text: The army sank the ship of the enemy.
Translation_Other: Die Armee versenkte das Schiff des Feindes.

Translated_Text: The army sank the ship of the enemy.
Translation_Other: Die Armee versenkte das Schiff des Feindes.

Translated_Text: The ship sank into the ocean.
Translation_Other: Das Schiff sank in den Ozean.

Translated_Text: The ball rolled on the ground.
Translation_Other: Der Ball rollte auf dem Boden.

Translated_Text: I'm hungry.
Comment: Unmarked adjectives for gender are masculine.
Translation_Other: Ich habe Hunger.

Translated_Text: I am sad.
Translation_Other: Ich bin traurig.

Translated_Text: The Egyptian president manipulated the results of the election.
Translation_Other: Der ägyptische Präsident manipulierte die Ergebnisse der Wahlen.

Translated_Text: The girl played with her brother.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen spielte mit ihrem Bruder.

Translated_Text: The thief pretended to be dead in front of the police.
Comment: simulative meaning of the stem I verb DIE
Translation_Other: Der Dieb stellte sich tot vor der Polizei.

Translated_Text: The man killed the thief.
Translation_Other: Der Mann tötete den Dieb.

Translated_Text: The man killed the thief.
Translation_Other: Der Mann tötete den Dieb.

Translated_Text: He was cold. (= he felt cold).
Comment: bard 'cold' = noun
Translation_Other: Ihm war kalt. (=Er fühlte die Kälte.)

Translated_Text: The woman hurt the boy with her words.
Comment: Stem II verb 'hurt' derived from stem I ʾalima 'feel pain', that is out of use.
Translation_Other: Die Frau verletzte den Jungen mit ihren Worten.

Translated_Text: The boy's hand hurts. lit. 'The hand causes the boy to hurt'.
Comment: ʾālama (stem IV) آلم derived from stem I verb I ʾalima 'feel pain', that is out of use.
Translation_Other: Seine Hand tut dem Jungen weh.

Translated_Text: He feels pain in his hand (= his hand hurts).
Comment: taʾallama (V) 'feel pain' is derived from ʾallama (II) 'cause pain'.
Translation_Other: Seine Hand tut ihm weh.

Translated_Text: The mother boils water for tea.
Translation_Other: Die Mutter kocht Wasser für Tee.

Translated_Text: The water boils.
Translation_Other: Das Wasser kocht.

Translated_Text: It rained (lit. The sky rained.).
Translation_Other: Es regnete (wörtl. Der Himmel regnete.).

Primary_Text: Fī tilka ssanati ʾamṭarat fī ʾaylūlin.
Translated_Text: That year it rained in September.
Comment:
The subjects of the verb can be omitted only in case of anaphoric or contextual ellipsis.
Alternative construction to ex. 138.
Original_Orthography: في تلك السنة أمطرت في أيلول
Translation_Other: In jenem Jahr regnete es im September.

Translated_Text: The girl cried because of fear.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen schrie vor Angst.

Translated_Text: His friend made him laugh (against his will).
Translation_Other: Sein Freund brachte ihn zum Lachen (gegen seinen Willen).

Translated_Text: The children laughed about their teacher together.
Comment: taḍāḥaka (VI) derived from ḍāḥ̣aka (IIII) 'joke'
Translation_Other: Die Kinder lachten zusammen über ihren Lehrer.

Translated_Text: He made him laugh with his talk.
Translation_Other: Er hat ihn mit seiner Rede zum Lachen gebracht.

Translated_Text: He made him laugh a lot with his talk.
Comment: Causative and intensive meaning of stem I verb of the same root.
Translation_Other: Er hat ihn mit seiner Rede sehr zum Lachen gebracht.

Translated_Text: The child laughed about you.
Comment: alternative construction to ex. 130
Translation_Other: Das Kind lachte über dich.

Translated_Text: The child laughed about you.
Translation_Other: Das Kind lachte über dich.

Translated_Text: The Muslims and Christians lived together in Egypt.
Comment: taʿāyaša (VI) derived from ʿāyaša (III) <NOM ACC> 'live with so.'.
Translation_Other: Die Muslime und die Christen lebten in Ägypten zusammen.

Translated_Text: He let his friend live at his expense.
Translation_Other: Er ließ seinen Freund auf seine Kosten leben.

Translated_Text: My girlfriend lived in Qairo for a year.
Translation_Other: Meine Freundin lebte ein Jahr in Kairo.

Translated_Text: The boy has gone to the capital.
Comment: here ġādara with the meaning 'leave for GOAL'
Translation_Other: Der Junge ist in die Hauptstadt abgereist.

Translated_Text: The boy left the house.
Translation_Other: Der Junge verließ das Haus.

Translated_Text: The mother made the boy go to the market.
Original_Orthography: أذهبت ال أم لاولد إلى السوق
Translation_Other: Die Mutter ließ den Jungen zum Markt gehen.

Translated_Text: The boy went to the market.
Translation_Other: Der Junge ging zum Markt.

Translated_Text: The mother sang a song for her child.
Translation_Other: Die Mutter sang ein Lied für ihr Kind.

Translated_Text: The mother sang.
Translation_Other: Die Mutter sang.

Primary_Text: Qafaza ṭṭiflu min aššaǧarati ʿalâ lʾarḍi.
Translated_Text: The child jumped from the tree to the ground.
Original_Orthography: قفز الطفل من الشجرة إلى الأرض
Translation_Other: Das Kind sprang vom Baum auf den Boden.

Translated_Text: He let his guests sit on chairs.
Comment: This causative can have permissive or coercive meaning - depending on the context.
Translation_Other: Er ließ seine Gäste auf Stühlen sitzen.

Translated_Text: He sat (down) in a cafe with his friend.
Translation_Other: Er saß in einem Café mit seinem Freund. / Er hat sich mit seinem Freund in einem Café hingesetzt.

Translated_Text: The Egyptian government ran new elections.
Translation_Other: Die ägyptische Regierung veranstaltete Neuwahlen. (=ließ laufen)

Translated_Text: He let him run to/into the house.
Comment: uncommon
Translation_Other: Er ließ ihn zum/in das Haus laufen.

Translated_Text: The frightened boy ran into the house.
Translation_Other: Der erschrockene Junge lief ins Haus.

Translated_Text: The boy climbed up the tree.
Translation_Other: Der Junge kletterte auf den Baum.

Translated_Text: The man coughed.
Translation_Other: Der Mann hustete.

Translated_Text: The girl blinked.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen blinzelte.

Translated_Text: The child covered itself with the blanket.
Translation_Other: Das Kind hat sich mit der Decke zugedeckt.

Translated_Text: The man covered the child with the blanket.
Translation_Other: Der Mann deckte das Kind mit einer Decke zu.

Translated_Text: The sweat dripped from his forehead.
Translation_Other: Der Schweiß troff von seiner Stirn.

Translated_Text: The water was poured into the glass.
Translation_Other: Das Wasser wurde in das Glas gegossen.

Translated_Text: The man poured water into the glass.
Translation_Other: Der Mann goss Wasser ins Glas.

Translated_Text: The man put the book on the table.
Translation_Other: Der Mann legte das Buch auf den Tisch.

Translated_Text: The poverty and illiteracy in Egypt are related (to each other).
Translation_Other: Die Armut und der Analphabetismus in Ägypten hängen zusammen.

Primary_Text: Hal irtabaṭat almuẓāharātu fī lʿirāq bilʾintiḫābāti?
Translated_Text: Were the demonstrations in Iraq related to the elections? (= Were the demonstrations triggered by the elections?)?
Original_Orthography: هل ارتبطت المظاهرات في العراق بالإنتخابات
Translation_Other: Hatten die Demonstrationen im Irak eine Verbindung mit den Wahlen? (= Wurden die Demonstrationen durch die Wahlen ausgelöst?)

Primary_Text: Rabaṭa rraǧulu lḥisāna ʾilâ ššaǧarati biḥablin.
Translated_Text: The man tied the horse to the tree with a rope.
Original_Orthography: ربط الرجل الحسان إلى الشجرة بالحبل
Translation_Other: Der Mann band das Pferd mit einem Seil an den Baum.

Translated_Text: The son threw himself into the arms of his mother.
Translation_Other: Der Sohn warf sich in die Arme seiner Mutter.

Translated_Text: The protesters and the police threw stones at each other.
Translation_Other: Die Demonstranten und die Polizei bewarfen sich mit Steinen.

Translated_Text: The boy threw a stone into the window.
Comment:
In this sentence ʿalâ nnāfid̠ati 'into the window' is stressed.
It is an alternative construction to ex. 98 and ex. 99.
Translation_Other: Der Junge warf einen Stein ins Fenster.

Translated_Text: The boy threw a stone into the window.
Translation_Other: Der Junge warf einen Stein ins Fenster.

Translated_Text: The boy threw a stone into the window.
Comment: In this sentence biḥaǧarin 'with a stone' is stressed.
Translation_Other: Der Junge warf einen Stein ins Fenster.

Translated_Text: The man loaded the truck with hay.
Translation_Other: Der Mann hat das Heu auf den Wagen geladen.

Translated_Text: The man loaded the truck with hay.
Comment: partitive meaning
Translation_Other: Der Mann hat das Heu auf den Wagen geladen.

Translated_Text: The man loaded the truck with hay.
Comment: holistic meaning
Translation_Other: Der Mann hat den Wagen mit Heu beladen.

Translated_Text: His friend has to carry the expenses (lit. It is on his friend, that he carries the expenses.).
Comment: the preposition ʿalâ 'on' is often used with the meaning 'have to /must'
Translation_Other: Sein Freund muss die Kosten tragen (wörtl. Auf seinem Freund ist, dass er die Kosten trägt.).

Translated_Text: The man loaded the camel with hay.
Comment: holistic meaning
Translation_Other: Der Mann hat das Kamel mit Heu beladen.

Translated_Text: The man loaded the hay on the camel.
Comment: partitive meaning
Translation_Other: Der Mann hat das Heu auf das Kamel geladen.

Translated_Text: My father carried my luggage to the car.
Translation_Other: Mein Vater trug mein Gepäck zum Wagen.

Translated_Text: The boy and his girlfriend were corresponding with each other secretly.
Comment: tarāsala (VI.) is a reciprocal to rāsala (III) 'to correspond'
Translation_Other: Der Junge und seine Freundin korrespondierten heimlich miteinander.

Translated_Text: The girl sent the book to the teacher.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen schickte das Buch dem Lehrer.

Translated_Text: The girl showed the book to the teacher.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen zeigte das Buch dem Lehrer.

Translated_Text: The girl gave the book to the teacher.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen gab das Buch dem Lehrer.

Translated_Text: The girl gave the book to the teacher.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen gab das Buch dem Lehrer.

Translated_Text: The girl hid the book from the teacher.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen versteckte das Buch vor dem Lehrer.

Translated_Text: The girl tore the page from the book.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen riss eine Seite aus dem Buch.

Translated_Text: Onion has been cut (into pieces).
Comment: The derivation takes place from stem II: 'cut sth. into pieces'
Translation_Other: Die Zwiebeln wurden (ganz klein) geschnitten.

Translated_Text: My mother cut onions for the soup.
Comment: intensive meaning of stem I
Translation_Other: Meine Mutter schnitt Zwiebeln für die Suppe.

Translated_Text: The child cut into his hand deeply with the knife.
Comment: a stem II verb. It has the intensive meaning of the stem I verb: CUT
Translation_Other: Das Kind schnitt sich mit dem Messer tief in seine Hand.

Translated_Text: The boy cut the bread with the knife.
Translation_Other: Der Junge schnitt das Brot mit dem Messer.

Translated_Text: The man groped his way in the dark.
Comment:
only semantic change.
Derivation takes place as follows: lamasa 'touch sth.' (I) > talammasa 'to grope sth.' (V). Stem II verb of the same root does not exist.
Translation_Other: Der Mann ertastete seinen Weg in der Dunkelheit.

Translated_Text: Your hands touched (each other).
Translation_Other: Eure Hände haben sich berührt.

Translated_Text: The boy touched the snake with the stick.
Translation_Other: Der Junge berührte die Schlage mit dem Stock.

Translated_Text: The ship collided with the waves.
Translation_Other: Das Schiff stieß mit den Wellen zusammen.

Translated_Text: The two boys hit each other.
Comment: talāṭama (hit with hand or head)
Translation_Other: Die zwei Jungen haben sich geschlagen.

Primary_Text: Laṭama lwaladu lbinta biyadihi ʿalâ waǧhihā.
Translated_Text: The boy hit the girl with his hand on her face.
Comment: laṭama = hit with hand or head
Original_Orthography: لطم الولد البنت بيده على وجهها
Translation_Other: Der Junge schlug das Mädchen mit seiner Hand ins Gesicht (Er hat ihr eine Ohrfeige gegeben.).

Translated_Text: The boxers beat each other outside of the battle arena.
Comment: taḍāraba (VI) derived from ḍāraba (III) 'fight with so.' <NOM ACC>
Translation_Other: Die Boxer schlugen einander außerhalb der Kampfarena.

Translated_Text: The boy beat the snake with the stick .
Translation_Other: Der Junge schlug die Schlange mit dem Stock.

Translated_Text: He fought/killed his rivals (and they fought him). / He fought with his rivals.
Comment: VIII.stem = fight/kill
Translation_Other: Er kämpfte mit seinen Gegnern. / Er tötete seine Gegner./ Er bekämpfte sich mit seinen Gegnern.

Translated_Text: He fought his rivals (and they fought him).
Comment: Stem VI = fight (not kill), derived from stem III of the same root.
Translation_Other: Er und seine Gegner bekämpften einander.

Translated_Text: He fought against his rivals.
Comment: Stem III = fight (not kill), derived from stem I of the same root (KILL) with a repetitive meaning of the base stem.
Translation_Other: Er bekämpfte seine Gegner.

Translated_Text: The king slaughtered his people.
Comment: stem II verb derived from stem I of the same root. It forms a verb with an intensive meaning of the base verb: kill (I) > slaughter (II)
Translation_Other: Der König hat sein Volk niedergemetzelt.

Translated_Text: Amr and his friend hugged each other.
Translation_Other: Amr und sein Freund umarmten sich.

Translated_Text: The glass was broken. / The glass broke.
Translation_Other: Das Glas wurde zerbrochen. / Das Glas zerbrach.

Translated_Text: The glass broke into pieces.
Comment: anticausative of the stem II verb: 'break sth. into pieces'
Translation_Other: Das Glas zerbrach in Stücke.

Translated_Text: The boy broke the glass in pieces.
Comment: stem II verb kassara 'break sth. into pieces' derives the intensive meaning of the stem I verb: BREAK
Translation_Other: Der Junge zerbrach das Glas in kleine Stücke.

Translated_Text: The mother let her neighbour shout at the thief.
Translation_Other: Die Mutter ließ ihre Nachbarn den Dieb anschreien.

Translated_Text: The mother washed her son thoroughly.
Comment:
Stem II verb with no valency change only semantic alternation: intensive meaning of the stem I verb of the same root: WASH
ġassala derived from ġusl (Islamic ritual body washing)
often used in context of washing of the body of the dead before burial
Translation_Other: Die Mutter hat ihren Sohn gründlich gewaschen.

Translated_Text: The boy broke the window with the stone.
Translation_Other: Der Junge brach das Fenster mit dem Stein.

Translated_Text: The house was built on weak foundations.
Translation_Other: Das Haus wurde auf schwachem Fundament gebaut.

Translated_Text: He was named Muhammad.
Translation_Other: Er wurde Muhammad genannt.

Translated_Text: The mother named her child Muhammad.
Translation_Other: Die Mutter nannte ihr Kind Muhammad.

Translated_Text: Umar and his friend met in a cafeteria.
Translation_Other: Umar und sein Freund trafen sich in einer Cafeteria.

Translated_Text: The police interrogated the man all day long.
Comment:
stem III verb with only semantic alternation (no valency change)
repetitive meaning of the stem I verb of the same root ASK
Translation_Other: Die Polizei befragte den Mann den ganzen Tag.

Translated_Text: The man asked himself what will happen to him.
Translation_Other: Der Mann fragte sich, was mit ihm geschehen wird.

Primary_Text: Takallama rraǧulu maʿa lwaladi ʿalâ albinti.
Translated_Text: The man talked to the boy about the girl.
Comment: alternative construction to ex. 53
Original_Orthography: تكلم الرجل مع الولد على البنت
Translation_Other: Der Mann sprach mit dem Jungen über das Mädchen.

Primary_Text: Takallama rraǧulu maʿa lwaladi ʿan albinti.
Translated_Text: The man talked to the boy about the girl.
Original_Orthography: تكلم الرجل مع الولد عن البنت
Translation_Other: Der Mann sprach mit dem Jungen über das Mädchen.

Translated_Text: The events followed quickly one after another.
Comment: HUM.PL noun phrases take F.SG agreement
Translation_Other: Die Ereignisse folgten schnell aufeinander.

Translated_Text: The police made a detective follow the terrorist.
Translation_Other: Die Polizei ließ einen Detektiv den Terroristen verfolgen.

Translated_Text: The man followed the girl.
Translation_Other: Der Mann folgte dem Mädchen.

Translated_Text: The man helped his son with his work.
Comment:
alternative: sāʿada rraǧulu ʾibnahu ʿalâ ʿamalihi
'the man supported his son in his work'
Translation_Other: Der Mann half seinem Sohn bei der Arbeit.

Translated_Text: The man shaved his beard.
Translation_Other: Der Mann hat sich seinen Bart rasiert.

Translated_Text: The boy washed (himself).
Translation_Other: Der Junge wusch sich.

Primary_Text: Tabāḥat̠a lwazīru lfilisṭīniyu walwazīru lmiṣriyu ʾirtifāʿa lʿasāri.
Translated_Text: The Palestinian and the Egyptian Prime Minister discussed the increase of prices.
Original_Orthography: تباحث الوزير الفلسطيني والوزير المصري إرتفاع العيار
Translation_Other: Der palästinensische und der ägyptische Ministerpräsident diskutierten (miteinander) über die Erhöhung der Preise.

Primary_Text: Taḥabbaba rraʾīsu ʾilâ šaʿabihi fī ḫiṭābihi lʾāḫiri.
Translated_Text: The president made himself popular with his people through his last speech.
Comment: Taḥabbaba (V) reflexive to ḥabbaba (II) 'make so. like so./sth.'
Original_Orthography: تحبب الرئيس ألى شعبه في خطاته الآخر
Translation_Other: Der Präsident machte sich beliebt bei seinem Volk mit seiner letzten Rede.

Translated_Text: France feared an economic crisis.
Translation_Other: Frankreich befürchtete eine wirtschaftliche Krise.

Translated_Text: The car has been eaten away by rust.
Translation_Other: Das Auto wurde vom Rost zerfressen.

Translated_Text: He dressed for the trip.
Comment: to dress for something (an event)
Translation_Other: Er kleidete sich für die Reise.

Translated_Text: He was possessed by a spirit.
Comment: It can be interpreted as passive of dress so. as well
Translation_Other: Er war von einem Geist besessen. (wörtl. Er wurde von einem Geist 'angezogen' ~ wie ein Kleid.).

Translated_Text: The boy hid the truth from his father (lit. The boy dressed (=covered) the truth from his father.).
Comment: metaphorical use
Translation_Other: Der Junge versteckte die Wahrheit vor seinem Vater (wörtl. Der Junge bekleidete (=versteckte) die Wahrheit vor seinem Vater.).

Translated_Text: The girl dressed the child.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen bekleidete das Kind.

Translated_Text: The mother thought about her children.
Translation_Other: Die Mutter dachte an ihre Kinder.

Translated_Text: Zaid and Amr got to know each other.
Translation_Other: Zaid und Amr haben sich kennen gelernt.

Translated_Text: The man informed the police about what has happened.
Translation_Other: Der Mann informierte die Polizei darüber, was passierte.

Translated_Text: Love each other because of God!
Comment: tradition of the Prophet (s.)
Translation_Other: Liebt einander um Gottes Willen!

Primary_Text: Ḥabbaba rraǧulu biḥadīt̠ihi liʾibnihi ssafara ʾilâ lḫāriǧi.
Translated_Text: With his narration the man made the trip abroad desirable for his son.
Original_Orthography: حبب الرجل بحديثه لإبنه السفر إلى الخارج
Translation_Other: Mit seiner Erzählung machte der Mann die Reise ins Ausland für seinen Sohn attraktiv.

Translated_Text: The boy likes his new toy.
Translation_Other: Der Junge mag sein neues Spielzeug.

Translated_Text: The girl frightened the child.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen erschreckte das Kind.

Translated_Text: The girl scared the child.
Comment: causative and intensive meaning (stem II)
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen erschreckte das Kind sehr.

Translated_Text: The thief made the policeman smell the drug.
Translation_Other: Der Dieb ließ den Polizisten an der Droge riechen.

Primary_Text: Inzalaqa raʾsī ʿalâ katifihā wašamamtu rāʾihata ssutrati ṣṣūfīyati lbayḍāʾ.
Translated_Text: My head slipped on her shoulder and I smelled the white woollen jacket.
Original_Orthography: أنزلق رأسي على كتفها وشممت رائحة السترة الصوفية البيضاء
Translation_Other: Mein Kopf fiel auf ihre Schulter und ich roch die weiße Wolljacke.

Translated_Text: He showed himself happy for the people./ He pretended to be happy to the people.
Comment: with simulative meaning.
Translation_Other: Er zeigte sich für die Menschen froh. / Er täuschte Fröhlichkeit vor.

Translated_Text: The two boys saw each other. / The two boys met each other.
Comment: The verb can have the 3SG form and does not need to agree with the dual subject if it precedes it.
Translation_Other: Die zwei Jungen sahen einander. / Die zwei Jungen trafen sich.

Translated_Text: Why don't you go out and show me yourself?
Translation_Other: Warum gehst du nicht heraus und zeigst dich mir?

Translated_Text: We looked at each other.
Comment: This is only a marginal meaning. The broader meaning is 'to discuss'.
Translation_Other: Wir haben uns gegenseitig angeschaut.

Translated_Text: We hugged each other.
Translation_Other: Wir umarmten uns.

Translated_Text: The mother hugged her child.
Translation_Other: Die Mutter umarmte ihr Kind.

Translated_Text: The man fed the child with bread.
Translation_Other: Der Mann fütterte das Kind mit Brot.

Translated_Text: The man filled the glass with water.
Translation_Other: Der Mann füllte das Glas mit Wasser.

Translated_Text: My father built a house out of (the) wood.
Translation_Other: Mein Vater baute ein Haus aus (dem) Holz.

Translated_Text: The mother shouted at her children.
Translation_Other: Die Mutter schrie ihre Kinder an.

Translated_Text: The boy asked his friends for money.
Translation_Other: Der Junge bat seinen Freund um Geld.

Translated_Text: The man died in a hospital.
Translation_Other: Der Mann starb in einem Krankenhaus.

Translated_Text: The boy told the girl a story.
Translation_Other: Der Junge erzählte dem Mädchen eine Geschichte.

Translated_Text: The boy told the girl a story.
Translation_Other: Der Junge erzählte dem Mädchen eine Geschichte.

Translated_Text: Did your mother meet her friend?
Translation_Other: Hat deine Mutter ihre Freundin getroffen?

Translated_Text: The girl washed the child.
Translation_Other: Das Mädchen wusch das Kind.

Translated_Text: The man said to his friend: "my wife is at home".
Original_Orthography: قال الرجل لصديقه مرأتي في البيت
Translation_Other: Der Mann sagte zu seinem Freund: "Meine Frau ist zu Hause."

Translated_Text: The boy killed the snake with the stick.
Translation_Other: Der Junge tötete die Schlange mit dem Stab.

Translated_Text: The man searched for the boy.
Translation_Other: Der Mann suchte nach dem Jungen.

Translated_Text: The man saw the child.
Translation_Other: Der Mann sah das Kind.

Translated_Text: The boy looked at the man.
Translation_Other: Der Junge schaute den Mann an.

Translated_Text: The boy ate the apple.
Translation_Other: Der Junge aß den Apfel.

Translated_Text: And you aren't afraid of death like us?
Translation_Other: Und du fürchtest dich nicht vor dem Tod, wie wir?

Translated_Text: Aren't you afraid of the war?
Translation_Other: Fürchtest du dich nicht vor dem Krieg?

Translated_Text: The boy knew the girl.
Translation_Other: Der Junge kannte das Mädchen.

Translated_Text: The glass filled up with water.
Translation_Other: Das Glas füllte sich mit Wasser.

Translated_Text: The man filled the glass with water.
Comment: e.g. draw the water with the glass out of something
Translation_Other: Der Mann füllte das Glas mit Wasser

Translated_Text: The man filled the glass with water.
Comment: e.g. by pouring something in it
Translation_Other: Der Mann füllte das Glas mit Wasser.

Translated_Text: The girl is busy making bread.
The girl washed herself.
The boy is busy following the girl.
The girl is busy throwing apples from the tree.
Comment: The antipassive is derived from the causative form 'cause to fall'.

Translated_Text: The girl is busy filling the bucket with the water.
The girl is busy boiling the water.
Comment: The antipassive of BOIL is derived from the causative form 'cause to boil'.

Translated_Text: The girl is busy drying her hair with the hair-drier.
Comment: The antipassive of BE DRY is derived from causative 'cause to be dry'.

Translated_Text: The boy is busy leaving the village.
The girl is busy learning the lessons.
The girl is busy pushing the boy.
The girl is busy laughing.
The girl is busy showing the mother.
Comment: The antipassive of SEE is formally derived from causative 'to cause to SEE'.

Translated_Text: The boy's eyes are blinking.
Comment: The antipassive of BLINK is formally derived from causative 'to cause to BLINK'. But semantically it is antipassive of intransitive.

Translated_Text: The girl is busy cooking potato.
The boy is busy killing the snake withthe stick.
The girl is busy playing with the doll.
The girl is busy going home.
The boy is busy running fast.
Comment: The antipassive of RUN is formally derived from causative 'to cause to take'. But semantically it is antipassive of transitive TAKE.

Translated_Text: The boy is busy breaking the glass with the foot.
The girl could put on the dress on the sister with mother's help.
The girl could tear the tissue from the dress.
The girl makes the boy talk to the father.
The boy makes the girl run.
The boy makes the girl run.
The boy could run fast.
The boy makes the brother touch the girl with the stick.
The boy could kill the dog.
The girl could take the mother home.
The girl could make father hungry.
The girl could smell the cheese.
The father could scare the girl.
The girl could put the basket on the table.
The girl was no longer angry with her mother (lit. The girl showed her face to her mother.).
Comment: This alternation is only used with this one affective verb and only in this sense.

Translated_Text: The boy could make the girl jump on the car.
The boy could jump on the car.
The girl could talk to her father.
The girl could talk to her father.
The girl talks to her father.
The father could think about his family.
The girl could play with the boy.
The girl could sit down.
The father could go to the farm.
The boy could climb up the tree.
The boy could follow the girl.
The boy could look at the girl.
The girl could cook the meat.
The boy could roll the wheel.
The girl could boil the water.
The boy could sink the boat.
The boy could drop the plate.
The girl could burn the firewood.
The girl could make the bread out of maize flour.
The sun could dry the grass.
The boy could trouble his mother.
The girl could cry loud.
The girl could cry loud.
The boy could shave his beard.
The boy could shout at the girl.
The girl could cough.
The boy could hug the girl.
The boy could ask money from his sister.
The girl could search for a book.
The boy could grind the ground.
The boy could grind the wheat on the mill.
Magomed could name his son Murad.
The boy could teach Arabic to the girl.
The boy could run fast.
The girl could take the book from the mother.
The boy could blink his eyes.
The boy could live in the village.
The girl could help her mother.
The teacher could tell a story to the children.
The girl could say to the father: "Give me as well!".
The boy could kill the snake with the stick.
The boy could hit the girl with the stick.
The boy made the brother grind the wheat on the mill.
The boy could cut the bread with the knife.
The girl scared the boy with the dog.
The boy could hide the book from his sister.
The boy made the brother live in the village.
The boy could steal the book from the girl.
The boy made the boat sink.
The boy could give book to the girl.
The boy made the brother hug the girl.
The boy could send flowers to the girl.
The father made the son leave the village.
Comment: The causative of yeⁿƛ'al 'leave' can only be expressed by a different verb form.

Translated_Text: The boy could carry the rucksack to his mother.
The boy made the brother hide the book from his sister.
The girl could bring sorrel to the mother.
The girl made the boy tell the story about the cat.
The boy could throw the ball to the girl.
The girl made the boy push the stone.
The girl could pour water into the bucket.
The boy made the brother throw the ball to the girl.
The boy could tie the cow to the tree.
The girl made the brother bring the sorrel to the mother.
The boy could load the car with the firewood.
The boy made the brother show the book to the girl.
The girl could sing a song to her mother.
The boy made the girl jump.
The girl could wash the clothes.
The girl made the mother cover the boy with the blanket.
The boy could eat the bread.
The boy made the brother give the book to the girl.
The boy made the girl hit the cat with the stick.
The brother made the sister ask money from the mother.
The God made the rain go.
The girl made the brother fill the bucket with the water.
The potato makes the girl cough.
The boy made the girl feel cold.
The boy made the girl sad.
The boy made the brother shout at the girl.
The girl dressed the sister with the mother's help.
The boy made the brother steal the book from the girl.
The boy let the dog follow the girl.
Comment: yeⁿƛ'al doesn't take causative morphology. The only way to achieve a causative meaning is by a different verb.

Translated_Text: The boy made the girl cut the bread with the knife.
The boy let the girl go home.
The boy is busy touching the girl with the hand.
The girl made the boy smell the cheese.
The boy is busy hugging the girl.
Comment: The antipassive of HUG is formally derived from causative 'to cause to fill'. But semantically it is antipassive of transitive.

Translated_Text: The boy could roll the wheel. / The boy accidentally rolled the wheel.
The girl made the boy boil potatoes.
The girl could cook the meat. / The girl accidentally cooked the meat.
The boy is busy tearing the dress pocket.
Magomed gives names to boys.
The girl made the boy take the book from the mother.
The girl is dressing the sister with the mother.
The girl made the boy search for the book.
The boy made the brother load the car with the firewood.
The boy is busy loading the firewood on the car.
The boy could grind the wheat. / The boy accidentally ground the wheat.
The boy grinds the wheat on the mill.
The boy is busy sending flowers to the girl.
The girl makes the boy hungry.

Primary_Text: Mähmädi ist'id öždiƛ'a Murad caaⁿ gulilliyo.
Translated_Text: Magomed made his brother name his son Murad.
The boy made the brother look at the girl.
The boy made up the story.
The boy made the girl put the book on the table.
The girl made the boy pour water into the bucket.

Primary_Text: Öždi kibbad waya sabaliyad xöxił micolliyo.
Translated_Text: The boy made the girl tie the cow to the tree with the rope.
The mother made the girl sit down.
The boy made the brother kill the snake with the stick.
The boy killed the dog.

Primary_Text: Öždi ist'id kibbal ʔarab mic małcibooyliyo.
Translated_Text: The boy made the brother teach the girl the Arabic language.
The teacher made the children tell him a story.
The girl made the boy say 'cat'.
The girl made the boy help the mother.
The disease made the body sick.
Comment: example from Toolbox [Bezhta5.118]

Translated_Text: The boy makes the girl sing the song.
The boy made the girl wash the clothes.
The boy likes the girl. (lit. The boy is cuddling the girl.).
The boy makes the girl eat the bread.
The boy makes the girl listen to the story.
The girl could boil the water. / The girl accidentally boiled the water.
The father made the boy shave his beard.
The boy made the girl smell the cheese.
The boy could bring the girl home. / The boy accidentally brought the girl home.
The boy could blink his eyes. / The boy accidentally blinked his eyes.
The girl accidentally burnt the house. / The girl could burn the house.
The boy accidentally made the girl get cold. / The boy could make the girl get cold.
The boy ties the rope to the tree.
The boy could kill the dog. / The boy accidentally killed the dog.
The boy could make the apple fall from the tree. / The boy accidentally made the apple fall from the tree.
The boy is busy eating the bread.
The boy made the brother get the book from the girl.
The girl makes the boy dig the ground.
The boy digs (in) the ground with the shovel.
The boy dried the grass.
The boy could dry the grass. / The boy accidentally dried the grass.
The boy made the girl laugh.
The girl is busy covering the boy with the blanket.
The boy made the girl sit down.
The boy made the girl carry the rucksack for the mother.
The boy made the girl send a flower to the mother.

Primary_Text: Öždi ist'id mizala aguriyas biƛo yoyliyo.
Translated_Text: The boy made the brother make the house out of ground bricks.

Primary_Text: Kibba iyod simindiyala hät't'äš bäbä boylis.
Translated_Text: The girl made the mother make the bread out of maize flour.
The girl introduced the boys to the mother.
The boy accompanied girl to the house.
The girl makes the boy play with her.
The boy learns a lesson.
Comment: Some affective verbs have meaning 'to cause to V', other affective verbs like 'to know', 'to find' have causative 2 for the literal causative. Causative 1 from such verbs would have inchoative meaning such as 'to learn' from 'to know', 'to search' from 'to find'

Translated_Text: The girl showed the cat to the mother.
The girl burns the firewood.
Accidentally the boy cut his finger with the knife.
Accidentally the boy broke the glass with his foot.
The boy runs fast.
The boy teaches the Arabic language to the girl.
The boy blinks his eyes.
The boy troubles the mother.
The girl makes the boy cry.
The boy makes the girl look at the mother.
The boy made mother think about the girl.
The boy rolls the wheel.
The girl made the boy fall from the tree.
The girl boiled the water.
The meat is cooking/boiling.
The girl goes home.

Primary_Text: Kibba hinila gedis öždil xabar mehca.
Translated_Text: The girl talks to the boy about her cat.
The boy grinds the wheat on the mill.
The girl is busy taking books from her mother.
Comment: The antipassive of TAKE is formally derived from causative 'to cause to take'. But semantically it is antipassive of transitive.

Translated_Text: The firewood is burning slowly.
Comment: The antipassive of BURN is formally derived from causative 'to cause to burn'. But semantically it is antipassive of intransitive.

Translated_Text: The girl is busy singing songs.
The girl is busy washing the clothes.
The teacher is busy telling a story to the kids.
The boy is busy hitting the girl with the stick.

The boy threw the ball to the girl (so as to hit her).

The girl brought sorrel to the mother.

The girl fills the bucket with the water.

The boy shouted at the girl.
The boy looked at the girl.
The girl looked for the book.
The boy thinks about the girl.

The boy follows the girl.
The boy cut the bread with the knife.
The boy loaded the firewood onto the car.

The boy fell from the tree.
The teacher told a story to the children.

Girl peeled off the potato's skin.
