The girl cries.
The girl sings the song.
The girl washes the clothes.
The girl frightens the boy.
The girl fears the fire.
The boy likes the girl.
The father knows many stories.
The girl saw her mother.
The boy ate bread.
The girl put on the dress.
The girl sat down.
The boy made the girl climb the tree.
Mark screamed with rage. / lit. Mark screamed his rage.

Primary_Text: Ho rubato il denaro a mia madre dalla sua borsa.
Translated_Text: I stole my mother’s money from her bag.

Primary_Text: Temo per il futuro del paese.
Translated_Text: I fear for the future of the country.
I fear for his health.
Mark made Grace take a seat.
Mark made the boys leave.

Primary_Text: Si piange ancora la sua morte.
Translated_Text: One still cries/We/You/They (indef.) still mourn his death.

Primary_Text: Marco urtò il tavolo con il bastone.
Translated_Text: Mark hit the table with the stick.
My sister laughs at me.

Primary_Text: Piovvero granate da tutte le parti.
Translated_Text: Grenades were falling everywhere.
Comment: This verb marginally allows a transitive use with a difference in meaning, whereby piovere granate means 'fall/come down' (Cennamo 2010).

Translated_Text: Paul lives on a tropical island.
Anne left for Milan.
He likes Maths.

Primary_Text: Maria odorò le lenzuola per essere sicura che fossero pulite.
Translated_Text: Mary smelled the sheets to be sure they were clean.
I am cleaning the cloth at the edges.
I am cleaning the edges of the cloth.

Primary_Text: Il forno di Anna cuoce bene la carne.
Translated_Text: Anne's oven cooks meat well.
I hit Mark on his arm.

Primary_Text: Ho urtato il braccio di Marco.
Translated_Text: I hit Mark's arm.

Primary_Text: L'aguzzino bruciò il braccio del prigioniero.
Translated_Text: The torturer burnt the prisoner's arm.

Primary_Text: L'aguzzino bruciò il prigioniero sul braccio.
Translated_Text: The torturer burnt the prisoner on his arm.

Primary_Text: Legai il braccio del prigioniero alla colonna.
Translated_Text: I tied the prisoner's arm to the column.

Primary_Text: Legai il prigioniero per il braccio alla colonna.
Translated_Text: I tied the prisoner to the column by his arm.

Primary_Text: Il taxi ci ha portati a casa.
Translated_Text: The taxi brought us home.

Primary_Text: Marco portò a casa Lucia in taxi.
Translated_Text: Mark brought Lucy home by taxi.

Primary_Text: Il campeggiatore ha bruciato gli arbusti con il lanciafiamme.
Translated_Text: The camper has burnt the shrubs with the flamethrower.

Primary_Text: Le cannonate hanno affondato la nave.
Translated_Text: The cannon salvoes have sunk the ship.

Primary_Text: La coperta non copre bene il bambino.
Translated_Text: The blanket does not cover the baby well.

Primary_Text: Anna copre sempre suo figlio con una coperta.
Translated_Text: Anne always covers her son with a blanket.

Primary_Text: Il lanciafiamme ha bruciato gli arbusti.
Translated_Text: The flamethrower has burnt the shrubs.
Cannon salvoes sink ships.

Primary_Text: Luigi fece caricare la legna a/da Mario.
Translated_Text: Luigi made Mario load the wood.

Primary_Text: Anna fece nascondere i gioielli a/da Marta.
Translated_Text: Anne made Martha hide her jewels.

Primary_Text: Marco lasciò pulire le scale a sua sorella.
Translated_Text: Mark let his sister clean the stairs.

Primary_Text: Marco fece pulire le scale a/da sua sorella.
Translated_Text: Mark made his sister clean the stairs.
Mark had John shaved.

Primary_Text: Marco fece inviare il libro a Giovanna da Anna.
Translated_Text: Mark made Anna send the book to Jane.

Primary_Text: Marco fece mangiare il dolce da suo padre.
Translated_Text: Mark made his father eat the cake.
Mark let it fall.
Mark let the spoon fall.
I know Mark's integrity.

Primary_Text: Conosco Marco per la sua onestà.
Translated_Text: I know Mark for his integrity.
I fear John's arrogance.

Primary_Text: Temo Giovanni per la sua arroganza.
Translated_Text: I fear John because of his arrogance.
Anne touched Mark on his face.

Primary_Text: Anna toccò il viso di Marco.
Translated_Text: Anne touched Mark's face.

Primary_Text: Il coraggio di Marco piace a tutti.
Translated_Text: Everbody likes Mark's courage.

Primary_Text: Marco piace a tutti per il suo coraggio.
Translated_Text: Everybody likes Mark for his courage.
Mario's skinniness frightens.
The ball broke the window.

Primary_Text: Il bambino ruppe la finestra con la palla.
Translated_Text: The child broke the window with the ball.

Primary_Text: Si è uditi anche a distanza quando si canta ad alta voce.
Translated_Text: One is/We/You/They (indef.) are also heard at a distance when one sings/we/you/They (indef.) sing loudly.
One/We/You/They (indef.) heard a blast.

Primary_Text: Il boato si udì a distanza.
Translated_Text: The blast was heard in the distance.

Primary_Text: Il rumore venne udito da Giovanna.
Translated_Text: The noise was heard by Jane.

Primary_Text: Marco udì un rumore in lontananza.
Translated_Text: Mark heard a noise in the distance.

Primary_Text: Ci si fa una chitarra di legno d'abete.
Translated_Text: One is making oneself/You are making yourself a guitar out of deal (wood)/We are making ourselves/You are making yourselves/They (indef.) are making themselves guitars out of deal (wood).

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si fanno reciprocamente una chitarra di legno d'abete.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke are making each other guitars out of deal (wood).

Primary_Text: Luca si fa una chitarra di legno d'abete.
Translated_Text: Luke is making himself a guitar out of deal (wood).

Primary_Text: La chitarra si fa di legno d'abete.
Translated_Text: The guitar is to be made out of deal (wood).

Primary_Text: Si fa una chitarra di legno d'abete.
Translated_Text: One makes/We/You/They (indef.) make a guitar out of deal (wood).

Primary_Text: La chitarra è fatta di legno d'abete.
Translated_Text: The guitar is made out of deal (wood).

Primary_Text: Ho fatto una chitarra di legno d'abete.
Translated_Text: I have made a guitar out of deal (wood).

Primary_Text: Il quadro non nasconde bene la cassaforte.
Translated_Text: The picture doesn’t hide the safe well.

Primary_Text: Questo coltello non sbuccia bene le mele.
Translated_Text: This knife does not peel the apples well.

Primary_Text: Si vestono capi eleganti a teatro.
Translated_Text: One wears/We/You/They (indef.) wear elegant clothes at the theatre.

Primary_Text: Si è mangiati vivi dalle zanzare.
Translated_Text: One gets/We/You/They (indef.) get eaten alive by mosquitos.
Anne is getting burned sunbathing.

Primary_Text: Questa zappa non dissotterra bene le patate.
Translated_Text: This hoe doesn’t dig up potatoes well.
Mary jumped to her feet.
Comment: The verb saltare in its intransitive use selects the auxiliary BE in compound tenses if the process is bounded, i.e., telic, with past particle agreement with the subject (Salvi 1988, Cennamo 1993: 36, 2011: 5).

Primary_Text: Gli ultimi spettatori si sedettero nei posti liberi.
Translated_Text: The last spectators sat in the unoccupied seats.

Primary_Text: Mario si siede sempre lì, in seconda fila.
Translated_Text: Mario always sits there, in the second row.

Primary_Text: Quando si accelera, si è spinti indietro.
Translated_Text: When one speeds up/we/you/They (indef.) speed up, one is pushed/we/you/They (indef.) are pushed backwards.
One is/We/You/They (indef.) are murdered for an idea.

Primary_Text: In alcuni paesi si viene ancora bruciati sul rogo.
Translated_Text: In some countries, people are still burnt at the stake.
One is/We/You/They (indef.) are loaded onto the truck.

Primary_Text: Si è coperti da uno strato di fango.
Translated_Text: One is/We/You/They (indef.) are covered with a layer of mud.

Primary_Text: Si è messi in un angolo.
Translated_Text: One is put//We/You/They (indef.) are put in a corner.

Primary_Text: Si è inviati come messaggeri di pace.
Translated_Text: One is sent as a messenger/We/You/They (indef.) are sent as messengers of peace.
One is shown in public/We/You/They (indef.) are shown in public.
One is/We/You/They (indef.) are hidden by the crowd.

Primary_Text: Marco e Giovanna si nascondono la verità.
Translated_Text: Mark and Jane are hiding the truth from each other.

Primary_Text: In guerra si viene uccisi senza motivo.
Translated_Text: At war, one is/we/you/they(indef.)/people are killed without any reason.

Primary_Text: Si è sgridati di solito per motivi sciocchi.
Translated_Text: One is usually shouted at/We/You/They (indef.) are usually shouted at for silly reasons.

Primary_Text: Si è vestiti da capo a piedi.
Translated_Text: One is dressed/We/You/They (indef.) are dressed from head to toe.

Primary_Text: Si è cercati tutto il giorno.
Translated_Text: One is looked for/We/You/They (indef.) are looked for all day long.
One is/We/You/They (indef.) are known by everybody.

Primary_Text: Si viene spaventati dai rumori di notte.
Translated_Text: One is/We/You/They (indef.) are frightened by noises at night.

Primary_Text: Si è temuti dagli studenti senza motivo.
Translated_Text: One is/We/You/They (indef.) are feared by the students without a reason.
One is smelled/We/You/They (indef.) are smelled by dogs.

Primary_Text: Si è guardati con curiosità dagli studenti.
Translated_Text: One is viewed at/We/You/They (indef.) are viewed with curiosity by the students.
Friends often hug each other.

Primary_Text: Si abbracciano spesso i propri amici.
Translated_Text: One often hugs one’s own friends/We often hug our friends/You often hug your own friends/They (indef.) often hug their friends.

Primary_Text: Si è spesso abbracciati dai propri genitori.
Translated_Text: One is often hugged/We/You/They (indef.) are often hugged by one’s own/our own/your own/their own parents.

Primary_Text: Senza tende, si è visti dalla finestra.
Translated_Text: Without curtains, one is/we/you/they (indef.) are seen from the window.
The meat is cooked.
Comment: With this verb, unlike with other change of state verbs which allow both the coded and the uncoded anticausative, according to whether the focus is on the process or on the final/result state, the BE+pp. form in compound tenses only has a stative interpretation, the past participle having an adjectival function.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si cuociono (reciprocamente) la carne.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke cook each other the meat.
Anne is cooking herself meat.

Primary_Text: Si cuoce la carne con attenzione.
Translated_Text: One cooks/We/You/They (indef.) cook the meat carefully.

Primary_Text: La carne si cuoce con attenzione.
Translated_Text: Meat is to be cooked carefully.
The meat is cooked slowly.

Primary_Text: La carne si cuoce in tre ore.
Translated_Text: The meat cooks in three hours.
Comment: With cuocere, the coded anticausative pattern only occurs in telic contexts, since the reflexive morpheme is a marker of telicity.

Translated_Text: The meat has been cooking for hours.
Comment: With this verb, the uncoded anticausative form occurs in both telic and atelic contexts.

Primary_Text: Le palpebre vanno sbattute per lubrificare gli occhi.
Translated_Text: Eyelids are blinked to lubricate the eyes.
Eyelids blink unconsciously.
One blinks one’s eyes/We blink our eyes/You blink your eyes/They blink their eyes unconsciously.
Anne often blinks her eyes.

Primary_Text: Ci si dissotterra le patate migliori.
Translated_Text: One digs for/We/You/They (indef.) dig up the best potatoes.

Primary_Text: Il contadino si dissotterra le patate migliori.
Translated_Text: The farmer digs up the best potatoes for himself.

Primary_Text: Le patate si dissotterrano a fine estate.
Translated_Text: Potatoes are dug up in late summer.

Primary_Text: Si dissotterrano le patate a fine estate.
Translated_Text: One digs up/We/You/They (indef.) dig up potatoes in late summer.

Primary_Text: Le patate vanno dissotterrate a fine estate.
Translated_Text: Potatoes are to be dug up in late summer.

Primary_Text: Il contadino dissotterra le patate con la zappa.
Translated_Text: The farmer digs up potatoes with a hoe.

Primary_Text: A scuola spesso ci si ruba la merenda.
Translated_Text: At school, we/you/They (indef.) steal each other’s snacks.
Comment: In the impersonal pattern ci si V the morpheme ci can also be the oblique first person plural clitic pronoun, whereby ci = 'to us', so that (i) ci si ruba can also exemplify an impersonal reflexive 'One steals/They (indef.) steal us our snack'.

Primary_Text: I bambini si rubano la merenda.
Translated_Text: Children steal each other’s snacks.

Primary_Text: Marco ha rubato, per questo è in carcere.
Translated_Text: One steals/We/You/They (indef.) steal the most precious jewels.

Primary_Text: Il bambino si ruba ogni giorno la merenda.
Translated_Text: The child steals a snack every day.

Primary_Text: Si rubano i gioielli più preziosi.
Translated_Text: One steals/We/You/They (indef.) steal the most precious jewels.
Jewels are frequently stolen.

Primary_Text: Il ladro rubò i gioielli alla signora.
Translated_Text: The thief stole the jewels from the lady.

Primary_Text: Ci si porta le valigie in albergo, perché non ci sono facchini.
Translated_Text: One is carrying/ You/We/ They (indef.) are carrying the suitcases to the hotel oneself/yourself/ourselves/themselves, since there are no porters.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si porta-no le valigi-e.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke carry each other the suitcases.
Anne brings her suitcases herself.

Primary_Text: I fiori vengono portati nelle ricorrenze importanti.
Translated_Text: Flowers are brought when an important anniversary takes place.

Primary_Text: I fiori si portano come omaggio.
Translated_Text: Flowers are brought as a homage.

Primary_Text: Si portano dei fiori alle puerpere.
Translated_Text: One brings/We/You/They (indef.) bring some flowers to the puerperas.

Primary_Text: Ci si macina il caffè tutte le mattine.
Translated_Text: One grinds/We/You/They (indef.) grind coffee for oneself/ourselves/yourselves/themselves every morning.
This grinder does not grind well.

Primary_Text: Anna si macina il caffè ogni mattina.
Translated_Text: Anne grinds her own coffee every morning.
Coffee is freshly ground.

Primary_Text: Un tempo si macinava il caffè in casa.
Translated_Text: Once one/we/you/They (indef.) ground coffee at home.
The coffee is freshly ground.
This detergent does not clean well.
Lucy is cleaning herself.

Primary_Text: Ci si pulisce le scarpe dalla polvere prima di entrare.
Translated_Text: One wipes/We/You/They (indef.) wipe the dust off one’s/our/your/their shoes before entering.

Primary_Text: Marco e Giovanna si puliscono a vicenda le scarpe dalla polvere.
Translated_Text: Mark and Jane are dusting off each other’s shoes.

Primary_Text: Si è puliti con cura da bambini.
Translated_Text: One is cleaned carefully as a child/We/you/They (indef.) are cleaned carefully as children.

Primary_Text: Il gatto si pulisce con cura.
Translated_Text: The cat cleans itself carefully.

Primary_Text: Il gatto si pulisce il pelo.
Translated_Text: The cat is cleaning its fur.

Primary_Text: Il tavolo si pulisce con cura.
Translated_Text: The table is to be cleaned carefully.

Primary_Text: Si pulì il pavimento con un detersivo biodegradabile.
Translated_Text: One/We/They (indef.) wiped the floor with a biodegradable floor-cleaner.

Primary_Text: Mario fece cantare una canzone dalla ragazza.
Translated_Text: Mario made the girl sing a song.

Primary_Text: Mario fece cantare una canzone alla ragazza.
Translated_Text: Mario made the girl sing a song.
Mario had the girl sing (a song).
Fruit fills (one) immediately.
Mark enquired about his friend.

Primary_Text: L'enorme massa d'acqua spinge contro la diga.
Translated_Text: The huge mass of water is pressing against the dam.

Primary_Text: Marco strappò la lettera a Luca.
Translated_Text: Mark snatched the letter from Luke.
Comment: Depending on the context, the predicate can also mean 'took away', rather than 'tore'.

Primary_Text: Si viene sentiti dagli animali nel bosco.
Translated_Text: One is/We/You/They (indef.) are heard by the animals in the wood.

Primary_Text: Anna si sente il rumore della strada fino a tarda notte.
Translated_Text: Anne hears the noise of the street until late in the night.
The bear is heard in the distance.
One/We/You/They (indef.) can hear the bear in the distance.

Primary_Text: L'orso viene sentito dai cani in lontananza.
Translated_Text: The bear is heard in the distance by the dogs.
My grandfather can't hear any more.
Don't push, please.

Primary_Text: A volte involontariamente ci si spinge.
Translated_Text: Sometimes we/you/They (indef.) accidentally push each other.

Primary_Text: Ci si spinse avanti per vedere meglio.
Translated_Text: One/You/We/They (indef.) pushed oneself/yourself/ourselves/themselves forwards to see better.

Primary_Text: Ci si insegna ad avere pazienza.
Translated_Text: One teaches oneself/We /You/They (indef.) teach themselves to be patient.

Primary_Text: Si è pianti da tutti se si lascia un bel ricordo.
Translated_Text: One is/We/You/They (indef.) are mourned by everybody if one leaves/we/you/they leave a loving memory.
One has cried/We/You/They (indef.) have cried for many days.

Primary_Text: Anna pianse il suo amico per mesi.
Translated_Text: Anne cried for her friend for months.
Anne wept bitter tears.
Comment: The verb piangere also occurs, albeit rarely, with a cognate object.

Primary_Text: Si è ricevuti dall'avvocato nel suo studio legale.
Translated_Text: One is received/We/You/They (indef.) are received by the lawyer in his office.

Primary_Text: Si è voluti dai propri genitori.
Translated_Text: One is desired/We/You/They (indef.) are desired by one’s/our/your/their own parents.

Primary_Text: Ci si vuole per la vita.
Translated_Text: One loves/We/They (indef.) love each other for life.
One wants/We/You/They (indef.) want everything immediately.

Primary_Text: Si viene lanciati dall'aereo col paracadute.
Translated_Text: One is thrown/We/You/They (indef.) are parachuted from the aircraft.

Primary_Text: Marco lanciò la palla molto in alto.
Translated_Text: Mark threw the ball very high.
The stick hit the table.
Mark hit against the dresser.

Primary_Text: Marco urtò il tavolino con la gamba.
Translated_Text: Mark hit the side-table with his leg.

Primary_Text: Marco urtò il bastone su-l tavol-o.
Translated_Text: Mark hit the stick on the table.
One has hit/We/You/They (indef.) were hit by the truck.
One hit/We/They (indef.) hit the vase accidentally.
One has/We/You/They (indef.) fell to the ground.

Primary_Text: Ci si colpisce a vicenda con calci e pugni.
Translated_Text: We beat each other /They (indef.) beat each other with kicks and fists.
The stick hit the wooden fence.

Primary_Text: L'uomo colpì la staccionata con il bastone.
Translated_Text: The man hit the wooden fence with the stick.

Primary_Text: Si è colpiti da calci e pugni.
Translated_Text: One is beaten/We/You/They (indef.) are hit by fists and kicks.
The man hit Mark on his shoulder.

Primary_Text: L'uomo colpì la spalla di Marco.
Translated_Text: The man hit Mark’s shoulder.

Primary_Text: L'uomo si colpì la fronte inavvertitamente.
Translated_Text: The man hit his forehead accidentally.

Primary_Text: Se si è cacciatori di cinghiali, bisogna essere prudenti.
Translated_Text: If one is a wild boar hunter, one needs to be careful.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si riempirono a vicenda il bicchiere di vino.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke filled each other’s wine glasses.

Primary_Text: Si è riempiti di false promesse.
Translated_Text: One was/We/You/They (indef.) were filled with false promises.
The house was filled with pictures. / The paintings filled the house.

Primary_Text: La casa viene riempita di quadri.
Translated_Text: The house is filled with pictures.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si prendono la mano.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke are taking each other’s hands.
Here I can’t touch.

Primary_Text: Si toccano con i guanti le lampade alogene.
Translated_Text: One touches/We/You/They (indef.) touch the halogen lamps with gloves.

Primary_Text: Le lampade alogene si toccano con i guanti.
Translated_Text: Halogen lamps are to be touched with gloves.

Primary_Text: Si è chiamati col nome dei nonni.
Translated_Text: One is named/We/You/They (indef.) are named after one’s grandparents/our/your/their grandparents.

Primary_Text: Si fondò una associazione e ci si chiamò 'La Combriccola' .
Translated_Text: We set up an association and we called it ‘La Combriccola ('The Gang’).

Primary_Text: I gioielli furono rubati dal ladro.
Translated_Text: The jewels were stolen by the thief.

Primary_Text: Nel libro si racconta la crisi interiore di un medico.
Translated_Text: A doctor's inner crisis is described in this book.

Translated_Text: Luke tied the key around his neck.

Primary_Text: Se si corre con regolarità ci si mantiene in forma.
Translated_Text: If one runs regularly one keeps fit. If we/you/they(indef.) run regularly, we/you/they(indef.) keep fit.

Primary_Text: Il tavolo va pulito dalla polvere.
Translated_Text: The table is to be dusted.
Mark ran in the park.

Primary_Text: Il miele andava messo nel vino.
Translated_Text: Honey was to be put into wine.

Primary_Text: La carne cuoce in cinque minuti.
Translated_Text: The meat cooks in five minutes.
Comment: With this verb, the uncoded anticausative form occurs in both telic and atelic contexts.

Primary_Text: Una montagna si scala passo dopo passo.
Translated_Text: A mountain is to be climbed one step at a time.

Primary_Text: Anna coprì il pavimento di fiori.
Translated_Text: Anne covered the floor with flowers.

Primary_Text: Si scala con la sola forza delle mani e dei piedi.
Translated_Text: One climbs/We/You/They (indef.) climb up with the strength of one’s/our/your/their hands and feet alone.
Mark is often to be scolded.
Mario lives in the countryside.
The wounded person is to be taken to hospital.

Primary_Text: Il K2 da due anni non viene scalato a causa del cattivo tempo.
Translated_Text: K2 has not been climbed for two years because of bad weather.

Primary_Text: La matematica va insegnata agli studenti dal primo anno.
Translated_Text: Maths is to be taught to the students from the first year.
One/We/They (indef.) climbed up a difficult mountain.

Primary_Text: La casa va riempita di quadri.
Translated_Text: The house is to be filled with pictures.

Primary_Text: I ladri hanno scalato il muro del giardino.
Translated_Text: The thieves climbed over the wall of the garden.

Primary_Text: I fiori vanno portati nelle ricorrenze importanti.
Translated_Text: Flowers are to be brought when an important anniversary takes place.
One coughs/We//You/They(indef.) cough because of the smoke.
Ferocious dogs are to be tied.

Primary_Text: Il vecchio tossisce tutto il giorno.
Translated_Text: The old man coughs all day long.

Primary_Text: Mio fratello si trasportò i libri da solo.
Translated_Text: My brother carried the books by himself.
A missile is to be launched.
The coffee is to be freshly ground.

Primary_Text: Ci si riempie la bocca di parole vuote.
Translated_Text: One fills one’s mouth/You fill your mouth/We/they(indef) fill our/your/their mouths with empty words.

Primary_Text: Il carrello va spinto dal commesso.
Translated_Text: The trolley is to be pushed by the shop-assistant.

Primary_Text: Il contenitore viene riempito dal fondo di acqua.
Translated_Text: The container is filled from the bottom with water.

Primary_Text: Il latte va bollito per cinque minuti.
Translated_Text: The milk is to be boiled for five minutes.
The can is to be filled in this way.

Primary_Text: Il pavimento va coperto di fiori.
Translated_Text: The floor is to be covered with flowers.

Primary_Text: Si riempie la propria casa di oggetti.
Translated_Text: One fills one’s house/We/You/They(indef.) fill our/your/their houses with things.
The dough is to be poured into boilling oil.

Primary_Text: Luca si riempie di cibo scadente.
Translated_Text: Luke is filling himself with junk food.

Primary_Text: I regali vanno ricevuti con gratitudine.
Translated_Text: Gifts are to be received with gratitude.

Primary_Text: La casa si riempì di quadri in poco tempo.
Translated_Text: The house filled with pictures in a short while.

Primary_Text: La verità va cercata con umiltà.
Translated_Text: Truth is to be sought with humility.

Primary_Text: Anna si riempì la casa di quadri.
Translated_Text: Anne filled her house with pictures.

Primary_Text: La verità va detta con coraggio.
Translated_Text: Truth is to be said with courage.

Primary_Text: Anna riempì il modulo con i suoi dati.
Translated_Text: Anne filled in the form with her generalities.
Meat is to be cooked slowly.

Primary_Text: Anna ha riempito la sua casa di quadri.
Translated_Text: Anne has filled her house with pictures.

Primary_Text: La chitarra va fatta di legno d'abete.
Translated_Text: The guitar must be made out of fir wood.

Primary_Text: D'inverno ci si copre con abiti pesanti.
Translated_Text: In winter, one wears/we/you/they (indef.) wear warm clothes.

Primary_Text: La mela va sbucciata con un coltello adatto.
Translated_Text: Apples must be peeled with a proper knife.

Primary_Text: Le patate vengono dissotterrate a fine estate.
Translated_Text: Potatoes are dug up in late summer.

Primary_Text: Si copre il pavimento di fiori per il matrimonio.
Translated_Text: One covers/We/They (indef.) cover the floor with flowers for the wedding.

Primary_Text: Il pavimento viene coperto di fiori.
Translated_Text: The floor is covered with flowers.

Primary_Text: Il pavimento si copre di fiori per un matrimonio.
Translated_Text: The floor is covered with flowers for a wedding.

Primary_Text: Maria si è coperta con lo scialle.
Translated_Text: Mary covered herself with the shawl.

Primary_Text: Luca si copre il capo con un cappello di lana.
Translated_Text: Luke covers his head with a woolen hat.
This tarpaulin does not cover well.

Primary_Text: Anna coprì il pavimento con il telone.
Translated_Text: Anne covered the floor with the tarpaulin.

Primary_Text: Ci si versa addosso il vino quando si è nervosi.
Translated_Text: One pours oneself wine when one is nervous.You/We/You/They(indef.) pour yourself/ourselves/themselves wine when you/we/they are nervous.

Primary_Text: L'impasto nell'olio si versa quando è bollente.
Translated_Text: The dough is to be poured into the oil when it is boiling.

Primary_Text: Si versa l'impasto nell'olio quando è bollente.
Translated_Text: One pours/We//YouThey (indef.) pour the dough into hot boiling oil.
The dough is poured into the boiling oil.

Primary_Text: Si versò il vino sul tavolo per protesta.
Translated_Text: One/We/They (indef.) spilled the wine onto the table as a protest.

Primary_Text: Luca si versò un po' di vino nel bicchiere.
Translated_Text: Luke poured himself some wine / Luke poured some wine into his glass.

Primary_Text: Il brodo si versò sul tavolo.
Translated_Text: The soup spilled onto the table.

Primary_Text: Anna versò il brodo nella zuppiera.
Translated_Text: Anna poured the soup into the tureen.

Primary_Text: Ci si mette sul divano solo quando il lavoro è finito.
Translated_Text: One only sits/We/You/They(indef.) only sit on the sofa when work is over.

Primary_Text: Il miele veniva/era messo nel vino.
Translated_Text: Honey used to be put into wine.

Primary_Text: Si mettono i vestiti in ordine nell'armadio.
Translated_Text: One tidies/We/You/They (indef.) tidy the clothes in the wardrobe.

Primary_Text: I vestiti si mettono nell'armadio in ordine.
Translated_Text: Clothes are to be put neatly in the wardrobe.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si mettono reciprocamente lo zaino sulle spalle.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke are putting each other’s rucksack on each other’s backs.

Primary_Text: Luca si mise lo zaino sulle spalle.
Translated_Text: Luke put the rucksack on his back.
Luke lay down on the deckchair.

Primary_Text: Luca mise la pirofila in forno.
Translated_Text: Luke put the pyrex saucepan into the oven.

Primary_Text: Luca mise i piatti sul tavolo.
Translated_Text: Luke put the dishes on the table.

Primary_Text: La barca si lega così al molo.
Translated_Text: The boat is to be tied to the dock in this way.

Primary_Text: La notte durante la navigazione ci si lega alla barca per non cadere a mare.
Translated_Text: When sailing at night, one ties himself/you tie yourself//we tie ourselves/they tie themselves to the boat, so as not to fall into the sea.

Primary_Text: Si lega la barca al molo e poi si esce.
Translated_Text: One ties/We/You/They (indef.) tie the boat to the dock and then one goes out /we/you/they(indef.) go out.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si sono legati reciprocamente alla barca.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke tied each other to the boat.
Ferocious dogs are tied up.

Primary_Text: Luca si è legato il braccio rotto al collo.
Translated_Text: Luke tied his broken arm to his neck.
Mark tied himself to the boat.

Primary_Text: Luca legò il cane al palo con la corda.
Translated_Text: Luke tied the dog to the post with the chain.

Primary_Text: Da bambini, con la fantasia ci si trasporta in un mondo fantastico.
Translated_Text: As a child, one transports oneself/ you transport yourself/ As children we transport ourselves/ you transport yourselves/ they (indef.) transport themselves to a fantastic world through fantasy.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si trasportavano reciprocamente i libri.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke carried each other’s books.

Primary_Text: I piatti di porcellana si trasportano in apposite scatole.
Translated_Text: Porcelain plates are transported in the correct boxes.
The injured person is taken to hospital.

Primary_Text: Si trasportano troppe merci sulle autostrade.
Translated_Text: One transports/We/You/They(indef.) transport too much goods on the motorways.

Primary_Text: Con la fantasia mi trasporto in un mondo fantastico.
Translated_Text: Through fantasy, I take myself to a fantastic world.

Primary_Text: Luca trasportò le valigie a casa.
Translated_Text: Luke carried the suitcases home.

Primary_Text: Gli inviti si inviano due mesi prima del matrimonio.
Translated_Text: Invitations are sent out two months before the wedding.

Primary_Text: Lo stesso messaggio viene inviato a tutti.
Translated_Text: The same message is sent to everybody.

Primary_Text: Anna e la sua amica si inviano sempre messaggi.
Translated_Text: Anne and her friend always send each other messages.
People of the same age send short messages to each other.

Primary_Text: A dicembre si inviano gli auguri per un felice anno nuovo.
Translated_Text: In December one sends/we/They (indef.) send New Year’s greetings cards.

Primary_Text: Quando si invia il modulo, bisogna includere due fotografie.
Translated_Text: When sending the form, one needs/we/you/they (indef.) need to attach two photos.

Primary_Text: Anna inviò una lettera alla sua amica.
Translated_Text: Anne sent a letter to her friend.
One gives oneself/You give yourself/We give ourselves/You give yourselves/They(indef) give themselves a gift / We/You/They give each other gifts.

Primary_Text: Si dà l'aumento ai lavoratori meritevoli.
Translated_Text: One gives/We/You/They (indef.) give the pay rise to deserving workers.

Primary_Text: L'aumento si dà ai lavoratori meritevoli.
Translated_Text: The pay rise is given to deserving workers.

Primary_Text: L'aumento va dato ai lavoratori meritevoli.
Translated_Text: The pay rise is to be given to deserving workers.

Primary_Text: Marco si diede un calcio involontariamente.
Translated_Text: Mark kicked himself accidentally.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si diedero la mano.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke shook hands.

Primary_Text: Anna dà spesso a Luca un regalo.
Translated_Text: Anne often gives Luke a gift.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si mostrarono le foto di quando erano bambini.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke showed each other the pictures of when they were little.

Primary_Text: Le prove vennero mostrate ai giudici dall'avvocato.
Translated_Text: The evidence was shown to the judges by the lawyer.

Primary_Text: Nelle problematiche sociali ci si mostra passivi.
Translated_Text: For/With social problems one seems/we/you/they (indef.) seem passive.

Primary_Text: La merce migliore si mostra solo ai clienti assidui.
Translated_Text: The best goods are only shown to habitual customers.

Primary_Text: Generalmente si mostra la merce migliore ai clienti.
Translated_Text: Generally one shows/we/you/they (indef.) show the best goods to customers.

Primary_Text: La verità si nasconde lì, in quel casolare.
Translated_Text: The truth is hiding there, in that cottage.
Comment: At times, only the context differentiates the anticausative from the passive interpretation of the [N si V] pattern, as in la verità si nasconde nel casolare and la verità spesso si nasconde per non allarmare 'the truth is often hidden in order not to alarm'.

Primary_Text: Spesso ci si nasconde la verità.
Translated_Text: One often hides the truth from oneself/ We/You/They (indef.) often hide the truth from ourselves/yourselves/themselves.
Comment: In some contexts the clitic ci may also realize the first person plural dative clitic pronoun ci 'to us'.

Primary_Text: Spesso si nasconde la verità ai cittadini.
Translated_Text: One often hides/We/You/They(indef.) often hide the truth from citizens.

Primary_Text: Anna si mostra in pubblico con piacere.
Translated_Text: Anne appears in public with pleasure.

Primary_Text: Il negoziante mostrò la merce al cliente.
Translated_Text: The shopkeeper showed the goods to the customer.

Primary_Text: La vallata era nascosta dalla nebbia.
Translated_Text: The valley was hidden by the fog.

Primary_Text: Il ladro si nascose dietro una siepe.
Translated_Text: The thief hid behind a hedge.

Primary_Text: Il bandito si nascose il viso con un passamontagna.
Translated_Text: The bandit hid his face with a balaclava.

Primary_Text: Anna nascose il regalo a Luca.
Translated_Text: Anne hid the gift from Luke.

Primary_Text: Marco si è sbucciato il gomito sciando.
Translated_Text: Mark grazed his elbow skiing.

Primary_Text: Ci si può sbucciare i gomiti se si cade sciando.
Translated_Text: One /We/You/They (indef.) can get a grazed elbow if one falls/we/they(indef.) fall when skiing.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si sbucciano a vicenda la frutta ogni sera.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke peel each other the fruit every evening.

Primary_Text: Un tempo non si sbucciava la frutta.
Translated_Text: Once one/we/they (indef.) didn’t use to peel fruit.

Primary_Text: Oggi la frutta si sbuccia sempre.
Translated_Text: Today fruit is always peeled.
I have peeled myself an apple.

Primary_Text: La mela viene sbucciata con un coltello adatto.
Translated_Text: Apples are peeled with the right knife.

Primary_Text: Anna sbuccia la mela per sua figlia.
Translated_Text: Anne is peeling the apple for her daughter.
The letter was torn up by the teacher.

Primary_Text: Non ci si strappa i capelli.
Translated_Text: One does not tear out one’s own hair/We/you/they (indef.) do not tear out our/your/their own hair / We/You/They do not tear out each other’s hair.

Primary_Text: Le pagine si strappano dai quaderni solo raramente.
Translated_Text: Only rarely are pages to be torn out of exercise books.

Primary_Text: Si strappano troppe pagine dai quaderni.
Translated_Text: One tears/We/You/They (indef.) tear too many pages out of one’s/our/your/their exercise books.

Primary_Text: Il ladro rubò i gioielli dalla cassaforte.
Translated_Text: The thief stole the jewels from the safe.
The trousers got torn.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si strappano i capelli litigando.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke are tearing out each other's hair while quarreling.

Primary_Text: Luca si strappò i capelli per la disperazione.
Translated_Text: Luke tore out his hair in despair.

Primary_Text: Luca si strappò i pantaloni involontariamente.
Translated_Text: Luke tore his trousers by accident.

Primary_Text: Luca strappa una pagina dal quaderno.
Translated_Text: Luke is tearing a page from the exercise book.

Primary_Text: Ci si prende spesso il denaro dei propri genitori.
Translated_Text: One often takes/We/you/They(indef.) often take our parents’ money.

Primary_Text: Il reperto si prende con i guanti.
Translated_Text: The find is to be taken when wearing gloves.

Primary_Text: Si prende in mano un reperto per esaminarlo.
Translated_Text: One holds/We/You/They (indef.) hold an archaeological find to analyse it.

Primary_Text: I libri vengono presi dai biliotecari e consegnati ai lettori.
Translated_Text: The books are taken by the librarians and given to the readers.

Primary_Text: L'attore si è preso gli applausi di tutta la platea.
Translated_Text: The actor received the applause of the whole theatre.

Primary_Text: Luca prese il denaro da/a sua madre.
Translated_Text: Luke took the money from his mother.

Primary_Text: I nostri balconi sono così vicini che quasi si toccano.
Translated_Text: Our balconies are so close that they nearly touch each other.

Primary_Text: Si toccano sempre con delicatezza i neonati.
Translated_Text: One always touches/We/You/They (indef.) always touch newborn babies delicately.

Primary_Text: I neonati si toccano con delicatezza.
Translated_Text: Newborn babies are to be touched delicately.

Primary_Text: Spesso ci si tocca i capelli per nervosismo.
Translated_Text: One often touches one’s hair/We/You/They (indef.) often touch our/your/their hair out of nervousness.

Primary_Text: Mario si toccava il polso lamentandosi.
Translated_Text: Mario touched his wrist moaning.

Primary_Text: Marco toccò il soffitto con la mano.
Translated_Text: Mark touched the ceiling with his hand.

Primary_Text: Marco si toccava per controllare di non avere le ossa rotte.
Translated_Text: Mark touched himself to check that he didn’t have any broken bones.

Primary_Text: I figli spesso si chiamano col nome dei nonni.
Translated_Text: Children are often named after their grandparents.

Primary_Text: Se ci si chiama Agnelli è tutto facile.
Translated_Text: If one is called Agnelli everything is easy/If we/you/they(indef.) are called Agnelli everything is easy.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si chiamano reciprocamente "Tesoro".
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke call each other "Darling".

Primary_Text: Mio padre in fabbrica era chiamato Nuvola Nera dai lavoratori.
Translated_Text: In the factory, my father was called "Black Cloud" by the workers.

Primary_Text: Spesso si chiama un bambino con il nome del nonno.
Translated_Text: We often name a child after his grandfather.

Primary_Text: Anna ha chiamato sua figlia Laura.
Translated_Text: Anne has called/named her daughter Laura.

Primary_Text: I papi spesso si chiamano come il proprio predecessore.
Translated_Text: Popes often take their predecessors’ names.

Primary_Text: La verità viene detta con coraggio.
Translated_Text: The truth is said with courage.

Primary_Text: La verità si dice con coraggio.
Translated_Text: The truth is to be said with courage.

Primary_Text: Si dice la verità a chi si ama.
Translated_Text: One tells/We/You/They (indef.) tell the truth to the one one/we/you/they (indef.) love.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si dicono sempre la verità.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke always tell each other the truth.

Primary_Text: Se ci si ama ci si dice sempre la verità.
Translated_Text: If we/you really love each other we/you always tell each other the truth.

Primary_Text: Anna dice sempre la verità a Luca.
Translated_Text: Anne always tells the truth to Luke.
Luke says he's surprised by what has happened.
Go ahead and tell me, I’m listening to you.

Primary_Text: Anna si è detta una bugia.
Translated_Text: Anne told herself a lie.

Primary_Text: L'episodio è raccontato magistralmente nel film dal regista.
Translated_Text: The episode is masterly narrated in the film by the director.

Primary_Text: È vero amore solo quando ci si racconta la propria vita.
Translated_Text: It’s only true love when we/you/they(indef.) tell one another about our/your/their own lives.

Primary_Text: Gli anziani si sedevano intorno al fuoco e si raccontavano storie.
Translated_Text: The old men used to sit around the fire and tell each other stories.
Mark spoke/wrote about his crisis.

Primary_Text: Anna racconta una storia a suo figlio ogni sera.
Translated_Text: Anne tells her son a story every evening.

Primary_Text: La sera spesso si racconta una favola ai bambini.
Translated_Text: One often tells/We/You /They(indef.) often tell a fairy tale to the children in the evening.

Primary_Text: Anna si è raccontata in un'autobiografia.
Translated_Text: Anna has written her story in an autobiography.

Primary_Text: Tra compagne di squadra ci si sgrida e ci si incoraggia.
Translated_Text: Team-mates encourage and shout at each other.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si sgridano a vicenda per il disordine.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke are shouting at each other because of the disorder.

Primary_Text: Si sgridano di più i bambini durante le feste.
Translated_Text: One shouts more at one’s children. /We shout more at our children/You shout more at your children/They shout more at their children during the holidays.

Primary_Text: I bambini spesso si sgridano a malincuore.
Translated_Text: Children are often scolded with reluctance.
Mark is often scolded.
Anne often shouts at her son.

Primary_Text: A Mario vengono chiesti i documenti dai poliziotti.
Translated_Text: Mario is asked for his identity papers by the policemen.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si chiedevano fedeltà reciproca.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke asked for mutual faithfulness of each other.

Primary_Text: Anna chiese i soldi a Luca.
Translated_Text: Anne asked Luke for the money.

Primary_Text: Si parlarono senza giungere ad un accordo.
Translated_Text: They talked without coming to an agreement.

Primary_Text: In questo periodo ci si incontra sempre meno.
Translated_Text: We meet less and less in this period.

Primary_Text: Anna si è incontrata ieri con quel suo vecchio amico.
Translated_Text: Yesterday Anne met that old friend of hers.

Primary_Text: Si segue la rotta prestabilita senza variazioni.
Translated_Text: One follows/We/You/They (indef.) follow the pre-established route without variations.
The ship follows its course.

Primary_Text: I turisti seguivano la guida nel museo.
Translated_Text: In the museum the tourists followed the guide.

Primary_Text: Marco si aiutò con una corda per arrampicarsi.
Translated_Text: Mark used a rope to help himself to climb.
That drug favours digestion.

Primary_Text: Il mio barbiere rade con molta accortezza.
Translated_Text: My barber shaves clients with great care.
One shaves /We/You/They (indef.) shave every morning.
Luke shaves every morning.

Primary_Text: Marco si rade la barba tre volte la settimana.
Translated_Text: Mark shaves his beard three times a week.

Primary_Text: Il barbiere sta radendo la barba a un cliente.
Translated_Text: The barber is shaving a customer’s beard.

Primary_Text: Anna veste sempre in modo originale.
Translated_Text: Anne always dresses in an original way.

Primary_Text: Alla festa molte signore vestivano l'abito lungo.
Translated_Text: A lot of ladies wore gowns to the party.

Primary_Text: La verità è stata cercata dai familiari per anni.
Translated_Text: The truth has been searched for by the relatives for years.

Primary_Text: La verità viene cercata con umiltà dai saggi.
Translated_Text: Wise men search for truth with humility (lit. truth is searched for with humility by wise men).
One/We/You/They (indef.) had been looking for each other for hours.

Primary_Text: I capi in saldo si cercano dopo Natale.
Translated_Text: Clothes on sale must be looked for after Christmas.

Primary_Text: Si cercano i capi in saldo.
Translated_Text: One is looking for /We/You/They (indef.) are looking for clothes on sale.
I must look for a lawyer.
Anne is looking for an important document.

Primary_Text: Ci siamo cercati per ore senza incontrarci.
Translated_Text: We looked for each other for hours without meeting.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si pensano spesso.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke often think of each other.

Primary_Text: Il piano d'attacco fu pensato dai congiurati di notte.
Translated_Text: The plan of attack was thought up by the night-time conspirators.

Primary_Text: Mario ha pensato a un piano di attacco.
Translated_Text: Mario has thought up a plan of attack.

Primary_Text: Mario ha pensato un piano di attacco.
Translated_Text: Mario has thought up a plan of attack.

Primary_Text: La situazione è ben conosciuta da tutti in paese.
Translated_Text: The situation is well-known by everyone in the village.

Primary_Text: Ci si conosce sempre meglio col tempo.
Translated_Text: One knows oneself/You know yourself/We know ourselves/They (indef.) know themselves better and better with time.

Primary_Text: Gli amici più cari si conoscono nell'infanzia.
Translated_Text: Dearest friends are met in childhood.
Mark knows a lot of secrets.

Primary_Text: Si odorano sostanze che stordiscono per alleviare la fame.
Translated_Text: One smells/We/You/They (indef.) smell numbing substances to relieve hunger.
Wood is burnt in this way.

Primary_Text: Mi brucio questa legna per riscaldarmi.
Translated_Text: I’m burning this wood to warm myself up.
The ship is sunk in this way.
The carpet is rolled in this way.

Primary_Text: I fusti d'olio furono rotolati a fondovalle.
Translated_Text: The oil barrels were rolled to the bottom of the valley.

Primary_Text: Si rotolò il masso fino a fondovalle.
Translated_Text: One/We/They (indef.) rolled the stone all the way down to the bottom of the valley.
One rolls/We/You/They (indef.) roll on the floor.

Primary_Text: Mario si è caricato la macchina.
Translated_Text: Mario loaded his car.

Primary_Text: Ci si carica di legna per l'inverno.
Translated_Text: One loads himself/We load ourselves/They (indef.) load themselves with wood for the winter.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si sono tagliati reciprocamente i capelli.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke cut each other’s hair.
One cuts one's finger/We cut our finger/They (indef.) cut their finger.

Primary_Text: Anna si tagliò il dito per non suonare il pianoforte.
Translated_Text: Anne cut her finger so as not to play the piano.
Quail are killed in this way.

Primary_Text: Le sostanze che stordiscono si odorano per alleviare la fame.
Translated_Text: Numbing substances are smelled to relieve hunger.

Primary_Text: Nel duello, i due nemici si uccisero.
Translated_Text: The two enemies killed each other in the duel.

Primary_Text: Si ruppe l'uovo di Pasqua per vedere la sorpresa.
Translated_Text: One/We/They (indef.) broke the Easter egg to see the surprise.

Primary_Text: Marco si è costruito una casa al mare.
Translated_Text: Mark has built a seaside house.

Primary_Text: Ci si costruisce una casa al mare.
Translated_Text: One builds oneself / We/They (indef.) build ourselves/yourselves/themselves a seaside house.
One likes oneself/You like yourself/We like ourselves/They (indef.) like themselves.

Primary_Text: La folla si spaventa in questo modo.
Translated_Text: The crowd is frightened in this way.

Primary_Text: Alcune sostanze che stordiscono vengono odorate per alleviare la fame.
Translated_Text: Some numbing substances are sniffed to relieve hunger.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si vedono dalla finestra.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke can see each other from their windows.

Primary_Text: Mario si vide un bel film da solo.
Translated_Text: Mario saw a beautiful film on his own.
One sees oneself/You/We/They (indef.) see yourself/ourselves/themselves as ugly.
Mario sees himself as ugly.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si temono reciprocamente.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke fear each other.
One fears himself/You fear yourself/We fear ourselves/They fear themselves with good reason/We/You/They fear each other with good reason.
Mario fears himself.

Primary_Text: Si teme la vecchiaia senza motivo.
Translated_Text: One fears/We/You/They (indef.) fear old age for no reason.
They murdered each other.
One/We/They (indef.) murdered the journalist.
Translation_Other: On a tué le journaliste.

Primary_Text: Ci si uccide per la disperazione.
Translated_Text: One kills oneself/We/You/They (indef.) kill ourselves/yourself/themselves out of despair.
One has killed/We/They (indef.) have killed innocent people.

Primary_Text: Quella pistol-a ha ucciso più volte.
Translated_Text: That gun has killed several times.
Mario burnt himself.

Primary_Text: Si spaventò la folla con un falso allarme.
Translated_Text: One/They (indef.)/We frightened the crowd with a false alarm.
One gets easily frightened./We/They (indef.) get easily frightened.

Primary_Text: Il professore si è spaventato per questo grido di allarme.
Translated_Text: The professor was frightened by this cry of alarm.

Primary_Text: Ieri sera si vedeva la luna.
Translated_Text: Yesterday evening one/we/you/ they(indef.) could see the moon.

Primary_Text: Alcuni bambini si sono rotolati per terra.
Translated_Text: Some children have rolled on the ground.
Comment: In the reflexive form, the pattern may have an agentive interpretation.

Primary_Text: Generalmente la macchina si carica la sera prima della partenza.
Translated_Text: Usually the car is loaded the night before leaving.
Mark has finished loading.

Primary_Text: La scala si costruisce facilmente in questo modo.
Translated_Text: The stairs are built easily in this way.
The stairs are to be built in this way.

Primary_Text: Si mangiò il dolce e poi si uscì.
Translated_Text: One/We/They (indef.) ate the cake and then went out.
Translation_Other: Nous avons mangé le gâteau et puis nous sommes sortis.

Primary_Text: Si tagliò la corda per liberare il cane.
Translated_Text: One/We/They (indef.) cut the rope to set the dog free.

Primary_Text: La corda si tagliò in quel punto.
Translated_Text: The rope cut in that point.
Paper is easily cut.

Primary_Text: Marco si è tagliato involontariamente il dito con i vetri.
Translated_Text: Mark cut his finger by accident with the glass.
Comment: Under the non-agentive interpretation of the subject the pattern instantiates a middle structure (Cennamo 2011d).

Primary_Text: Ci si odora sempre le mani dopo aver cucinato.
Translated_Text: One always smells one's hands/We/You/They (indef.) always smell our/your/their hands after cooking.

Primary_Text: Il pesce non va mangiato crudo.
Translated_Text: Fish is not to be eaten raw.
Translation_Other: Le poisson ne doit pas être mangé cru.

Primary_Text: Marco e Giovanni si conoscono da una vita.
Translated_Text: Mark and John have known each other for ages.
One knows/We/You/They (indef.) know numerous chemical elements.

Primary_Text: Ci si mangia un dolce a colazione.
Translated_Text: One eats/We/You/They (indef.) eat a cake for breakfast.
Mark was looking and he didn’t speak.
Humus is seen through a microscope.

Primary_Text: Ci si guarda con astio senza motivo.
Translated_Text: We/You/They (indef.) look at each other with resentment, without reason.

Primary_Text: Marco si conosce fin troppo bene.
Translated_Text: Mark knows himself all too well.
They looked at each other with hatred.
Translation_Other: Ils se regardaient avec haine.

Primary_Text: Le sostanze tossiche non vanno odorate.
Translated_Text: Toxic substances must not be smelled.

Primary_Text: Marco guardava le stelle dal balcone.
Translated_Text: Mark looked at the stars from the balcony.
Translation_Other: Marc regardait les étoiles du balcon.

Primary_Text: Anna si odora sempre le mani dopo aver cucinato.
Translated_Text: Anne always smells her hands after cooking.
The sheets smell of lavander.
Comment: This examples instantiates the intransitive use of the verb odorare.

Translated_Text: Mark hugged himself to Laura.

Primary_Text: Marco e Laura si abbracciano ogni volta che si incontrano.
Translated_Text: Mark and Laura hug each other every time they meet.
Mark is hugging Laura.
Translation_Other: Marc embrasse Laure.

Translated_Text: The dog smells its owner.

Primary_Text: La partita è stata giocata nonostante la pioggi-a.
Translated_Text: The match was played despite the rain.
Translation_Other: Le match a été jouée malgréla pluie.

Translated_Text: I'm going to watch a film this evening.

Primary_Text: I nostri bambini giocano con i coetanei.
Translated_Text: Our children play with children of their own age.
Translation_Other: Nos enfants jouent avec les enfants de leur âge.

Primary_Text: Giocammo una partita e segnai quattro gol.
Translated_Text: We played a match and I scored four goals.
Translation_Other: Nous avons joué un match et j'ai marqué quatre buts.

Primary_Text: La partita Napoli-Roma si gioca oggi.
Translated_Text: The Naples-Rome match is being played today.

Primary_Text: Si teme da parte del partito la candidatura di Marco.
Translated_Text: The party fears Mark's candidacy.
Translation_Other: La candidature de Marc est redoutée par le parti.

Primary_Text: La discussione è trascesa e si è temuto che potesse degenerare.
Translated_Text: The discussion got out of hand and one/we/ they (indef.)/feared/it was feared that it could degenerate.
Translation_Other: La discussion a dépassé les bornes et on a craint qu'elle puisse dégénérer.

Primary_Text: Il generale è temuto dai suoi soldati.
Translated_Text: The general is feared by his troops.
Translation_Other: Le général est redouté par ses soldats.

Primary_Text: Per alcune ore si è temuto il peggio sulla sorte di Simone.
Translated_Text: For some hours one feared /we/they (indef.) feared the worst for Simon’s fate.
Translation_Other: Pendant plusieurs heures, on a craint le pire pour le destin de Simon.

Primary_Text: La vecchiaia si teme senza motivo.
Translated_Text: Old age is feared without any reason.

Primary_Text: Il Re piemontese teme la potenza austriaca.
Translated_Text: The king of Piedmont fears Austrian power.
Translation_Other: Le roi du Piémont craint la puissance autrichienne.

Primary_Text: Il bambino viene abbracciato dai genitori.
Translated_Text: The baby is hugged by his parents.

Primary_Text: Maria si è rotta un polso sciando.
Translated_Text: Mary broke her wrist skiing.
Translation_Other: Marie s'est cassée le poignet en faisant du ski.

Primary_Text: L'uovo di Pasqua si rompe così.
Translated_Text: The Easter egg is broken like this.

Primary_Text: Ci si ruppe reciprocamente le matite.
Translated_Text: We broke each other's pencils.

Primary_Text: Il sigillo della vostra scatola è stato rotto.
Translated_Text: The seal of your box has been broken.
Translation_Other: Le cachet de la votre boîte a été brisé.

Primary_Text: I bambini si ruppero reciprocamente le matite.
Translated_Text: The children broke each other’s pencils.

Primary_Text: Ci si rompe un polso sciando.
Translated_Text: One breaks/We/You/They (indef.) break one’s/our/your/their wrist skiing.

Primary_Text: Mario ruppe il bicchiere con il pallone.
Translated_Text: Mario broke the glass with the ball.
Translation_Other: Mario a cassé le verre avec le ballon.

Translated_Text: The pot broke.
Translation_Other: Le pot s'est cassé.

Primary_Text: Il mio rapporto di fiducia si è rotto.
Translated_Text: My trust is ruined.
Translation_Other: Mes rapports de confiance se sont cassés.

Translated_Text: The glass broke immediately.

Primary_Text: Il giornalista è stato assassinato da due individui.
Translated_Text: The journalist was murdered by two unidentified men.
Translation_Other: Le journaliste a été tué par deux individus.

Primary_Text: L'uomo ha fatto uccidere il suo nemico da un sicario.
Translated_Text: The man had his enemy killed by an assassin.
Translation_Other: L'homme a fait tuer son ennemi par un sicaire.

Primary_Text: L'uomo ha fatto assassinare il suo nemico da un sicario.
Translated_Text: The man had his enemy murdered by an assassin.
Translation_Other: L'homme a fait tuer son ennemi par un sicaire.

Primary_Text: L'automobilista ha ucciso il gatto involontariamente.
Translated_Text: The driver killed the cat accidentally.

Primary_Text: L'omicida ha assassinato la vittima con una corda.
Translated_Text: The killer killed his victim with a rope.
Translation_Other: L'homicide a tué la victime avec une corde.

Translated_Text: We play cards on Sunday.

Primary_Text: L'uomo ha ucciso la vittima con una pistola.
Translated_Text: The man killed his victim with a gunshot.
The young lady killed herself.
Translation_Other: Le jeune fille s'est tuée.

Translated_Text: The two witnesses will be killed.
Translation_Other: Les deux témoins seront tués.

Primary_Text: Ai nostri giorni si uccide per futili motivi.
Translated_Text: Nowadays one kills/we/they (indef.) kill for futile reasons.
Translation_Other: Aujourd'hui on tue pour des motifs futiles.

Translated_Text: Smoking kills.
Translation_Other: Fumer tue.

Primary_Text: Ha ucciso ripetutamente, ecco perché è in carcere.
Translated_Text: He has killed repeatedly, that’s why he’s in prison.
Translation_Other: Il a tué plusieurs fois, et c'est pour ça qu'il est en prison.

Primary_Text: Una tempesta fa affondare la nave.
Translated_Text: A storm is sinking the ship.
Translation_Other: Une tempête coule le navire.

Primary_Text: Si affonda il piede sull'acceleratore troppo facilmente.
Translated_Text: One puts one’s foot /We/You/They (indef.) put our/your/their foot down on the accelerator all too easily.
Translation_Other: On pousse le pied sut l'accélérateur à fond trop simplement.

Translated_Text: The ship has sunk.
Translation_Other: Le navire a coulé.

Primary_Text: Il capitano ha affondato la nave con le cannonate.
Translated_Text: The captain sank the ship by cannonfire.
One burns /We/You/They (indef.) burn because of the heat.
Translation_Other: Ici on crève de chaud.

Translated_Text: Too much rubbish is burnt/One burns/We/They (indef.) burn too much rubbish.
Translation_Other: Trop de déchets sont brûlés.

Primary_Text: Il cassonetto è stato bruciato dai manifestanti.
Translated_Text: The bin was burnt by the demonstrators.
Translation_Other: La poubelle a été brûlée par les manifestants.

Primary_Text: Durante il matrimonio viene bruciato incenso.
Translated_Text: Incense is usually burnt during the wedding.
Translation_Other: Pendant le mariage, de l'encens est brûlé.

Translated_Text: You were burning all that waste paper.
Translation_Other: Tu brûlais tout cette paperasse là.

Primary_Text: I rifiuti si bruciano in questo capannone.
Translated_Text: Rubbish is burnt in this shed.

Primary_Text: La carne si bruciò in pochi minuti.
Translated_Text: The meat burnt in a few minutes.
Comment: With the verb bruciare the presence of the reflexive morpheme si in the anticausative pattern signals a high degree of affectedness of the subject/completion of the process (see Cennamo 1984: 49, 1995: 98-99, Cennamo & Jezek 2009).
Translation_Other: La viande s'est brûlée en quelques minutes.

Primary_Text: La carne bruciò in pochi minuti.
Translated_Text: The meat burnt in a few minutes.
Translation_Other: La viande brûla en quelques minutes

Primary_Text: Mario fece spaventare i ragazzi da Luca.
Translated_Text: Mario made Luke frighten the boys.
Translation_Other: Mario fit effrayer les garçons par Luc.

Primary_Text: Quei due si spaventano intenzionalmente ogni volta che ne hanno l'occasione.
Translated_Text: Those two (men) frighten each other whenever they get the chance.
Translation_Other: Ces deux là s'effraient intentionnellement chaque fois qu'ils ont la possibilité.

Primary_Text: Mario ha spaventato Laura di proposito.
Translated_Text: Mario has frightened Laura on purpose.
Translation_Other: Mario a effrayé Laure de propos.

Primary_Text: Il professore è spaventato da questo grido di allarme.
Translated_Text: The professor is frightened by this cry of alarm.
Translation_Other: Le professeur eat effrayé par ce cri d'alarme.

Primary_Text: Gregorio si è spaventato della sua ombra.
Translated_Text: Gregory was frightened of his shadow.

Primary_Text: Mario spaventa per la sua magrezza.
Translated_Text: Mario frightens everybody because of his skinniness.
Fiascos don't frighten us.
Translation_Other: Les échecs ne nous effraient pas.

Primary_Text: Il lavoratore italiano viene visto il più delle volte come un peso.
Translated_Text: Italian workers are seen as a burden most of the time.
Translation_Other: Le travailleur italien est vu la plupart du temps comme un poids.

Primary_Text: Si gioca a carte tutta la notte.
Translated_Text: One plays cards/We/They (indef.) play cards all night.
Translation_Other: On joue aux cartes toute la nuit.

Primary_Text: Il progresso non è visto come uno strumento per migliorare la qualità della vita.
Translated_Text: Progress is not seen as a means of improving the quality of life.
Translation_Other: Le progrès n'est pas vu comme un outil pour améliorer la qualité de la vie.

Primary_Text: Si vede chiaramente che la sinistra ha molti problemi.
Translated_Text: One/We/They (indef.) can clearly see that the left wing party has a lot of problems.
Translation_Other: Comme on le voit, la gauche a beaucoup de problèmes.

Primary_Text: Stasera la luna si vede chiaramente.
Translated_Text: Tonight the Moon can be seen clearly.
I have seen those pages.
Translation_Other: J'ai vu ces pages là.

Translated_Text: I don't see well at night.
Comment: The omission of the object mainly occurs in modal and negative polarity contexts.

Translated_Text: We often meet each other in the summer.

Primary_Text: Una grossa pietra ha rotolato nel bosco.
Translated_Text: A big rock has rolled in the wood.
Comment: The degree of telicity of the predicate is reflected in the choice of auxiliary in compound tenses, 'have' if the process is unbounded, 'be' if it is bounded.
Translation_Other: Un grand rocher a roulé dans le bois.

Primary_Text: Una grossa pietra è rotolata fino a fondovalle.
Translated_Text: A big stone rolled all the way down to the bottom of the valley.
Comment: The degree of telicity of the predicate is reflected in the choice of auxiliary in compound tenses, have if the process is unbounded, be if it is bounded.

Translated_Text: We got burnt.

Primary_Text: Ero pronto a rotolare fusti d'olio.
Translated_Text: I was ready to roll oil barrels.
Translation_Other: J'étais prêt à rouler des futailles d'huile.

Primary_Text: Il pesce in Giappone si mangia crudo.
Translated_Text: Fish in Japan is eaten raw.
Translation_Other: Le poisson au Japon est mangé cru.

Primary_Text: La torta è stata tagliata dagli sposi.
Translated_Text: The cake has been cut by the bride and the bridegroom.
Translation_Other: Le gâteau a été coupé par les époux.

Primary_Text: Il treno è stato caricato di valigie dai facchini.
Translated_Text: The train has been loaded with suitcases by the porters.
Translation_Other: Le train a été chargé de valises par les porteurs.

Primary_Text: Ci si abbraccia frequentemente in pubblico.
Translated_Text: We/They (indef.) often hug each other in public.

Primary_Text: Il luogo si carica di significati simbolici.
Translated_Text: The place is being pervaded by symbolic meanings.
Translation_Other: Le lieu se remplit de significations symboliques.

Primary_Text: Abramo si caricò di un po' di legna.
Translated_Text: Abraham loaded himself up with some wood.
Translation_Other: Abram se charge d'un peu de bois.

Primary_Text: I venditori caricano i giornali e i libri sulla loro macchina.
Translated_Text: The sellers load the newspapers and the books into their car.

Primary_Text: Generalmente si caric-a la macchina la sera prima della partenza.
Translated_Text: Usually, one loads/we/they (indef.) load the car the night before leaving / Generally cars are loaded the night before leaving.

Primary_Text: Le valigie sono state caricate dai facchini sul treno.
Translated_Text: The suitcases have been loaded onto the train by the porters.
Translation_Other: Les valises ont été chargées par les porteurs sur le train

Primary_Text: I venditori caricano la loro macchina di giornali e libri.
Translated_Text: The sellers load newspapers and books onto their car.
Translation_Other: Les marchands chargent des journaux et des livres sur leur voiture.

Primary_Text: I camion vanno caricati sui treni.
Translated_Text: The trucks are to be loaded onto the trains.
Translation_Other: Les camions doivent être chargés sur les trains.

Primary_Text: Il primo teatro venne costruito da Pompeo.
Translated_Text: The first theatre was built by Pompeus.
Translation_Other: Le premier théâtre fut constuit par Pompée.

Primary_Text: Si costruisce prima la scala e poi il solaio.
Translated_Text: First one builds/we/they (indef.) build the stairs and then the roof.

Primary_Text: La ditta ha costruito le case di legno.
Translated_Text: The firm has built houses out of wood.
Translation_Other: L'entreprise a construit les maisons en bois.

Primary_Text: Non si piaceva e perciò non si è guardata allo specchio.
Translated_Text: She didn’t like herself and that’s why she didn’t look at herself in the mirror.
Translation_Other: Elle ne se plaisait pas, et c'est pourquoi elle ne s'est pas regardée dans la glace.

Primary_Text: Il gatto si è mangiato tutto il filetto.
Translated_Text: The cat has eaten the whole fillet.
Translation_Other: Le chat a mangé tout le filet.

Primary_Text: Il pesce in Giappone viene mangiato crudo.
Translated_Text: Fish is eaten raw in Japan.
Translation_Other: Le poisson est mangé cru au Japon.

Primary_Text: Quell'impresa costruisce in Sicilia, non nel Lazio.
Translated_Text: That firm builds in Sicily, not in Latium.

Primary_Text: Anna e Luca si sono piaciuti subito.
Translated_Text: Anne and Luke immediatly liked each other.

Primary_Text: Il masso rotolò fino a fondovalle.
Translated_Text: The rock rolled all the way down to the bottom of the valley.
Translation_Other: Le rocher roula au fond de la vallée.

Primary_Text: L'insegnante fa piacere la matematica agli studenti.
Translated_Text: The teacher gets the students to like Maths.
Mario likes equations.
Translation_Other: Mario aime les équations.

Translated_Text: The knife doesn't cut well.
Translation_Other: Le couteau ne coupe pas bien.

Primary_Text: Marco taglia il pane con un coltello affilato.
Translated_Text: Mark is cutting the bread with a sharp knife.
Translation_Other: Marc coupe le pain avec un couteau.

Primary_Text: Gli spaghetti furono mangiati da tutti.
Translated_Text: The spaghetti was eaten by everyone.
Translation_Other: Les spaghettis ont été mangés par tout le monde.

Translated_Text: Mark eats a lot.
Translation_Other: Marc mange beaucoup.

Translated_Text: Mark ate the cake.
Translation_Other: Marc mangea le gâteau.

Translated_Text: A place seen with a child's eyes.
It smells as if it had been eaten just now.
Why did you show it to them?
Try to make the dog carry it!
Rame makes her cry a lot.
One has to fill in water and boil it.
But he's made Saili peel it.
Let it bounce with all your force!
Make it appear over there!
Maybe she makes them all sit down.
They cut this one's hair, too.
He will steal and eat everything from you.

Primary_Text: Phakce cam piducaʔ ni, them-them kondupiduca ni!
Translated_Text: Give fodder to the pigs, search something for them!
Let me peel it for you.
He's going to tear this one (apart)!
I heard you're washing Rame's (clothes).
But it looks like it's been peeled.
That is covered ginger.
The pot where the soybeans have been put.

Primary_Text: Huŋgo khalko sahayog pikapi lusikiya teĩbe.
Translated_Text: We give that kind of help to each other in the village.

Primary_Text: Tubiŋsi ghari nikani lusi, rettine, cektine.
Translated_Text: When we have met let's get to know each other, let's laugh and talk.

Primary_Text: Khaŋkakhaŋ lusi gari chitti likhi ta lusaŋsehẽʔ.
Translated_Text: I felt like we could find something just watching each other.
Let's not beat each other!
They say it jumped into the well.
Why did this one fall down?
We look after ourselves.
Now they (come from) various places (and) learn our language.
He's crying, he's covered himself!
Sit down on a stool.
Kancha, throw (something) on your younger brother down there!
This one must be sent to Malaysia.
We had brought him to Dhankuta.

Primary_Text: Ba upadumbe haŋsandothaptuhẽ ta na, hokeʔni masade?
Translated_Text: I did send this one to his uncle - where did it get lost?
Let's bring it to the veranda.

Primary_Text: Anikocuwa huk gari chaceŋa hunikiʔma kattoko.
Translated_Text: When our dog barks the children get frightened.
That guy is a hunter.
The old man doesn't hear his granddaughter's voice.
The women grind millet.
The women grind the millet.
The sun has dried out the pond.
That guy is laughing at us.
Kancha has rolled his ball down there.
Did he tell you his story?
I heard Rame has shaved his beard.
My younger sister is washing our clothes.
Your brother makes Rame afraid of the pigs.
This dog frightens the child.
Rame and the others are afraid of snakes.
The mother has hugged her child.
The child dropped his bike from the cliff.
I want/have an appetite for those citrus fruits.
The child has got a book from the teacher.
Centi is making a plough.
The man has fallen down.
Do you cry?
His sister is ill.
The child appeared on the road.
What have you boiled?

Primary_Text: Cuwa lokto pache choku cimtaŋa lapma kina tima konnoʔ.
Translated_Text: After the water comes to a boil, one has to take the nettles with pincers and put them in.
I've cooked a banana leaf with chilli in that pot.
Speak up, my sister doesn't hear it.
My father taught my younger brothers his language.
Push it up there!
Whose child is pushing me?
Who has dug the hole behind my house?
Is it a person who has dug out this one or what?
Let him try to dig them out.
The child has wiped the dirt off the clothes.
I ground millet.
What is he grinding with the grinding stone?
It has rained.
Up there it has dried up one.
The ducks' pond has dried out.
The sun has burnt the soil.
Mother, the beans got burned!
Rame sank his clothes in the river.
Somebody drowned in the river.
Let him roll it.
This one rolls nicely. / This one rolls (things) nicely.
Comment: S/A detransitivisation and S/P ambitransitivity have the same morphological effect. The only difference is that S/A detransitivisation does not change the valency of a verb. But since there is only one overt argument here, it could be either interpreted as S (< P, S/P ambitransitivity) or as A (S/A detransitivised).

Translated_Text: The child is hungry/has started to feel hungry.
In that case don't be worried.
Don't you feel sad?
Down there the older guys are playing.
The cat plays with mice.
The cat plays with the mouse.
The man has died.
The child feels cold/has started feeling cold.
My belly is aching.
The (two) children were screaming.
This one laughs out loud, like some slut!
Maybe he comes out if we laugh about his ears.
The child lived in the village.
The child went from/left the village.
I had gone to the village.
Why has he gone to Sambugaũ?
We used to sing songs of various types.
The man has sung a song.
The child has jumped (down) to the floor.
The man was sitting on the floor.
The man has sat down on the floor.
The child has run over the floor.
The man has climbed (up) the hill.
The man has coughed.
The sour stuff makes our eyes blink.
The man has loaded hay onto the truck.
The water has come to the top/has filled the tank.

Primary_Text: Huŋgo ibari na sontoloŋŋa abo tiptoŋse.
Translated_Text: Oranges have filled that field of yours.
Friends covered me with wood.
The man has covered the child with a blanket.
The man has filled the tank with water/has poured water into the tank.
The man put the book on the table.
I tied three with a chain.
The man has tied the horse to a tree.
My father has thrown his money at me.
The child has thrown a stone into the window.
This one carries (things) the whole day.
The child carried/brought a book to the teacher.
I sent a letter from Germany.
Rame's father sent money to his younger siblings.
My uncle gives sweets to the children.
He shows us his ass.
The child showed the book to the teacher.
The child has torn a page from the book.
The child hid the teacher's book.
Let the older girl peel it.
The child took away/stole the teacher's book.
Thuli used to take one sack from the Newar woman down there.
The child has cut the bread with a knife.
The child touched the snake with a stick.
The child has hit the snake with a stick.
The child has beaten the snake with a stick.
The child has killed the snake with a stick.
Last time I broke this here with a knife.
Is your leg broken?
Just before the hens broke its side.
Is her nose broken?
The child has broken the window with a stone.
The man has built a house.

Primary_Text: Thitta teĩbe huĩ teĩbeko unɨŋ Dãphe teĩ mo uludoyakte.
Translated_Text: In one village they called that village's name Dãphe (= 'there was a village they called Dãphe').
The woman has called the man an idiot.

Primary_Text: Hou, Syam ubojuŋa "nacuwa" mo ludokokhalo naŋ.
Translated_Text: Yes, Syam's grandmother says "dancer" to him/calls him a dancer.
The man has told the woman a story.
The goats are bleating.
The man has shouted at the woman.
The child has asked the man for money.
The man told his friend (the story) about the woman.
They don't talk up there.

Primary_Text: Aiya, hana payaŋ themma ahandokokha naŋ?
Translated_Text: My, why do you talk about (your) husband, too?
I met a girl on the road.
Here we meet, don't we.
The man has come across the woman.
The man has followed the woman.
The man has helped the woman.
The flood swept away all the soil.
The woman has dressed the child.
Who washed them?
Wash your father's clothes!
Now the crybaby is going to wash it.
The woman has washed the child.
The man has searched for the child.
Debi thinks of that apple.
Kheme knows that.
The man has come to know the child.
The child likes the man.
The man has frightened the child.
The woman is afraid of the mouse.
Comment: This example is far from ideal for illustrating the agreement pattern of the associated frame since the two third persons singular implied by the verb suffixes could be linked to any two of the three roles (experiencer, stimulus, emotion). We have examples for other verbs from this class where linking is unambiguous.

Translated_Text: The woman is afraid of the mouse.
The child has become afraid of the man.
Hey, Maila's pants smell really bad!
The dog has smelled at a(nother) dog's dirt.
The man has seen the child.
The man has looked at the child.
I had hugged Lakhman.
Did Rames also eat sacrificed meat or not?
The woman has eaten the bread.
Her pocket has been torn.
The child has torn the page from the book.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi wentru llumümi ti lifru.
Translated_Text: The boy hid the book.
I met the boy yesterday.
S/he threw a stone / stones.
S/he told me.
S/he tore a page (from something).
I talked to/with him yesterday.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi wentru llowi ti lifru.
Translated_Text: The boy received the book.
Heartburn occurs together with back pain.
I have a sore head.
His/her work did not prosper.
Where do you (sg.) come from?
The man covered the child.
The boy wiped (the dirt off) the table.
S/he threw a stone at me.
S/he thought about his/her mother.
S/he talked about the war.

Primary_Text: Fey kimelmaenew ñi fotüm ñi wedafemagel.
Translated_Text: S/he taught my son to act badly.
Some other transmitted the disease to him/her.
S/he took my spinning top from me.
S/he stole the money.
I stole the money for him/her.
S/he stole my axe.
Do not sit on the hat!

Primary_Text: Iñche ñi chedkuy anüñmaley kutran mew.
Translated_Text: My father-in-law['s house] is besieged by disease.
S/he did not see my apples (e.g. the ones I had stolen from him/her).
Take a look at my wound.
S/he was given a death sentence.
Tell that to the gentleman on my behalf.
S/he has bad intentions concerning my horse (e.g. s/he wants to steal it).
I'll carry the shovel.
I burned my mouth.
S/he is angry at me.
The apple has made me ill.
That made me hungry.
S/he dried the blanket.
S/he dried the blanket.
S/he asked me for my rosary.
You have not made the nail appear yet.
The blanket dried.
The man received his money.

Primary_Text: Ñi ñuke dewmayay kiñe makuñ kal ofisa mew.
Translated_Text: My mother will make a blanket (of sheep's wool).
Her child cried.
S/he taught the man to behave badly.
The man pushed the table.
The man dug.
The woman ground the cooked wheat.
The warlock screamed.
The boat sank.
The egg rolled.
His/her mother is sad.
The girl is cold.
The woman blinked.
You tied the luggage.
She took his/her sheep.
S/he took the horse.
S/he broke a bottle.
My father gave my brother his name / named my brother.
The man shaved.
The man is ill.
I left the court.
You (sg.) peeled this apple.
The man wants a new job.
The girl laughed.
The boy played.
The men heard the thunder.
This meat boiled.
S/he cooked (=baked) two pieces of bread.
The (fire)wood is / has become dry.
The house is burning.
The man thinks about (the celebration of) New Year.
The man smelled the meat.
The man hugged the woman.
It rained.
The boy was hungry.
The man fell into the water.
The man died.
My arm hurts.
My arm hurts.

Primary_Text: Wefpay ti pichi wentru rüpü mew.
Translated_Text: The boy appeared on the road.
The boy sang.
This house is inhabited. / People live in this house.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi wentru amuy waria mew.
Translated_Text: The boy went to the town.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi wentru rüngküy pülli mew.
Translated_Text: The boy jumped on the ground.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi wentru lefi lelfün mew.
Translated_Text: The boy ran on the field.
The man sat on the ground.
The man sat down on the ground.
The man climbed (up) the hill.
The man coughed.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi domo küchafi ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The girl washed the boy.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi domo takufi ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The girl dressed the boy.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi domo i ti kofke.
Translated_Text: The girl ate the bread.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru kellufi ti pichi domo.
Translated_Text: The man helped the girl.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru inafi ti pichi domo.
Translated_Text: The man followed the girl.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru ka ti malen trafüyengu rüpü mew.
Translated_Text: The man met the girl on the road.
The man is a hunter.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru kintufi ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The man searched for the boy.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi wentru kümentuy ti muday.
Translated_Text: The boy likes the chicha.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi wentru ayüfi ti wentru.
Translated_Text: The boy liked the man.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi wentru llükafi ti wentru.
Translated_Text: The boy feared the man.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru trupefülfi ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The man frightened the boy.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru adkintufi ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The man looked at the boy (from afar).

Primary_Text: Ti wentru lelifi ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The man looked at the boy.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru pefi ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The man saw the boy.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru kimfuy ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The man knew the boy.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru ngütramkayefi ti pichi domo ti pichi wentru mew.
Translated_Text: The man talked to the boy about the girl.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru ngütramkalelfi ti pichi wentru ti pichi domo mew.
Translated_Text: The man talked to the boy about the girl.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi wentru ngillatufi ti wentru pülata.
Translated_Text: The boy asked the man for money.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru kiñe ngütram pifi ti pichi domo.
Translated_Text: The man told a story to the girl.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru ngütramelfi ti pichi domo.
Translated_Text: The man told a story / stories to the girl.
