Primary_Text: Ti wentru wirarütufi ti pichi domo.
Translated_Text: The man shouted (angrily) at the girl.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru wirarüfi ti pichi domo.
Translated_Text: The man shouted (from afar) to the girl.

Primary_Text: Chemnorume pilafi ti wentru tati pichi domo.
Translated_Text: The man said nothing to the girl.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru dewmay kiñe ruka mamüll yengu.
Translated_Text: The man built a house with wood.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi wentru watrofi ti malal kiñe fütra kura yengu.
Translated_Text: The boy broke the pen with a big stone.

Primary_Text: Kiñe mamüll mew langümfi ti filu ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The boy killed the snake with a stick.

Primary_Text: Kiñe mamüll mew trawawtrawawtuy ti filu ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The boy beat the snake with a stick.

Primary_Text: Kiñe mamüll mew trawawi ti filu ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The boy hit the snake with a stick.

Primary_Text: Kiñe mamüll mew kachillmafi ti filu ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The boy touched the snake with a stick.

Primary_Text: Katrüy ti kofke ti pichi wentru kuchillu engu.
Translated_Text: The boy cut the bread with a knife.

Primary_Text: Kacharnentumay ñi lifru kiñe hoja ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The boy tore a page from the book.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi wentru llumümmafi ti lifru ñi kimeltuchefe.
Translated_Text: The boy hid the book from the teacher.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi wentru weñeñmafi ti lifru ti kimeltuchefe.
Translated_Text: The boy stole the book from the teacher.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi wentru llowmafi ti lifru ñi kimeltuchefe.
Translated_Text: The boy got the book from the teacher.

Primary_Text: Pengelfi lifru ñi kimeltuchefe ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The boy showed a book to the teacher.

Primary_Text: Elufi lifru ñi kimeltuchefe ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The boy gave a book to the teacher.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi malen amuli ti lifru ñi colegio mew.
Translated_Text: The girl sent the book to her school.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi malen amulelfi ti lifru ñi kimeltuchefe.
Translated_Text: The girl sent the book to her teacher.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi malen yetuy kiñe rayen colegio mew.
Translated_Text: The girl carried a flower to school.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi malen yelfi kiñe rayen ñi kimeltuchefe.
Translated_Text: The girl carried a flower to the teacher.

Primary_Text: Ti pichi malen küpalelfi kiñe rayen ñi kimeltuchefe.
Translated_Text: The girl brought the flower to the teacher.

Primary_Text: Kiñe kura ütrüftufi ti ventana mew ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The boy threw a stone into the window.

Primary_Text: Wenta mesa mew eli ñi lifru ti wentru.
Translated_Text: The man put his book on the table.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru wütruntukuy ko shifüñ mew.
Translated_Text: The man poured water into the glass.
The man tied his horse.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru chechümi ti kareta kachu mew.
Translated_Text: The man loaded the hay on the cart.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru apoli ñi shifüñ ko mew.
Translated_Text: The man filled the glass with water.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru takulfi ti pichiche ti makuñ mew.
Translated_Text: The man covered the child with the blanket.

Primary_Text: Ti wentru takulmafi ti makuñ ti pichiche.
Translated_Text: The man covered the child with the blanket.

Primary_Text: Pod nentuy mesa mew ti pichi wentru.
Translated_Text: The boy wiped the dirt from the table.
The boy is hungry.

Primary_Text: Mwââdö nä fabaa rè kwéé kèè-töpwé rè dèèri.
Translated_Text: The traditional Kanak house represents the symbol of the welcoming of people.
I make him fall.
She makes them cover themselves.

Primary_Text: È faja ri ngê chaa kwéfaö chaa nèpô.
Translated_Text: He made them dig a hole with an iron bar.

Primary_Text: Nâ tê xù è chaa sêgè.
Translated_Text: I threw a stone to him/her.

Primary_Text: Êê fafaxwata ngêê kèè-xa rè chaa märä.
Translated_Text: Someone makes us listen to the song of a bird.

Primary_Text: Mika fafaxûda ngê dökwé chaa mwîî purèkwé.
Translated_Text: Mika made filled up with freshwater a big bottle.
Comment:
Also possible: Mika fafaxûda chaa mwîî purèkwé ngê dökwé "Mika made filled up a big bottle with freshwater".
Or: Mika fafaxûda ngê chaa mwîî purèkwé # dökwé "Mika made filled up with a big bottle # freshwater".

Translated_Text: Mummy made them fill up empty bottles.

Primary_Text: Kèè-toa fè rè ngêê, êê wâ fafamwâmwâ ngêê bwèrè xöu abêêrî.
Translated_Text: At our arrival, we were dressed with old clothes. / lit. ... someone made us put on some old clothes.
Don't be afraid of dying!

Primary_Text: Êê nää fapaiimè rè dèèri tö kètè nä.
Translated_Text: We used to let people die in that place.

Primary_Text: Ke fapaiimè na xuu rè nâ.
Translated_Text: You have let my son die. / You are responsible of the death of my son.

Primary_Text: Kètè nä müü jaja, wâ kèè-xùpè rè ngêê!
Translated_Text: This place is very cold and humid, we were very cold!

Primary_Text: Mîî dèèri nä wâ fafaxùpè ngêê töwâ kwiè.
Translated_Text: These people let us catch a cold under the rain.
Comment: Double causative

Translated_Text: This rain cooled me down.

Primary_Text: Mê röö müü, ke faxùpè péépé.
Translated_Text: Your hands are cold and humid, you are making the baby feel cold.
Come back in, don't catch a cold! / lit. Come in, don't make you cold!

Primary_Text: Aaxa fapwââmè ngê dèèri saa chapöri.
Translated_Text: The chief is having the enemies killed with a war club.
Comment: Alternative word order could be: Aaxa fapwââmè dèèri saa ngê chapöri.

Translated_Text: The chief is having the enemies killed.

Primary_Text: Va kèè-ja rè ri wèi nä.
Translated_Text: This is their way of digging.

Primary_Text: È faja ngê ri chaa nèpô.
Translated_Text: He made them dig a hole. (with something).
Comment: The instrumental preposition stands by itself in this sentence, and could be deleted.

Primary_Text: Kèè-jee rè nêdöö, è chaa mwîî wakè bare.
Translated_Text: Housework is also an important task.
Mummy made him wipe his nose.
It is forbidden to throw stones.
Léo made him throw stones (to teach him how to do it).

Primary_Text: Anyââ fasùsùù ngê è chaa buruatè.
Translated_Text: Mummy made her/him push a wheelbarrow.
The rain made us change our plan. / The rain pushed us out.
His way of throwing is fine.

Primary_Text: Êê fagwéré ngê è chaa böpèkwââ.
Translated_Text: Someone made him throw a wooden stick.

Primary_Text: Îrî catù rö nèpwéé kwiöödöu êê suè rè pa pwâgara.
Translated_Text: We are entering into the system set up by the Europeans.

Primary_Text: Ngêê xacië mîî kwéédöu nârâ kèè-tèpe rè pa xûûchî.
Translated_Text: We are showing these pictures so that children will speak (about them).

Primary_Text: Nä xai kèè-xô rè nî söö rèè?
Translated_Text: And how are we going to sing his song?
Be careful not to tear the book!

Primary_Text: Nä kêrênôdö döbwanä ke téé, è xëtë kèè-xâpârî rè.
Translated_Text: It is true that when you look (at it), it is difficult to see anything.

Primary_Text: Xai kèè-ché rè mîî döu a?
Translated_Text: How do you call these things?

Primary_Text: Ri fädë ngê mô tööi ngê chêêdè nârâ kèè-pisi cè rè nênè-ri.
Translated_Text: They walk around during the night or in the evening searching for food.

Primary_Text: Rè dù kèè-bwa röö xû kwâ mè ke téé kèè-sa rè ngôô dawa.
Translated_Text: It is better if you stay on the boat in order to see us catching dawas(fish).

Primary_Text: Kèè-xù rè pa ga xäba pichöö nä xwi rè wakè rè chaa xwâmwâdö.
Translated_Text: The gift of the niaouli frames by the sculptors is under the responsibility of the clan.

Primary_Text: Dèèri muru nä xânî fa-tèpe rè pa paii.
Translated_Text: The living often speak to the dead.

Primary_Text: Pa pââdö nä cuè mââî ùbwa ti ùbwa rè ri mââîtaa kèè-nû rè taiki.
Translated_Text: First the men must be sitting at their place before sending the dogs.

Primary_Text: Êrê pä mwêgè döö mwîrî mââîtaa kèè-nîî rèè tö nêböö-kwâ.
Translated_Text: The soil is sorted again before filling up the boat with it.

Primary_Text: Nä kèè-xacië rè nâ rö xù è, nâ xwèrii tèpe ngê nââ kèè-xa rè nâ, nââ xârâgurè.
Translated_Text: Then (since) I am introducing you to him, I would prefer to talk in my own language, Xârâgurè. / Then my showing you to him ... .
How did you know?

Primary_Text: Kèè-dii nä xêwi toa saù bwèrè kèè-mwârâ pai.
Translated_Text: A refusal is each time provoking bursts of laughter.

Primary_Text: Ke ché na xù nû nämè ke nä faxwata rè nâ ngê xiti rè ku.
Translated_Text: You said to me that you will tell me about the yam feast.

Primary_Text: Mîî mo bwa nä saù jai rè bwaö mè ri siè amwêrê kèè-suè rè kwéré mê kä pichöö.
Translated_Text: These rafters usually are not higher than the posts so that they do not prevent the laying of straw and niaouli bark.

Primary_Text: Xwânèkii rè gèwâ kèè-cuè rè bwèrè ba afädë tö bare Cöö.
Translated_Text: The reason could be that other ethnic groups are also settled in Thio. / Maybe it comes from the settlement of some migrate groups in Thio.

Primary_Text: È dù kaù mè ke ché bwèrè kèè-ché rè xû dö söö?
Translated_Text: Could you tell me some words about the pilou dance?

Primary_Text: Dèèri kè Pwângara xâdùù na pa faînû.
Translated_Text: French people paid the teachers.

Primary_Text: È sii mwaa nä wâ cokwa kèè-da.
Translated_Text: The meal is going to end soon. / It is not long and the meal will be finished.

Primary_Text: Cokwa bèti, dèèri wâ cuè nârâ kèè-da fachaa.
Translated_Text: After the food sharing has been done, people sat to eat together.

Primary_Text: Êrê siè da ääda êê-chutââ ngê kwé.
Translated_Text: One does not eat food boiled in water.

Primary_Text: Pââübêêrî nää bèti rè xwâda xû kèè-abaa rè mwéa.
Translated_Text: Old people used to divide the year according to the coming out of the moon.

Primary_Text: Xäba pichöö faabaa kwéé pa nûnûû, xöö mèèwânyi.
Translated_Text: The niaouli door frames are representations of the ancestors, the protecting spirits.

Primary_Text: Ri wâ fëi ngê è kwiinètoo, fîda ngè è sîmîâgatè.
Translated_Text: They tied him with a rainbow, hit him with a lightning.
Comment: The object comes between the instrument and the instrumental marker

Primary_Text: Ngêê dè xacië xù rè wîrî!
Translated_Text: It is our turn to show (it) to you!

Primary_Text: È nä xacè rè nâ nârâ kèè-xô.
Translated_Text: He is calling me in order to sing.

Primary_Text: Wâ wakè röö mè ke xwè ke sa è.
Translated_Text: Your work will be to eat it, to kill it.

Primary_Text: È wâ ché xacië wèi a dê...
Translated_Text: He says, pointing to the buzzard...
Do stop crying, eat!
They are crying and screaming.
They dig/lift anything with the landing net.
Comment: sëi also means "shovel"

Primary_Text: È wâ ché nämè: "wèi, jööpè nä, jè faxwata?"
Translated_Text: He said: "eh you! What is this, what is the news?"

Primary_Text: Kù téé, kù nä kèè-paii rè nû ii.
Translated_Text: You see, you always make us suffer.

Primary_Text: Nä wèi a dö, rè xërù nä dê fè sa xwè rè xuu rèè.
Translated_Text: And when the hen has fledglings, the buzzard goes and catches and eats them.
She also organizes her lifestyle.
A running competition for men.
He is tired of running.

Primary_Text: Pââübêêrî rè nâ, ri sati xù bare na nû kèè-piicè rè kèè-mwâwîyâ toa mê.
Translated_Text: My old people, they also taught me how to look for a way of rising (above one's situation).
I have a wound on my foot/leg.

Primary_Text: È xöru mè sii nûgachö nâ kè mwâinû!
Translated_Text: It would be good if I am not expelled from school!

Primary_Text: Ri ché na nämè nêmwâ döu röwâ sati mê fanêgé rè pa afaînû bwa, pa xârâcùù pa înû-gwéré séatö.
Translated_Text: They said that nowadays things about studies and formation of teachers, few Xârâcùù people are successful.
Translation_Other: Ils ont dit qu'aujourd'hui, concernant les études et la formation des enseignants, peu de Xârâcùù réussissent.

Primary_Text: Îrî xacië ùnéxä xù pa xûûchî.
Translated_Text: We showed our knowledge to the children.
People changed their minds.
I am thinking of you. / I feel pity for you.

Primary_Text: Rè va dù xuu kèè-xê rè nâ, mè nâ muru taa kèè nä mutu rè nâ.
Translated_Text: I can only swim a little, in order to avoid drowning.
This disease is contagious.
This child is juggling.
The fish is biting. / lit. The fishing line is biting.
He will only tell one story. / He spontaneously tells a story.

Primary_Text: Ri wâ curu ngê nèmû rèè.
Translated_Text: They tied their belt.

Primary_Text: Ri sööpö ngê kâmîâ âgwii, nä chêêdè, ri akö péré mûgé.
Translated_Text: They were doing the washing during the entire day, and in the evening, they were carrying back up (the clothes).

Primary_Text: Mîrî pââübêêrî bwa ri nää saù akö rè kêböö-xöu rè ngêê kè mê axwè.
Translated_Text: This old men used to carry our basket full of clothes from up there.
They are alive.

Primary_Text: Pa kwara famuru dèèri ngê nô.
Translated_Text: The subjects feed the people with fish.

Primary_Text: Mè nâ nä fètaa rè wîrî!
Translated_Text: I will leave you!
I am taking my shoes off.
They are sitting down together.
My young brother is playing the drum.
Mummy makes them cover themselves.

Primary_Text: Aaxa chéxwaé kèè nä péré rè du wè a toaa.
Translated_Text: The chief is explaining how they will be going all the way up.
He goes straight home.

Primary_Text: Ri fèèté kèèbwa rè döu nä.
Translated_Text: They were following this principle.

Primary_Text: Jööpè döubwa mè è ciiwi töwâ mîî kèè-sèngû nä?
Translated_Text: What can help, concerning these methods?

Primary_Text: Chaakè dèèri wâ xwicè mè ri pwââmè è.
Translated_Text: Several people tried to kill him.
The smoke of the fire makes me blink.

Primary_Text: Nea söpuru rè kèi-äda, aji a.
Translated_Text: This is a knife for cutting meat/fish.

Primary_Text: Panèè-nâ faxwi na mûduè-nâ (ngê) chaa dömwâ.
Translated_Text: My father made my little brother build a traditional house.
He makes them hunters.
I make him speak about the country.

Primary_Text: È nä fadë nä è nä bare tèpe.
Translated_Text: He is walking and talking in the same time.
I am very hungry. / lit. My hunger is big.

Primary_Text: Nèxuu fangûrû chaa xûûchî ngê sê.
Translated_Text: The young girl makes a woman wash the child.
They give them a smell.
They make them smell a perfume.
The master of the earth made the people sit.
The young girl ate (something) with bread.
They feed the people with fish.
The fish is biting.
The fire smoke makes me cough.
It rains.
It rains.
Comment: equivalent to kwiè xwa lit. rain falls , and to kwiè (impersonal alternation) "it rains"

Translated_Text: This old man made the rain fall.

Primary_Text: Pa xûûchî chëi na ri ngê kwâ.
Translated_Text: Children hit them with a stick. / Children hit each other with a stick.

Primary_Text: Pa xûûchî chëi mûgé na ri ngê kwâ.
Translated_Text: Children hit each other with a stick. / Children hit themselves with a stick.
Comment: The addition of mûgé after the verb forces a reflexive or a reciprocal interpretation (and marginally, a repetitive interpretation).

Primary_Text: È nèxä xöru kèè-xwi rè xiti tö mê axwè...
Translated_Text: She knows well how the feast is organized up there.
People from a clan are gathering.

Primary_Text: Ri nä poa ché rè tèpe rè paii.
Translated_Text: They are helping in saying the death rituals.

Primary_Text: Ri nä mètu chuu rè nèmû, nä êrê fëi ri ngê jöökwii.
Translated_Text: They are put on the belts, and then tied with vine.

Primary_Text: Êrê fëi nèmû tö xû mo...
Translated_Text: Belts are tied on the joist. / Someone are tying belt on the joist.
He takes off the coconut fibre.
Mummy is cooking the pork.
His desire for my house makes me angry.

Primary_Text: È xwata kéé-tapö rè chaa döu.
Translated_Text: He hears something bursting.
He refuses to listen to you.
I am grating coconuts.
Why do you cry?

Primary_Text: È ché nemè "wèi, ke téé, nâ kwèti!"
Translated_Text: He says: "Eh you, you see, I am tired!"
I turn the light on to see the house.

Primary_Text: Kârâmè röö paii ùtéé rè kâmîâ.
Translated_Text: I feel pain in my eyes looking at the sun. / My eyes hurt because of looking at the sun.
They see them. / They see each other.

Primary_Text: Aaxa Pokwé faari taa dèèri rèè mè ri dèpuu sùù chaa mwîî kwâdè...
Translated_Text: The chief of Uvea asked his people to push a big wind at their turn...

Primary_Text: Ri fè ùsömârâ ngê tèpe nä.
Translated_Text: They are going to tell this story. / They are going in order to tell this story.

Primary_Text: Anyââ wâ sömârâ ngê chaa tèpe xù ri.
Translated_Text: Mummy is telling them a story.

Primary_Text: Döbwanamè è xâânîî pè-kwiè, è fa-xwa na kwiè.
Translated_Text: When he touched the sacred stone for the rain, he would make the rain fall.

Primary_Text: Dä, acaa pwèkè na è ngê chaa êrêjö.
Translated_Text: The notu pigeon, the hunter killed it with (just) one cartridge.

Primary_Text: Chaaké dèèri wâ xwicè mè ri sa è.
Translated_Text: Several people tried to kill him.

Primary_Text: È nää sa rè dèèri ri nää fè tè chéé a pwanâwâ.
Translated_Text: He used to kill people walking along down on the beach.
His father killed him.

Primary_Text: Wita pûxûrû tö nèsipùpùrè-xwâî ngê gè!
Translated_Text: Don't you run in the middle of the road!
I am running (coming) from the village.
The robber robs the merchant.
The robber steals money from the merchant.
The woman is carrying her basket with a harness.
I accept the cooking-pot of the subjects.

Primary_Text: Pè cè mîrî nä taa Famuru!
Translated_Text: Take the plate from (the hands of) Famuru!

Primary_Text: È xwi bachéé daa mè péépé wâ paii.
Translated_Text: The baby died three days ago.
Comment: Compare with example 202

Primary_Text: È xwi bachéé daa mè péépé paii.
Translated_Text: The baby has been sick for three days.

Primary_Text: È nää bêêrî jaé rö döbwanä rè paii na.
Translated_Text: He was older than you when he died.

Primary_Text: Taiki rè nâ paii, ngêê-Sili xöru.
Translated_Text: My dog is sick, Sili's dog is well.

Primary_Text: Chaa sê ngûrû mîrî, dè saakä kùrè.
Translated_Text: One woman washes the dishes, the other one stows away the cooking pots.
Go wash your face!

Primary_Text: Nâ nû na pââü rè nâ ti xwârè.
Translated_Text: I sent my children to the river.

Primary_Text: Nâ nîmè è xwi ngê kâmîâ.
Translated_Text: I am blinking because of the sun.

Primary_Text: Rè wâ xacè pa kwara rèè mè ri wâ fè piicè nêêwâ-rè.
Translated_Text: He calls his servants so that they go searching for his daughter.
He is sure of it: "My daughter is in Uvea!"

Primary_Text: Pa pwângara va néxä mè îrî pââbu-döö.
Translated_Text: The white people do know that we are the masters of this soil.

Primary_Text: Nâ nêgé xù rö chaa péci.
Translated_Text: I respecfully ask you for a book. / lit. I respectfully ask to you a book.
I feel like sleeping.
I am asking you for banana suckers.

Primary_Text: Nâ nââ taa rö kèè-fè ti niira.
Translated_Text: I ask you to go to the plain.
I am laughing at this story.
Hoping I will live for a long time!

Primary_Text: Bwèrèkètè, ketè wâ paii ngê mêrê.
Translated_Text: Sometimes, the octopus is starving.
Comment: In this example, mêrê means "hunger", formally identical to the verb 'be hungry', even if the verb can also be derived (kèè-mêrê 'my way of being hungry')

Primary_Text: Apaa pè mê na puuchéé ku.
Translated_Text: Dad brought three yams (or three hips of three yams each).
People dug a hole.

Primary_Text: Wâ daa rè kîî cè rè ku.
Translated_Text: It is the time to dig up yams.
My house almost burnt down.
The weather becomes overcast. / lit. The sky has covered it(self).
Comment: The construction is transitive, but only a pronominal object coreferent with the inanimate subject is allowed.

Translated_Text: Mummy covers the child (with a blanket).

Primary_Text: Yaapè gwéré toa na chaa sêgè?
Translated_Text: Who threw up a stone?

Primary_Text: È gwéré chéé chaa pârâ tö nèpwéé-kéé-rè.
Translated_Text: She throws an eel into her basket.

Primary_Text: Xai rö Kasöömèrè mè ke xwi mèrè mè rî fèèté mwaraa-rè...
Translated_Text: Where are you, Glow Worm, let the daylight come so that we may follow the first light of dawn...

Primary_Text: Dui mê Léo nä da pepe rè.
Translated_Text: Dui and Léo will eat separately.
He doesn't eat much.

Primary_Text: È ché nemè: "wèi kù téé, nâ kwèti wâ rö".
Translated_Text: He says: "Eh you! you see, I am tired of you!".
My uncle often sits there.
They are both warming themselves sitting on the sun.

Primary_Text: È nä mê ciiwi rè rî töwâ xwi rè mwâ nöö.
Translated_Text: He will come to help us build that house.
He tears the piece of tissue.
The subjects are separating today. / The subjects are separating them today.
Comment: In this example, the pronominal object is coreferent with the animate subject, expressing reciprocity, or not.

Primary_Text: Nee nyârî biri tö nèpwéé-kwé döbwa ri bu na bumata.
Translated_Text: Sharks are turning back and forth in the water because they smelt a smell of raw flesh.

Primary_Text: Îrî nîî chéé röwâ döu bö.
Translated_Text: We put it in boiling water.

Primary_Text: Rî fabata ngê kura chaa ketè kèèrèmè rè catoa kè nêmwââ-rè.
Translated_Text: We frighten the lobster with an octopus so that it gets out of its hole.
The child is just born.

Primary_Text: Dééri wâ baa kèrè jö mê jia.
Translated_Text: People appeared with spears and war clubs.
The fish hit the water with its tail.

Primary_Text: Wita péré chuu chaa nèpärä wâ nèsipùpù rè kâmîâ.
Translated_Text: Don't climb in a yam field in the middle of the day.

Primary_Text: Duè bwa du axa, du ja na rè bwaanyöu atù.
Translated_Text: These two chiefs, the ones who dig the water conduit over there.

Primary_Text: Rè xwêê saa, döbwa rè siè dù kèè-fè chââri mwââ-nûû kwiöö-wakè rè nikèl ti Xômwâ.
Translated_Text: It is too bad that it is not possible to go to Thio village and visit the nickel museum.
Comment: This impersonal use of xwêê seems to be copied from French "ça tombe mal".

Primary_Text: Wâ-daa chùù nä kwiè nä saù xwa.
Translated_Text: It is cloudy and it rains from time to time.

Primary_Text: Wita bata, nâ tâmwâ döu bwa mè nâ xwi xöru kèèrè gè!
Translated_Text: Don't be afraid, I know how to do as well as you do!

Primary_Text: Ri nârâ cè chaa xwâ caa.
Translated_Text: They are thinking about a way of hunting.

Primary_Text: Ri nä bare xwè rè piö êrêcaa kè nèmëtë.
Translated_Text: They also eat meat (obtained) from hunting in dry places.

Primary_Text: Êê nä bare xô rè söö dèèri néxä xöru mè ba xô wânîî.
Translated_Text: One also sings songs people know well so that all the assembly will sing.

Primary_Text: Ke néxä kaù xwâda bwa êê xwi ngê na mwââxiti a?
Translated_Text: Do you know which year this church was built?

Primary_Text: Ri nä muru ngê nôômara mê caa.
Translated_Text: They are living from cultivated plants and from fishing.
I am filled of coconuts.

Primary_Text: Mwîî aaxa kè Cöö nä cuè tö Wénênê.
Translated_Text: The main chief from Thio stays at Wénênê.

Primary_Text: Êê pwââxwâ tèpe wâ nèpwéé-kètè Cöö.
Translated_Text: One has so often talked about the Thio region.

Primary_Text: Tê chéé ri xêvadi tö nêböö-kwâ!
Translated_Text: Throw them all in the boat!

Primary_Text: Pa Pokwé tê kwii mwîrî nä rè chètùrù kwââ-dèèri rè Deekwââxiti.
Translated_Text: People from Uvea throw a rope which blocks up the boat of Deekwââxiti's men.

Primary_Text: Ri pisi cè nênê-ri, nä ri wâ da.
Translated_Text: The looked for food, and then ate.

Primary_Text: Rè va dù xuu kèè-xê rè nâ mè nâ muru taa kèè-nä mutu rè nâ.
Translated_Text: Indeed, I only swim a little so that I escape from drowning..
Do you know how to swim?

Primary_Text: Nâ nä xwi rè chaa xiti nârâ kèè-faabaa rö xù dèèri kè xûâ.
Translated_Text: I will organize a feast to introduce you to the people of the village.
Comment:
the verb abaa is causativized (fa-) and the derived form is nominalized by kèè-
nârâ "for" comes from the grammaticalization of the verb nârâ "to think"; it introduces nominal phrases complement

Primary_Text: Wâ xutuè ûrû siè ùxâpârî rû.
Translated_Text: It has been a while since we didn't see each other.
Comment: he use of the prefix ù- to express reciprocity (in a transitive construction) only occurs in Thio village, it never occurs in the main part of the Xârâcùù region. It might be due to contact with Xârâgurè, a language which has kept the use of this prefix to express reciprocity. Elsewhere in the Xârâcùù region, reciprocity is marked with the (ad)verb "return, again" postposed to the pronominal object.

Primary_Text: Rè ché na xù nû mè è nä dù rè mè göu fè téé rèè anâ.
Translated_Text: He said to me that you can go and see him now.

Primary_Text: Rè tèpe kaù ngê nââ pwângara, na aaxa röö?
Translated_Text: Is your chief speaking French? / Is your chief speaking with the French language?

Primary_Text: È dù mè ke xacè è ngê Myriam.
Translated_Text: You can call her Myriam.

Primary_Text: Arè è xöru mè nâ nä xacië röö xù aaxa.
Translated_Text: Tomorrow, I will introduce you to the chief.
He sees as well as I do.
Comment: No object in this sentence, in which xâpârî refers to the capacity of vision of the subject.

Primary_Text: Wîrî nä xâpârî rè chaa mwââxiti.
Translated_Text: You will see a church.

Primary_Text: Nâ nârâ mè ûrû nä ùpùùtè rè ngê chaa daa...
Translated_Text: I think we will meet [again] one day...
Comment: The middle prefix ù- is a reflex of POc middle/reciprocal prefix *paRi-, but has very few occurrences in Xârâcùù. It is more often attested in the Thio region Xârâcùù variety, where Nguyen and Ipéré have worked. In Canala, the ù- prefix would never occur with pùùtè, and is not obligatory as shown in the example 233, also from Nguyen and Ipéré.

Primary_Text: Ke tâmwâ kaù mè nâ mââ xöyö chaa sê ngürü?
Translated_Text: Do you know that I just married a Kanak woman?
Comment: The verb tâmwâ may take a clausal object, introduced by the conjunction mè "that".

Primary_Text: Q. Yaapè ché na xù rö? A. Nâ tâmwâ.
Translated_Text: Who told you? - I know it.
I know him well.
Comment: The pronominal object refers to an animate. Otherwise, no pronominal object can be expressed (see other example)

Translated_Text: You know how to count.

Primary_Text: Nâ siè tâmwâ kètè bwa rè nöö nä.
Translated_Text: I don't know where he is staying. / lit. I don't know the place he is staying there.
Comment: In this example, tâmwâ has a nominal direct object: kètè "place"

Primary_Text: Nâ siè nârâ mè wîrî nöö Cöö.
Translated_Text: I don't think you are living in Thio.

Primary_Text: Mârâdii a ne têîdùù rè kä-rè mwiri.
Translated_Text: The snake is crying about his skin.
The child is crying.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû nä abaa tö kûcaa rè xwâî.
Translated_Text: The man appears at the corner of the road.
Water is boiling.

Primary_Text: Xwata kèè-sööté rè apaa tö nuö!
Translated_Text: Listen to the noise that Daddy makes in the forest!
He doesn't listen at all. / He doesn't listen to anything.
Sing louder so that we can hear you!
The ball is rolling.

Primary_Text: Gwèè îrî nää sëi ngê nachê.
Translated_Text: In the past we used to dig with a wooden shovel.
Kachuupôô digs the tunnel.

Primary_Text: Êê nää chûrû mê bikörö rè pîî-köfi.
Translated_Text: We used to grill and grind coffee beans.
The taro field is slowly getting dry.

Primary_Text: Xöu mëtë töwâ kâmîâ tö nä.
Translated_Text: Clothes are drying under the sun over there.

Primary_Text: È wâ mëtë xöru na mèi.
Translated_Text: The grass is very dry.
The sun is burning the island.
The yam is burnt.
The boat sank.
I am sad.
I regret my father. / I am sad because of my father.

Primary_Text: Siè xêê-da rè nâ, pââ-nâ paii.
Translated_Text: I can't eat, my teeth hurt.
My arm hurts.

Primary_Text: Nâ ngââ chavaa lotoo xù chaa kâmûrû.
Translated_Text: I scream to warn someone of the car.

Primary_Text: Pâê nä tèpe mê mwârâ döbwanä ri nä pètù rè döxöu.
Translated_Text: Women are talking and laughing while they are plaiting mats.
The children are playing outside.
They are living at the river.
They left their boat.

Primary_Text: È bata taa na fètaa rè mwâciri rèè.
Translated_Text: He was afraid to leave his country.

Primary_Text: Xötö wâ fè na kè döxûâ.
Translated_Text: The boy left the village.
Children are going to the river.

Primary_Text: È xô xöru bare kèèrè märä.
Translated_Text: He sings as well as birds.
The boy sang (a song).
The man sat (on the floor).
Comment: dynamic event: a directional is expressed

Translated_Text: The child jumped on the floor (from a chair, a wall...).
The child ran.
The man climbed on the hill.

Primary_Text: Ri fètaa kwââ-ri nä ri döö fädë péré toa ti xûâ.
Translated_Text: They leave their boat and go up to the village with bare hands.
I am peeling the tree.

Primary_Text: Anyââ satee na xuu xûûchî rèè.
Translated_Text: Mummy hugged her young child.

Primary_Text: Xwârè bwa ke mââ ciköpuru na êê xacè ngê xwâ-Jarimwâ.
Translated_Text: The river you just crossed is called river Jarimwâ.

Primary_Text: Ke tèpe wâ puu-rö mê nîî-rö.
Translated_Text: You are talking about your origin and your name.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû tèpe na wâ nèxuu xù xötö.
Translated_Text: The man talked to the boy about the girl.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû pùùtè na niè mê nèxuu.
Translated_Text: The man met the girl. / lit. The man met, he and the girl.
The man met the girl.

Primary_Text: Dèèri mê anyââ pùùtè tö Kwênyêngêrê.
Translated_Text: People and Mummy meet at Kwênyêngêrê.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû fèèté na nèxuu xû xwâî.
Translated_Text: The man followed the girl on the road.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû ciiwi na nèxuu tiwâ kèè-caa.
Translated_Text: The man helped the girl fishing.
They are helping them. / They are helping each other.

Primary_Text: È nä piicè rè nea rèè tö kètè wânîî.
Translated_Text: He is searching for his knife everywhere.
You are going to search for a place to stay.

Primary_Text: È wâ fâwi chaaké dèèri mè ri wâ fè piicè rè ru.
Translated_Text: He chooses several persons to go search for the two of them.
I am homesick. / I am thinking about my house.
I feel pity for someone. / I am thinking about someone.
The man looked at the boy (who was coming).
The man looked at the boy (who was going away).
I am blinking (my eyes).
The man died.

Primary_Text: Nèxuu pè na péci taa afainû.
Translated_Text: The girl took the book from the teacher. / The girl got the book from the teacher.
I shave.
I shave him.
The man washed (himself). / The man washed him again.
Comment: mûgé "return, again" is used as reflexive and reciprocal marker; its marks coreference between the subject and the object. But it may also express a repetitive action.

Translated_Text: The girl washed the child.
The girl dressed the child (with a robe).
He smells a smell coming from the earth. / Lit. He smells a smell of earth.

Primary_Text: Nâ faînû xù è ngê nââ xârâcùù.
Translated_Text: I am teaching him the Xârâcùù language. / Lit. I am teaching to him with the Xârâcùù language.

Primary_Text: Nâ nä faînû rèè ngê nââ xârâcùù.
Translated_Text: I am teaching him the Xârâcùù language.
Comment: The patient (the one who is taught) is the direct object (-è) while what is taught is introduced by the instrumental preposition ngê.

Translated_Text: It was cold yesterday.
Comment: In an impersonal construction (without subject), xùpè means "cold" for the weather.

Translated_Text: The boy is cold.
The boy is hungry.
They are gathering. / They are sitting together.
The man was sitting (on the floor).
Comment: static event (no directional needed)

Translated_Text: The man coughed.
The girl ate some bread.
The girl ate the entire bread.
You are eating fish. / You are eating your food (which is) fish.
This man is a hunter/fisherman.
The boy liked the man.

Primary_Text: Xötö bata xwi cara na kamûrû.
Translated_Text: The boy feared the man. / The boy was afraid of the man.
Comment: The transitive form of bata "be afraid" necessarily takes a compound form.

Translated_Text: He is afraid of speaking.
The man frightened the boy.
The man saw the boy.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû néxä na xötö nä mè niè mê è wâ fè.
Translated_Text: The man knew the boy with whom he was going to go.

Primary_Text: Xötö nä nêgé rè chaa péci xù chaa kamûrû.
Translated_Text: The boy asks someone for a book.

Primary_Text: Xötö nââ na mwânè taa kamûrû.
Translated_Text: The boy asked the man for money. / The boy asked money from the man.

Primary_Text: Ri wâ sömârâ ngêrê chaa tèpe.
Translated_Text: They are going to tell a story.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû faxwata ngê chaa tèpë xù nèxuu.
Translated_Text: The man tells a story to the girl.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû xangââ ngê na xwâxatii xù nèxuu.
Translated_Text: The man shouted reprimands at the girl. / The man shouted at the girl with a reprimand.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû xangââ ngê na chaa ùnââ taa nèxuu.
Translated_Text: The man shouted to ask something from the girl.
The man shouted at the girl (to yield at her).
The man shouted at the girl (to say hello to her).
Comment: The use of the beneficiary preposition xù indicates that the man shouted at the girl to say hello to her, and not to yield at her or to ask her something.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû sii ché na döu xù nèxuu.
Translated_Text: The man said nothing to the girl.

Primary_Text: Pa pwâgara xwi farawa va nèkè-ri.
Translated_Text: Europeans make bread for their starchy food.

Primary_Text: Xè mîî êrêcaa bwa purè-ri xwi.
Translated_Text: Colour the living creatures which have a shell.
What's going on?

Primary_Text: Kamûrû xwi na mwâ ngê sêgè.
Translated_Text: The man built the house with stones.

Primary_Text: Xötö jikörö na xwânyûû ngê sêgè.
Translated_Text: The boy broke the window with the stone.
The boy killed the snake (with the stick).
Comment:
There are several specific verbs expliciting in which manner the killing action took place: boèmè "kill by hitting", chaamè "kill with an axe", chuuamè "kill with the fist", pwââmè "kill by hitting on the head with a stick", söömè "kill with a stick", taamè "kill with a gun or a spear", etc.
Because of this compound forms which include the instrument of the killing, there is not necessity to express "with I".

Primary_Text: Xötö fîgai na mârâdii ngê köökwââ.
Translated_Text: The boy beat the snake with the stick.

Primary_Text: Xötö fîda na mârâdii ngê köökwââ.
Translated_Text: The boy hit the snake with the stick.

Primary_Text: Xötö sakai na mârâdii ngê köökwââ.
Translated_Text: The boy touched the snake with the stick.
The boy cut the bread (with the knife).
Comment: sö- already indicates that the cutting is a circular action, done with a cutting instrument.

Translated_Text: I am wiping my nose.

Primary_Text: Nèxuu jee na chirèdöu kè xû taapërë.
Translated_Text: The girl wiped the dirt from the table.
They are hiding the skin of the snake.

Primary_Text: Nèxuu sûûârâ na péci taa afainû.
Translated_Text: The girl hid the book from the teacher.

Primary_Text: Nèxuu pêdè na péci taa afainû.
Translated_Text: The girl stole the book from the teacher.
Comment: taa, the non-beneficiary preposition comes from the verb taa 'leave', which is seldom used by itself and is mostly used as part of verbal compounds.

Primary_Text: Nèxuu xacië na péci xù afainû.
Translated_Text: The girl showed the book to the teacher.

Primary_Text: Nèxuu xù na ngê chaa péci xù afainû.
Translated_Text: The girl gave the book to the teacher (to show off).
Comment: T is peripheralized by the use of the instrumental preposition ngê.

Primary_Text: Nèxuu xù xù na afainû péci.
Translated_Text: The girl gave the book to the teacher.
Comment: The benefactive preposition xù can be postposed to the verb xù 'give' from which it grammaticalized, as in a serial verb construction.

Primary_Text: Nèxuu xù na péci xù afainû.
Translated_Text: The girl gave the book to the teacher.

Primary_Text: Nèxuu nû na péci ti mwâinû.
Translated_Text: The girl sent the book to school.

Primary_Text: Nèxuu nû na péci xù afainû.
Translated_Text: The girl sent the book to the teacher.
Comment: benefactive preposition xù < verb xù 'give'

Translated_Text: He brings a basket full of coconuts.

Primary_Text: Nèxuu pè mê na péci ti afainû.
Translated_Text: The girl brought the book to the teacher.
Comment: The girl was not near the teacher, took the book, had to come near, and gave it.

Primary_Text: Nèxuu pè fè na péci ti afainû.
Translated_Text: The girl brought the book to the teacher.
Comment: The girl was near the teacher, took the book, gave it and went away.

Primary_Text: Xûûchî gwéré catù na sêgè tö xwânyûû.
Translated_Text: The child threw the stone through the window.

Primary_Text: Xûûchî gwéré na sêgè xû xwânyûû.
Translated_Text: The boy threw the stone into the window.

Primary_Text: Êê suè na pènèrè tö xû sêgè Nèsiwéa.
Translated_Text: The foundation stone has been laid on the rock Nèsiwéa. / One has laid the foundation stone on the rock Nèsiwéa.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû suè na péci xû taapërë.
Translated_Text: The man put the book on the table.

Primary_Text: Kwââ a xwêê na töwâ kwâdè.
Translated_Text: This tree fell because of the wind.

Primary_Text: Nâ xwêê kwé nèpwéé chaa mîrî.
Translated_Text: I am pouring water into a plate.
The man fell down.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû nä suxwêê kwé nèpwéé vèr.
Translated_Text: The man poured the water (into) the glass.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû curu na oosi töwâ puukwââ.
Translated_Text: The man tied the horse to the tree.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû nîî na karèèsi ngê nyüükwéré.
Translated_Text: The man loaded the cart with hay.
I am filling a bucket.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû nä faxûda na vèr ngê dökwé.
Translated_Text: The man filled the glass with fresh water.

Primary_Text: Kamûrû nä kasache na xûûchî nä ngê kwèrètii.
Translated_Text: The man covered the child with a blanket.
It rains.

Primary_Text: Nèxuu chètia na nènèpéci kèwâ péci.
Translated_Text: The girl tore the page from the book.

Primary_Text: Ke poa xwèi mèi taa nyââ.
Translated_Text: You are helping Mummy cut off the grass.
Comment: The preposition is taa, since because of one's help (by doing the same thing as someone else), one is withdrawing something from someone! One may change the word order, and say: ke poa xwèi taa nyââ mèi.

Translated_Text: He told her.
He saw the boy.
We see the seal.
He showed me the fish.
His foot is hurting (him).
Comment: The causative form with this root seems to work differently. Details still need to be studied.

Translated_Text: He made it cold.
I let it get hungry.
Salmonberry shoots made me hungry. / Salmonberry shoots whetted my appetite.
I will scold you.
He made me throw the wood (into fire).
Throw my coat to/for me!
He made him kill it.
I will kill it for you.
The little dog got killed.
I am going to kill the bear.
Let it die!
I got hurt.
You are sitting on me.

She had/has the elder sitting down.

They brought out a pretty coat for him/her.

I brought my ax back.
He went to find out what time it's going to start.
He made us search for his glasses.
She startled me.
to startle s.o.
Fill up your basket!
I already gave (it/sth.) to him.
He had him give (e.g. donations).
He gave it away.
Did the table get wiped?

He made me wipe the table.
Wipe some of the cups!
He made me follow the deer.
The woman screamed.
blanket
I made Cynthia cover the baby (child) with a blanket.
He will be okay. / lit. 'He will be good.'
The glass broke.
Break it for me!
He made him break the bottles.
Break (off) the ice!
Mary is bathing a baby. / lit. 'A baby/child is being bathed by Mary.'
I will bathe Norma's baby/child.
shave/scrape something
I will sink the boat (canoe).
She made him cough.
The man coughed.
I got it dry.
I got hit.
Hit it for me!

My net ripped.
Think about the next one we are going to do.
John is carrying it.
Hide my money for me!

I hid some money.

Run for me!
You run to your father!
I will run away with you.

fell trees
Comment: Note that this form has lexicalized meaning 'to fell trees'.

Translated_Text: I went to Powell River yesterday.
Mink went towards the knot in the wall.
Comment: The oblique marker is omitted.

Translated_Text: He went towards the knot(hole) in the wall.
I will take you guys to Powell River.
I finally made it.
I will build your house for you.
I made the man make (it).
I will build a box.
I smell it now.
They let the dog smell (it).

She has already asked her mother.
I heard it.
Mary cooked the meat slowly. / The meat was cooked slowly by Mary.
Let it cook well.
She made me cook.
I have cooked it.
The bread is cooked.
She cooked some bread for me.
I will bake bread.

Cut some wood!
I have already cut the fish.
My forehead got cut.

He made him steal it.

All the cats died.
Catherine gets scared easily.
Comment: root vowel change is unexplained

Translated_Text: You startled me.
Comment: The SBJ/OBJ roles switch from non-(relational) applicative, i.e., regular transitive form.

Translated_Text: You are going to scare the baby.
Take some for your lunch!
He likes himself.
I will eat the fish.
He ate my food.
I will let you eat it.
He ate bread.
You dig it.
I am going to dig some potatoes.
They are laughing at me.
She laughs.
Comment: no better example

Translated_Text: She plays.
I will play with her.
Comment: This “causative” is an instance of associative causative (e.g., 'go'-CAU means ‘bring X, go with X’). qaqs-imʼ means ‘to play (intr. with the middle)’. The reading ‘make him/her play’ is not attested.

To smell one's own foot.

Translated_Text: Oje used black soap to wash plates. / Oje washed plates with black soap.

Oje washed the gourd.

Primary_Text: Òjè gbúlú ọ́lí íkẹ̀kẹ́ yé òhí.

Oje coughed all over. / Oje coughed away.

Primary_Text: Òjè húá élì ọ̀gẹ̀dẹ̀ ọ́ vbì ìtébù.

Oje chopped wood to a rubble. / Oje cut the wood away.

Primary_Text: Òjè gbóó élí ívbèkhàn kú à.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ àgbòí mẹ̀ zẹ́ étò.
Translated_Text: Oje shaved his hair with my jackknife. / Oje used my jackknife to shave his hair.

Primary_Text: Ọ̣́lì òmì ọ̀ ọ́ tín kú à.

Translated_Text: The soup is boiling over into the fire.

Oje pushed a rock away.

Primary_Text: Òjè súá údò fí ọ́ vbí ẹ́dà.

Primary_Text: Òjè súá ọ́lí údò yé òhí.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ sùà ẹ̀kpètè lí àlèkè.

Oje took cassava to Ohi.
Oje took yam to Ohi.
Oje dug yam for Ohi. / Oje harvested yam for Ohi.

Primary_Text: Òjè kálọ́ évbìì ọ́ vbì ìtébù.
Translated_Text: Oje wiped oil onto the table. / Oje rubbed oil onto the table.

Primary_Text: Àlèkè ọ̀ ọ́ kàlọ̀ ìtébú lì òhí.
Translated_Text: Aleke is wiping the table for Ohi. / Aleke is wiping the table for Ohi's benefit.

Primary_Text: Òjè lọ́ ísíẹ́ìn kú ọ́ vbì ìtásà.

Primary_Text: Òjè lọ́ ísíẹ́ìn ọ́ vbì ìtásà.

Primary_Text: Òjè tóó ọ́lí ébè kú à.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ èràìn tóó ọ́lí ébè á.
Translated_Text: Oje used a fire to burn up the leaves. / Oje burned up the leaves with a fire.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ rẹ̀ ègbé gbùlù èkẹ̀n.
Translated_Text: Oje is rolling in the sand with his body. / Oje is rolling his body in the sand.

Primary_Text: Ọ́lì ìkhùnmì ọ̀ ọ́ rẹ̀ òhánmí gbè òjè.
Translated_Text: The medicine is making Oje hungry.

Primary_Text: Ọ̣̣́́lí ọ́mọ̀ ọ̀ ọ́ rẹ̀ èkẹ́n dòó.
Translated_Text: The child is fantasizing with sand. / The child is playing with sand.

Primary_Text: Áléké ú ọ́ vbí ídámí úkpódẹ̀.
Translated_Text: Aleke died up ahead on the road.
Aleke died off. / Aleke dropped dead.

Primary_Text: Áléké ú fì ọ́ vbí ídámí úkpódẹ̀.
Translated_Text: Aleke dropped dead up ahead on the road.
Oje left. / Oje exited.
Oje sang a song to Aleke.
The frog jumped away. / The frog leaped away.

Translated_Text: The frog jumped onto the road. / The frog leaped onto the road.
The leopard jumped away.

Primary_Text: Ọ̣́lì ẹ̀kpẹ̀n vbọ́ọ́ fì ọ́ vbì òtọ̀ì.
Translated_Text: The leopard jumped onto the ground.
Oje ran off. / Oje ran away.

Primary_Text: Ójé ọ̀ ọ́ lá lí ọ̀nwìmè.
Translated_Text: Oje is running from the farmer.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ úì hẹ́ẹ́n ọ́lí údìn.
Translated_Text: Oje climbed the palm tree with a rope. / Oje used a rope to climb the palm tree.

Primary_Text: Òjè kẹ́nhẹ́n kú ọ́ vbí émàè.
Translated_Text: Oje coughed all over the food.
Oje coughed.

Primary_Text: Àlèkè gbá ìsávbẹ̀ẹ́ ọ́ vbì àwẹ̀.
Translated_Text: Aleke tied dika nut anklets onto her feet.
Aleke tied the baby sash for Oje.

Primary_Text: Àlèkè fí éànmì fí ọ́ vbì òkpàn.
Translated_Text: Aleke threw meat into the gourd.

Primary_Text: Àlèkè fí èkhọ̀ì fí ẹ́ òhí.
Translated_Text: Aleke threw a worm onto Ohi.
Oje carried yam with a bag. / Oje used a bag to carry yam.
Oje peeled yam for Aleke.

Primary_Text: Òjè bóló ọ̀gẹ̀dẹ̀ fí ọ́ vbí úkpódẹ̀.
Translated_Text: Oje peeled plantain all over the road. / Oje tossed plantain peelings all over the road.
Oje peeled plantain for Ohi.

Primary_Text: Òjè nyá úsúọ́ká vbí óràn ré.
Translated_Text: Oje tore an ear of maize from the stalk. / Oje ripped an ear of maize from the stalk.

Primary_Text: Òjè bẹ́nnọ́ ùkèlè lí élí ívbèkhàn.
Translated_Text: Oje cut morsels for the children. / Oje chopped morsels for the children.

Primary_Text: Òjè bẹ́nnọ́ éràn kú ọ́ vbí úkpódẹ̀.
Translated_Text: Oje cut wood all over the road. / Oje chopped wood all over the road.

Primary_Text: Élí ímọ̀hè híán ọ́lí úgbó' kú ọ́ vbì òtọ̀ì.
Translated_Text: The men cut the forest all the way to the ground.
Oje took yam to Ohi.

Primary_Text: Òjè híán ọ́lí úì ọ́ vbì èvá.
Translated_Text: Oje cut the rope into two.

Primary_Text: Òjè híán ọ́lí úì lí òhí.
Translated_Text: Oje cut the rope for Ohi.
The rope got cut off.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ gbè ọ̀lí ọ́vbékhán lì ọ̀há ọ́ì.
Translated_Text: Oje is beating the youth for his wife.

Primary_Text: Òjè gbóó élí ívbèkhàn kú ọ́ vbí úkpódẹ̀.
Translated_Text: Oje killed the youths all over the road.

Primary_Text: Òjè gbóó élí ékhè kú ọ́ vbí úkpódẹ̀.
Translated_Text: Oje broke the pots all over the road.

Primary_Text: Òjè gúọ́ghọ́ úkpàsánmì kú ọ́ vbí úkpódẹ̀.

Oje built a house for Ohi.

Primary_Text: Òjè zẹ́ étò lí ínyọ́ ọ́ì.
Translated_Text: Oje shaved his hair for his mother. / Oje shaved in honor of his mother.
Aleke bathed Oje. / Aleke gave a bath to Oje.

Primary_Text: Àlèkè rẹ́ íhìọ̀n khọ́ọ́ ọ́lí ọ́mọ̀.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ rẹ̀ ùrúkpá mẹ́ hòò ákhè.

Primary_Text: Ójé lọ́ hòò émà lí ọ́lì ọ̀nwìmè.
Translated_Text: Oje will search for yam for the farmer.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ hòò lí áléké dà ẹ́nyọ̀.
Translated_Text: Oje wants Aleke to drink wine. / Oje intends that Aleke should drink wine.
Oje received money from Aleke. / Oje accepted money from Aleke.
Oje received money. / Oje accepted money.
Oje made a box (of wood). / Oje built a box.
Oje fell.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ vìẹ̀ èrá ọ́ì.
Translated_Text: Oje is crying for his father. / Oje is mourning his father.
Oje cried.
Oje is ill. / Something is paining Oje.

Primary_Text: Àlèkè rẹ́ égbè vbíẹ́ẹ́ ívbíá ọ́ì.

Aleke appeared. / Aleke made her body apparent.

Aleke used a pot to cook soup. / Aleke cooked soup with a pot.
Aleke cooked soup. / Aleke prepared soup.

Primary_Text: Ọ̣́lì èràìn í khà vbìè émàè.
Translated_Text: The fire will not cook food.

Primary_Text: òjè ọ̀ ọ́ họ̀n ìkhúéé àlèkè.

Oje perceives with his nose. / Oje smells (something).
Oje hears. / Oje perceives with his ear.
Oje taught Ohi arithmetic.
Oje taught arithmetic to Ohi. / Oje showed arithmetic to Ohi.
Oje stole the goats.
Oje stole the cloth.
Oje brought yam.
Oje is pushing a stool.
Oje used a cutlass to uproot cassava. / Oje uprooted cassava with a cutlass.
Oje dug up cassava. / Oje uprooted cassava.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ ọ́píá mẹ̀ tọ́n émà.
Translated_Text: Oje used my cutlass to dig for yam. / Oje dug for yam with my cutlass.
Oje dug for yam. / Oje harvested yam.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ rẹ̀ èsọ́nkpún kàlọ̀ ìtébù.
Translated_Text: Oje is using a rag to wipe the table. / Oje wiped the table with a rag.
Oje is wiping the table.

Primary_Text: Òjè kálọ́ évbíí vbì ìtébù ré.
Translated_Text: Oje wiped oil from the table. / Oje rubbed oil from the table.

Primary_Text: Òjè kálọ́ évbíí shọ́ọ́ vbì ìtébù ré.
Translated_Text: Oje wiped oil way off the table. / Oje rubbed oil way off the table.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ rẹ̀ ùdó lọ̀ ìsíẹ́ìn.
Translated_Text: Oje is using a stone to grind pepper. / Oje is grinding pepper with a stone.
Oje is grinding pepper.
He’s a hunter.
Oje is not a hunter.
It is raining. / Rain is falling.
The cloth is dry.
Oje is burning leaves.
The leaves are burning.
The moon has sunk. / The moon had gone down.
Oje sunk into the ground. / The ground swallowed up Oje.
The ground sunk.
The orange is rolling.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ gbùlù ọ̀lí íkẹ̀kẹ́.
Translated_Text: Oje is rolling the bicycle.
Oje is hungry.
Oje is sad. / Oje is not happy.
The child is fantasizing. / The child is at play in his fantasy.
The child is playing.
Aleke died.
Aleke has the chills. / Aleke is feverish.

Primary_Text: Ọ́lì èmàì ọ̀ ọ́ rẹ̀ ùíín gbè àlèkè.
Translated_Text: The wound is making Aleke feverish.
Oje's waist is paining him. / Oje has a pain at his waist.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ khùèè ọ́lì òkpòsò.
Translated_Text: Oje is screaming at the woman. / Oje is insulting the woman.
Oje is laughing at Aleke.
Oje laughed.
Oje lived in Afuze.
Oje left the room. / Oje exited the room.
Oje has left the house. / Oje has moved away from the house.
Oje has moved away. / Oje has left.
Oje is going to the house.
Oje is singing a song.
The frog jumped. / The frog leapt.
The leopard jumped.
Oje sat down in a chair.
Oje sat in a chair.
Oje is running.
Oje climbed a wall.
Oje climbed a tree. / Oje ascended a tree.
Oje blinked.
Oje loaded up Ohi.
Oje loaded his burden. / Oje arranged his load.

Primary_Text: Òjè máá élí ékẹ́ín ọ́ọ́khọ̀ ọ́ vbí íhùà.
Translated_Text: Oje loaded the chicken eggs onto his burden. / Oje arranged the chicken eggs onto his load.
Oje loaded the chicken eggs. / Oje arranged the chicken eggs (on a load).
Oje filled the gun (with gunpowder). / Oje loaded the gun (with gunpowder).
My pot is full.
Meat filled the pot of Oje. / Meat filled Oje's pot.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ ìsọ́bìlì vóó ọ́lí ékpà.
Translated_Text: Oje used a shovel to cover the vomit. / Oje covered the vomit with a shovel.
Oje covered the vomit.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ àtìró ọ́ọ́n àmẹ̀ ọ́ vbì ọ̀gọ́.
Translated_Text: Oje used a funnel to pour water into a bottle. / Oje poured water into a bottle with a funnel.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ́ọ́n àmẹ̀ ọ́ vbì ọ̀gọ́.
Translated_Text: Oje poured water into the bottle.

Primary_Text: Òjè nwú ọ̀gẹ̀dẹ̀ ọ́ vbì ìtébù.
Translated_Text: Oje put plantain onto the table.
They tied Oje with ropes. / They bound Oje with ropes.
Oje has tied Aleke. / Oje has bound Aleke.

Primary_Text: Òjè dín úkpúì ọ́ mẹ́ vbí óbọ̀.
Translated_Text: Oje tied a piece of rope onto my arm. / Oje tied a rope onto my arm.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ ẹ̀wàìn dín ọ́lí úì.
Translated_Text: Oje used his intelligence to tie the rope. / Oje tied the rope with intelligence.
Oje tied a piece of rope. / Oje tied a rope.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ ọ́lí úì dín ọ́lí ẹ́wè.
Translated_Text: Oje used the rope to tie the goat. / Oje tied the goat with a rope. / Oje tethered the goat with a rope.
Aleke threw a stick to Oje.
Aleke threw a stick.
Aleke carried the yams.
Aleke carried the yam.

Primary_Text: Òjè yé òhí úhùnmì yé áfúzé'.
Translated_Text: Oje sent Ohi on an errand to Afuze. / Oje sent Ohi with a message to Afuze.
Oje sent Ohi with a message. / Oje sent Ohi on an errand.
Oje sent Ohi to Afuze.
Oje sent Ohi.
Oje sent a message to Afuze.

Primary_Text: Élí ívbèkhàn húá élí émà lí égbè.
Translated_Text: The youths gave the yams to one another.

Primary_Text: Òjè nwú ọ́lí émà lí òhí.
Translated_Text: Oje has given the yam to Ohi.
Oje showed Aleke the poison arrow.
Oje will hide from the farmer.
Oje is hiding.

Primary_Text: Òjè nwú ọ́lì ọ̀gọ́ héé lí òhí.
Translated_Text: Oje hid the bottle from Ohi.
Oje hid the bottle.
Oje used a cutlass to peel yam. / Oje peeled yam with a cutlass.
Oje peeled the yam.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ éhìẹ́n bóló ọ́lì ọ̀gẹ̀dẹ̀.
Translated_Text: Oje used his fingernail to peel the plantain. / Oje peeled the plantain with his fingernail.
Oje peeled the plantain.
The ear of maize got torn off. / The ear of maize got ripped off.
Oje tore off an ear of maize. / Oje ripped an ear of maize off.
Oje seized a cutlass from Ohi.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ rẹ̀ ùghámá bẹ̀nnọ̀ éràn.
Translated_Text: Oje is using an axe to cut wood. / Oje is cutting wood with an axe.
Oje is cutting wood. / Oje is chopping wood.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ úvbíághàè híán ọ́lí úì.
Translated_Text: Oje used a knife to cut the rope. / Oje cut the rope with a knife.
Oje cut the rope. / Oje severed the rope.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ rẹ̀ òbọ́ sò ọ́pìà.
Translated_Text: Oje is touching the cutlass with his hand. / Oje is touching the cutlass.
A stick hit Oje on his back. / A stick hit Oje’s back.

Primary_Text: Òhí fí ójé úkpórán vbì ùòkhò.
Translated_Text: Ohi hit Oje on his back with a stick. / Ohi hit a stick on Oje's back.
Ohi hit Oje with a stick. / Ohi hit a stick on Oje.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ úkpóràn gbé ọ́lí ọ́vbèkhàn.
Translated_Text: Oje used a stick to beat the youth. / Oje beat the youth with a stick.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ gbè ọ̀lí ọ́vbèkhàn.
Translated_Text: Oje is beating the youth.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ údò gbóó élí ívbèkhàn.
Translated_Text: Oje used a stone to kill the youths. / Oje killed the youths with a stone.
Oje killed the youths.
Oje used a slingshot to kill a lizard.
Oje killed a lizard.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ údò gbóó élí ékhè kú à.
Translated_Text: Oje used a stone to break the pots into smithereens. / Oje broke the pots into pieces with a stone.
The pots broke into smithereens. / The pots broke into pieces.

Primary_Text: Òjè gbóó élí ékhè kú à.
Translated_Text: Oje broke the pots into pieces. / Oje broke the pots into smithereens.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ údò gbé ọ́lí ákhè á.
Translated_Text: Oje used a stone to break the pot. / Oje broke the pot with a stone.
The pot broke.
Oje broke the pot.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ údò gúọ́ghọ́ ọ́lí úkpóràn.
Translated_Text: Oje used a stone to break the stick. / Oje broke the stick with a stone.
The stick broke.
Oje broke the stick.

Primary_Text: Òjè hú àsẹ̀ ọ́ vbí ímè.
Translated_Text: Oje built a hut on the farm.

Primary_Text: Òjè rẹ́ ébé ọ̀gẹ̀dẹ̀ hú àsẹ̀.
Translated_Text: Oje used banana leaves to build a hut.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ hù ọ́lì àsẹ̀.
Translated_Text: Oje is building the hut.

Primary_Text: Òjè zẹ́ óà ọ́ vbì èkó.
Translated_Text: Oje built a home in Lagos.
Oje used mud brick to build a home. / Oje built a home with mud brick.
Oje built a home.
They gave a name to her. / They named her.

Primary_Text: Ójé rẹ́' ẹ́ áléké “ébé' ọ́lí ókpósó í' gbé ọ́lí ófè?”
Translated_Text: Oje asked Aleke, “How did the woman kill the rat?”

Primary_Text: Ójé rẹ́' ẹ́ áléké “ọ́lì òkpòsò gbé ọ́lí ófè.”
Translated_Text: Oje told Aleke, “The woman killed the rat.”

Primary_Text: Ójé rẹ́' ẹ́ ọ́í “ébé' ọ́lí ókpósó í' gbé ọ́lí ófè?”
Translated_Text: Oje asked, “How did the woman kill the rat?”

Primary_Text: Ójé rẹ́' ẹ́ ọ́í “ọ́lì òkpòsò gbé ọ́lí ófè.”
Translated_Text: Oje said, “The woman killed the rat.”
Aleke informed Oje.
Aleke disclose information to Oje.

Primary_Text: Àlèkè gúé ìnyẹ̀mì lí ójé họ̀n.
Translated_Text: Aleke disclosed the matter to Oje. / Aleke informed Oje about the matter.
Aleke is disclosing information. / Aleke is relating information.
Aleke narrated a saying to Oje.

Primary_Text: Àlèkè kpé ìtàn lí ójé họ̀n.
Translated_Text: Aleke narrated a saying to Oje.
Aleke is narrating a saying.
Oje is shouting. / Oje is screaming.
Oje is shouting at Aleke. / Oje is screaming at Aleke.

Primary_Text: Ójé míáá étá vbí óbọ́ ísì àlèkè.
Translated_Text: Oje asked a question of Aleke.
Oje asked Aleke a question./ Oje asked a question of Aleke.
Oje asked a question.

Primary_Text: Òjè tá étà lí áléké họ̀n.
Translated_Text: Oje spoke frankly to Aleke. / Oje told the hard truth to Aleke.
Oje spoke. / Oje spoke his words frankly.
Oje spoke to Aleke.
They are talking. / They are chatting.
Oje has met the woman.
Oje is following Ohi.
Oje helped Aleke. / Oje gave Aleke a helping hand.
Oje shaved his hair.

Primary_Text: Àlèkè kú ẹ̀ùn ọ́ mẹ́ vbí égbè.
Translated_Text: Aleke put a shirt on my body. / Aleke dressed me with a shirt.
Aleke is bathing.
Aleke bathed the child.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ hòò ọ̀lí émà.
Translated_Text: Oje is searching for the yam.
Oje pondered the matter. / Oje thought about the matter.
Oje knew Emai.
Oje knew.
Oje knew Afuze.
The cloth is liked. / The cloth is pleasant.
The cloth pleased the child. / The child liked the cloth.
The meat smells.
Oje got startled/frightened.
Ohi frightened Oje.
Oje is becoming afraid.

Primary_Text: Ọ́lì àtàlàkpà rẹ́ ófẹ̀n nwú òjè.
Translated_Text: Oje feared the lion.

Primary_Text: Òjè ọ̀ ọ́ yàà ọ̀lí éànmì.
Translated_Text: Oje is smelling the meat.
Oje saw Aleke.
Oje is watching/looking at Aleke.
Oje hugged Ohi. / Oje embraced Ohi.
Oje ate pounded yam.

The girls always help each other.
The women are shouting at/to each other.
Evenks now call each other by Russian names.

They built houses for each other.
The beetle is moving on the (surface of the) water as if on ice.
The boy's bow is hidden in the house.
He/she is always afraid of all other people.
Those people are afraid of each other.
They killed each other.
The squirrel was killed (by the boy).
The boat broke (by itself; spontaneously).
His hand was hurt very much.
That house was/got burned.
I liked them very much.

Translated_Text: His/her house was covered with pine-tree branches.
We found out that the bread was stolen.
The boy asked the teacher for advice.
Hovoko's younger brother was led away by the Nirumnjals.

The man hunted for deer.
The man remembered the boy.
The man married the girl.
The water is boiling.
The women cooked the meat.

The old lady taught the girl a song.

This man is a hunter.
‘The ground is dry’.
The house is burning.
The boat sank.
‘The ball is rolling’.
‘The girl was sad’.
‘The child is playing.

The girl laughed.

The girl thought about her grandmother yesterday.

The subject is usually omitted.

(Tygde) tygded’ečen.
(Tygde) tygde- d’eče-n
(rain) rain-IPFV-3SG

The boy froze.

Primary_Text: Musóo ye kewó mindi bóoroo la.
Translated_Text: The woman made the man drink the medicine.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye í miŋ jíyo la.
Translated_Text: The man drank water.
The man drank water.

Primary_Text: Moojámaa ka í báluu senóo le la jaŋ.

Comment: The middle construction is only possible with the addition of an oblique phrase, and its meaning is ‘live off something’.

Translated_Text: The injured person will not survive.
The man had a rest.
It is cold (the weather got cold).

Primary_Text: Kewó ye wulóo dundi búŋo kóno.
Translated_Text: The man let the dog come into the room.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye batáayoo duŋ kíilaa búlu.
Translated_Text: The man handed the letter to the messenger.
The dog came into the room.
The man was born in Sédhiou.
The woman gave birth to a boy.
The woman gave birth to a boy.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye musóolu teyindi báa la.
Translated_Text: The man conveyed the women across the river.
The women crossed the river.
The women crossed the river.
The work was done.
The man worked (lit. did work).
It rained today.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye bootôo sóoli tiyôo la.
Translated_Text: The man stuffed the bag with peanuts.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye tiyôo sóoli bootôo kóno.
Translated_Text: The man crammed the peanuts into the bag.

Primary_Text: Mus-óo ye kew-ó ñiniŋkaa a kontóŋ-o la.
Translated_Text: The woman asked the man his surname.

Primary_Text: Faá ye súŋkútoo nii kewó la.
Translated_Text: The father married (lit. offered) the girl to the man.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye kambaanôo kúmándi moo hákílíntáŋo la.
Translated_Text: The man called the boy a fool.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye kambaanóo karandirindi batáayoo la.

The boy read the letter.
The girl married the man (lit. was married to the man).
The man married the girl.
The man hunts (habitually).
The man hunted deer.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye wulôo báyi súwo kóno.
Translated_Text: The man chased the dog from the house.
The woman likes this cloth.
Stars twinkle.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye têe súmáyándi janníŋ a bé a mińna.
Translated_Text: The man let the tea get cold before drinking it.
The water is cold.
