The drum sounded.
The man talked to the woman.
The man spoke.

Primary_Text: Muŋ́ ne yé musôo bálándi dóntóroo la?
Translated_Text: What made the woman refuse the loan?

Primary_Text: Musôo bálánta kewó ma dóntóroo la.
Translated_Text: The woman refused the man a loan.

Primary_Text: Kewó ka dáañínoo sotondi dímbáayaa ye.
Translated_Text: The man provides the family with food. / lit. makes food available for the family.

Primary_Text: Ñéwo sotóta le márséwo to bii.
Translated_Text: There is fish available at the market today.
The boy got the book / has a book.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye kitáaboo soto a karammôo búlu.
Translated_Text: The boy got the book from his teacher.
The iron changed into gold.

Primary_Text: Báamaa yé a díŋo kéndi kewó ti.
Translated_Text: The mother helped her son become a man.
The child became a man.

Primary_Text: Batuutáa ye newó ke sánoo ti.
Translated_Text: The magician made gold out of iron (lit. changed the iron into gold).
The bed was made / repaired.
The man made a bed / repaired the bed.
The rain fell on the ground violently.
The rain fell on the ground violently.

Primary_Text: Sulóo ye í joloŋ yíroo sánto.
Translated_Text: The monkey let itself fall from the tree.
The man let the knife fall.
The mango fell on the ground.
The bandits attacked the merchants.
The bandits attacked (lit. fell on) the merchants.
The man cut down the tree.
The man cut down the tree.
The tree fell on the ground.
What made the woman cry?
The woman laments the loss of her husband.
The woman cried.
The bad food made the man ill.
The man fell ill.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye murôo fúntíndi bootôo kóno.
Translated_Text: The man took the knife out of the bag.
The moon appeared.
The woman went out from the house.
The woman boiled the water.
The water boiled.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye musôo tábíríndi subôo la.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman cook the meat.
The woman did the cooking.
The meat was cooked.
The woman cooked the meat.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye musóo moyirindi muŋ́ ne la?
Translated_Text: What did the man tell the woman?

Primary_Text: Kewó ye musóo moyindi muŋ́ ne la?
Translated_Text: What did the man promise the woman?
The old woman does not hear.
The people heard about that matter. / lit. This matter was heard.
The boy heard a noise.
This man is a very learned person.
The boy learned Mandinka.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye Mandinkakáŋo karandi kambaanóo ye.
Translated_Text: The man taught Mandinka to the boy.
Comment: The construction of this clause is not regular for a clause headed by a causative verb, since the causee normally fulfills the object function.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye kambaanóo karandi Mandinkakáŋo la.
Translated_Text: The man taught Mandinka to the boy.
The boy learned driving.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye kambáanoo nikindi wotóo la.
Translated_Text: The man taught driving to the boy.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye a karammóo suuñaa kitáaboo la.
Translated_Text: The boy stole the book from his teacher.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye kitáaboo suuñaa a karammôo búlu.
Translated_Text: The boy stole the book from his teacher.
The president postponed the meeting.
The child moved (out of the way).
The men pushed the car.
The man dug for cassava.
The man dug a hole.
The girl wiped the table.

Primary_Text: Súŋkútoo ye kíníjólóndáŋo kóŋkoŋ táabúloo kaŋ.
Translated_Text: The girl wiped the crumbs from the table.

Primary_Text: Musóo ye tiyóo sii beróo la.
Translated_Text: The woman ground the peanuts with a stone.
The sun dried up the shirt.
The shirt dried up in the sun.
The enemies burned the village.
The village burned / was burnt.
The boat sank into the river.
The woman starved the children.
The children got hungry.

Primary_Text: Musóo la saayáa ye kewó sunundi.
Translated_Text: The woman's death made the man sad.
These words made the man sad.
The man got sad.
The woman made the children play / played with the children.
The man behaved frivolously towards the woman.
The man did not keep his word (lit. played with his word).
The children played.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye ŋ́ búloo dete fó a ye ŋ́ dímíndi.
Translated_Text: The man squeezed my arm to the extent that he hurt me.
Comment: Dímíndi does not show the regular behavior expected from a causative form.

Primary_Text: Ñiŋ kínoo si í kónoo dímiŋ.
Translated_Text: This food may hurt your stomach.
My arm is hurting.
What made the boy laugh?
The boy laughed at the girl.
The boy laughed at the girl.
The boy laughed.

Primary_Text: Musóo ye taalíŋo laa díndíŋo ye.
Translated_Text: The woman told a story to the child.
The girl sang (a song).
Transfer the file to a folder!
The cat jumped on the chair.

Primary_Text: Kewó sawúnta a lá koridaakútoo to.
Translated_Text: The man moved to his new house.
The child jumped.
The child's uncle lives in Ziguinchor.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye díndíŋo sindi siiráŋo kaŋ.
Translated_Text: The man sat the child on the chair.
The child sat on the chair.
The man rode the horse / made the horse run.
The man rode the horse.
The child ran (away).
The ball rolled on the ground.
Comment: Mandinka has no verb expressing specifically 'move rolling'.

Translated_Text: The child ran (away).

Primary_Text: Kewó ye kambaanóo selendi suwô sánto.
Translated_Text: The man helped the boy get on the horse.
The man climbed up the hill.
The man climbed up the hill.
The smoke makes the man cough.
The man coughed.
The water filled up the hole.
The hole is full of water.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye a díŋo fándíríndi maanóo la bootôo kóno.
Translated_Text: The man made his son fill the bag with rice.
Comment: In principle, in the causativization of a transitive construction, the initial object is transposed into an oblique marked by the postposition la; if however this postposition must be used to mark another term of the construction (here an instrumental adjunct), another postposition must be used with the term transposing the initial object.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye a díŋo fándíríndi bootóo la.
Translated_Text: The man made his son fill the bag.
The bag was filled with rice.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye bootôo fándi maanóo la.
Translated_Text: The man filled the bag with rice.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye díndíŋo múura mbajóo la.
Translated_Text: The man covered the child with the blanket.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye musóo soorindi jíyo la wéeroo kóno.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman pour the water into the glass.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye jíyo soo wéeroo kóno.
Translated_Text: The man poured the water into the glass.
The water was poured on the ground.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye jíyo boŋ baŋkóo to.
Translated_Text: The man poured the water on the ground.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye kambaanóo sitirindi suwó la yíroo bála.
Translated_Text: The man made the boy tie the horse to the tree.
The horse was tied to a tree.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye suwó siti yíroo bála julóo la.
Translated_Text: The man tied the horse to the tree with a rope.
A bee stung the child.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye palantéeroo búŋ beróo la.
Translated_Text: The boy threw the stone into the window.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye berôo fáyi palantéeroo kaŋ.
Translated_Text: The boy threw the stone into the window.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye kitáaboo naati karambúŋo to.
Translated_Text: The boy brought the book to school.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye kitáaboo naati a karammóo ye.
Translated_Text: The boy brought the book to his teacher.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo naáta kitáaboo ti karambúŋo to.
Translated_Text: The boy brought the book to school.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo naáta kitáaboo ti a karammóo ye.
Translated_Text: The boy brought the book to his teacher.
The man came to the village.

Primary_Text: Kambaanôo táata kitáaboo ti karambúŋo to.
Translated_Text: The boy carried the book to school.
The man went to the field.
The man went away.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye kitáaboo sambá naŋ a karammóo ye.
Translated_Text: The boy brought the book to his teacher.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye kitáaboo samba a karammóo ye.
Translated_Text: The boy brought/carried the book to his teacher.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye kitáaboo samba karambúŋo to.
Translated_Text: The boy brought/carried the book to the school.
The girl peeled the orange.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye batáayoo kíi a karammóo ye.
Translated_Text: The boy sent a letter to his teacher.

Primary_Text: Karammóo ye kambaanóo so kitáaboo la.
Translated_Text: The teacher gave the book to the boy.
The book was given to the boy.

Primary_Text: Karammóo ye kitáaboo díi kambaanóo la.
Translated_Text: The teacher gave the book to the boy.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye díndíŋo yitandirindi natáaloo la musóo ye.
Translated_Text: The man made the child show the picture to the woman.
The picture was shown to the woman.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye natáaloo yitandi musóo la.
Translated_Text: The man showed the picture to the woman.

Primary_Text: Díndíŋo ye í maabo kewó ma.
Translated_Text: The child hid from the man.
Comment: The example is an illustration of the reflexive use of the transitive construction.

Translated_Text: The child hid from the man.
The money was hidden from the man.

Primary_Text: Musóo ye díndíŋo maaborindi kódoo la kewó ma.
Translated_Text: The woman made the child hide the money from the man.

Primary_Text: Musóo ye díndíŋo maabondi kewó ma.
Translated_Text: The woman hid the child from the man.

Primary_Text: Musóo ye kódoo maabo kewó ma.
Translated_Text: The woman hid the money from the man.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye kitáaboo taa kambaanôo búlu.
Translated_Text: The man took the book from the boy.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye ñantáŋo teyi faŋó la.
Translated_Text: The man cut thatching-grass with a cutlass.
The meat was cut.

Primary_Text: Musóo ye subóo kuntu muróo la.
Translated_Text: The woman cut the meat with a knife.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye saá maa fáloo la.
Translated_Text: The boy touched the snake with a stick.
The peanuts were threshed.
The man threshed the peanuts.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye saâ búsa fáloo la.
Translated_Text: The boy hit / beat the snake with a stick.
The man died.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye a díŋo faarindi saajíyo la.
Translated_Text: The man made his son kill the sheep.
The sheep died / was killed.
Comment: Speakers tend to avoid using this verb intransitively with a passive meaning, and killing events with an unspecified agent are rather encoded by means of a transitive construction with a 3rd person plural pronoun in subject function. It is however possible to find faa used intransitively with a passive meaning, in contexts triggering a passive interpretation.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye saá faa faŋó la.
Translated_Text: The boy killed the snake with a cutlass.

Primary_Text: Musóo ye dendikóolu ke kúnéwo kóno.
Translated_Text: The woman put the clothes in the chest.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye kitáaboo ke táabúloo kaŋ.
Translated_Text: The man put the book on the table.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye musóolu lándíríndi baramatóo la laaráŋo kaŋ.
Translated_Text: The man made the women lay the wounded person on the bed.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye kambaanôo láaríndi lóo la saréetoo kaŋ.
Translated_Text: The man made the boy load the wood on the cart.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye baramatôo lándi laaráŋo kaŋ.
Translated_Text: The man laid the wounded person on the bed.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye í laa laaráŋo kaŋ.
Translated_Text: The man lay down on the bed.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye mbajóo laa díndíŋo kaŋ.
Translated_Text: The man put a blanket on the child.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye lóo laa saréetoo kaŋ.
Translated_Text: The man put/loaded the wood on the cart.
The man stopped drinking.
The man left the village (i.e. he does not live in the village anymore).

Primary_Text: Kewó ye ŋáníŋo bóndi a siŋô kóno.
Translated_Text: The man removed the thorn from his foot.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye a lá dendikóo bo.
Translated_Text: The man took off his shirt.
A rainbow appeared.
The man left the village.
The egg broke.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye palantéeroo teyi beróo la.
Translated_Text: The boy broke the window with the stone.
There remained two old women.
Two old women remained in the village.

Primary_Text: Musóo ye díndíŋolu tu súwo kóno.
Translated_Text: The woman left the children in the house.
The man blinked.
The boy broke the stick.

Primary_Text: Kewó boyíta yíroo sánto, a káŋo kátíta.
Translated_Text: The man fell from the tree and broke his neck.
The house was built.
The people organized a dance.
The woman put the mortar in standing position.
The man stood up / stopped.
Comment: This example can be viewed as an illustration of the reflexive use of transitive construction.

Translated_Text: The man stood up / stopped.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye búŋo loo biríkoo la.
Translated_Text: The man built the house with bricks.
Who shaved you?
The man shaved (his beard).

Primary_Text: Musóo ye díndíŋo dundirindi kurtóo la.
Translated_Text: The woman made the child put on trousers.
The child dressed.

Primary_Text: Díndíŋo ye a la féŋolu duŋ.
Translated_Text: The child dressed.
The child put on trousers.

Primary_Text: Musóo ye kurutóo duŋ díndíŋo la.
Translated_Text: The woman put trousers on the child.

Primary_Text: Musóo ye féŋolu duŋ díndíŋo la.
Translated_Text: The woman dressed the child.
The man shouted the girl's name.
The man shouted the girl's name.
The man shouted to the girl.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye a dímmúsoo too laa Ámi la.
Translated_Text: The man called his daughter Amy.
The man screamed.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye kódoo dáani kewô búlu.
Translated_Text: The boy asked the man for money.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye kewô dáani kódoo la.
Translated_Text: The boy asked the man for money.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye a fó kambaanóo ye kó 'haní'.
Translated_Text: The man said 'no' to the boy.
Comment: For reported speech, Mandinka uses the quotative marker ko, alone or in combination with a verb of speech. When fo is used to introduce a reported utterance, the reported utterance occurs in final position, represented by a 3rd person pronoun in cataphoric function occupying the canonical object position in the construction of fo.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye kambaanóo (la kúmoo) fó musóo ye.
Translated_Text: The man talked to the woman about the boy.
Comment: Mandinka expresses 'A talks to X about Y' as 'A tells words about Y to X', or simply 'A tells Y to X'.

Translated_Text: The man speaks Mandinka.

Primary_Text: Musóo ye kewô fóoríndi tooñáa la kambaanóo ye.
Translated_Text: The woman made the man tell the truth to the boy.
The truth was told to the boy.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye tooñáa fo kambaanóo ye.
Translated_Text: The man told the truth to the boy.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye kambaanóo bula dookúwo to.
Translated_Text: The man made the boy work.

Primary_Text: Musóo ye kewô hákíloo bulandi kambaanóo la.
Translated_Text: The woman reminded the man of the boy.
The man remembered the boy.
The man followed the girl.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye kambaanóo bulandirindi lóo la saréetoo kóno.
Translated_Text: The man made the boy load the wood into the cart.
The wood was loaded into the cart.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye lóo bulandi saréetoo kóno.
Translated_Text: The man loaded the wood into the cart.
The man boarded the ship.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye subóo bula kufôo kóno.
Translated_Text: The man put the meat into the bag.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye ŋáníŋo bóndi díndíŋo siŋô kóno.
Translated_Text: The man removed the thorn from the child's foot.
The man followed the girl.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye kambaanôo máakóyi kódoo to.
Translated_Text: The man helped the boy financially.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye musóo kuurindi dendikóo la.
Translated_Text: The man made the woman wash the shirt.
The woman did the washing.
Comment: This example illustrates the standard antipassive periphrasis, possible for all transitive verbs. For WASH the middle construction is possible, but can only be interpreted as reflexive, not as antipassive.

Translated_Text: The woman washed (herself).
Comment: The middle construction for this verb has a reflexive reading, and is not synonymous with the intransitive construction of the same verb (which can only be interpreted as passive).

Translated_Text: The child has been washed.
The woman washed the child.
The woman washed the shirt.
The man searched for the boy.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye í míira kambaanóo la kúwo la.
Translated_Text: The man thought about the boy.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye a míira kó musóo ye a kanu.
Translated_Text: The man thinks that the woman loves him.
Comment: The first occurrence of the third person pronoun represents the complement clause (musóo ye a kanu 'the woman loves him') introduced by the quotative marker kó in complementizer function.

Translated_Text: The boy loves the girl.
The girl likes this cloth.
The boy wants/likes the book.

Primary_Text: Muŋ́ ne yé kambaanoó lafindi kitáaboo la?
Translated_Text: What made the boy like the book?
The man wants money.
The man liked the boy.
The man frightened the boy.
The boy feared the man.
The dog smelled the child.
The blind do not see.
The boy was seen near the river.
The man saw the boy.
The man looked at the boy.
This man knows many riddles.
This man is a very learned person.
The man knows the boy.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye julôo míniŋ fáloo la.
Translated_Text: The man wound the rope around the stick.
The army encircled the fortress.
The creeper wound around the tree.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye í míniŋ musóo la.
Translated_Text: The man hugged the woman.
The man hugged the woman.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye díndíŋo dómóríndi mbúuroo la.
Translated_Text: The man made the child eat the bread.
The child ate.
Comment: As a rule, the antipassive form of Mandinka transitive verbs can only be used nominally; dómo 'eat' is the only Mandinka verb whose antipassive form can be used as a verbal predicate.

Translated_Text: The child ate.
The bread was eaten.
The child ate the bread.
The woman can usually be found at the market.

Primary_Text: Kewó ye musóo tara márséwo to.
Translated_Text: The man met/found the woman at the market.
The man wandered around the whole country.
Comment: In its basic meaning, beŋ 'meet' is a plain intransitive verb; this sentence illustrates the possibility to use it transitively with the meaning 'wander around a place'.

Translated_Text: The villagers were gathered.
Comment: This example illustrates the passive use of a causative verb.

Translated_Text: The chief gathered the villagers.
The villagers gathered.
The man met the girl. \ Lit. The man with/and the girl met.
The page was torn from the book.

Primary_Text: Kambaanóo ye léeríjámboo fárási kitáaboo bála.
Translated_Text: The boy tore the page from the book.
I am cooking food.
The women used to help them (the men).
Comment: -mila is a suppletive form of -angu 'get/handle'.

Translated_Text: Let it cook for you on the coals, the food.
Nawurla cooked the meat on the coals.
Today, Namij cooked it in the ashes.
I was worried.
It (the song) makes me feel sad/sorry about your boyfriend (who is far away).
They run after him.
Comment: As in: they find him attractive.

Translated_Text: We used to cut it up, and it used to dry for us.
Comment: From an account of making soap.

Translated_Text: (It is) the hot season now, (it is) dry / the dry season.
A child is sitting in the water.

Primary_Text: Dididmayan garam ... ganajgiyany didid ... dididmayan ganantha.
Translated_Text: It is rolling, he rolled it, he is rolling it along. /Lit. translation of last clause: 'He takes it along, rolling it'.
Translation_Other: Im teikim rolim im.

Translated_Text: He rolled it down, the milk tin, it rolled down.
You made me hungry!
The children take dogs for (hunting) goanna.
You shouldn't go stealing on/from them.
Maybe they robbed me. / Maybe someone robbed me.
Comment: Referring to missing bank card.

Translated_Text: The bottle broke.
She broke the wood by smashing it against another branch.
The rat is making rain.
Comment: mythical

Translated_Text: The woman is asking around.
Comment: Expression in brackets added by linguist.

Translated_Text: The man is facing this way.
He is going towards the cow, facing it.
The old man searched for goanna taking a dog.

Primary_Text: Gurrany jurriya yirriyu nu yinyjuwu yagbali.
Translated_Text: We do not know this country. / Lit. We are not knowledgeable about/for this country.
Why are you shouting/screaming?
They hit her such that she was sore, I don't know who hit her.

Primary_Text: Burduj ngajgany, jid ngardbany, jamana janga ngarrgu.
Translated_Text: I went up and I went down, now my feet are sore.
I had sore legs from walking. / My legs were hurting from walking.
I lifted something heavy, and now I'm sore / in pain.
I'm no good, the cold is affecting me.

Primary_Text: Dibardbiya ganibarrga mugmug-ni, wirrij gayu nu.
Translated_Text: It is going to jump at him now, the owl, it is fighting him. (Lit. It is going to approach him jump(ing), the owl is.).
Comment: Frog Story

Translated_Text: The frog now jumped away, the two will look in vain for him.
Comment: Frog Story

Translated_Text: The frog now is jumping away leaving the two, look.
Comment: Frog Story

Translated_Text: They "wound" the short stick with a rope.
Translation_Other: Sie haben den Stock mit einem Seil umwickelt.

Translated_Text: The rope is wound around the stick.
Comment: Picture stimuli.

Translated_Text: They wound it (the rope) around the short stick.
They immerse/sink the net in the water.
She plucks off leaves (off a branch).
I'm going to make (the child) laugh.

Primary_Text: Ngiyinanu yirrg burrurrarram mayi, murrgun burruyuma warrb.
Translated_Text: They are discussing (gossiping about) those people, the three sitting here.
It is sniffing around for its home (animal in cage).
The small child is eating boab nut.
The fish lives in freshwater.
The black-headed python (is the one that) lives on the rocks.
I am/live/stay here in my place.
Translation_Other: Ai stop hiya la mai pleis.

Primary_Text: Ngayu ngiya, Murranginy. Gurrany Bulla ngayu, waj ngawungany.
Translated_Text: I am/live here in Murranginy. I don't live in Bulla (any more), I left it.
I call that jarning.
What do we call this bird?
She called her own name.
Comment: Note cognacy of nominal jinij 'name' and uninflecting verb nij 'be named'. Verb 'get/handle' used for 'using a name' rather than 'bestowing a name'.
Translation_Other: Im kol-im mijelb neim na.

Translated_Text: I almost said the name of your (deceased) grandfather.
Comment: Name should not be said because the person passed away recently. Verb 'get/handle' used for 'using a name' rather than 'bestowing a name'.

Primary_Text: Yirrinyi Namij yinygarram .. dardaga. Nij nyanying yinygarram mangarra.
Translated_Text: We two, Namij (and me) call it (a plant) dardaga. We call the plant by its right name.

Primary_Text: Yagbali ngiya <Timber Creek> nij gayu mangurn-giyag, mayini nij yirrarram Gunamu.
Translated_Text: This place is called Timber Creek by white people; we Aboriginal people call it Gunamu.
I took your clothes off. / I deprived you off your clothes.
Comment: Ditransitive frame.

Translated_Text: A tooth fell out.
Who took this out / who tore this off?
I have a toothache.

Primary_Text: Warlad ga-yu janyju warladbari. Ga-rda-m luba warlad.
Translated_Text: That old man is sick. He got/fell very ill.
Comment: Note stem warlad in warlad-bari 'old men'

Primary_Text: Gub bamili ngarrgu lirrjin, warlad ngayu.
Translated_Text: Pull my tooth out, I'm sore.
At the junction (of tree and leaf) she pulled off the pandanus (leaf).
Comment: Verb stem -mili is a suppletive alternant of -angu 'GET/HANDLE'.

Translated_Text: We were washing/bathing because of (i.e. to get rid of) the saltwater.
The horse is afraid, look!

Primary_Text: Yarrajgu gayu nu gujarding janju jaliggu, <accident>gu.
Translated_Text: The mother is afraid for that child, (afraid) of an accident.
These two were afraid / frightened.
The man laughed at (the other one).
Comment: Based on attested elicited uses without full NP arguments.

Translated_Text: You two make her sad.
I will pour it for you two. (Lit. 'I will give it to you two pouring').
The child spilled the milk.
They (the men) took the women up on top.
The child is lifting that C up.
Comment: Context: lifting child into car.

Translated_Text: I too am worried for / sad about Nangari.
She is sad, my old lady (mother).
Comment: Context: seeing house where the family used to live when the speaker's father (= mother's husband) was still alive.

Translated_Text: I feel sad.

Primary_Text: Barrajburruni durl ganuga janyungbari mayi wurdbajbina buluwujgu, (...) gugubina durl ganiyu.
Translated_Text: The saltwater crocodile pushed over one man looking around for eggs (...) it pushed him into the water.
The woman is singing.
L left the dog behind.
My grandson then went to the Cafe.
He came, and sat down there (the galah).
My mother is sitting here.
The teacher then ran up to him (to) pick (him) up / The teacher then approached him running (a boy who had fallen).
They took him running to the hospital then / They ran with him to the hospital then.
(My wife) ran away from me / left me running.
Comment: Phrase in brackets added by linguist.

Primary_Text: Yugung gangga janju jalig nu gujardingbina.
Translated_Text: The child runs to her, to the mother.
My grandchild climbed/went up a tree.
She blinked for the eye (i.e. to protect the eye).
He wouldn’t give (him) the two, his children.
Comment: It is clear from the context that a potential father-in-law refuses to give his two daughters to a single, specific man; in isolation this sentence could also mean ‘he wouldn’t give the two (men) his child’.

Translated_Text: I didn't want to sit around (i.e. stay).
Comment: Context: Leaving a place after a relative has passed away, not wanting to stay and be reminded.

Translated_Text: They also made axes out of the quartz.
The child has already fallen on the ground.

Primary_Text: Ngilijga burragba janjunud jalig mangarrawu gujardinggu.
Translated_Text: Those children were crying for food (and) for their mother.
A saltwater crocodile might appear on them (people in boats).

Primary_Text: Jamang bul burrurumany yinyag jalig yagburru.
Translated_Text: Finally the children appeared on us with fish.
The tea is boiling now.
Nalyarri is cooking meat.
We heard the ambulance.
"Listen to the two!" he said to him.

Primary_Text: Malangayij biyang bunyguga malara majani jalwany.
Translated_Text: The two hear the frogs, maybe talking.
Yolngu (Aboriginal organisation) used to bring us big tents.
You all teach me language. (Lit. 'you (PL) make me knowledgeable about language').
The two were training/teaching their horse.
She brings it (long yam) back to/for the child.
I was digging for a goanna that had buried itself in the ground.
We dug (up water), and made a well.
Comment: Phrase in bracket added by linguist (based on parallel examples).

Translated_Text: It is making us deaf. (Lit. 'it is wiping us').
Comment: Metaphorical use of "wipe" complex predicate - demonstrating that ground is indeed the direct object.

Translated_Text: I wiped the ground.
Comment: Elicited by acting out drawing in the ground and wiping it out.

Translated_Text: We used to grind waterlily seed with a stone.

Primary_Text: Janyjugun lalabangngarna mayi. Lalabang gangga, yangarrawu.
Translated_Text: That man is a kangaroo hunter. He goes kangaroo hunting, for kangaroo.
Comment: Elicited by 'that man is a good hunter'.

Primary_Text: Ngiyagun jirrman gayu, ngarla Port-Keatsmalang larrman gayu.
Translated_Text: Here (the country) is moist, but in Port Keats it is dry.
It is burning brightly now (i.e. with a flame), the stick.
(The tea bag) got immersed / sank.
Comment: Phrase in brackets added by linguist.

Translated_Text: The ball is rolling.
Comment: Phrase in brackets added by linguist.

Translated_Text: (The child) is hungry for milk.
Maybe grandfather is hungry.

Primary_Text: Gagawurli bagurr burr-arra-nyi, (...) mugurruni burrarranyi bagurrbagurr.
Translated_Text: They used to load the long yam in there, they used to put it in the paperbark cooliman.
(...) the one that is always full of water (lit. the one that water is always full).
The water filled the hole/bowl.
The women used to fill the tin with water (lit. ...fill water into the tin).
Nalyarri is all covered up, she is cold.
The water pours/spills.
I will pour it (the tea) for you two, in the billycan.
We put the grass into the trailer.
The red cloth, they (the women) put it in a basket.
Comment: Phrase in brackets added by linguist.

Translated_Text: He covered himself (with negative effect) for the two, with paperbark.
Comment: Referring to a (mythical) man going into hiding to be able to surprise and assault two women.

Translated_Text: I put the things back in the box.
It is tied around a tree.
Tie these things (onto the car) side by side first!
He (the white man) tied them like that to a tree (with rope).
Comment: Referring to captured people. Phrases in brackets added by linguist.

Translated_Text: He (the child) threw it with his hand, the pencil.
Comment: Phrase in brackets added by linguist.

Translated_Text: He threw her into the water, (so that she got) just bogged (in the mud).
The rainbow shows up. (lit. 'shows itself').
Comment: Reflexive alternant example

Translated_Text: They used to show us two, you know, food and other things like that.
Comment: Ditransitive alternant.

Translated_Text: She showed (it) to me. (Lit. 'She showed me').
Comment: Referring to yam root. Ditransitive alternant example.

Translated_Text: I'm showing you the Ngaliwurru country.
Comment: Dative alternant example.

Translated_Text: The old women showed me yam in Gilwi.
Comment: Ditransitive coding frame.

Translated_Text: I will keep it (the food) hidden.
Comment: Phrase in brackets added by linguist.

Translated_Text: The car is hidden.

Primary_Text: Yugung gajgany burri, jarligmarlang marrug gardbany.
Translated_Text: He ran away from them, the child, and hid.
I'm hiding the meat from the dog.
They (the women) used to peel bark off a tree.
Comment: Phrase in bracket added by linguist. The verb stem -mila is a suppletive alternant of -angu 'get/handle'.

Translated_Text: We all get money on a payday.
She put it on top so the child would not get/take it.
Comment: Apple on table.

Translated_Text: Maybe someone will take her (your wife) away from you.
Mother would take it (toy) off her, "give it to her!" and she would give it to her.
Comment: Account of childhood arguments between sisters.

Primary_Text: Guyug larrmangun bangu:, gurrany thanthu wilannyunga!
Translated_Text: Get/take dry firewood, not that (deposited) from the flood!
She took it right away from the water on the dry (land).
Comment: Watching video of pulling a large sawfish from the water.

Translated_Text: They are cutting it for her, they will be cutting until lunchtime.
Comment: Referring to grass being mown near speaker's place, preventing us from recording there. Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: The boy cut himself with a knife.
The queen cut the dam, the ribbon.
Comment: I.e. the Queen opened the dam by cutting the ribbon. Account of the opening of Argyle dam near Kununurra, W.A. Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: They cut it with a knife.
Comment: Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: Nawurla cut its neck.
Comment: Describing photos of slaughtering and cooking a turtle.

Translated_Text: The child touched the car.
Comment: Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: Don't touch it, it is hot (lit. 'fire-having'), you might get burned!
The women fought with fighting sticks.
He hit us with a stick (as you know already).
(...) Another one was killed by Aboriginal people. / Aboriginal people killed another one. (From an account of several deaths).
At Gunamu I'm talking/telling, in the Park.
Comment: Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: I'm telling her the story.
That white man used to beat us (with a stick).
Comment: Phrase in brackets added by linguist on the basis of other attested examples. Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: We used to carry fish under our arms (i.e. in a cooliman / wooden carrying vessel) (back to the camp).
Comment: Phrase in brackets added by linguist. The verb stem -anyi is a suppletive variant of -uga 'take'.

Primary_Text: Mali ngarrgu dalag ganarrany ngarrgu, <teip>nguji, Nangarini.
Translated_Text: Nangari sent my things for me, tapes and others, Nangari.
Comment: Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: They only sent us those big bags (of salt).
Comment: Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: They took all of it from me, the women did, what’s it called, ashes.
Comment: ashes being used to mix with chewing tobacco

Translated_Text: The man is laughing.
(The woman) stole that chicken, I don't know from where.
Comment: Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Primary_Text: Birrg ganjunggana, majani ngarrgina mali, garlagarla-gina.
Translated_Text: She used to take them away from me, my things, toys.
This child was playing.
(Many kites are circling there), maybe a kangaroo died.
The child killed the bird with a stone.
The power ticket (lit. '(thing) for power') ran out / 'died'.
Comment: Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: They are killing them with a stick.
Comment: referring to fish, after having been "poisoned"

Translated_Text: But some people killed it for her, with a stick.
Comment: Referring to a flying fox that was biting a woman. Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: They used to break its legs with a boomerang.
Comment: referring to kangaroos

Translated_Text: Her hair is coming out.

Primary_Text: Warnda jabbayan gayu yina mangurn, bangawu.
Translated_Text: That white man is weeding the grass, look.
The crocodile got into the water from there.
They were building us iron (houses) then.
Comment: Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: We used to erect small tents.
Comment: Reduplication of UV used for multiplicity of undergoers. Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: Maybe the man is building this house.
Comment: From a picture description.

Translated_Text: They shouted for them.

Primary_Text: Nganthannyunga bawamayan ngayu ngunggu, gurrany malangayij nayurrgu!
Translated_Text: Why am I shouting at you!? You are not listening to me!
That other old man gave me food.
I gave them the food, all of it.
You cover the meat with paperbark.
You might cough / be coughing.
She coughs.
It is raining now (lit. 'rain falls'), with lightning.
I called her I. after my mother.
Comment: Figurative use of omplex predicate meaning 'break + HIT' meaning 'bestow a name onto someone'

Translated_Text: "You come here", the doctor said to her.
Comment: Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: "You have disturbed a dangerous thing!" he said to him, to the dog.
Comment:
Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.
Frog Story

Translated_Text: My grandfather asked me: "..."
Don't ask us two for food, you two!
Me, I will be talking to her!
Maybe we two will meet you halfway.
Her husband followed her running. /Her husband ran after her.
Let's follow this man!
I want to shave (my) beard. (Lit. 'I want to pluck myself with respect to the beard').
You don't wash clothes for me.
Comment: Said accusingly

Translated_Text: Bathe her (the child), maybe she is hot. (child, in river).
Comment: Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words. Expression in brackets added by linguist.

Translated_Text: Here I was looking for the (street) sign.
Comment: Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: We searched for long yam.
You two only think about alcohol.
Comment: Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: I was thinking about you all.
All right, I know you (now).
Auntie, do you know the place?
Comment: Illustrates a verbless clause. Context: account of visiting traditional country.

Primary_Text: Majani malara ngunthug gananggam, majani yaniba malara.
Translated_Text: Maybe they (fish) like frogs (as bait), maybe they will bite frogs.
Comment: Singular agreement for lower animates.

Translated_Text: The owl frightened him (...).
Comment:
Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.
Frog Story

Translated_Text: The little Nangari was was frightened of you, wasn't she?
Comment: Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: (The Aboriginal) man feared the white man.
Comment: Agent added by linguist.

Translated_Text: The fire smells.
The dog smelled the two.
The dog smells the meat.

Primary_Text: Wiribni ngarrginani nganthanwarra ganingayim, majani mangurn ganingayim.
Translated_Text: My dog, I don't know what it sees, maybe it sees a white man.
The cow is looking in that direction.
A rock rat is now looking at this child.
Comment: Frog Story

Translated_Text: She hugged you, and you hugged her, too.
Comment: Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words.

Translated_Text: (The mother) is holding the child in her arms.
Comment: Phrases in brackets added by linguist.

Translated_Text: He's hugging him now, the little child is.
Comment: boy > dog, in Frog Story scene where the dog had fallen out of the window. Angular brackets <> mark Kriol words. The verb stem -(a)ntha is a suppletive alternant of -uga 'take'.

Translated_Text: The flying fox eats flowers.
The daughter put on the clothes.
The child liked the toy.
The child liked the toy.
The teacher taught the students.
Mari peeled the apple.
Comment: Sounds like an ellipitical sentence, where the identity of the possessor needs to be retrieved contextually.

Translated_Text: Mari peeled the skin off the apple.
Ken filled the cup with water.
Ken talked about that matter.
Comment: ni-tuite 'about' has been grammaticalized into a single word, orignally meaning 'attach to'.

Translated_Text: Ken talked on that matter.
Ken met with Mari.
The man climbed on the tree.
Ken carried the boxes toward the market.
Ken asked Mary for her help.
The teacher looked at the pictures. / The teacher saw the pictures.
Comment: This sentence is ambiguous between the two senses of 'coming into sight' and 'look at'.

Translated_Text: Ken rolled the ball.
Comment: Gorogasu is a transitive counterpart of korogaru. In Japanese, transitive-transitive pairs often have slightly different forms.

Translated_Text: The vase broke.
Pictures were shown to the teacher.
Mari can sing a song.
Mari sings a song.
The horse can run.
The water boiled.
Mari cooked the fish (for her child).
The boy heard the bear's voice.
The teacher taught the students math.
The thief stole money from the old man.
The girl brought flowers to me.
The boy pushed the girl.
The woman is digging for potatoes.
Mari wiped dirt off the table.
The woman ground the wheat.
That man is a hunter.
It rained.
The ground is dry.
The house is burning.
The boat sank.
The ball is rolling.
The baby is hungry.
The girl was sad.
The child is playing.
The insects died.
Ken felt cold.
Comment: The sentence is usually topicalized, but here I use a non-topicalized form. In this case, it needs to have a contrastive interpretation, which might not be easy to imagine for some speakers.

Translated_Text: I had a pain on my stomach.
The man screamed.
Mari laughed.
The friend lives in Tokyo.
The boy left the village.
The woman went to the market.

The boy jumped.
The children sat down on the bench.
The children sat on the floor.
The horse is running.
The man climbed the tree.
The old man coughed.
Mari blinked.

Ken covered the baby with a cloth.
Ken poured water into the glass.
I put the cup on the table.
The man tied a horse to the tree (with a rope).
The boy threw the ball to the window.
Ken carried the boxes to the market.
Ken sent Mari the letter.
The parents gave the child the book.
Ken showed pictures to the teacher.
The child hid the book.
The child tore the page from the book.
The man took money from the friend.
Mother cut the bread (with a knife).
The boy touched the frog.
The boy hit the wall (with a stick).
The child beat the snake (with a stick).
The boy killed the mosquitos (with the insecticide).
Ken broke the window (with a hammer).
The men build the house (out of wood).
Ken called that child Mari.
Ken said "Yes." to Mari.
Ken told Mari the truth.
The woman shouted (something) at the child.
Ken asked Mari for her help.
Ken talked to Mari about that matter.
Ken met Mari.
The children followed the adults.
I helped the child.
The man shaved his beard.
The mother dressed her daughter.
Ken washed the plates.
The man searched for the woman.
The girl thought about that matter.
The boy knows the girl.
The child liked the toy.
The bear frightened the child.
The child feared the bear.
The bear sniffed the boy.
The man saw the bear.
Ken looked at Mari./Ken saw Mari.
Comment: This sentence is ambiguous between the two senses of 'coming into sight' and 'look at'.

Translated_Text: Ken filled water into the cup.
The ball rolled.
Mary broke the vase.
Mother hugged her little child.
Comment: The verb dakisimeru is a compound verb consisting of daku 'hold in one's arms' and simeru 'wring, tighten'.

Translated_Text: The teacher was shown a picture.
Comment: (lit. 'The teacher was made to see a picture.')

Translated_Text: Mari showed pictures to the teacher.
The horse runs.
Ken ate the rice.
The boy was afraid of the snake.
I wiped the table.
The table is wiped off.
I come with (=bring) father today.
I come today.
The mother causes the boy to start laughing (regularly).
Translation_Other: Мама рассмешивает мальчика.

Translated_Text: The mother causes the boy to start laughing (once).
Translation_Other: Мама рассмешила мальчика.

Translated_Text: The person is eating grouse meat.
Comment:
example of object incorporation with the verb EAT
The bird is 'hazel grouse' (Bonasa bonasia).
Translation_Other: Человек ест мясо куропатки.

Translated_Text: The fishermen tethered each other.
Comment: Done in winter during ice fishing as a precaution against slipping into the water.
Translation_Other: Рыбаки привязали друг друга.

Translated_Text: They hug each other. / They hug themselves.
Comment: To disambiguate, the verb-external adverb qujvaŋ 'together' could be added to specify reciprocal action.
Translation_Other: Они обнимаются. / Они обнимают самих себя.

Translated_Text: The fisherman tethered himself.
Comment: When fishing by an ice hole, in winter, Ket fisherman tied themselves to a nearby tree as a precaution against falling into the water.
Translation_Other: Рыбак привязался.

Translated_Text: The woman rolls a log.
Translation_Other: Женщина катит бревно.

Translated_Text: The soup is boiling. / The soup is cooking.
Translation_Other: Суп кипит. / Суп варится.

Translated_Text: Mother cooks soup.
Translation_Other: Мама варит суп.

Translated_Text: I hear you. / I hear your words.
Comment: The glossing of -b- as "object" may not be correct, as this might be a thematic consonant. In any event, this verb never agrees with an animate-class object.
Translation_Other: Я слышу тебя. / Я слышу твои слова.

Translated_Text: The woman teaches the children.
Translation_Other: Женщина учит детей.

Translated_Text: The mother pushes the boy.
Translation_Other: Мама толкает мальчика.

Translated_Text: I dig roots.
Translation_Other: Я выкапываю корни.

Translated_Text: I grind flour.
Translation_Other: Я молю муку.

Translated_Text: My father was a hunter.
Comment: predicate N with linking verb
Translation_Other: Мой отец был охотником.

Translated_Text: The ground is dry.
Comment: predicate nominal construction with adjective + agreement suffix
Translation_Other: Земля сухая.

Translated_Text: Fire burns. / Fire begins to burn.
Translation_Other: Огонь горит. / Огонь загорается.

Translated_Text: The woman sank. / The woman drowned.
Translation_Other: Женщина утонула.

Translated_Text: A log is rolling.

Translated_Text: The boy is sad.
Translation_Other: Мальчик грустит.

Translated_Text: Children are playing.
Translation_Other: Дети играют.

Translated_Text: Mother is shouting (out).
Comment: also means 'call, holler'
Translation_Other: Мама кричит.

Translated_Text: Mother laughed.
Translation_Other: Мама смеялась.

Translated_Text: The hunters went to the river.
Translation_Other: Охотники пошли к реке.

Translated_Text: Mother blinks.
Translation_Other: Мама моргает.

Translated_Text: The mother calls the boy.

Translated_Text: The man shaves his beard.
Translation_Other: Мужчина бреет бороду.

Translated_Text: The man smells the fish. / The man catches the scent of the fish.
Comment: -it-it are both the same, but one it got incorporated.
Translation_Other: Мужчина нюхает рыбу. / Мужчина чувствует запах рыбы.

Translated_Text: They hug the children.
Translation_Other: Они обнимают детей.

Translated_Text: The boy appeared (on the road).
Translation_Other: Мальчик появился (на дороге).

Translated_Text: The child jumped.
Translation_Other: Ребёнок прыгал.

Translated_Text: The child ran (on the floor).
Comment: LOC is optional
Translation_Other: Мальчик бежал по земле.

Translated_Text: The man climbed up the hill.
Comment: inanimate object --> zero marked
Translation_Other: Мужчина вскарабкался на холм.

Translated_Text: The man coughed.
Translation_Other: Мужчина кашлянул.

Translated_Text: The girl washed the child.
Translation_Other: Девочка помыла ребёнка.

Translated_Text: The girl dressed the child.
Translation_Other: Девочка одела ребёнка.

Translated_Text: The man helped the woman.
Translation_Other: Мужчина помог женщине.

Primary_Text: Hīɣ qīmd oŋta qolʲepka eiŋ aɣoɣon.
Translated_Text: The man followed the woman.
Comment:
lit. 'The man started walking behind the woman.'
postpositional construction, therefore there is no object marking (just like with adjuncts)
Translation_Other: Мужчина пошёл за женщиной.

Translated_Text: The man and the woman met.
Comment:
lit. 'The man and the woman went halfway (back) to each other.'
lexicalized
-bu- has RCIP meaning for 3rd person
Translation_Other: Мужчина и женщина встретились.

Translated_Text: The man searched for the boy.
Translation_Other: Мужчина искал мальчика.

Translated_Text: The boy liked the man.
Comment: lit. 'To the boy the man started being good.'
Translation_Other: Мальчику понравился мужчина.

Translated_Text: The boy feared the man.
Comment: 2nd subj. marker is the reanalysis of but (incorporated N)
Translation_Other: Мальчик испугался мужчину.

Translated_Text: The man frightened the boy.
Comment: lit. 'put into fright', 'cause so. to start being frightened' (inceptive)
Translation_Other: Мужчина напугал мальчика.

Translated_Text: The man looked at the boy.
Comment:
2nd subj. marker is the reanalysis of baŋ 'gaze'
tān 'path, in the direction of'
lit. 'The man looked towards the boy's path/direction.'
Translation_Other: Мужчина посмотрел на мальчика.

Translated_Text: The man thought about that boy.
Comment: -dat is the masculine benefactive, but it's historically the same as the adessive -daŋte
Translation_Other: Мужчина подумал о том ребёнке.

Translated_Text: The man saw the boy.
Translation_Other: Мужчина видел мальчика.

Translated_Text: The man knew the boy.
Comment:
lit. The man knew about the boy.
'image' qon does not occur with proper nouns, it is used here as a postposition.
morphologically intr. syntactically tr. with qon
Translation_Other: Мужчина знал мальчика.

Translated_Text: The man talked to the boy about the girl.
Translation_Other: Мужчина поговорил с мальчиком о девочке.

Translated_Text: The boy asked the man for money.
Translation_Other: Мальчик попросил у мужчины денег.

Translated_Text: The man told a fairytale to the girl.
Translation_Other: Мужчина рассказал девочке сказку.

Translated_Text: The man shouted at the girl.
Comment:
Or: 'The man called to the girl.'
-es- is an adverbial.
Translation_Other: Мужчина кричал на девочку.

Translated_Text: He said to him: "I’m alive".
Translation_Other: Тот ему ответил: "Я жив".

Translated_Text: The man builds a house out of wood.
Comment: wood.PL = pieces of wood
Translation_Other: Мужчина строит делает дом из брёвен.

Translated_Text: The boy broke the window with the stone.
Comment: lit. 'He made small pieces out of it.'
Translation_Other: Мальчик разбил окно камнем.

Translated_Text: The boy killed the snake with the stick.
Translation_Other: Мальчик убил змею.

Translated_Text: The boy beat the snake with the stick.
Translation_Other: Мальчик бил змею палкой.

Translated_Text: The boy hit the snake with the stick.
Comment: can also mean 'poke'
Translation_Other: Мальчик ударил змею палкой.

Translated_Text: The boy touched the snake with the stick.
Translation_Other: Мальчик потрогал змею палкой.

Translated_Text: The boy cut the bread with the knife.
Translation_Other: Мальчик резал хлеб ножом.

Primary_Text: Qimdɯlʲ lamd ətdiŋalʲ sʲīn kəma raovilvet.
Translated_Text: The girl wiped the dirt off the table.
Translation_Other: Девочка вытерла грязь со стола.

Primary_Text: Qimdɯlʲ eslʲadiŋalʲ eslit lʲamt kəma raqətejula.
Translated_Text: The girl tore the page from the book.
Translation_Other: Девочка вырвала страницу из книги.

Translated_Text: The girl hid the book from the teacher.
Translation_Other: Девочка спрятала книгу от учителя.

Translated_Text: The girl took the book from the teacher.
Comment: kaj- < kas-b (b = obj. marker)
Translation_Other: Девочка взяла книгу у учителя.

Translated_Text: The girl stole the book from the teacher.
Comment: iterative meaning has been lost because of the frequency of this pattern
Translation_Other: Девочка украла книгу у учителя.

Translated_Text: The girl showed the book to the teacher.
Comment: lit. 'put sth. on the outer surface for people to see'
Translation_Other: Девочка показала кунигу учителю.

Translated_Text: The girl gave the book to the teacher.
Comment: V = 'out, away'
Translation_Other: Девочка дала книгу учителю.

Translated_Text: The girl sent the book to the teacher to school.
Comment:
one DAT argument would be enough here
CAUS is historically 'into' (inessive)
'send' is an infinitive
Translation_Other: Девочка послала книгу учителю в школу.

Translated_Text: The man sat down on the ground.
Comment: TH -k- probably means 'down'
Translation_Other: Мужчина сел на пол.

Translated_Text: The man sat on the ground.
Translation_Other: Мужчина сидел на земле.

Translated_Text: The boy went (from the village).
Translation_Other: Мальчик ушёл из деревни.

Translated_Text: The boy lived in the village.
Comment: -daq here comes from də'q '(to) live, life'
Translation_Other: Мальчик жил в деревне.

Translated_Text: The boy sang (it).
Translation_Other: Мальчик пел.

Translated_Text: My arm hurts (me).

Translated_Text: The man died.
Translation_Other: Человек умер.

Translated_Text: The man fell to the ground.
Translation_Other: Мужчина упал на землю.

Translated_Text: The boy froze.
Translation_Other: Мальчик мёрз.

Translated_Text: The boy was hungry.
Comment:
not sure whether this verb was borrowed from Russian
-d(e) is a predicate agreement marker that usually occurs on adjectives -d(e) masc.poss
Translation_Other: Мальчик был голоден.

Translated_Text: It rained.
Translation_Other: Шёл дождь.

Translated_Text: The girl dragged it.
Translation_Other: Девочка тащила его.

Translated_Text: The girl brought the book to the teacher (once).
Translation_Other: Девочка принесла книгу учителю.

Translated_Text: The boy threw the stone into the window.
Translation_Other: Мальчик бросил камень в окно.

Translated_Text: The man put the fish on the table.
Comment: lit. 'The man put the fish onto the table's back.'
Translation_Other: Мужчина положил рыбу на стол.

Translated_Text: The man poured the water into the dipper.

Translated_Text: The man tied the deer to the tree.

Translated_Text: The man filled the dipper with water.

Translated_Text: The man covered the child with the blanket.

Translated_Text: The man covered the child with the blanket.
Translation_Other: Мужчина укрыл ребёнка одеялом.

Translated_Text: The child ate the bread.

I steal that thing from you.
Let’s rob that person.
I stole a bike.

Primary_Text: Le koolnáalo' tu but'ah ixi'm ti' le kaamiono'.

Translated_Text: I am filling the load into the truck.
Comment: This is equivalent to ex. 346.

Primary_Text: Tíin na'ksik le kuuch teh káamiona'.
Translated_Text: I am loading the load onto this truck.

Primary_Text: Yah tin wóol u lo'bita'l le mehen paalalo'bo'.
Translated_Text: I feel sorry that the little children are maltreated.
I am peeling the orange.
Where do you come from?
Let me detach this (thing).
I am called this.
Comment: k'aaba-t is a dialect variant of k'aaba-int

Primary_Text: Tíin hats'ik le che' yéetel u yéet che'ila'.
Translated_Text: I am hitting this branch with another branch of the same tree.
That is Peter's dress.

Primary_Text: Ts'a' u boholil le wayu'mo' yo'lal mu' taal u ch'íich'il.
Translated_Text: Put a scarecrow on the guaya tree so that the birds won't come.
Comment: = RMC_2167

Primary_Text: Wa'pach'e' ka bin ho'p' u ch'úuktik máax ookoltik.
Translated_Text: The giant started watching who was robbing him.

Primary_Text: Tíin but'ik u kuuch le káamiona'.
Translated_Text: I am filling the load into the truck.
Comment: This is equivalent to ex. 357

Primary_Text: Tíin na'ksik u kuuch le káamiona'.
Translated_Text: I am loading the load onto this truck.

Comment: = SME_0063

Primary_Text: Le xch'úupo'bo' tu huch'aho'b teen k'u'm.

Primary_Text: Le xch'úup-o'b-o' t-u huch'-ah-o'b in k'u'm.
Translated_Text: The women ground my nixtamal.
Peter's dress is very handsome.
You think well.

Primary_Text: Le boolaha' h taal tin k'ab.

Primary_Text: Tin t'anah in wíits'in ti' haanal.
Translated_Text: I called my younger sibling to eat.

Primary_Text: Ch'a'a'n sahakil ti' le báalam tumen le máasewaalo'bo'.
Translated_Text: The jaguar is feared by the indios.
I loook at you.
I steal that thing from you.

I loaded my younger sibling on my back.

Translated_Text: I washed with cold water.
My son's name is John.

The ground is getting dry.
The girl is blinking.
I shave.

Translated_Text: The bucket fills with earth.

Primary_Text: U le' le su'ko' ku xoot.
Translated_Text: The leaves of the grass cut .
Translation_Other: la hoja del zacate corta

Primary_Text: Le ko'lelo' ku k'amik hunp'éel nikte' ti' le xch'úupalo'.
Translated_Text: The woman receives a flower from the girl.
Translation_Other: la mujer recibe un flor de la muchacha.

Primary_Text: Le wíiniko' ku lúubul teh che'o' ichil le ts'ono'to'.
Translated_Text: The man falls out of the tree into the cenote.
Comment: The example is highly artificial. A more natural version would be le wíinik-o' tu k'ab le che' yaan ka h lúub ichil le ts'ono't-o' "The man was on a branch of the tree and fell into the cenote."
Translation_Other: El hombre cae del arbol al cenote.

Primary_Text: Le paalo' ku yook'ol ka'ch tu yo'lal u haatal báaxal.
Translated_Text: The child cried over its torn toy.
Translation_Other: el nino lloraba por su juguete roto

Primary_Text: Le wíiniko' ku chíikpahal ti' le naho'.
Translated_Text: The man appears at the house.
Translation_Other: El hombre aparece a la casa.

Primary_Text: Ku paaklan tikinkunsik u tso'tsel u poolo'b.
Translated_Text: The dry each other's hair.
Translation_Other: ambos se secan el cabello

Primary_Text: Tikinkuns a báah yiknal le k'áak'o'.
Translated_Text: Dry yourself near the fire.
Translation_Other: secate junto al fuego

Translated_Text: I dried the corn.
Translation_Other: yo sequé el maíz

Translated_Text: It was dried under the sun.
Translation_Other: fue secado bajo el sol

Translated_Text: I dried the pumpkin seed.
Translation_Other: yo sequé la pepita

Translated_Text: All the trees were peeled.
Translation_Other: fueron peladas todas las maderas

Translated_Text: He got sick of searching.
Translation_Other: se fastidió de buscar

Primary_Text: U paaklan k'ahóol u báaho'b le beetik ma' tu ya'liko'b mixba'l.
Translated_Text: They know each other that is why they say nothing.
Translation_Other: ambos se conocen por eso no dicen nada

Translated_Text: They frighten each other.

Primary_Text: Tu paktah u báah ti' le néeno'.
Translated_Text: He looked at himself in the mirror.
Translation_Other: Se miró en el espejo.

Primary_Text: Tu paaklan paaktik u báaho'be' utia'l u hach k'ahóoltik u báaho'b.
Translated_Text: They are looking at each other in order to recognize each other.
Translation_Other: se miran de frente en frente para reconocerse

Translated_Text: I can't see.
Comment: There is no introversive of il 'see'.
Translation_Other: yo no veo

Primary_Text: Tu méek'ah u báaho'b úuchik u yilik u báaho'b.
Translated_Text: They hugged each other when they met.
Comment: GMC: = t-u méek'-ah u báah-o'b káa t-u yil-ah u báah-o'b
Translation_Other: se abrazaron al verse

Primary_Text: Ku haantik u báaho'b tu yo'lal le p'eekil yaan ti'o'bo'.
Translated_Text: They nearly eat each other due to the hate they feel against each other.
Comment: idiomatic
Translation_Other: se comen debido al odio que se tienen entre si

Primary_Text: Le peek'o' ku ch'a'ch'a'boktik tu'x máan le kéeho'.
Translated_Text: The dog smells where the deer passed.
Translation_Other: el perro olfatéa donde pasó el venado

Primary_Text: Tu'x kóoh a k'ab h boonol?
Translated_Text: Where got your hand tossed, which is coloured?
Comment:
donde pegaste la mano que está manchada
h es eufónico
Translation_Other: dónde se te golpeó tu mano que está pintada?

Translated_Text: My arm broke.
Translation_Other: me quebró el brazo

Translated_Text: My present was received.
Translation_Other: se recibio mi ofrenda

Translated_Text: Who cleans here?
Translation_Other: qui está limpiando aqui?

Translated_Text: I am laughing about what you say.
Translation_Other: me estoy riendo de lo que dices

Translated_Text: Lupe was taken to live with (~ married) by John.
Translation_Other: se llevaron a vivir a Lupe por Juan

Translated_Text: Chase the dog out of the house.
Translation_Other: saca el perro de la casa

Primary_Text: Le xk'ook'o' ts'o'k u kahik u k'ay.
Translated_Text: The nightingale has begun to sing.
Translation_Other: el ruiseñor ya empezó a cantar

Primary_Text: Le máako' ku síit'tik le kooto'.
Translated_Text: That man jumps over the wall.
Comment: Spanish translation wrong CL
Translation_Other: ese hombre brinca albarradas

Translated_Text: Make him sit (down) on the stool.
Translation_Other: sientalo sobre el banquillo

Primary_Text: Kin na'ksik le kuuch yóok'ol le tsíimino'.
Translated_Text: I load the burden on the horse.
Translation_Other: yo subo la carga sobre el caballo

Primary_Text: Le xch'uupalo' tu chak'ah teen u yich.
Translated_Text: The girl blinked at me.
Translation_Other: la muchacha me guiñó los ojos

Translated_Text: The bucket is filled.
Comment: The Spanish translation is wrong. CL
Translation_Other: se llena

Primary_Text: K'áax in wook ichil le suumo'.
Translated_Text: My foot got tied in the rope.
Translation_Other: se amarró/enredó mi pie entre la soga

Translated_Text: My clothes tore.
Translation_Other: se rompio mi ropa

Primary_Text: Ha't u nook' tumen u yíitsin.
Translated_Text: His dress was torn by his younger brother.
Translation_Other: le fue rota su ropa por su hermanito

Translated_Text: That person beats.
Translation_Other: ese persona da cinturazos

Primary_Text: Ma' a beetik a báah beey ma' a wohele' .
Translated_Text: Don't pretend not to know it.
Comment: idiomatic
Translation_Other: no te hagas como que no lo sabes

Primary_Text: Beeta'b le nah yéetel xa'no' tumen hach k'íilk'ab.
Translated_Text: The house was built out of palm leaves because it is really hot.
Translation_Other: hicieron la casa con huano porqué hay mucho calor

Primary_Text: K'a'm yéetel ki'mak óolal tumen u suku'no'b.
Translated_Text: He was received with joy by his brothers.
Translation_Other: fue recibido con alegría por sus hermanos

Translated_Text: Today I receive.
Translation_Other: hoy recibo

Primary_Text: Lúubsa'b le che' tumen le iik'o'.
Translated_Text: The tree was felled by the wind.
Translation_Other: fue tirado el arbol por el viento

Translated_Text: I felled that old/big tree.
How did it fall?
Translation_Other: como fue que se cayó

Primary_Text: Ook'ta'b tumen u paalalo'b káa h kíimih.
Translated_Text: His children cried for him when he died.
Translation_Other: fue llorado por sus hijos cuando murío

Translated_Text: What are you crying about?
Translation_Other: qué estás llorando?

Primary_Text: K'oha'nkunt a báah tu yóolal ma' bin meyah.
Translated_Text: Make yourself sick so that you don't go to work.
Translation_Other: enférmate para que no vayas al trabajo

Translated_Text: He got sick from the cold.
Translation_Other: fue enfermado por el frío

Translated_Text: What made you sick?
Translation_Other: qué te hacía enfermo

Translated_Text: I let it appear before you.
Comment: like a magician
Translation_Other: llo hago aparecer delante de ti

Translated_Text: Has the food been boiled?
Translation_Other: hirvieron la comida?

Translated_Text: I am boiling the food.
Translation_Other: estoy hirviendo la comida

Primary_Text: Cha'k u bak'el k'éek'en utia'l in haante'.
Translated_Text: Pork meat was cooked for me to eat.
Translation_Other: fue cocinada carne del puerco para que lo comiera

Primary_Text: Le ko'lelo' ku chaakal bul k'iin.
Translated_Text: The woman cooks all the day.
Translation_Other: la mujer cocina todo el día

Translated_Text: They hear each other.
Translation_Other: se escuchan mutualmente

Primary_Text: Ku paaklan ka'nsik u báaho'b heheláas t'aano'b.
Translated_Text: They teach each other various languages.

Primary_Text: Ka'nsa'ben utsil t'aan maaya tumen in ahkaanbesah.
Translated_Text: I was taught to speak Maya well by my teacher.
Translation_Other: fui ense~nada de hablar bien maya por mi maestro

Translated_Text: Yesterday all my money was stolen.

Primary_Text: Ma' in wohel máax ku yookol waye'.
Translated_Text: I don't know who is stealing here.
Who teaches here?

Primary_Text: Le ko'lelo' tu ka'nsah ti' le xch'úupalo' hunp'éel k'aay.
Translated_Text: The lady taught the girl a song.
Comment: This is the dominant construction.

Translated_Text: They bring each other's burden.
Comment: Two people who are carrying heavy luggage exchange it to make it easier for both.
Translation_Other: ambos traen sus cargas

Translated_Text: I was brought a handful of flowers.
Translation_Other: me fue traido un ramo de flores

Translated_Text: He was pushed and fell.
Translation_Other: fue empujado y cayó

Translated_Text: They push each other.
Translation_Other: ellos se empujaron el uno al otro

Primary_Text: Léench'inta'b tumen u suku'n ichil le ha'o'.
Translated_Text: He was pushed into the water by his elder brother.
Translation_Other: fue empujado por su hermano al agua

Translated_Text: All my corn plants were dug out.
Translation_Other: escarbaron toda mi siembra de maiz

Primary_Text: Le xch'úupalo' bin u páan u wi' makal.
Translated_Text: The girl went to dig out yams bulbs.
Translation_Other: la muchacha fue a escarbar la raiz del ~name

Translated_Text: They clean each other's face.
Translation_Other: ambos se limpian la cara

Translated_Text: Clean yourself.
It was cleaned inside the house.
I went cleaning.
Translation_Other: fui a limpiar

Translated_Text: Clean yourself!
Translation_Other: límpiate!

Primary_Text: Hu'ch' in k'ab tumen le tuunicho' .
Translated_Text: My hand was crushed by the stone.
Translation_Other: me molío mi mano en la piedra

Translated_Text: I went to grind.
Translation_Other: fui a moler

Primary_Text: Le ts'oonnáalo' tu kíinsah huntúul kéeh.
Translated_Text: The hunter killed a deer.
Translation_Other: el casador mató un venado

Translated_Text: It rained misfortune on him.
Comment: GMC: tenía el infortunio encima
Translation_Other: le llovió chingas encima

Primary_Text: Ku k'áaxal u le' nikte'o'b (tu) yóok'ol in nahil.
Translated_Text: It rains leaves of flowers on my house.
Comment:
Ku k'áaxal lool'o'b yóok'ol in nahil.
u le' nikte' pétalos
Translation_Other: llueve pétalos sombre mi casa

Primary_Text: Tin tóok in báah káa tin machah le xamacho' .
Translated_Text: I burnt myself when I touched the cooktop.
Translation_Other: me quemé cuando agarré el comal

Primary_Text: Tóoka'b u kool tumen u paal.
Translated_Text: His milpa was burnt by his son.
Translation_Other: le fue quemada su milpa por su hijo

Translated_Text: How did you get burnt?
Translation_Other: cómo te quemaste?

Primary_Text: Ku paaklan bulik u poolo'b ichil le ha'o'.
Translated_Text: They submerge each other's head into the water.

Primary_Text: Le kutsha'o' tu bulah u báah káa tu yilahen.
Translated_Text: The duck dived when it saw me.
Translation_Other: el pato se hundío cuando me vío

Translated_Text: They roll each other.
Translation_Other: se hacen rodar uno al otro

Translated_Text: He/she/it was rolled down there.
I am rolling this big tree.
I roll that stone.
Translation_Other: yo ruedo esta piedra

Primary_Text: Kin wilik le hanalo' ku wi'hkunsiken.
Translated_Text: It makes me hungry to see the food.
The food makes me hungry.
Translation_Other: el guiso me da hambre

Translated_Text: It caused grief that she died.
Comment: ok'om-óol-t 'mourn sb./sth.'
Translation_Other: causó tristeza que se muriera

Translated_Text: Don't be sad about it.
Comment: ok'om-óol-t 'mourn sb./sth.'
Translation_Other: qué no te pongas triste

Primary_Text: Le paalo'bo' ku paaklan báaxal ti' le k'íiwiko'.
Translated_Text: The kids play with each other on the market.
Comment: The construction is not reflexive.

Translated_Text: Football was played yesterday.
What does the child play?
A deer was killed in the woods.
The wind cools me down.
Translation_Other: El vento mi hace tener frío.

Primary_Text: Le ke'lo ku yahkunsik in k'ab.
Translated_Text: The cold makes my hand hurt.
Comment: factitive verbalizer -kun may always take either a transitive or a causative suffix
Translation_Other: el frío hace que me duela el brazo

Translated_Text: I roll the ball.
Translation_Other: hago rodar la bola

Translated_Text: The work makes me hungry.
Translation_Other: el trabajo me causa hambre

Translated_Text: That thing makes me sad.
Translation_Other: esa cosa me pone triste

Translated_Text: Each of them has to play with one of the others.
Comment: Despite the translation, this is not a reciprocal construction.
Translation_Other: tienen que jugar cada uno con cada uno de los otros

Primary_Text: Tin yahkuntah in k'ab ikil in pets'ik le boolaho'.
Translated_Text: I injured my hand because I grabbed that ball.
Translation_Other: me hice dolor en la mano por apretar esa bola

Translated_Text: I am laughing about myself.
Translation_Other: me río de mi

Translated_Text: Pedro married Lupe.
Comment: This is idiomatic.
Translation_Other: llevó a Lupe a vivir con él

Translated_Text: They sing for each other.
Comment: This is extraversive of the reciprocal derivation.
Translation_Other: ellos se cantan mutuamente

Primary_Text: Le ahk'aayo'bo' h k'aaynaho'b ti' le hala'cho'.
Translated_Text: The singers sang for the nobleman.
He coughed at my face.
Translation_Other: me tosió en la cara

Translated_Text: They blink at each other.
Translation_Other: se guiñan uno al otro

Translated_Text: I blink at the girl.
Translation_Other: le guiño a la muchacha

Translated_Text: They load each other with their burdens.
Translation_Other: se ponen la carga mutuamente

Translated_Text: Put the corn cobs into the basket (to fill it).
Translation_Other: hecha el helote al canasto

Primary_Text: Ku píixil in nal yéetel k'áax.
Translated_Text: My corn plants cover with brush.
Translation_Other: mi maíz se cubre de maleza

Primary_Text: Áant a báah ka áanta'kech tumen yúum k'uh.
Translated_Text: Help yourself, then god will help you.
Translation_Other: Hilf dir selbst, dann hilft dir Gott.

Primary_Text: Le máako'bo' ku paaklan áantik u báaho'b.
Translated_Text: The persons help each other.
They shave each other.
The two bathe together.
Comment: This sentence is not reciprocal.
Translation_Other: ambos se bañan

Primary_Text: Le xch'úupalo' chéen ku tukultik u báah.
Translated_Text: The girl thinks only of herself.
Translation_Other: esa muchacha solo piensa en si misma

Translated_Text: I know myself.
They like each other.
Comment: uts-ich is a neologism by GMC, analogical to ku ki'ki'ichtik u báaho'b 'they love each other'
Translation_Other: ellos se agradan mutuamente

Translated_Text: They frighten each other.
Translation_Other: se meten miedo a si mismos

Translated_Text: He is afraid of himself.
Translation_Other: tiene miedo a si mismo

Translated_Text: They fear each other.
Translation_Other: tienen miedo uno al otro

Primary_Text: Leti'o'be' tu yu'bah u báaho'b hach xibo'b.
Translated_Text: They felt really macho.
Translation_Other: ellos se sintieron muy machos

Translated_Text: They felt/heard each other.
The boy does not listen.
Comment:
The example is highly artificial. Version with generic direct object are much more natural:
ma' tu yu'bik mixba'l 'he hears nothing'. ma'tech u yu'bik t'aan "no obedience", "doesn't obey"
Translation_Other: ese muchacho no escucha/oye

Primary_Text: Ku yilik u báah ichil le ha'o'.
Translated_Text: He sees himself in the water.

Primary_Text: Le máako'bo' ku paaklan méek'ik u báaho'b tumen táant u yilik u báaho'be'.
Translated_Text: The men hug each other because they just met.

Primary_Text: Le ba'lche'o' ku haantik u báah.
Translated_Text: That animal eats itself.
Translation_Other: ese animal se come a si mismo

Primary_Text: Le yik'lo'bo' ku paaklan haantik u báaho'b.
Translated_Text: The insects eat each other.
Comment: GMC: y- es obligatoria
Translation_Other: los insectos se comen entre si

Translated_Text: They throw water at themselves.
Translation_Other: ellos se echan agua

Primary_Text: Le paalalo'bo' ku paaklan láalik ha' tu báaho'b.
Translated_Text: The children dabble water at each other.
Translation_Other: los niños se avientan agua uno al otro

Translated_Text: I poured water over myself.
Comment: *tin láalah ha' tin báah
Translation_Other: vertí agua sobre mi

Translated_Text: They tie each other.
Comment: The "reciprocal" adverb may or may not be incorporated. Here, it is.

Primary_Text: Lep' a wóol yéetel le suumo'! - Pa'tiki', h k'áaxih.
Translated_Text: Hurry up with the rope! - Wait a moment, it got entangled.
Comment: The answer could be: Pa'tik in wach'ik. 'Wait a moment, I'll loosen it'
Translation_Other: Apurate con la soga! - Espérate que se enredó.

Translated_Text: It's your turn to throw.
Translation_Other: tu tiras (en un juego)

Primary_Text: Ku paaklan ch'inik u báaho'b yéetel tuunich.
Translated_Text: They throw stones at each other.
Translation_Other: se tiran piedras mutuamente

Primary_Text: Ku pulik u báah (tu húunal) le tuk'ucho'.
Translated_Text: The bug bounces up by itself.
Comment: le tuk'ucho' ku ch'inik u báah ka'nal
Translation_Other: el escarabajo se impulsa / se avienta solo

Translated_Text: We get along with each other.
Comment: paaklan u bisik u báaho'b 'they both get along with each other' (without uts)
Translation_Other: nos llevamos bien

Translated_Text: I sent flowers to myself .

Primary_Text: Tu paaklan túuxtah lool'ob ti' u báaho'b.
Translated_Text: They sent each other flowers.
Flowers were sent to the grandmother.

Primary_Text: Ku ts'a'ik síihbalo'b ichil u báatsilo'b.
Translated_Text: They give each other presents.
Comment: ku paaklan ts'a'ik síihbalo'b (complete this way)

Primary_Text: Ku ts'a'ik u k'abo'b ichil u báatsilo'b.
Translated_Text: They give each other their hands.
Translation_Other: se dan las manos entre ellos

Translated_Text: They show/exhibit themselves.
Translation_Other: ellos se muestran/exhiben a si mismos

Primary_Text: Ku paaklan ye'sik u báaho'b ichil leti'o'b.
Translated_Text: They show themselves to each other.
Translation_Other: ellas se muestran entre ellas

Translated_Text: He is showing.
Translation_Other: está mostrando

Primary_Text: Le paalo'be' ku ta'kik u báaho'b tu báatsilo'b.
Translated_Text: The children hide from each other.
Translation_Other: los niños se esconden uno del otro

Primary_Text: U nohochilo'be' tu kíinsah u báah.
Translated_Text: Their chef killed himself.
Translation_Other: el jefe de ellos se suicidó

Translated_Text: They killed each other.
Translation_Other: se mataron uno al otro

Primary_Text: Tu paaklan ya'lah u báaho'be' buka'h u yaabiltmah u báaho'b .
Translated_Text: They told each other how much they love each other.
Comment:
alternative tu paklan a'l-ah t-u báah-o'b buka'h u yáabilt-mah-il u báah-o'b
(all the changes being mutually independent). The preposition ti' is apparently rendered superfluous by paklan. GMC is loath to accept a version with the preposition.
Translation_Other: ellos se dijeron cuanto se quieren

Translated_Text: They shout at each other.
Translation_Other: se gritan uno al otro

Primary_Text: Kin k'áatchi'tik in báah wáa hach haahil in yaabilmah.
Translated_Text: I ask myself if I really love her.
Translation_Other: me pregunto si de verdad la quiero

Translated_Text: They speak to each other.
Comment: = ku paaklant'aano'b
Translation_Other: se hablan mutuamente

Translated_Text: They met at the market.
They pursue each other.
Comment: paaklan is superfluous
Translation_Other: ellos se persiguen

Translated_Text: The boy peels.
Translation_Other: el muchacho pela

Primary_Text: Le xibpalo' tu ts'íilah u sool le che'o'.
Translated_Text: The boy peeled the bark off the tree.
Translation_Other: el muchacho peló la corteza del palo

Primary_Text: Hwaan yéetel u yatane' ku (paaklan) hats'ik u báaho'b.
Translated_Text: John and his wife beat each other.
Comment: without paaklan this is ambiguous between a reflexive and a reciprocal interpretation
Translation_Other: Juan y su esposa se pegan

Translated_Text: The boy beats.
Translation_Other: el muchacho bate

Translated_Text: I submerged the stone.
Comment: transitive form (basic one) to deagentive búul
Translation_Other: sumergí la piedra

Primary_Text: Ha't hunwáal le analte' tumen le xch'úupalo'.
Translated_Text: A page of the book was torn by the girl.

Primary_Text: Ch'a'b u taak'in le wíinik tumen u láak'o'.
Translated_Text: The man's money was taken by his friend.
Comment: ch'a'b ti' le wíiniko' u taak'in tumen u láak'

Translated_Text: The window is being broken.
Translation_Other: la ventana es quebrada (por alguien)

Translated_Text: In the rainy season, the savannah gets drowned.
Translation_Other: en la época de lluvias se inunda la savana

Primary_Text: Le xibpalo'bo' ku ch'a'iko'b u paach le xch'úupalo'bo'.
Translated_Text: The boys follow the girls.

Primary_Text: Kíinsa'b yéetel báat u k'ux-óolal le wíiniko' .
Translated_Text: The enemy was killed by the man with an axe.

Primary_Text: H kíim u k'ux-óolal le máak yéetel báato'.
Translated_Text: The man's enemy died from an axe.
Translation_Other: se murió el enemigo del hombre por hacha

Translated_Text: The handle of my jug broke off.
Translation_Other: se quebró el asa de mi cántaro

Translated_Text: I am talking to myself.
Translation_Other: me platico a mi mismo / conmigo mismo

Primary_Text: Ichil to'ne' paaklan k tsikbaltik úuchben tsikbalo'b.
Translated_Text: In our group we tell each other old stories.
Comment: ningún reflexivo
Translation_Other: entre nosotros nos platicamos cuentos

Primary_Text: Tu yilah le kaano' káa aawatnahih.
Translated_Text: He saw the snake and cried.
Translation_Other: vio la víbora y gritó

Primary_Text: In taataho'be' paaklan u k'áatik u báaho'b taak'in.
Translated_Text: My parents ask each other for money.
Comment: in taataho'be' ku paaklan k'áatik u báaho'b taak'in
Translation_Other: mis padres se piden dinero uno al otro

Translated_Text: The boy always demands.
Translation_Other: el muchacho siempre pide

Translated_Text: He is called by his name.
Comment: ku t'a'nal u k'aaba' 'le dicen/llaman su nombre'
Translation_Other: lo llaman por su nombre

Translated_Text: The girl is talking.
Translation_Other: la muchacha está platicando

Primary_Text: Le xch'úupalo'bo' ku ch'a'bal u paacho'b tumen le xibpalo'bo'.
Translated_Text: The girls are followed by the boys.
Translation_Other: las muchachas son seguidas por los muchachos

Translated_Text: This person helps.
Comment: ti' le naho' ku yúuchul áantah 'en esa casa se presta ayuda'
Translation_Other: esa persona ayuda

Translated_Text: The boys were helped by me.
Translation_Other: los muchachos fueron ayudados por mi

Translated_Text: That person shaves (people).
Translation_Other: esa persona rasura

Translated_Text: John shaved Peter.
Translation_Other: Juan rasuró Pedro.

Primary_Text: Le wíiniko' tu ts'ikah u báah.
Translated_Text: The man shaved (himself).
Comment: le wíiniko' tu ts'ikah u me'x, ?ts'ikme'xnahih
Translation_Other: el hombre se rasuró

Translated_Text: The woman is bathing.
Translation_Other: la mujer se está bañando

Primary_Text: Isinta'b le chaampal tumen le ko'lelo'.
Translated_Text: The baby was washed by the woman.
Comment: ichkíilnen 'báñate'; *tu yichkiltah. isinsa'b ~ isinta'b
Translation_Other: el bebé fue bañado por la mujer

Translated_Text: I am searching.
Comment: kaaxan ~ kaxan. Tíin máan kaaxan. 'I am searching'.
Translation_Other: estoy buscando

Primary_Text: Ku kaxta'l le xch'úupo'b tumen le máako' .
Translated_Text: The women are sought by the man.
Translation_Other: las mujeres son buscadas por el hombre

Translated_Text: The girl thinks much.
Comment: tuukul may be a verbal noun here.
Translation_Other: la muchacha piensa mucho

Primary_Text: Ho'lheake' tukulta'b/tukla'b le chiichtsil(o') tumen le xch'úupalo'.
Translated_Text: Yesterday the grandmother was thought of by the girl.

Primary_Text: Le xibpalo' u k'ahóoltmah ka'ch le xch'úupalo'.
Translated_Text: The boy knew the girl.
Translation_Other: el muchacho conocía a la muchacha

Translated_Text: The boy is eating.
Comment: This is morphologically irregular, be it that it is basically intranstive, be it that it is an introversive derivation.
Translation_Other: el muchacho está comiendo

Primary_Text: Le xch'úupalo' k'ah-óolta'n ka'ch tumen le xibpalo'.
Translated_Text: The girl was known by the boy.
Translation_Other: la muchacha era conocida por el muchacho

Primary_Text: Le xibpalo' ku k'ahóoltik le xch'úupalo'.

Translation_Other: el muchacho conoce a la muchacha

Primary_Text: Le wíiniko' tu ch'a'ah sahakil ti' le báalamo'.

Translation_Other: el hombre tuvo miedo al jaguar

Primary_Text: Búukinta'b le nook' tumen le ko'lelo'.
Translated_Text: The dress was put on by the woman.
Translation_Other: ese vestido fue puesto por la mujer

Translated_Text: I had the horse run.
Translation_Other: correteé al caballo

Translated_Text: That horse runs four miles.
Comment: tin wáalka'tah u paach in kool recorrí el perímetro de mi milpa'
Translation_Other: el caballo corre cuatro leguas

Primary_Text: Le tsíimino' áalkabnah ti' le beho'.

Translation_Other: el caballo corrió por el camino

Translated_Text: That (is what) they said to me.
Translation_Other: eso me dijeron
