Translated_Text: I was told 'no' by them.
Translation_Other: me dijeron que no

Primary_Text: Le taatahtsilo'bo' tu ts'a'ho'b Ana u k'aaba'int u paal.
Translated_Text: The parents named their child Anna.
Comment: lit.: the parents put 'Ana' to be used as a name by their child
Translation_Other: los padres llamaron 'Ana' a su niña

Primary_Text: Le ko'lelo' tu búukintah u nook' u paal.
Translated_Text: That woman put on her child's clothing.
Comment: There is no verb in Yucatec to code 'to dress a person'. It would have to be paraphrased as le ko'lelo' tu ts'a'h u nook' u paal, lit. the woman gave/put the child a dress'. Even that would be ambiguous between just giving her the dress and actually putting in on her.
Translation_Other: la mujer se puso el vestido de su hija

Primary_Text: Ch'a'n sahakil ti' le báalam tuláakal tu'xo'.

Translation_Other: el jaguar se teme en todos los lugares

Primary_Text: Ch'a'bokta'b le xibpal tumen le kéeho'.

Primary_Text: Le kéeho' tu ch'a'boktah le xibpalo'.

Primary_Text: Le paaxe' ma' tu yu'ba(')l waye'.

Primary_Text: Le báalamo' u'ya'b tumen le xibpalo'.

Translation_Other: la mujer fue al mercado

Primary_Text: Le xibpalo' tu k'ayah hump'éel k'aay.

Translation_Other: los niños se sentaron en la silla

Comment: This is one of the many derivations of this class of base. The present one illustrates 'X sits (somewhere)'
Translation_Other: los niños estaban sentados en el suelo

Primary_Text: Le wíiniko'bo' h na'ko'b ti' le che'o'.
Translated_Text: The men climbed (up) the tree.

Comment: RMC_1701.

Translated_Text: I am loading (on myself) these corncobs.
Comment: kuch is the default verb for 'load'. Traditionally one does not load burdens on anything or anybody but oneself. Thus, the goal is lexically implicit.
Translation_Other: estoy cargando estos helotes

The girl brought me flowers.

The woman wiped the dirt off the table.

The woman grinds the corn with a tool.

The ball rolls down the hill.

I threw the ball to him.

They sat down on the bank.

They played with each other.

He stole parts of the money.

He took it well.
They argued with each other.

Translated_Text: The window was banging back and forth in the wind.
He died.
He broke his way into the house. / He broke into the house.
They shouted at each other.
He said that he didn't want ...
I slandered him.
They shout to each other.
I persuaded him.
They didn't talk to each other. / They were not on speaking terms with each other.
They kept each other company a part of the way. / They walked together a part of the way.
They helped each other.
They know each other.
They looked each other in the eyes.
They hugged each other.
They saw each other.

Translated_Text: Then I met with my Maria and ...

This was thought of in such a way that ...
I thought that thought.
The snow is piling up.
The ship can make good use of the wind.
A lightning struck the house.

He felt nauseous.
His heart was gladdened.
They got overexcited.
It burdens him.
He has something on his mind.
This is on his mind.
He has this on his mind.
He deserves the credit.

The sails bursted.
The boat got swamped.
The walls leak.
The boat was smashed to pieces.
The car went by quickly.
The road was difficult to see.

The horse got tied to the tree.
That man tied the horse to the tree.
Because it is not heavy, that stone can be thrown at the window.
That man can throw the stone at the window.
The stone was thrown at the window by that man.

Primary_Text: Darekaga sono otokoni isio madoni nagesaseta.
Translated_Text: Someone made that man throw the stone at the window.
That man threw a stone at the window.
That girl can carry the book to school.
The book was carried to school by that girl.

Primary_Text: Darekaga sono musumeni hono gakko:ni hakobaseta.
Translated_Text: Someone made that girl carry the book to school.
The book got carried to school.
That girl carried the book to school.

Primary_Text: Sono musumewa hono sense:no tokoroni hakoberu.
Translated_Text: That girl can carry the book to the teacher.

Primary_Text: Sono musumeniyotte honga sense:no tokoroni hakobareta.
Translated_Text: The book was carried to the teacher by that girl.

Primary_Text: Darekaga sono musumeni hono sense:no tokoroni hakobaseta.
Translated_Text: Someone made that girl carry the book to the teacher.
The book got carried to the teacher.

Primary_Text: Sono musumega sense:no tokoroni hono hakonda.
Translated_Text: That girl carried the book to the teacher.
The book can be sent to the teacher.

Primary_Text: Musumesanwa hono sense:no tokoroni hono okureru.
Translated_Text: That girl can send the book to the teacher.
The book was sent to the teacher by the girl.
The teacher/school was sent the book by that girl.
Comment: sense:wa is preferred to gakko:wa

Primary_Text: Darekaga sono musumeni hono sense:no tokoroni okuraseta.
Translated_Text: Someone made that girl send the book to the teacher.
The book got sent to the school.
That girl sent the book to the teacher/school.
That book can be given to my son.
That girl can give a book to the teacher.
I gave a book to my son.
This book can be shown to the teacher.
That girl can show a book to the teacher.
The teacher was shown a book by the girl.
The teacher will look at the book.
The book will get shown to the teacher.
That girl showed a book to the teacher.
That book is easy to hide.
That girl can hide the teacher's book.
The teacher's book was hidden by that man.
Someone made the girl hide the teacher's book.
That girl hid the teacher's book.
That girl can peel the apple.
The apple was peeled by that girl.
Because of the sun burn, the skin is peeling.

Primary_Text: Darekaga sono musumeni ringono kawao mukaseta.
Translated_Text: Someone made that girl peel the apple.
The apple got peeled.
That girl peeled the apple.
That book's pages tear easily.

Primary_Text: Sono musumewa, kowaimonosirazudakara, donna daizina hondemo hikitigireru.
Translated_Text: Because she is fearless, that girl can tear even the very expensive books.
The page of the book was torn by that girl.

Primary_Text: Darekaga sono musumeni hon{no/kara} pe:zio hikitigiraseta.
Translated_Text: Someone made that girl tear the page from the book.
The page of the book got torn.
That girl tore the page from the book.
Comment: kara is preferred to no

Translated_Text: That cucumber is ready to be harvested.
The girl can harvest that cucumber.
The cucumber was harvested by the girl.
The twig snapped off.
Someone made the girl harvest a cucumber.
The cucumber got harvested.
That boy picked an apple from the tree.
(Someone) can take a pen from the girl.
The girl had her pen taken by the boy.
The poster/lump came off.
Someone made the boy take a pen from the girl.
That boy took a pen/lump from that girl.
The bread cuts easily.
That boy can cut the bread.
The bread was cut.
Someone made that boy cut the bread.
The bread got cut with the knife.
That boy cut the bread with a knife.
That snake is easy to touch (because it is not fearful).
The boy can touch the snake.
The snake was touched by the boy.
Someone made the boy touch the snake.
That boy touched the snake.

Primary_Text: Ano hebiwa, amari ugokanaikara, bo:de tatakeru.
Translated_Text: That snake is easy to hit because it does not move a lot.
The boy can hit the snake with a stick.
The snake was hit with a stick by the boy.
Someone made the boy hit the snake with a stick.
That boy hit the snake with a stick.
The boy can kill the snake with a stick.
The snake was killed with a stick by the boy.
Someone made the boy kill the snake with a stick.
That boy killed the snake with a stick.
The window is easy to break with a stone.
The boy can break the window with a stone.
The window was broken by the boy.
Comment: The instrument can be expressed in the passive sentence.

Translated_Text: The window broke.
Comment: According to my consultant, the instrument cannot be expressed in this intransitive sentence.

Translated_Text: Someone made the boy break the window with a stone.
The window got broken.
Comment: According to my consultant, the instrument cannot be expressed in this anticausative sentence.

Translated_Text: That boy broke the window with a stone.
He can build the house.
The house was built by him.
The house got built.
Someone made him build the house.
The stick is standing.
He built the house.
The boy can be called a fool.
The girl can call the boy a fool.
The boy was called a fool by the girl.
Someone made the girl call the boy a fool.

Primary_Text: Sono musumega sono syo:neno bakato yonda.
Translated_Text: That girl called that boy a fool.
The boy could say something to the girl.
The girl was told something by the boy.
Someone made the boy say something to the girl.
The boy said something to the girl.

Primary_Text: Sono otokowa sono musumeni monogatario hanaseru.
Translated_Text: That man can tell the story to that girl.
The story was told to the girl by that man.

Primary_Text: Darekaga sono otokoni musumeni monogatario hanasaseta.
Translated_Text: Someone made that man tell the story to the girl.

Primary_Text: Sono otokoga sono musumeni monogatario hanasita.
Translated_Text: That man told the story to that girl.
Someone made the boy ask for money.
Comment: The dative argument in this sentence is a causee. The dative argument bearing goal role cannot be expressed according to my consultant.

Translated_Text: Things about the girl can be told to the boy.

Primary_Text: Sono danse:wa syo:nenni syo:zyono kotoo hanaseru.
Translated_Text: That man can talk to the boy about the girl.
Something about the girl was told to the boy by the man.
The boy was told about the girl by the man.

Primary_Text: Darekaga sono otokoni syo:nenni syo:zyono kotoo hanasaseta.
Translated_Text: Someone made that man talk to the boy about the girl.

Primary_Text: Sono otokoga sono syo:nenni syo:zyono kotoo hanasita.
Translated_Text: That man talked to that boy about the girl.
That man can meet the girl.
Someone made that man meet the girl.
That man met the girl.
The man can follow the girl.
The girl was chased by the man.
Someone made the man follow the girl.
That man followed that girl.
The man can follow the girl.
The girl was followed by the man.
Someone made the man follow the girl.

Primary_Text: Sono otokoga sono musumeni tuite itta.
Translated_Text: That man followed that girl.
I can help the boys.
The children are helped by him.
Mother made me help the boys.
I helped the boys.
That girl can be helped.
The man can help the girl.
The girl was helped by the man.
That girl was helped.
Someone made the man help the girl.
That man helped that girl.
That man can shave his beard.
My beard was shaved by the man.
Someone made that man shave his beard.
The beard is not shaved.
That man shaved his beard.
Mother can dress her daughter.
The daughter wore the clothes.
Father made mother dress the daughter.
The mannequin is dressed up.
Mother dressed her daughter.
Those clothes are washable.
That girl can wash the clothes.
The clothes were washed by the girl.
Someone made the girl wash the clothes.
This cup got washed.
That girl washed the clothes.
The building lot can be found.
The man can search for the boy.
The boy is searched for by the man.
Someone made the man search for the boy.

Primary_Text: Sono otokoga sono syo:neno sagasite ita.
Translated_Text: That man was searching for that boy.
The man can think about the boy's future.

Primary_Text: Byo:kino kansengenga kasitukito minnani kangaerarete iru.
Translated_Text: The cause of the disease is considered to be the air-humidifier.
Someone made the man think about the boy's future.

Primary_Text: Sono otokoga sono syo:nenno syo:rainituite kangaeta.
Translated_Text: That man thought about that boy's future.

Primary_Text: Sono syo:nenga sono otokoni sirarete iru.
Translated_Text: That boy is known to that man.

Primary_Text: Sono musumega sono otokoni syo:nen{no kotoo/nituite} siraseta.
Translated_Text: That girl let that man know about the boy.
That man knows that boy.

Primary_Text: Tonarino onnanokoga sono syo:nenni sukarete iru.
Translated_Text: The girl next door is liked by that boy.
That boy likes the girl next door.
Being a coward, that boy can be frightened.
That man can frighten the boy.
The boy was frightened by the man.
The boy was frightened of the man.
Someone made that man frighten the boy.
That man frightened that boy.
Someone made that boy fear that man.
That man will be feared by the boy.
The boy is afraid of that man.

Primary_Text: Sono syo:nenwa sono otokoo kowagatte ita.
Translated_Text: That boy feared that man.

Primary_Text: Tosio totta kumadakedo, imadani nioio kageru.
Translated_Text: Although it is an old bear, it still has a good nose.
He made the dog smell (something).
The boy was smelled by the bear.
Comment: possessive

Translated_Text: The bear caught the boy's scent.
The ghost was seen.
That man can see the ghost.
Someone made the man look at the boy.
The boy was looked at by the man.
The boy was seen.
That man looked at that boy.
(Because he is slow,) that man is easy to hug.
(Because she is quick,) the girl can hug the man.
Someone made the girl hug the man.
The man was hugged by the girl.
That girl hugged that man.
The boy can ask the man for money.
The man was asked for money by the boy.

Primary_Text: Sono syo:nenga sono otokoni okaneo motometa.
Translated_Text: That boy asked that man for money.
That mushroom is edible.
The girl can eat natto.
Someone made the girl eat the bread.
The bread was eaten by the girl.
That girl ate bread.

Primary_Text: Asinuma anak isitoma=an pe ne kusu.
Translated_Text: I was scared, so (I stayed far away.)
Comment:
Nakagawa, Hiroshi and Bugaeva, Anna 2010
FieldRecK7803232UP.023
Translation_Other: 私はおそろしいので、（遠くに離れていた。）

Translated_Text: To give pleasure to. To make another pleased.
Comment: Batchelor 1938: 126
Translation_Other: 喜バセル

Primary_Text: Coypep hoppa pa p anakne suy tak pa kunak ye.
Translated_Text: (The regular folks said that they would) come back for the remaining dishes later.
Comment: (K8010281.UP.207)

Primary_Text: Sake kor pa kor i=tak kusu arki pa.
Translated_Text: Each time they got a hold of some wine, they came to invite me.
I took off from myself all the armor I was wearing.
Comment: (Nakagawa 1995: 117)
Translation_Other: 「着ていたよろいを全部脱いで」

Translated_Text: (For everyone to) have many children together / they have/had many children together.
Comment: (Tamura 1996: 761)
Translation_Other: 「二人の間に子どもがたくさんできる」

Primary_Text: Otashut kotan chikoshirepa, humpearke etutumpe kotanrakehe chikooputuye.
Translated_Text: We arrived to the village and pushed (=dragged) one and a half of the whale to the village beach.
Translation_Other: 「オタシュツ村に着いて一ッ半の鯨を村の浜へ押し上げてやった。」

Primary_Text: Iresu sapo hawean kor, cise or un ioputuye kor.
Translated_Text: My foster sister (lit. 'an older sister (who) raised me') said (so) and pushed me into the house.
Translation_Other: わが養姉いひて、家の中へ我を押し入んとすれば「」

Primary_Text: Poro su sikteno usa kam usa cep suwe wa.
Translated_Text: (She took a big pan and) cooked a full pan of all kinds of meat and fish.
We went by boats in order to dig up turep – lily roots.

Primary_Text: Sirpaykar kor turep ata wa turep irup akar wa.
Translated_Text: In Spring, I dug up turep-lily roots from which I made starch.
Translation_Other: 「春になると、オオウバユリを掘ってでんぷんを作り、」

Primary_Text: Kaparamip mi kane wa iyuta kor an.
Translated_Text: He/She is wearing embroidered ceremonial clothing.
Comment: photograph description
Translation_Other: 「刺しゅう入りのひとえの着物を着て「つきもの」している(絵はがきの写真を見て)。」

Primary_Text: Shito uta kor okai okkayo utar menoko utar Panampe orun inkar wa mina kane okai.
Translated_Text: Men and women (who) were pounding dumplings looked at Panampe and laughed.

Primary_Text: Nipopke yak wen na, na arsuyne popte wa anu.
Translated_Text: It is not good if (the food) spoils. Boil (it) one more time.
Translation_Other: 「 (食べ物が)「あめる」(悪くなる)といけないからもう一度煮立てておきなさい (食べ物が)「あめる」(悪くなる)といけないからもう一度煮立てておきなさい」

Translated_Text: The hot water is boiling.
Translation_Other: 「お湯が煮立っている。」

Translated_Text: To make grow. \ To send forth. \ To give birth to.
Comment: No sentential examples.
Translation_Other: 「生長サス,生ム.」

Primary_Text: Yaunkur moshir kamui oma nish kohetuku.
Translated_Text: The land of the people of Hokkaido (=the Ainu) appeared at the sky (where) gods reside.
Translation_Other: 「本島の国に神をこめたる雲むらだち起こり。」

Translated_Text: If (because of me) you are strongly criticized... / lit. If people's harsh voice exits towards you.
Translation_Other: 「私のせいであなたが厳しい談判を受けたなら。」

Primary_Text: Sorekus_ iwor so kurka erok kamuy opitta anure wa.
Translated_Text: (You must live and come find me.) I have prayed to all of the Kamui living on the hunting fields.
Translation_Other: 「（『何とか生き延びて、私のことを探してくれよ。）それこそ猟場の上にいるカムイ全部に私は頼んで」

Primary_Text: Amatkarkuutari amippoutari ene iki pa hi anukar wa mosirhoppaan yakne.
Translated_Text: I watched over the lives of my nieces and grandchildren, and then I left this world.
Translation_Other: 「姪たち、孫たちの暮らしぶりを見届けて、私がこの世を去ったら、」

Primary_Text: Yuk ne ciki kamuy ne ciki nuwe akoan wa aacautari akohoppa.
Translated_Text: I will catch many deer and bears and leave them for uncles.
Comment: Here APPL ko- has a benefactive function.
Translation_Other: 「シカやクマをたくさん捕ってきて、おじさんたちに残して。」

Primary_Text: "Epoho ikohoppa." sekor kane hawean wa kusu...
Translated_Text: "Leave your son with me," (He) said, so...
Translation_Other: 「「お前の子供を、私の元へ置いて行ってくれ」などと言うので」

Primary_Text: Aunuhu aonaha kira hine yap hine oraun sinenne aihoppa tono or ta ki p ne kusu...
Translated_Text: My father and mother ran away and returned (home) and I was left alone at the place of a Japanese lord, so...
Translation_Other: 「私の母と父は逃げて国ヘ帰ってしまってそれから私は一人和人の殿様の家に残されたので。」

Primary_Text: Sekor asa iye kor ihoppa ruwe ne hine orano okaan.
Translated_Text: My bolder sister said to me as she left this world.
Comment: Here the APASS prefix i- has a meaning 'this world'.
Translation_Other: 「と、姉は私に言いながらこの世を去った。」

Primary_Text: Akor nispa mosir hoppa hi oro wano.
Translated_Text: Since the moment my husband has left this world...
Translation_Other: 「私の主人が世を去ったときから。」

Primary_Text: Iresukamuy ye p enu wa arkuwanno sinrit mosir ekoarpa p ne ruwe ne na.
Translated_Text: You should listen to what the Fire goddess is saying and go straight ahead to the land of ancestors (said asa requiem for a departed soul).
Original_Orthography: イレスカムイ　イェ　ﾌﾟ　エ・ヌ　ワ　アﾗクワンノ　シンリッモシﾘ　エ・コアﾗパ　ﾌﾟ　ネ　ルウェ　ネ　ナ
Translation_Other: 「火の神の言うことを聞いてまっすぐにあなたは先祖の国へ行くのだよ（引導渡しの言葉に出て来る）．」

Primary_Text: Ram cikuni hap kitayke aarukamare, ri cikuni suptom orke aehopuni wa.
Translated_Text: I crossed over all tops of low trees and I jumped over the roots of tall trees.
Comment: an expression of fast motion
Translation_Other: 「低い木は梢のてっぺんをまたぎ越し、高い木は根元のところを走って（宙を飛ぶようにして急いで走る時の常套句）」

Primary_Text: Sinen ka kamuy hopunire eaykap pa p ne yak aye p ne kusu.
Translated_Text: As is well-known, one person cannot send off (the spirits of) the Kamui, so...
Comment: hopuni-re 'to ceremonially send off to heaven the souls/spirits of animals killed at a hunt or otherwise'. Lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「ひとりとして、カムイの霊を送ることができないという話なので、」

Primary_Text: Kanto kotor akohopuni ehorka cip puta asapaeotke akusu.
Translated_Text: I jumped to the heaven and opened the lid of the boat with my head upside down.
Translation_Other: 「天まで飛び上がって、さかさまに（飛び降りて）舟のふたを頭で突くと」

Primary_Text: Too hopuni hine orano uni pakno ek hine uni soyke ta turse hine.
Translated_Text: I jumped faraway and then came to the house and fell outside the house.
Translation_Other: 「ずうっと遠く飛んで彼の家まで来て家の前に落ちて。」

Primary_Text: Aesinot pe ukoeunaraas wa kakihi kuciste.
Translated_Text: We were fighting for a toy and I made my younger brother cry.
Original_Orthography: アエシノッ　ペ　ウコエウナラ・アｼ　ワ　カキヒ（ク・アキヒ）　ク・チｼテ
Translation_Other: 「おもちゃを取り合いして（私は）弟を泣かせた．」

Translated_Text: (My older brother) dropped that ball drop, the ball drop (with the dead person's soul).
Translation_Other: すると、兄はその玉粒、死者の玉粒を落としました。

Primary_Text: Hunak un awakina pencay kayapaste wa payean.
Translated_Text: The cargo boat (made) of common grass moved quickly under sail in an undetermined direction and (so) we went (lit. 'the cargo ship made the sail (O-inc) run').
Comment: Simultaneous causativization and O-incorporation. Lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「何処を指してともなく青草で作った弁財船を帆走らせて」

Primary_Text: Tu iworso ka tu kenasso ka anopasopas.
Translated_Text: I ran and ran on many hunting fields and tree plains.
Translation_Other: いくつもの山奥の地いくっもの川端の木原を走って行った。

Primary_Text: Somo ekopas y_akun ehekote kamuy amaketa noyne.
Translated_Text: (Your husband your precious husband has fought 60 battles with that demon god. This is a situation where) if you do not go to help him (lit. 'run for him') it looks as if your divine husband will be defeated.
Comment: Applicative ko- has a benefactive function here.
Translation_Other: 「（お前の夫大事な夫がその魔神と６０の戦いを交わしていて、）お前が助けに行かなければ、お前の夫の神はやられてしまいそうな状況なので」

Translated_Text: I ran under him (i.e. under my husband who was rising to heaven in the shape of a bird).
Translation_Other: 「 私はその(天に帰るために鳥になって飛んでいる父の)下を走って。」

Primary_Text: Nep kusu epas wa eek ya?
Translated_Text: Why did you run (here)?
Translation_Other: 「なぜ走って来たの？」

Primary_Text: "Hinak wa ek seta ene iki an?" sekor yaynuan.
Translated_Text: “Where did that dog come from?” I thought.
Comment: 'hear oneself' = 'think'
Translation_Other: 「「どこから来た犬だろう？」と思い、」

Translated_Text: A person who teaches to people reading and writing (=a teacher).
Comment: Antipassivization of R.
Translation_Other: 「読み書き(勉強)を人に教える人(=先生)。」

Translated_Text: He made me a successful hunter.
A rainmaker / lit. a person (who) makes rain (lit. who makes rain stand).
Translation_Other: 「雨ヲ降ラセル人.」

Primary_Text: Kem apto as kor siran ruwe anukar_ ruwe ne korka.
Translated_Text: (There fell a fog over the Tomisanpet river) and I saw the sight of a blood rain raining.
Translation_Other: 「（トミサンペチ川に血のようなもやが流れて、）血の雨が降っている様子が見えるのだが、」

Translated_Text: Older sister laid out many fish slices to dry.
Translation_Other: 「姉はたくさんの魚の身を干した。」

Translated_Text: We will burn down the village.
Translation_Other: 「村を焼き払ってしまうから」

Primary_Text: Ipetam anakne suma akote wa poro to noski un arere.
Translated_Text: As to the man-eating sword, I have tied up a stone to it and made it sink at the middle of the lake.
Translation_Other: 「人食い刀は石を結びつけて大きな沼の中に沈める。 」

Translated_Text: Roll the mortar to the right side.
Original_Orthography: エシソウン　ニス　カﾗカﾗセレ　ワ　アﾗパ
Translation_Other: 「右隣へ臼を転が（回す）して行け．」

Translated_Text: I cannot let my son go hungry.
Translation_Other: 「息子に腹をすかさせてはいけない」

Primary_Text: Soy ta aesinotte SITARI nen nen ne ya.
Translated_Text: If I amuse you outside, (somehow since they were bad men, they would hear about it.They would find a way to kill you...).
Comment: This causative form may have both direct causative ('amuse') and indirect causative ('make/let play') meanings.
Translation_Other: 「表でお前を遊ばせたりすると、（どうにかしてどうにかしてお前が殺されたり、私たちの村にトパットゥミが来たりするのが、）」

Translated_Text: Play on top of (it).
Translation_Other: その上で遊ぶ。

Translated_Text: Is it said that you have hurt your hand?
Translation_Other: 「あなたは手を痛くしたって?」

Translated_Text: Make laugh.
Comment: No sentential examples.
Translation_Other: 「笑わす．」

Primary_Text: Hekattara pas rok pas rok kor oka kusu rokte wa anu.
Translated_Text: Children are running around, so sit them down.
Original_Orthography: へカッタﾗ　パｼ　ロｸ　パｼ　ロｸ　コﾛ　オカ　クス　ロｸテ　ワ　アヌ
Translation_Other: 「子供たちが走り回っているので座らせておけ．」

Translated_Text: Drop/spill/pou down / drop/spill/pour down to the bottom.
Comment: No good sentential examples.
Translation_Other: 「下にひつくりかへす,落す.こぼす」

Primary_Text: Ora su oha h_i kusu ora soy ta ruri akuta.
Translated_Text: When the pot was empty, I threw the soup outside.
Translation_Other: 「鍋が空になったら、外に汁を捨てた。」

Translated_Text: (Again I pulled out the silver dipper and) when I poured [water] into the sea (the water raised to the middle of the sea.).

Primary_Text: Wakkataan wa su or wakka aomare.
Translated_Text: I drew some water and put it in a pot.
Translation_Other: 「水を汲んで来て鍋に入れ、」

Translated_Text: Pour alcohol.
Comment:
Lexicalized. APASS (or generalized object) marker means here 'alcohol'.
No sentential example in the source but the plain verbal form by itself may be interpreted as a sentence with the third person arguments.
Translation_Other: 「お酌する、酒をつぐ」

Translated_Text: We put a sake bottle on top of treasures.
Translation_Other: 「秀罇を宝壇の上に我のせ置きて」

Translated_Text: All of this woman's clothes were taken off ('all clothes were put (aside) from this woman').
Translation_Other: 「その女性の着ていたものを全部脱がせた。」

Translated_Text: Carry sth by sth/sb / carry sth with sb.
Comment: No sentential examples.
Translation_Other: 「1.～を～で運ぶ　2.～を～といっしょに運ぶ」

Primary_Text: Shisoya kotan Shisoya moshir aioarpare katu ne rok oka.
Translated_Text: I was sent to a hornet village, to a hornet land.
Translation_Other: 「熊蜂の村熊蜂の国に我は逐ひやられて来られるなり」

Translated_Text: We send two or three sleepiness gods on Okikurumi's younger sister.
Translation_Other: 「オキクルミの妹神に二つの睡りの神三つの睡りの神を襲いかからせた。」

Primary_Text: Rupne mat utar_ ne yakka aipere pa aikorpare pa.
Translated_Text: We were charitable and fed the older women.
Comment: Here the antipassive i- means 'food' ('give food to (the older women)').
Translation_Other: 「年老いた女性にも食べものを与え、ほどこしをしてやった。」

Primary_Text: Itura utar apumakore sinep sinep ki ruwe ne h_ine ase.
Translated_Text: We paid wages to each person who came with us to carry the things down.
Translation_Other: 「一緒に行った人たちに、ひとりひとり報酬を与えて背負ってきた。」

Translated_Text: Hide me (from other people) for my sake.
Translation_Other: 「(ほかの人に)かくして私にちょうだい.」

Primary_Text: Kotan noski wa poro kem tak hopuni wa kotan enka ta yaske.
Translated_Text: A big clot of blood flew from the middle of the village and tore apart above the village.
(He) torn off the (salmon’s) belly and took its roe off.
Translation_Other: 「（魚の）腹を割いて筋子を出した。」

Translated_Text: A big clot of blood flew from the middle of the village and tore apart above the village.
Translation_Other: 「この谷が両方からくずれて、」

Translated_Text: Singing, clapping the hands and dancing in a circular canon.
Translation_Other: 「輪唱するウポポ。」

Primary_Text: Sintoko patci ka akouk utar anakne nep ka pirka pirka nukar somo ki yakka ...
Translated_Text: Although the people who were robbed of lacquer-ware and bowls, didn’t look carefully at [the things] at all ...
Comment: Here ko- has a Source function.

Primary_Text: Aunuhu nep ka tekekere siri ka isam.
Translated_Text: That young woman ...worked hard and my mother did not touch anything with her hands.
Comment: Intrumental applicative e- and intrumental O-incorporation.
Translation_Other: 「その娘は..私の母に何も触らせることもなくよく働いても、」

Translated_Text: It felt as if they touched each other.
Translation_Other: 「相磨れる音がした.」

Translated_Text: Don't touch me [with the stick].
Comment: I could not find a naturalistic of an overtly expressed instrumental oblique. The part in brackets is constructed by me.
Translation_Other: 「俺に[棒で]さはるな.」

Primary_Text: Ku kor kur ni eak kusu ... ku paro ka perke.
Translated_Text: Since my husband threw a stick, my mouth got torn (lit. 'broke').
Translation_Other: 「夫木なげて、．．．口はさけ．．．」

Translated_Text: (The village chief cut my hair, cleaned my face), brought out beautiful garments and dressed me [in them].
Translation_Other: 「（村長は私の髪を刈り、顔を整え、）立派な着物を出して私に着せてくれた。」

Translated_Text: She did laundry in a tub / lit. washed things.
Translation_Other: 「桶(おけ) (=たらい) で洗濯する。」

Primary_Text: Akot turesi ahunarare kusu aye kane kor.
Translated_Text: I asked to look for my younger sister for my sake (lit. 'said in order to make him/her search for my younger sister').
Translation_Other: 「我が妹を捜し呉れよと言いつつ」

Primary_Text: Tanpe kusu ne iki kamuy tu moto orke re moto orke a=kohunara ki a korka.
Translated_Text: For this reason, I have been looking what kind of god (I was) here and there (lit. 'towards the place of two rumors, three rumors (=many rumors)).
Translation_Other: 「そこをもて如何なる神なるか、その根元をその出自をわれ訊ねもとめたけれども、

Primary_Text: Pirkap tapne asurorke hopuni hawe ayairamure.
Translated_Text: I made myself think that there was a rumor such as she was a beauty.
Comment:
cf. yay-ramu-re 'think, think/recognize spontaneously' (Kubodera 1992: 312) < lit. 'make oneself think'.
No data of ramu-re 'make sb think of sth' as a single verb.
Translation_Other: 「美女なればこそその噂が立つめれとわれ思ひいたり。」

Translated_Text: To suspect. \ To think.
Comment: AB: 'think sth of sb (lit. 'towards sb')

Primary_Text: Op ek noyne iramu hi kusu.
Translated_Text: I thought/felt as if a spear came, so.
Translation_Other: 「槍が(飛んで)来そうな気 がしたから。」

Translated_Text: I warned this village chief.
Comment: In addition to the causative suffix -re/-e/-te, this verb also contains O-incorporation (itak 'speech'). No data for amkir-e 'make/let sb rememnber sth' alone.

Translated_Text: Please understand me. /lit. Please understand it for me and give it to me.
Comment: Here the applicative ko- has a benefactive function.
Translation_Other: 「私のことをわかってください」

Primary_Text: Ene ya sinen ne, iomapan h_umi anan!
Translated_Text: But here I am cherising the child all alone!
Translation_Other: 「私一人で子どもをかわいがっていることよ」

Translated_Text: What a cute child!
Comment: i-i-y-omap-ka 'cute' (lit. 'make people love thing/person') (vi) - contains two antipassive prefixes, lexicalized. No data for omap-ka 'make sb like sb/sth', but it should be possible.
Translation_Other: 「かわいい子だねえ! 」

Primary_Text: Kutci pirka wa keramasuy korka, eytasa ni ri wa kuhemesu ka niwkes.
Translated_Text: The actinidia arguta fruit is good (=well ripen) and I want it but the tree is tall and I cannot climb it.
Translation_Other: 「コクワがよく実っていて、欲しいのだけど、あまり木が高くてのぼることができない」

Primary_Text: Ene rametokkor wa isiekimatekka acapo ne a korka.
Translated_Text: It was such a brave uncle who scared me but...
Translation_Other: 「あんなに度胸があって、私をおどしていたおじであったが．．．」

Translated_Text: Oh my gosh! How suprising!
Translation_Other: 「おやまあ、驚いた/あきれた。」

Translated_Text: Make sb. fear sth./sb.
Translation_Other: 「(人)に...を恐れさせる。」

Primary_Text: Einkarpe pon nociw ne cewsamkur unuunu.
Translated_Text: His eyes (lit. 'the things (which) (he) looks with') are glittering like stars.
Translation_Other: 目は小さな星のようにキラキラ光って、そこらじゅうを見わたしている。

Primary_Text: Aituye kusu ne hi ta akot tono ieikisma ne yakka.
Translated_Text: At the moment when I was about to be cut (=killed), my Japanese master (=lover) [tried to] stop people (=seize people) for my sake.
Comment: This example is lexicalized HUG>seize/take hold of>prevent/stop, plus it additionally contains the applicative e- which is probably used here in the benefactive function.
Translation_Other: 斬られようとした時私に目をかけて下さる和人の旦那はそれを抑え止めさせようと

Translated_Text: To seize./ To take hold of.
Comment: This example is lexicalized HUG>seize/take hold of, plus it additionally contains an unproductive applicative suffix -kar which probably newly introduces the object that has been suppressed with the antipassive i-.
Translation_Other: ツカマヘル

Translated_Text: I'm going to feed it to my horse.
Comment: Depending on the properties of the causee (animate vs. inanimate, volutional vs. involutional) the same verbal form may also be interpreted as the indirect causative.
Translation_Other: 馬に食べさせるつもりです。

Translated_Text: He/she/it sees me.
Comment: Tamura (2000: 52)

Primary_Text: Cikuni ne ciki nep ne ciki, a=tekehe kere ka somo ki no kar kor oka=an ruwe ne a p.
Translated_Text: We lived that way without him even letting (lit. 'making') my hands touch the firewood and so on.
Comment:
(K7803232UP.083)
kere ‘(for hands) to touch sth (work)’ (vt) is an equivalent of 'touch' which, however, does not fit in the specified role frame and therefore is not included here as a separate verb entry.
Note: the predicate kere ‘touch sth’ (vt) usually co-occurs with the subject tek ‘hand’ and the Actor is encoded as the possessor of tek ‘hand’.
Translation_Other: 「薪でも何でも私の手も触れさせないようにして、暮らしていたが、」

Translated_Text: He/she peeled the skin.
Comment: Tamura (1996: 677)
Translation_Other: 「皮をはぐ。」

Translated_Text: (The entire village was ruined.) Your mother sneaked you out.
Comment:
base construction
(K7807151UP.016)
Translation_Other: 「お前の母親がお前を隠して」

Primary_Text: Inan pe kukor kor pirka hawe an?
Translated_Text: Which one should I choose?
Comment: Tamura (1996: 333)

Primary_Text: Poro aynu yuk tapkir sine-p ani kane wa, ek wa.
Translated_Text: Suddenly an old man brought a single deer fore leg.
Comment: (Bugaeva 2004: 123)

Primary_Text: Penampe…ne posta utar suma ari nihum ari koyapkir.
Translated_Text: Penampe threw stones and pieces of wood at these little dogs.
Comment:
Dative applicative ko- construction: A-nom > R-acc > I+INST > subj[A].obj[R].V
(Chiri, Mashiho 1981: 112)
Translation_Other: 「ペナンペはそれに腹を立てて、小犬たちに石ころや木片を投付ける」

Primary_Text: Teeta wenkur tane nispa nep poutari suma ari nihum ari yapkir.
Translated_Text: The children of the people who were poor in the past but are rich now were throwing stones and pieces of wood.
Comment:
Base construction: S-nom > I+INST > subj[S].V
(Chiri, Yukie 1978: 16)
Chiri, Yukie (1978) Ainu shin’yooshuu [Ainu songs of gods]. Tokyo: Iwanami Bunko.
Translation_Other: 「昔は貧乏人で今は金持ちの子共等が意思や木片をなげつけれど」

Translated_Text: Go draw some water.
Comment: (Bugaeva & Endo #1134) – Imperative.

Translated_Text: The name of stone tied to the weaving thread is "pit".
Comment: constructed example, based on Tamura (1996: 344)
Translation_Other: 「ござを編む糸に結びつけてある糸の名前は「ピッ」。」

Primary_Text: Sekor asa hawean hine cip iore hine.
Translated_Text: Older sister said as she put me in the boat.
Comment: (K8109193.UP.045)
Translation_Other: 「と、姉は言って舟に私を乗せ、」

Primary_Text: Neyta ne yakka pirka uske ao ro.
Translated_Text: (Once I bought the tickets,) we can get on anywhere.
Comment:
vt
(KJ # 2210)

Translated_Text: My father taught me (like this).
Comment: Nakagawa (1995: 318)
Translation_Other: 「（～とばかり、）父は私に教えていた」

Primary_Text: Aenkoikka yakun okake ta ke p ka isam pe ne kusu.
Translated_Text: If they steal from me, I will have nothing to eat afterwards.
Comment: Nakagava (1995: 38)

Translated_Text: Even if you were stolen and killed (you were still young, so they may have dumped you off somewhere).
Comment:
base constructions
(K7908032UP)

Primary_Text: Ainu or un iteki ikka yan!
Translated_Text: Don’t steal in the land of the Ainu!
Comment: Kubodera (1972: 117)

Translated_Text: I borrowed money from you.
Comment: double applicative (e-ko-) (OI)

Primary_Text: Ito Anna oro wa amip esouk wa an.
Translated_Text: Anna has borrowed a dress from Ito.
Comment: e- applicative (OI) (ex. 233)

Primary_Text: Ene kunne hene tokap hene ene sinotcakian kor anan hawe ene an hi ne.
Translated_Text: I sang songs like this night and day.
Comment: Cf. Without the incorporation (rare) ex. 149
Translation_Other: 「こんなふうに、夜も昼も歌を歌っていたのです。」

Translated_Text: Let’s go to work tomorrow!
Comment: Bugaeva (2004: 124)

Translated_Text: I couldn’t even go to the other world. (lit. ‘to the land of gods’).
Comment: (K8109171UP.121)
Translation_Other: 「あの世へ行くこともできなかったのですが、」

Primary_Text: Mour mi wa kasi wa amip mi ur mi.
Translated_Text: Put on the underwear, on top of that put on the dress (and) put on the fur coat.
Comment: Tamura (1996: 8)

Translated_Text: He/She put on nice clothes.
Comment: Tamura (1996: 230)

Primary_Text: Inne utari turano ukoipean wa yakun po keraan pe ne.
Translated_Text: When we eat together with many (other) people the food is much more delicious.
Comment: OI

Primary_Text: Tokaci wa ek pewre kur monrayke eirkasuy.
Translated_Text: A young man who came from Tokachi helped everyone with work.
Comment:
Sunazawa Kura: 160
applicative e- (adds Theme)

Translated_Text: (Having heard that it was the squirrel), I was surprised/scared.
Comment:
Satoo (1998: 20)

Satoo, Tomomi. 1998. “Kinezumi (ezorisu) ga onna o kadowakasu hanashi." [A story of a squirrel who kidnapped a woman].” Watanabe, Hitoshi, Minoru Ooshima, Hideo Kirikae & Tomomi Satoo (eds.) Ainu minzoku bunkazai choosa hookokusho 18. Sapporo: Hokkaido kyooiku iinkai, 15-29.
Translation_Other: 「（リスだと聞いたのでなおさら、）驚いて、」

Primary_Text: Tan ponmenoko ene wa itakan ciki e=nu katu an na.
Translated_Text: Young girl, listen well to what I have to say.
Comment: (SN.N)
Translation_Other: 「娘よ、私の言うことをよく聞け。」

Primary_Text: Asaha orano easir sorekusu mina tura isoytak.
Translated_Text: Then my older sister for the first time told her story smiling.
Comment: (K8007292UP.288)
Translation_Other: 「姉さんもニコニコしながら話に加わりました。」

Translated_Text: He is going to hit you repeatedly by a tree.
Comment: Kubodera (1977: 110)
Translation_Other: 「汝は木に打ちつけんとすること」

Translated_Text: Having clapped their hands, they pray.
Comment:
Tamura (1996: 806)
Object-oriented reciprocal with the meaning of joining sth/sb together (u-)
a rite at a Sinto shrine

Translated_Text: There was a flood and it has passed the house / lit.(The flood) has swept things at the house.
Comment: Bugaeva, Anna and Shiho Endo 2010; #0607
Translation_Other: 「洪水が起きて家を一掃した。」

Primary_Text: Taan ta an anan pe urar kamu wa aesiknak.
Translated_Text: A mist covered the thing that was here and I cannot see it.
Comment:
base (non-causative) construction
(N 208)

Translated_Text: Play together / they played together.
Comment:
When the reciprocal prefix u- and a causative suffix co-occur, they trigger the subject-oriented sociative interpretation 'together'.
Here we have the circumfix u-...-te.
Translation_Other: 「 騒ぐ。」

Primary_Text: Pon cikappo ne yaykaran ki wa.
Translated_Text: I have turned myself into a little bird.
Comment: Lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「小さな小鳥に私は化けて」

Translated_Text: (For many people) to say things together / they said things (together).
Translation_Other: 「(二人以上が皆で) 人に言う」

Translated_Text: Tell to each other / they told each other.
Translation_Other: 「互いに...を聞かせ合う、(一対/一群の人の間で)一方が他方に...を聞かせる。」

Translated_Text: Barber / lit. Japanese person (who) shaves.
Translation_Other: 「床屋(店ではなく人)」

Translated_Text: Examine sth by joining together / compare (two things).
Comment: originally u-<REC> + ko- <APP>. Synchronically, uko- object-oriented reciprocal or object/subject-oriented sociative.
Translation_Other: 「両方を一緒にして見る.一所にして見る,見くらべる.」

Primary_Text: Yuk cikoykip nep pahawe ikonu rok pe.
Translated_Text: Deer [game] asked me about some rumours.
Comment: ko-nu <from.APPL-hear> 'ask sb about sth', ko- has a Source function.
Translation_Other: 「鹿てふ獣は何か噂に我がことで聞き込みしにや」

Primary_Text: Inuan hike ahoppa hekaci poro wa.
Translated_Text: As far as I heard, a boy that I had left grew big.
Translation_Other: 「聞くところによると、私が置いて行った男の子は大きくなって」

Translated_Text: Since you want to hear the story of the anscestors...
Comment: (Kubodera 1977: 429)

Translated_Text: It is said that he/she was sick.
Translation_Other: 「病気だったそうだ。」

Translated_Text: Cry about / He cried about it.
Translation_Other: 「を泣く.」

Translated_Text: "Mother! Ouch! " They said and cried altogether.
Translation_Other: 「お母さんやあい。」と言いながら皆で泣くと

Primary_Text: Akor huci cis kor wakkata cis kor suke hine an.
Translated_Text: (I then realized that) grandmother was crying while drawing water and crying when she prepared meals.
Translation_Other: 「おばあさんが泣きながら水を汲み、泣きながら食事の支度をしていたのだった。」

Primary_Text: Nisatta ne oro un isirepakasnu yak pirka.
Translated_Text: Tomorrow teach me the way there.
Translation_Other: 「明日になったらそこへの道を教えてください」

Primary_Text: Akor hekattar uimak ta uwepakasnu wa, ene aynumotokor hi ye.
Translated_Text: My children! Over many generations teach to each other about it, tell that (we) have an Ainu origins like this.
Translation_Other: 「私の子どもたちよ、(このことを)次から次の世代に教え伝えて、アイヌの起源はこうなのだということを言って( ...しなさいよ)。」

Translated_Text: This is what I have been taught about.
Translation_Other: 「教わっているんです。」

Primary_Text: Amacihi anakne menokopo menoko monrayke epakasnu.
Translated_Text: My wife taught women’s work to (our) daughters.
Comment:
(SN.N)
Cf. Base construction (ex. 237)

Primary_Text: Sonno sunke sak no isepo aenkoeikka ka ki p ne a wa.
Translated_Text: Seriously, a hare has been stolen from me.
Comment: Cf. Base constructions cf. ex. 234, 235, 236
Translation_Other: 「本当に嘘なしに、私のウサギが盗まれていて」

Translated_Text: Tuminchi-devils cried and rolled together with the house.
Comment: Here the applicative prefix ko- has a Comitative: co-patient function.
Translation_Other: 「トウムンチたちは泣き叫びながら家とともに広がっていった。」

Primary_Text: Sintoko utar hene cise oske ta ukokarkarse.
Translated_Text: Even wine vessels were rolling altogether inside the house.

Primary_Text: Upas tum aoma wa karkarsean wa ranan.
Translated_Text: He fell into the snow and was rolling down.
Translation_Other: 「雪とともに転がった。」

Translated_Text: Half of my body sank in the earth.

Primary_Text: Pet asam ta rer wa an.
Translated_Text: It has sunk to the bottom of the river.
Translation_Other: 「川の底に沈んでいる」

Translated_Text: The road is dry.
Translation_Other: 「道 乾く」

Primary_Text: Poro ape ari wa uhuy-ka kusu, sunku uhuy wa arpa ayne.
Translated_Text: Since he lit the big fire, and burned it, the fir-tree burned (well).
Translation_Other: 「大きな火を焚いて燃やしたので、エゾマツは燃えて行って」

Primary_Text: Sinen ne okaan hi anemismu kus.
Translated_Text: I feel sad about being alone.
Comment: Pefix e- has a content function.
Translation_Other: 「一人でいるのも寂しいので」

Primary_Text: Ene mismuan kor anan humi ene an.
Translated_Text: Why have I been so sad, living like this.
Translation_Other: 「こんなに寂しい思いをして暮らしているのだろうか」

Translated_Text: If you are cold, put on clothes.
Translation_Other: 「あなた寒いなら着物を着なさい。」

Primary_Text: Kikay esinot wa tun ne wa sinot kor oka.
Translated_Text: The two of them are having fun, they are playing with a machine.
Translation_Other: 「彼らは機械をいじって二人で遊んでいる。」

Primary_Text: Kamuy ne noyne an matkaci sinot kor an wa anukar a p.
Translated_Text: (I saw that) the girl who looked like a goddess was playing.
Translation_Other: 「カムイのように美しい女の子が遊んでいるのを見かけたのだが、」

Primary_Text: Kukokkasapa arka korka, kunetopake anak totek pe ne kusu.
Translated_Text: My knees hurt, but my body is healthy.
Translation_Other: 「膝は痛むけれど、体のほうは丈夫だから」

Translated_Text: Give birth / she gave birth.
Comment: lit. 'feel pain at thing', lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「出産する」

Translated_Text: My leg hurts.
Translation_Other: 「私は足が痛い。」

Primary_Text: Nisatta tunasno tan kotan wa kuarpa kusne na.
Translated_Text: I will leave this village early tomorrow.
Even if everyone screams altogether...
Translation_Other: 「皆がキーキー泣き叫ぼうが」

Primary_Text: Toy tum un nep ka kirirse haw as pekor hawas hawas.
Translated_Text: It sounded as if there was someone screaming in the ground.
Translation_Other: 「土の中で何かキイキイ言う声がするように聞こえる、聞こえる。」

Primary_Text: Sonno pon hekattar utar uminare kor ukesanpa wa.
Translated_Text: Indeed, little children are laughing and chasing each other.
Translation_Other: 「本当に小さな子供たちが笑い合いながら追いかけっこして」

Translated_Text: I laughed at them.

Primary_Text: Umurek utar inukar wa, mina kane okay.
Translated_Text: A couple saw me, smiled and so on.
Blink / He/she blinks.
Comment: sik-rap-rapu <eye-P.RED-flap.wings> 'blink' (lit. 'flao one's eys' (vi) - O incorporation, lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「瞬く」

Translated_Text: My brothers shaved their beards.
Shave your beard.
Original_Orthography: エ・ナヌフ　メﾑケ＝髭を剃れ．
Translation_Other: 「髭を剃れ．」

Translated_Text: I will shave your head.
Original_Orthography: エ・サパハ　ク・メﾑケ
Translation_Other: 「お前の頭を私が刈る」

Primary_Text: Sama ta aekasi cep aukosina p ne apekor an pe, ran hine oraun ehonkokisma.
Translated_Text: Something that looked like a bundle of fish came down near my grandfather, then he tucked it at his belly.
Comment: Prefix ko- has a goal function here. Note the incorporation of the applicative object.
Translation_Other: 「おじいさんのそばに、魚を束ねたようなものが降りて来て、それからおじいさんがそれをおなかに抱えて」

Translated_Text: Hold each other's arms / show affection to each other.
Comment: Lexicalized recipocal (<'hug each other').
Translation_Other: 「手を握り合ふ,仲よく睦じくする.」

Translated_Text: Hold each other's hands.
Comment: u-tek-kisma 'hold each other's hands' (vi): u-tek- 'each other's hands' is incorporated into the verb kisma 'hug/grab'as O; lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「手を握りあう」

Primary_Text: Nep ka kukar ka somoki no, kuyaytekkisma kor kan kor earkinne ku-mismu.
Translated_Text: I had nothing to do and felt really bored keeping my hands in pockets.
Comment: yay-tek-kisma 'hold one's hands in pockets' (vi): yay-tek- 'own hands' is incorporated into the verb kisma 'hug/grab'as O; lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「何もしないで懐手をして　いてひどく退屈で気持ちが悪かった。」

Translated_Text: I have peacefully calmed myself down.
Comment: ko-kisma <to.APPL-hug> 'surpress sth (one's feelings)'. Goal applicative, lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「私は静かに気持ちを押えた。」

Translated_Text: I was hugged (by my elder brother and sister).
Translation_Other: 「（お姉さんも私をなだめて）いっしょに私を押えた。」

Translated_Text: I hugged the baby and made him dance.
Translation_Other: 「赤ん坊の息子をつかんで踊らせた。」

Primary_Text: Ene poro horkew ahun wa... katkemat utar hurarakkar kor...ihurarakkar.
Translated_Text: A huge wolf came in, smelled the women and smelled me.
(My husband) shouted at those people (because of that).
Translation_Other: 「その人たちをどなりつけて」

Translated_Text: (Say quickly!...) They will probably shout at you like this.
I was hit by everyone.
Translation_Other: 「私は皆に叩かれて」

Translated_Text: To slap the face.

Primary_Text: Nea cip ka pira tom aekik hine.
Translated_Text: That boat was hit against the cliff.
Comment: (T 89)
Translation_Other: 「その舟も崖面のまん中にぶつけられて。」

Primary_Text: Rapokke nea okkaypo ani kik kuni, kisma hum pirkano an, an cikuni tuye.
Translated_Text: Then that young man cut a tree (such that) the feeling is good of grabbing (it) [i.e. which fits his hand] in order to beat with (it). / lit. Then that young man cut a tree_i [(such that) the sound/feeling j [(that) he grabs __i in order to beat with __i] is good].
Comment: (based on K7708242UP.199)
Translation_Other: 「そのとき、例の若者が（それ）で（犬を）殴りつけるように、握りやすそうな木を切って持っていたので、」

Translated_Text: They have large debts.
Comment:
Cf. further derivations: e- applicative (ex. 232)
Cf. further derivations: double applicative (e-ko-) (ex. 233)
Translation_Other: 「借財をしている。」

Primary_Text: Tan toy oro wa makanak pakno auk ruwe an?
Translated_Text: What can one grow on this plot? / lit. How much can one get from this plot?
Comment: Alternative coding frame with the base(non-applicative) verb. The oblique ablative coding WA is registered only with an inanimate taking source; an animate taking source triggers the use of dative applicative ko-.
Translation_Other: 「この畑からどれくらい取れますか？」

Translated_Text: Please take a wine cup.
Comment: Base (non-applicative) construction.
Translation_Other: 「盃を受け取ってください」

Primary_Text: Apohoutari ne yakka koinkar siri ne kuni kuramu.
Translated_Text: I thought that (the gods) are going to protect my sons.
Translation_Other: 「息子たちのことも神様が見守ってくれているのだなと思う」

Primary_Text: Ene “wenkur okkaypo” sekor aiye p ne a korka.
Translated_Text: Once they called me a “young poor man”.
Comment: (K7803232UP.108)
Translation_Other: 「かつては「貧乏人の若者」と言われていたのに、」

Primary_Text: Orano akor son utar ona ne ye pa kor.
Translated_Text: (He came in and sat down). Calling (him) “Father”, (my children jumped all over him).
Comment: lit. 'say/name sb as'. The paticipant marked with ne <MUT> 'as' is an oblique.
Translation_Other: 「すると、子供たちが「お父さんだ」と言いながら、（後ろから前から飛びついている。）」

Translated_Text: It rained.
Translation_Other: 「 雨が降る。」

Primary_Text: Ene ae rusuy ene iperusuyan pe ...
Translated_Text: Even though I was so hungry and wanted to eat, ...
Translation_Other: 「あれほどお腹がすいて食べたかったもの、」

Primary_Text: Poro nitne kamuy sapa kasi un iyutani okkayo hacir rok awa.
Translated_Text: The pestle men fell on the head of the big fierce god.
Translation_Other: 「大魔神の頭上めがけて杵男が落ちてきたので」

Primary_Text: Amut emusi notak kasike eray kuni p ene ruwe ne na!
Translated_Text: You will die at the edge of the sword that I wear!
Translation_Other: 「俺の刀で死ぬことになるぞ。」

Primary_Text: Tan ay ani acotca ciki kamuy ray ruwe an?
Translated_Text: Will a bear die if this arrow hits it?
Comment: (KJ #3657)
Translation_Other: 「この矢にあたったら、クマは死にますか？」

Primary_Text: Akor huci sinotcaki kor wakkata. Sinotcaki kor suke ike, ...
Translated_Text: Grandmother would sing while drawing water and she would sing while preparing meals...
Translation_Other: 「おばあさんは歌を歌いながら水を汲み、歌を歌いながら食事の支度をしていたが、」

Primary_Text: Káni ka sinotca kuki kusune na.
Translated_Text: I will sing a song, so you should also sing.
Comment: Bugaeva, Anna and Shiho Endo (2010: #0367)
Translation_Other: 「わたしも歌うから君も歌いなさい。」

Primary_Text: Hempara cup kamuy hetuku ruwe an?
Translated_Text: What time does the moon appear?
Translation_Other: 「何時ごろ月が出るのですか？」

Primary_Text: Okkaypo tun pakno an ruwe ne noyne siran.
Translated_Text: It seemed that there appeared two men (on the road).
Comment: (AB 261)

Primary_Text: Tan kotan ta hempak pa ean ruwe an?
Translated_Text: How many years have you lived in this village?
Translation_Other: 「この村に何年いるのですか？」

Translated_Text: I came (here) for sightseeing.
Comment:
(T 79)
cf. Further derivation: Noun incorporation (O) (ex. 230)
Translation_Other: 「私は見物するために来たんですよ。」

Primary_Text: Ne wenkur okkaypo eun anakne iteki arpaan yak pirka.
Translated_Text: You must never go to that young poor man’s place.
Comment: The dative case postposition eun ‘to/toward (sb)' is employed for marking animate obliques such as Recipient, Addressee or animate Goal, cf. locative/allative un ‘to/towards (sth)’ which ia emplyed for inanimate Goal.
Translation_Other: 「あの貧乏人の若者のところへは、決して行ってはいけないぞ。」

Translated_Text: (IfＩdie at the place of devil),Ｉwill go to hell (lit. to the place of devil).
Comment: Cf. further derivations: noun incorporation (O) ex. 229
Translation_Other: 「（極悪の化物が死んだところで死んだならば、魂が）極悪の化物のところへ行くことになる」

Translated_Text: I wanted to go to the hunting cabin.
Translation_Other: 「狩小屋に行きたい、」

Primary_Text: Tu takne nisi re takne nisi ukotetterke.
Translated_Text: Two short clouds, three short clouds jumped altogether.
Translation_Other: 「長いのやら短いのなどさまざまな形で広がっていて（その雲間をポンヤウンペ...飛んでいく）」

Primary_Text: "Aunarpehe" sekor haweoka kor asucihi kotetterke pa.
Translated_Text: "Grandmother" the young men said and jumping at my grandmother ( they embraced her, crying).
Comment: Prefix e- has a goal function; slightly lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「おばさんと、若者たちは言っておばさんに飛びつき、（おばあさんを抱いて泣きに泣いた）。」

Translated_Text: The baby jumped on the seat of honor.

Primary_Text: Hemanta iesikari hine orowano ekimne iehoyupu humi as.
Translated_Text: It felt as if someone grabbed me and then ran to the mountains, holding me.
Comment: Prefix e- has a comitative meaning; lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「私は何かにつかまえられてそれから山へ(走って)持って行かれる気配がしていた。」

Translated_Text: I saw wild beasts running and jumping around.
Comment:
When the reciprocal prefix u- and a causative suffix co-occur, they trigger the subject-oriented sociative interpretation 'together'.
Here we have the circumfix u-...-re.
Translation_Other: 「獣が走り回り飛び回っているようすうが見えた。」

Translated_Text: I ran over tree tops of low trees.
Comment: Prefix e- has a locative function.
Translation_Other: 「低い木はその梢をはしった。」

Primary_Text: Matne ekaci hoyupu kusu cinukar kusu payeas.
Translated_Text: It was the girls' running contest (lit. 'since girls ran'), so we went to watch it.
Translation_Other: 「女の子の運動会ですから、見に...来ました。」

Primary_Text: Itukari ta ek hi kusu, mono aan.
Translated_Text: He came right in front of me, so I sat down properly (on the floor).
Comment: This is an example without a specified Locative participant. There is no lexical difference between SIT (=stay in a sitting position) an SIT DOWN (=change of one's position into a sitting position).
Translation_Other: 「私の目の前まで来たので、 わたしはきちんとすわった。」

Primary_Text: Kim erok kamuy ne yakka inaw akorpare siri ne kusu.
Translated_Text: Since I gave inaw-prayer sticks to gods who live in (lit. sit in) the mountains, (please protect me).
Comment: e-rok ‘live at some place (for a god only)’ (vt) (Tamura 1996: 107); lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「山にいらっしゃいます神様にもイナウをさしあげたのですから、私をお守りください」

Primary_Text: Ne kotan kor nispa oro ta ahunan apa sam ta aan.
Translated_Text: I entered the village chief’s house, shaking all over. I sat down near the front door.
Translation_Other: 「村長の家に入り、（震えながら）玄関のそばに座った。」

Translated_Text: (The fox) climbed halfway up the mountain and...
Translation_Other: 「山の中腹へ登っていき、」

Primary_Text: Tan nupuri atcas ne ekohemesu wa.
Translated_Text: You climbed this mountain at one try.
Translation_Other: 「この山をひとのぼりにのぼって」

Primary_Text: Tan nupuri or ta hemespaan ciki hokampa isam ya?
Translated_Text: Is it not difficult to climb this mountain?
Translation_Other: 「 この山に登るのは難しくないですか？」

Primary_Text: Kunuhu ka omke a omke a p.
Translated_Text: My mother coughed and coughed.
Translation_Other: 「私の母親も咳のひどい人であった」

Translated_Text: I boiled water and happily washed myself.
Translation_Other: 「私は水を沸かして喜んで自分の体を洗い」

Primary_Text: Orano nani usey kar nea iwatarap huraye a huraye a.
Translated_Text: Right away, my wife boiled some water, and washed the baby’s body carefully.
Translation_Other: 「それから妻はすぐにお湯をわかして、その赤ん坊の体をよく洗って、」

Primary_Text: Sorekusu yayipere yayimire easkay pakno okaan nispa ne rokan kus.
Translated_Text: We can provide our food and we can provide the things we wear.
Translation_Other: 「「それこそ、我々は自分で食べるものも、自分で着るものもまかなえるので、」

Primary_Text: Pon asaha imire kor okaan ruwe ne.
Translated_Text: (I carried her down, and raised her.) Second older sister dressed(lit. 'made her wear cloths') her and (in this manner) we led our lives.
Comment: Cf. Base constructions ex. 227, 228
Translation_Other: 「下の姉さんが着物を着せたり、食事をさせたりして暮らしていましたが、」

Primary_Text: Nep ka ae ka akoe ka somo ki no.
Translated_Text: Whatever I ate, I ate it without (a side dish).
Comment: Here applicative ko- has a Comitative: co-patient function; the applicative form is lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「何をたべるんでも、おかずもなしに食べて」

Primary_Text: Kotanu utar yuk cikoykip uk wa yuk kam uere pe ne.
Translated_Text: Villagers get deer gain and eat deer meat altogether.
Comment:
When the reciprocal prefix u- and a causative suffix co-occur, they trigger the subject-oriented sociative interpretation 'together'.
Here we have the circumfix u-...-re.

Translated_Text: Practice cannibalism.

Primary_Text: Asaha suke hine ipean pa ruwe ne.
Translated_Text: Older sister had prepared dinner, so we ate dinner.
Comment:
i-p-e <APASS-EP-eat> 'eat, have a meal' (vi) is a lexicalized antipassive; note also the phonological changes involving an epenthetic -p-.
Cf. further derivations: subject oriented sociative (ex. 226)
Translation_Other: 「すると、姉さんが食事の仕度をしてくれたので、御飯を食べました。」

Translated_Text: What do you want to eat?
Translation_Other: 「君は何が食べたいの？」

Translated_Text: Help oneself, be(come) independent / he/she helped himself/herself, be(came) independent.
Translation_Other: 「自ら助ける.独立でする.」

Primary_Text: Cep supa kur cep supa kam supa kur kam supa kane ukasuy hine.
Translated_Text: A man responsible for cooking fish cooked fish, and a man responsible for cooking meat cooked meat, and so they helped each other.
Translation_Other: 「魚を煮るものは魚を煮、肉を煮るものは肉を煮て、協力し合って」

Primary_Text: Ukuran wano arpa wa ikasuy kor an.
Translated_Text: (Our grandmother) from evening went (to the place where a wife had died) and is helping there.
Comment: Further alternations: applicative e- (adds Theme) cf. ex. 225
Translation_Other: 「(おばさんは奥さんの亡くなった家に)ゆうべから行って手伝いをしている。」

Primary_Text: Asautarihi nep ka aekasuy ka somo ki no.
Translated_Text: I did not help my sisters with anything.
Translation_Other: 「姉さんたちの仕事を何も手伝うこともせずに」

Translated_Text: (Older sister went down and started to gather firewood.) Then I helped older sister.
Translation_Other: 「私も姉を手伝った。」

Primary_Text: Nen kane eos nen ka arki yak wen kusu...
Translated_Text: In any way, no one must follow you, so...
Translation_Other: 「どうにかして、お前の後を誰かが追ってきてはいけないので」

Translated_Text: He/She is following me.
Translation_Other: 「私の後から来ている。」

Primary_Text: Kamuy aonaha anukar nani itakan pe ne kusu.
Translated_Text: (I was now able to speak. ) I had met the kamui father and had immediately been able to speak.
Translation_Other: 「（私がしゃべれるようになったので、）カムイのとうさんに会ってすぐにしゃべれるようになったので、」

Primary_Text: Aonaha anakne isonkur ne p ne kusu.
Translated_Text: My father was a really good hunter, (so everyday he brought as game a deer or bear).
Original_Orthography: ア・オナハ　アナｸネ　シノ　イソンクﾙ　ネ　ﾌﾟ　ネ　クス
Translation_Other: 「私の父は本当に狩の名人なので，毎日鹿とか熊とかを家へ運んで来た」

Translated_Text: I search looking on top of this (but did not notice it).
Translation_Other: 「その上を見て（気がつかずに）探していた」

Translated_Text: I came down the mountain looking for people (and found this house).
Translation_Other: 「人を探しに山を下りたところ、（このように家があったので）」

Primary_Text: Ecinukar rusuy kusu te ta ecihunara.
Translated_Text: I was searching for you here, because I wanted to meet you.
Translation_Other: 「（しばらくお目に掛かりませんでしたので、）お会いしたくてここで探していました」

Primary_Text: Ponan hi epitta ayuputari asaha iukoomap kor okaan.
Translated_Text: Throughout my childhood, my elder brother and sister cared for me, and so we lived.
Comment: uko- is not always compositional with the meaning of ko- , cf. ko-omap 'love sb of/for sb' (Benefactive ko-), so it it should rather be regarded as a complex sociative prefix uko-.
Translation_Other: 「私が小さかった間じゅういつも兄たちと姉にかわいがられて一緒に暮らしていた。」

Primary_Text: Ayuputari anak yaykata poutari omap ka somo ki no a poutari patek ikoomap pa.
Translated_Text: The brothers ignored their own children, and adored only my child.
Translation_Other: 「兄さんたちは自分の子どもたちをかわいがりもせず、私の子どもばかりをかわいがった。」

Translated_Text: It seems that children play with each other as friends!
Comment: Lexicalized (as it is used only to refer to children who are in good terms).
Translation_Other: 「仲良く大きい子が小さい子をっれて遊んでいる」

Primary_Text: Akor huci akor ekasi earkinne iomap wa.
Translated_Text: Grandfather and grandmother loved me dearly.
Translation_Other: 「おじいさんおばあさんは私をとてもかわいがってくれて、」

Translated_Text: (They) like each other/sleep.
Translation_Other: 「愛し合う(恋愛)、一緒に寝る。」

Primary_Text: Sisamutari katkemat eneramasuy pe ka okay.
Translated_Text: (Among) the Japanese women, there were those who liked me.
Translation_Other: 「和人の人々（の奥さん）私をホーコーにほしがったのでしたが」

Translated_Text: Do you like soup?
Translation_Other: 「お汁は好きですか？」

Primary_Text: Wen kur sani, ne hi iyekoyki, pe ne kusu po hene yaysitomaan wa.
Translated_Text: I felt even more ashamed because they bullied me that I was the descendant of a poor/bad person / lit. bullied that she is the descendant of a poor/bad person.
Comment: yay-sitoma 'be ashamed' (lit. 'fear oneself') (vi) - lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「貧乏人の子供だと私をいじめるものだから、なおさら恥ずかしくて」

Primary_Text: Wen kamuy ne wa ausitomare kor siran pe ne a p.
Translated_Text: It is an evil god, so we are altogether afraid of him.
Comment: When the reciprocal prefix u- and a causative suffix co-occur, they trigger the subject-oriented sociative interpretation 'together'.
Translation_Other: 「悪い神で、みんなに恐れられているものだが」

Translated_Text: All the Ainu are afraid of (smallpox from a smallpox god).
Comment: ko-sitoma 'fear sth from sb' (ko- Malefactive Source)
Translation_Other: 「人は皆...(疱瘡の神に)恐れられて...」

Translated_Text: That bear is afraid of me as well.
Comment: 'mountain god' = bear
Translation_Other: 「もうあのクマも私をおそれて、」

Translated_Text: Our people had a great fuss.
Comment: This verb is derived from the second meaning of the base verb kimatek 'ii. hurry/panic'. When the reciprocal prefix u- and a causative suffix co-occur, they trigger the sociative interpretation 'together'.
Translation_Other: 「仲間たちは大騒ぎをして」

Translated_Text: Hurry somebody about something.
Comment: This verb is derived from the second meaning of the base verb kimatek 'ii. hurry/panic'.
Translation_Other: 「あわただしくする」

Translated_Text: He frightened me.
Comment: Cf. Base construction (ex. 224)
Translation_Other: 「私を驚かせた．」

Primary_Text: Wakkaus kamuy ratcitara payekaas kuni enkoinkar yan!
Translated_Text: Water goddess! Please please protect us in our trip!
Comment:
ko-inkar 'guard/protect sb' (vt) is a lexicalixed applicative; a non-lexicalized form (if existed) should have had a meaning 'look at sth/sb' but I could not find it the sources.
Cf. e-ko-nukar <APPL-APPL-see> 'protect sb from sth' (vd) (Nakagawa 1995: 179)
Translation_Other: 「水の神よ、何事もなく私たちが行かれるように見守りたまえ！」

Primary_Text: Ponpetteksama aoinkar kor pon pet etoko un arpaan.
Translated_Text: As I looked at the side of (this) little river, I went to the source of (this) little river.
Translation_Other: 「小川の脇の方を見やりながら、小川の先へと進んだ」

Primary_Text: Ni ka un inkar wa inukar.
Translated_Text: The pup looked up at the tree and then looked at me.
Comment: inkar < i-nukar <APASS-see>
Translation_Other: 「子犬は木の上を見上げ、私を見る。」

Translated_Text: Compare sth with sth / he/she compares sth with sth.
Translation_Other: 「へ比べる.較べる　へ合せて見る.」

Primary_Text: Re pa ka somo unukaran a wa.
Translated_Text: We haven't seen each other for three years.
Comment:
Cf. futher derivations: “Quasi-possessive” reciprocals with O-incorporation
u-kiror-nukar ‘compete in strength.’ (lit. ‘see each other’s strength’) (OI) (vi)
Translation_Other: 三年も会いませんでした。

Translated_Text: Grandfather saw grandmother.
Do you remember the way if we were to go there?
Comment: Incorporation of T.
Translation_Other: 「「そこに行くとしたら、道は覚えているか？」」

Translated_Text: Know yourself! (imperative) / He/she knows him/herself.

Primary_Text: Ora Iskar emkoho kor okkaypo utar iamkir pa p ne.
Translated_Text: Even the youngsters from Upstream Ishikari knew me.
Translation_Other: 「そして、石狩上流の若者たちも、私のことを知っているので、」

Translated_Text: (At night, we would gather and) and talk about hunting and other things.
Comment: The reciprocal marker u- is attached between two applicative markers.
Translation_Other: 「（夜になると集まって、）狩の話などをしあい、四方山話に興じました。」

Translated_Text: He really talked to me about these matters.
Translation_Other: 「ということを私に向かって言ったのであった。」

Primary_Text: Piskan kotan oro un nispa utar rametok utar sikotak ranke ronno wa isam.
Translated_Text: Each time he invited to his place (lit. to him) rich men and brave men from surounding villages, he killed them.
Comment: Here the reflexive form is derived from a homonymous applicative ko-tak <to.APPL-call/invite/get> 'invite to sb to sb' (vd).
Translation_Other: 「まわりの村にいる紳士たちや勇者たちを呼び寄せて殺してしまったのだ。」

Translated_Text: They are asking me for the payment (lit. 'the payment for (it)' as is expressed by the possessive marking).
Comment: Base construction cf. exx. 339, 340
Translation_Other: 「(私は)代金を請求されている。」

Primary_Text: Nep ka kamuy oruspe hene teeta aynu oruspe hene aewkoysoytak wa.
Translated_Text: We told to each other various stories about gods and about the Ainu of the past.
Comment: Reciprocalization of R.
Translation_Other: 「何か神のことでも昔のアイヌのことでもお互いにいろいろ話をし合って。」

Primary_Text: Cise kor tono umurek… usa okay pe iekoysoytak.
Translated_Text: The couple of the master of the house told me stories about various things.
Comment:
(T3 8)
Cf. Base construction ex. 222
Translation_Other: 「家のご主人様夫妻が...いろいろなことを私に話していました。」

Primary_Text: Tomesan peci Sinutapka ekotankor kur aynu nispa a=sonkonure kusu keraypo...
Translated_Text: Thanks to my sending message to the Ainu rich man, a village chief of Shinutapka at Tomesan river...
Comment: Incorporation of T.
Translation_Other: 「トメサンペチ　シヌパプカに村を領する人　人間の首領に我が便りをやりて知らせたるお陰にて」

Primary_Text: Kamuy or wa okamkir ene aeyaynure.
Translated_Text: I made you think that I am a god on purpose.
Comment: Cf. yay-nu <REFL-hear> 'think' (lit. 'hear onself') (vi); lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「あなたは神様からわざとそのように思わされた。」

Translated_Text: You will be notified.
Comment: Antipassivization of T
Translation_Other: 「聞かせる、知らせる」

Primary_Text: Nea poniwne noyne an okkaypo … aep su esikte pa.
Translated_Text: That younger man …filled the pot with food (to cook it).
Translation_Other: 「年下らしい若者が...食べ物を鍋いっぱいに入れて、」

Translated_Text: I will tell you the story of the ancestors.
Comment: Base construction cf. ex. 209
Translation_Other: 「先祖の話を聞かせます。」

Translated_Text: They quarreled with each other.
Comment: Subject-oriented "indirect" reciprocal (reciprocalization or R). Lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「互いに言い合う」

Primary_Text: Anan hi, nea pon menoko, ahokuhu eun ye noyne.
Translated_Text: It seemed that that young woman said to my husband that I was (there).
Comment: R is not a syntactic argument. This is an indirective object construction. The IOC is possible in Ainu only either with those verbs which have no applicative (three-argument; DOC) counterparts (e.g. ye 'say sth; say to sb') or with ditransitive verbs of a slightly extended ditransitive case frame including Source/inanimate Goal instead of Recipient proper. The word order is not fixed.
Translation_Other: 「私がいることを、その若い女の人が私の夫にいっているらしく」

Primary_Text: Ene okay noya pon ay nep aekar pe ta an a?
Translated_Text: What do you use for this these small mugwort arrows?
Comment: Here the applicative prefix e- has a function of Purpose.
Translation_Other: 「あんな蓬の小矢は何に使うものだろう。」

Translated_Text: So, I built a house here.
Translation_Other: 「ここに家を作って」

Primary_Text: Oro ta asucihi tasiro ani ki mose wa ani pon cise kar.
Translated_Text: Grandmother then cut reed grass with her mountain knife and built a small house with that reed grass where they lived.
Comment: In the second clause with kar 'make/buld' predicate, instrumental argument is omittted (because it is topical and was introduced in the preceeding clause) but the instrumental postposition ani is retained which rather typical for Ainu. This indicative of a vey early stage of grammaticalization of ani <INST> from the verb ani ‘hold sth (SG)’ (vt).
Translation_Other: 「おばあさんは山刀で草を刈って、その草で小さな家を作って暮らしていたのだ。」

Translated_Text: My garment is torn.
Translation_Other: 「私の着物が破れた。」

Primary_Text: Ahunan pakno (ni ani) cip puta aperpa ruwe ne.
Translated_Text: He broke the boat lids (with the stick) until (it was possible) to enter them.
Translation_Other: 「（船の中に）入れるようになるまで、船のふたをこわして」

Translated_Text: Kill oneself. / He/she killed himself/herself.
Translation_Other: 「自殺する」

Translated_Text: (I felt) I will be killed (by my siblings and parents).
Comment: Since O is singular, the verbal stem is singular. In the case of transitive verbs, plural stems are commonly used for plural O.
Translation_Other: 「二人一緒に殺されかねない雰囲気を感じとることができました。」

Translated_Text: Fight and kill each other.
Translation_Other: 「戦って殺しあう」

Primary_Text: Emus hene tasiro hene ruyke wa, ani (aresu cape) rayke.
Translated_Text: Sharpen your sword and your mountain knife, and kill the cat (that we used to have) with them.
Translation_Other: 「太刀でも山刀でも研いで、それで殺してください。」

Translated_Text: I hit myself repeatedly and jumped.
I repeatedly struck my hand on the tree (because I killed my brothers).
Comment:
Here E- has a locative function.
Further derivations: Object-oriented reciprocal with the meaning of joining sth/sb together (u-) cf. ex. 220
Futher derivations: Noun incorporation cf. ex. 221
Translation_Other: 「手を木に叩け付け」

Primary_Text: Ne hekattar aukokikkik aukoronnu anki yaynuan a korka.
Translated_Text: I thought I was close to smashing and killing these children altogether.
Translation_Other: 「もう少しでその子供たちをぶん殴って殺してやろうと思ったが」

Primary_Text: Mimtuci ukokikkik hine rayke ruwe ene an hi ne.
Translated_Text: They have beaten the mermaid altogether and killed him.
Translation_Other: 「ミムトゥチをみんなでぶんなぐって殺した。」

Primary_Text: Aynu utar cep ronnu kor munin cikuni ani kikkikpa.
Translated_Text: To kill fish the Ainu hit it repeatedly with a piece of rotten wood.
Translation_Other: 「人間たちは魚をとるには朽ちた木で叩き叩いて」

Primary_Text: Aramu rok pe... apaotki ne manu p emus etuye.
Translated_Text: The man I was thinking about...cut the thing called a door bamboo blind with a sword.
Translation_Other: 「あの男が... 戸のすだれを刀で切手」

Primary_Text: Toan nitek noko ani tuye yan.
Translated_Text: Cut that branch with a saw.
Translation_Other: 「あの枝をのこぎりで切りなさい。」

Translated_Text: Total devastation by war [or flood].
Comment:
Lexicalized.
cf. Further derivations: locative applicative o- (ex. 219)
Translation_Other: 「鏖殺戦」

Primary_Text: Surku kamuy utar ka teyne pokna mosir akonuwe kusu ne sekor haweanan.
Translated_Text: We wished that the Aconite-poison gods would be wiped away to hell (=wet low country).
Translation_Other: 「毒の神を湿地の国へ蹴り落とす、ともろもろ神に祈った。」

Primary_Text: Orowa iahunke kuni menoko munnuwe humi as.
Translated_Text: Then it sounded as if, in order to let me in, the woman was sweeping.
Translation_Other: 「すると、私たちを招き入れるために床を掃く音が聞こえた。」

Translated_Text: I swept and wiped inside the house with all my might.
Comment: 'A wipes L'
Translation_Other: 「家の中を掃きに掃いて、拭きに拭いた。」

Primary_Text: Munihi anuwenuwe akerkeri wa soy ao.
Translated_Text: I vigorously swept the rubbish and scrapped it and took it off outside.
Comment: 'A wipes (off) T'
Translation_Other: 「ごみを掃いて掃いて、掻きとって外に出した」

Primary_Text: Ahokuhu ka tepaha ka mipihi ka akososo kuni.
Translated_Text: (I sang) that I would take from my husband his loincloth and clothes.

Primary_Text: Aosoro ne usi asapaha ne usi ayaykonuyna.
Translated_Text: I hid my buttocks and head by pulling them to my body (lit. hid at myself).
Comment: The reflexive yay-ko-nuyna 'hide sth at one's body' (vt) is derived from the homonymous applicative ko-nuyna 'hide sth at' (vt), not from ko-nuyna 'hide sth from' (vt) which is questioned here.
Translation_Other: 「自分の尻や頭を体を丸めて隠した。」

Translated_Text: The girl hid the basket from her grandmother.

Primary_Text: Okikurmi aynu pito esinukare ki rok oka?
Translated_Text: Have you shown your nude body (lit. yourself) to the human god Okikurmi?
Comment: Reflexivization of T. Lexicalized.
Translation_Other: 「オキクルミの神人にあなたの肉体を見せたのですか。」

Primary_Text: Paycar sey kuytop sinukare wa kinno.
Translated_Text: In March, the shell fish wanted to show itself to the wild goose and got fat.
Comment: Reflexivization of T.
Translation_Other: 「三月ごろのホッキ貝は雁に見てもらいたくてまるまると太っている。」

Translated_Text: Don't show me to him (lit. Don't let him see my appearance!)!
Comment: T-incorporation. si- <REFL> modifies kur 'appearance', i.e. si-kur 'oneself's appearance'.
Translation_Other: 「決して汝の姿を見せしむるな。」

Translated_Text: Anna and granny showed each other their headbands.
Comment: Subject-oriented reciprocal “indirect” reciprocal (u-): Reciprocalization of R.

Primary_Text: Kamuy ka neno ainukare, eani ka neno ainukare ruwe ne na.
Translated_Text: (I did not swallow snakes.) I have just shown myself like this to the gods, I have shown myself like this to you.
Comment: This is the only example of the Theme object cross-referencing in the ditransitive construction which is used for an animate non-third person Theme. It occurred in a folktale narrated by one of the last fluent speakers of Ainu, Mrs. Toshi Ueda (1912-2005), so one may possibly cast a doubt on its grammaticality. It is important to find out whether similar examples occurred in the speech of earlier generations of Ainu speakers.
Translation_Other: 「（丸飲みしていたのではない。）そのようにお前達に神様にもそのように私は自分を見せていたのだ。お前にもそのように私は自分を見せていたんだよ。」

Primary_Text: Apoutari aacautari anukare somo ki yak wen kusu ...
Translated_Text: We had to show our children to uncles, so...
Translation_Other: 「子供たちをおじたちに見せなくてはいけないので、」

Translated_Text: I will show you the bed.
Translation_Other: 「寝床をお見せしますよ。」

Primary_Text: Epon hi wano aeciukore kunihi aye kor okaan ruwe ne.
Translated_Text: Since your childhood we agreed to give you (as bride and bridegroom) to each other, and so we live (lit. let you have each other).
Comment: Object-oriented reciprocal with the meaning of joining sth/sb together (u): Reciprocalization of T (lexicalized).
Translation_Other: С твоего детства вас отдать друг другу уговорились мы, и так живем.

Primary_Text: Akor ninup Anna kor ninup, aukorpare.
Translated_Text: As to my sewing and Anna’s sewing, we (you and I) gave (them) to each other (lit. let each other have them).
Comment: Subject-oriented reciprocal “indirect” reciprocal (u-): Reciprocalization of R.

Primary_Text: Itura utar apumakore sinep sinep ki ruwe ne hine ase.
Translated_Text: We paid each person who came with us to carry the things down.
Comment: P/T-incorporation.
Translation_Other: 「一緒に行った人たちに、ひとりひとり報酬を与えて背負ってきた。」

Translated_Text: Anna gave me a sewing (lit. let me have a sewing).

Primary_Text: Ora suy mosirkarkamuy eun, sonkopayere hawe ene an hi.
Translated_Text: Then they send the following message to the world-creator god.
Comment: P/T-incorporation.
Translation_Other: 「そして、それからまた国造りの神様のところへ使いをやって、こう言いました」

Translated_Text: (He instructed us to) send him to the dog master.
Translation_Other: 「犬の親方のところへ行ける（ように指示したらしく、）」

Primary_Text: Akon yupi siknure wa akor kotanu akor casi orura wa ikorpare yan.
Translated_Text: Please for my sake save my brother and carry him to my village and my castle.
Translation_Other: 「兄を生き返らせて、私の村、私の城へ運びんでください」

Translated_Text: Ito carried honeysuckle and walnut together.
Comment:
Unlike subject-oriented sociatives, object-oriented sociatives may have a singular subject, while the object
is as a rule plural semantically or it refers to an entity composed of some parts involved in
the action. The form is homonymous with the subject-oriented sociative (ex. 47) and indirect reciprocal, see Comments in (ex. 26).

Translated_Text: Bring sth/sb together. / He/She brought them together.
Comment:
Subject-oriented sociatives must have a plural subject, while the object
may be singular. The form is homonymous with the object-oriented sociative (ex. 31) and indirect reciprocal, see Comments in (ex. 26).
Translation_Other: 「（何人かが）～を一緒に運んで来る」；「彼らがこれを一緒に運んできた。」

Primary_Text: Konto kotan kor utar ne yakka apumakore pa wa irura pa.
Translated_Text: (I carried the things that the wise man had owned.) Then I paid the villagers and they carried (the things).
Translation_Other: 「（長者の持っていたものもせおって、）村の人々にも報酬をやって運ばせた。」

Translated_Text: Then I carried the fish.
Translation_Other: 「魚を運んだ。」

Primary_Text: Nea kotan pa un nispa macihi ewtanne kur, kotan pa un kur uni o p yayteknata cip or un rura.
Translated_Text: The man who married the wife of the elder from above the village carried the things from the house of the man from above the village to his boat.
Comment: The allative postposition un ‘to/towards (sth)’ is employed for marking inanimate Goal obliques.
Translation_Other: 「例の村の上手の長者の妻と結婚した男が村の上手の男の家にあるものを自分の舟に運んだ。」

Primary_Text: Aynurakkur kamuy akarku an kusukeraypo akor turesi aikorura.
Translated_Text: Thanks to my divine nephew Ainurakkur my younger sister has been carried to me.
Comment:
A-nom > R-acc > T-acc > subj[A].obj[R].V.
cf. Further derivations:
ko-rura ‘carry sth/sb to sb/some place’ Goal APPL (vd) >
u-ko-rura ‘carry sth to each other’ (OI) (vt) indirect reciprocal (subject-oriented), valency-reducing.
Translation_Other: 「アイヌラックル我が甥の御蔭にて我が妹が送り帰されて」

Primary_Text: Aynu nimara Iskar emko kor nispa eun nea nispa kor pa p opitta rura pa.
Translated_Text: The (remaining) half of the Ainu carried all of that rich man’s belongings to the the rich man at Upstream Ishikari.
Comment: The dative case postposition eun ‘to/toward (sb)’ is employed for marking animate obliques such as Recipient, Addressee or animate Goal.
Translation_Other: 「残った半分の人たちは、石狩上流の長者の家へ、その長者の持っていたものを全部運んだ。」

Primary_Text: Anna anak wakka kor wa ek, wa en=kore.
Translated_Text: Anna brought me some water. /lit. Anna brought water and gave it to me.
Comment: Here we have a multiclausal (non-applicative) benefactive construction wa kor-e lit. "(did) and gave (lit. 'made have') it to sb‟ which probably developed in Ainu under the influence of Japanese having a structurally similar construction with the verb kureru "give‟ (Jap.). Note that Beneficiary and Theme are encoded in different clauses.
Translation_Other: 「アンナが私にお水を持って来てくれた。」

Primary_Text: Kuneywa isimne an akusu ayuputari sorekusu cip sikno kane cep kor wa arki pa.
Translated_Text: The next morning, older brothers brought home a boatful of fish.
Translation_Other: 「翌朝になると、兄たちが舟いっぱいに魚を積んで帰って来た。」

Translated_Text: They brought it together.
Comment:
Subject-oriented sociatives must have a plural subject, while the object
may be singular. The form is homonymous with the object-oriented sociative (ex. 20) and indirect reciprocal (ex. 21).
Translation_Other: 「彼らはこれを一緒に持ってきた。」

Translated_Text: (They) brought delicious things to each other.
Comment: Indirect reciprocal (A/R). The form is homonymous with the object-oriented sociative (ex. 20) and subject-oriented reciprocal (ex. 22).
Translation_Other: 「お互いに美味しいものを持ってきた。」

Primary_Text: Kon-kani pon ku kon-kani pon ay ci=uko-ani.
Translated_Text: I (a god) took into my hands a small gold bow and a small gold arrow together.
Comment:
Unlike subject-oriented sociatives, object-oriented sociatives may have a singular subject, while the object
is as a rule semantically plural or it refers to an entity composed of some parts involved in
the action. The form is homonymous with the subject-oriented sociative (ex. 22) and indirect reciprocal (ex. 21).
Translation_Other: 「金の小弓に金の小矢を持って」

Primary_Text: Pon cep ne korka arturere poka e=kor unarpe ko-ani wa ek.
Translated_Text: It is a little fish but bring at least half of it to your grandmother.
Comment: (KAY 248)
Translation_Other: 「小さいサケだけれど半身ばかりでもお前の伯母に持って行って来い．」

Primary_Text: Poro rokunto akar hine rokunto noski ta yayeyapkiran.
Translated_Text: I made a big boat and threw myself to the middle of the boat.
Translation_Other: 「（木の葉を集めて）大きな舟を作って舟のまん中に身を投げ出し（丸くなって寝た。）」

Primary_Text: Panampe tane sioka un kunne katak eyapkir kusne.
Translated_Text: Panampe was going to throw the ball of black string behind himself.
Translation_Other: 「パナンペが後ろのほうへ黒い糸玉を投げようとすると」

Primary_Text: Akor ya asanke hine to kurka akoeyapkir.
Translated_Text: I took out my fish net and threw it to the lake.
Comment: Double applicative: A-nom > T-acc > G-acc > subj[A].obj[T].V
Translation_Other: 「（ふところに入れた）網を取り出して沼の上に放り投げた。」

Translated_Text: Put to a different house / He/she put him/her to a different house.
Comment: Horobetsu dialect
Translation_Other: 「[別の家におく]《ホロベツ》分家する。」

Primary_Text: Orowa mi pa p opitta akoanu hine.
Translated_Text: I took off all her clothing (from her).
Comment:
ko- Malefactive Source; lexicalized APPL.
cf. Further derivations: Reflexive (valency-reducing, object-deleting) cf. ex. 338
Translation_Other: 「そして、着ているものを全部脱がせて」

Primary_Text: Nea asikehe ape etok un anu. Oharkiso un aan.
Translated_Text: (The woman) placed my luggage at the upper seat of honor, and I sat at the lower seat of honor.

Primary_Text: Orano akor ekasi anak aoypepi sirka ta anu.
Translated_Text: Grandfather put the dish down on the ground.
Translation_Other: 「おじいさんは食器を地面に置くと、」

Translated_Text: My elder brothers also had many children.
Comment:
Both P (sir 'ground/world') and I (po 'child') are incorporated, i.e. the resultant verb is intransitive: S subj[S].<I><P>V.
cf. Further derivations: Subject-oriented sociative. The sociative uko- does not change valency (Cf. ex. 337).
Translation_Other: 「兄達も子供をたくさん持った、」

Translated_Text: Cover ground with sth. / He/she covers/covered ground with it.
Comment: This is a constructed example, cf. the base naturalistic example: sir-kamu　<ground-cover> ‘cover ground; lie spread-eagled on the ground (lexicalized)’ (vi) (Nakagawa 1995: 222). Cf. further derivations: Anticausative. As a result of the anticausative alternation, original A is deleted and original I (object) is promoted to S.
Translation_Other: 「～で地面を覆う。」

Primary_Text: Amacirpehe ne a p, wakkata kusu pet or ta ran siri anukar yakun.
Translated_Text: If I see my younger sister go down to the river to fetch some water...
Comment: P is incorporated.
Translation_Other: 「妹であったものが、水を汲みに川へ下りて行ったのを見たので」

Primary_Text: Ratcako sum hene ponno oro ota wa uhuyka.
Translated_Text: Pour at least some lamp oil there and light it.
Comment: Imperative sentence, no verbal cross-referencing for the subject.
Translation_Other: 「油でもそこにかけて燃やしなさい。」

Translated_Text: (Since I cut his throat I could not carry him on my back, so) I tied his throat with a rope and (dragged him).
