Translation_Other: 「（首筋を切って、背負えないので）荷縄をこうやって首にしばりつけて（引っ張って引っ張って来て）」

Translated_Text: Tie (it) to the tree.

Primary_Text: Cikuni kotca ta seta asirkote wa an.
Translated_Text: The dog is tied in front of the tree.
Translation_Other: 「木の前にイヌがつないである。」

Translated_Text: She put the fish into the boat (and stood on the bow of the boat).
Translation_Other: 「あの魚を舟に積み込んで、（舟のへさきに陣取った。）」

Primary_Text: Penampe ci kursutu kisma, tek kamure kane.
Translated_Text: Penampe grabbed his penis and covered (it) with his hand.
Comment: lit. ‘made his hand cover (his penis)’
Original_Orthography: Penampe chi-kurshutu kishma , tek kamure kane
Translation_Other: ペナンぺは陰茎の根元を押え、手で覆いながら

Translated_Text: Lay one on top of another / (He/she) lays/laid (them/a thing) on top of another.
Comment: No sentential example in the source but the plain verbal form by itself may be interpreted as a sentence with the third person arguments.
Translation_Other: (二枚)を重ね合わせる

Primary_Text: (Aekasi) cep aukosina p ne ápekor an pe... kasi wa amip kamure kane an.
Translated_Text: (My grandfather) covered up something that looked like a bundle of fish with his clothing.
Comment: Base construction cf. ex. 218
Translation_Other: （おじいさんのそばに）、魚を束ねたようなものが、（降りて来て、それから）おじいさんはそれを（おなかに抱えて）その上から着物をかぶせて（隠して、こちらに来そうな様子です。）

Translated_Text: I made the child listen to the story.
I was affected by my neighbor's hearing of my secret story.
Comment: indirect passive

Translated_Text: I heard a big sound.

Primary_Text: Ore amakkonge sonna godo sjtsja oenenatte itta.
Translated_Text: I said to the girl "It's not good to do such a thing.".
I cannot shout.
I made my son shout at her/him.
I made my son shout at her/him.
I shouted at her/him.
I was shouted at by her/him.
I was shouted at by her/him.
I shouted at her/him.
I can surprise her/him.
I made that man surprise the boy.
The boy was surprised by that man.
The boy was surprised.
That man surprised the boy.
She/he felt cold.
I made her/him climb the roof.
She/he climbed Mt. Tsukuba.
The teacher saw a baby.
I made her/him meet the girl.
The rabbit was hunted by her/him.
Comment: passive sentence (DO)

Translated_Text: She/he feels sad.
I made the boy sing a school song.
I made the girl carry a book to school.
The girl carried a book to school.
I made the girl send a book to school.
The girl sent a book to school from the post office.
The girl can show a baby to the teacher.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: The teacher was shown a baby by the girl.
Comment: passive sentence (IO)

Translated_Text: I made the girl show the homework to the teacher.
The girl showed a baby to the teacher.
I boiled the water.
I met that girl.
The water boiled.
The clothes were washed by the girl.
Comment: passive sentence (DO)

Translated_Text: I can hear that sound.
I like manju.
She/he can teach this to her/him well.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: I like the girl next door.
I was taught this by her/him.
Comment: passive sentence (IO)

Translated_Text: The baby was hugged by her/his mother.
Comment: passive sentence (DO)

Translated_Text: I learnt this from the teacher.
The baby was hugged in her/his mother's arm.
I made her/him teach this to the boy.
Mother hugged the baby.
The teacher taught me math.
The bread had been eaten by her/him.
Comment: passive sentence (DO)

Translated_Text: The girl can steal the teacher's book.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: The teacher was stolen her/his book by the girl.
Comment: passive sentence (IO)

Translated_Text: I made the girl steal the teacher's book.
The girl stole the teacher's book.
That girl can push her/his back.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: She/he had her/his back pushed by the girl.
Comment: passive sentence (IO)

Translated_Text: I made the girl push her/his back.
The girl pushed her/his back.
She/he can dig for potatoes.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: I made her/him dig for potatoes.
She/he is digging for potatoes.
She/he can dig a hole soon.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Primary_Text: Ore arenge uena hadagesa medo horaseda.
Translated_Text: I made her/him dig a hole in the field above.
I dug a hole in the field above.
The girl can wipe the water well.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: I made the girl wipe the water.
The girl wiped the water from the table.
The girl can wipe the table well.
I made the girl wipe the table.
The girl wiped a table.
She/he can grind buckwheat with a millstone.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: I made her/him grind buckwheat with a millstone.
She/he ground buckwheat with a millstone.
She/he can grind sesame well.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: I made her/him grind sesame.
She/he ground sesame.
I'm good at hunting a rabbit.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: The rabbit was hunted by her/him.
Comment: passive sentence (DO)

Translated_Text: I made her/him hunt a rabbit.
I hunted a rabbit.
We will make it rain, by performing a ceremony at the crossroads.
Because it begins raining, take the clothes into the house!
I dried the clothes.
The clothes dried.
She/he got her/his house burned because she/he did not watch the fire properly.
The house is burning.
She/he can grill a saury well.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: I grilled a saury.
Comment:
This is jag-u 'burn'
jage-ru is a lexical anticausative version of jag-u.

Translated_Text: I made her/him grill a saury.
A saury was grilled.
I sank the boat.
The boat sank.
I rolled a ball.
The ball rolled.
The child came home hungry.
I am hungry.
I am sad.
That child can play by herself/himself.
I made the children play.
The children are playing.
She/he died.
I feel cold.
This morning my waist hurt.
I made her/him scream.
She/he screamed.
She/he was laughed at by that girl.
Comment: passive sentence (DO)

Translated_Text: That girl was laughing at her/him.
I made the girl laugh.
That girl laughed.
That boy can live even in the small room.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: I made the boy live there.
The boy lives there.
I made a child leave.
I made a child leave.
I left there.
She/he can go there.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: I made her/him go there.
The boy went to the station.
The boy can sing well.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: The boy sang a school song.
I made the boy sing.
The boy sang.
That boy may be able to jump high.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: I made that boy jump.
That boy was jumping in the garden.
Comment: location is optional

Primary_Text: Ano kodomongani, egagu nattande, hjtonde (kosi)kage(rare)rujo:ni natta.
Translated_Text: The child became big and she/he could sit down by herself/himself.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: I made her/him sit down on the chair.
The child sat down on the chair.
She/he can sit for a long time.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: I made her/him sit there.
She/he is sitting there.
The boy can run fast.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: I made the boy run around the corridor.
The boy ran around the corridor.
She/he may be able to climb Mt. Tsukuba.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: I made her/him climb the roof.
She/he climbed Mt. Tsukuba.
She/he coughed.
The girl blinked.
She/he can load hay on the wagon well.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Primary_Text: Ore arenge ningurumasa wara eppe tsumaseda.
Translated_Text: I made her/him load hay on the wagon full.
She/he loaded hay on the wagon full.

Primary_Text: Arenganiwa, hadaragimondagara, nagaja sazumade eppeni degiru.
Translated_Text: Because she/he is a hardworker, she/he can fill the barn with sweet potatoes.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Primary_Text: Ore arenge inomi ozjade ktsieppeni saseda.
Translated_Text: I made her/him fill the cup with tea.
She/he filled the cup with tea.

Primary_Text: Arenganiwa, me: samesasenede, kodomonge mo:hu kagerareru.
Translated_Text: She/he can cover the child with the blanket without letting the child awaken.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: The child was covered with a blanket by her/him.
Comment: passive sentence (IO)

Translated_Text: The blanket is covering the child.
I made her/him cover the child with the blanket.
She/he covered a child with a blanket.
She/he can pour tea well.
Comment: potential sentence (ability)

Translated_Text: I made her/him pour tea into the cup.
She/he poured tea into the cup full.

The cat caught the mouse's scent.

Translated_Text: Mt. Tsukuba can be seen.

That man looked at the boy.
Now the mother can hug the baby.
The baby was hugged by her/his mother.

I made my wife hug the baby.

I cannot eat that.

Comment: passive sentence (DO)

Translated_Text: I made her/him eat bread.
The girl ate bread.
Two skills have been taught.

Primary_Text: Zhèkǒu guō yóu tài hòu, cā qǐlái bú róngyì.
Translated_Text: The pot is too oily that it is not easy to wipe it clean.
Original_Orthography: 这口锅油太厚，擦起来不容易。

Primary_Text: Zhè bǎ tìxūdāo bèi wǒ guā huài le.
Translated_Text: I have broken this shaver.
Original_Orthography: 这把剃须刀被我刮坏了。

Primary_Text: Duì chūxuézhě láishuō，diànzǐyóujiàn fā qǐlái jiùshì máfan.
Translated_Text: To beginners, it is just troublesome to send an email. / It is just difficult for beginners to learn to send emails.
Comment: duì... láishuō functions as a circumposition, meaning to ..., or speaking of ... or regarding ... or so far as ... be concerned, etc. The focus is laid on the NP in between.
Original_Orthography: 对初学者来说，电子邮件发起来就是麻烦。

Translated_Text: *The police have searched for the suspect.

Primary_Text: Tā yǐjīng bǎ nánguā xiāo le pí.
Translated_Text: He has peeled the pumpkin. / He has peeled the skin off the pumpkin.
Comment: In this disposal sentence, the semantic focus is put on what has been done to the pumpkin, or how the pumpkin is disposed of.

Translated_Text: The money was given to him.
Mom threw a ball to me. / Mom threw me a ball.
Comment: Some hold that the ditransitive equivalent in Mandarin is SVO construction in nature because of the possession of qíu by wǒ. When treating the Mandarin sentence as a ditransitive one, some hold it is ambigous because it can also mean Mom threw away a ball of mine. This potential ambiguity can be removed if a PP is used immediately after the verb indicating the direction of throwing (e.g. rēng-gěi, lit. throw-to) or a complement if used to indicate the result of throwing (e.g. rēng-diào, lit. throw_away).

Primary_Text: Tā wā(zǒu)le wǒ jǐ kǎchē tǔdòu.
Translated_Text: He dug several trucks of potatoes of mine and took them away.
Comment: This kind of ditransitive use is not very popular among strict PTH speakers. In some dialectal areas, a beneficial interpretation of the construction is also possible, which renders a possible interpreation of the sentence as "He dug several trucks of potatoes and gave them to me". For this ambiguity, the ditransitive use like that is rather restricted or not preferred.

Primary_Text: Nàgè túfū qiē le tā liǎngkuài zhūròu.
Translated_Text: That butcher cut two pieces of pork for him. / That butcher cut two pieces of pork and gave them to him.
Comment: When such a two-valency verb as 'qie' is used in a ditransitive construction, the direction of transference is a two-fold one, i.e. rightward and leftward transference. In other words, the construction is ambiguous. However, some semantic and contextual clues can determine the meaning. According to a questionaire-based survey, this kind of ditransitive use of two-valency verb is most popular among dialect speakers.
Original_Orthography: 那个屠夫切了他两块猪肉。

Translated_Text: An old man died in the village.
Comment: In this case, -zàile following the verb sǐ seems necessary, or at least preferrable, as it is acceptable to say that Yīgè lǎorén sǐ cūnzǐli le. And in the latter sentence, the use of le is compulsary. An alternative for the primary text is Yīgè lǎorén sǐzài cūnzǐli-le. The flexible position of le seems to show that the V+PP structure is not so tight but the semantic focus seems to be put on sǐ(die) rather than the PP.
Original_Orthography: 一个老人死在了村子里。

Translated_Text: An old man died in the village.
The book is placed on the desk.
Comment: Without using the aspectual marker ZHE, one has to use a post-verbal PP to express almost the same content. Interestingly, if the same PP is put pre-verbally, then using the ZHE marker is necessary, with practically the same meaning. In this example, when zài is absent, another possible interpretation would be The book is to be put on the desk.

Primary_Text: Cūnzi lǐ chūxiàn le yīzhī lǎohǔ.
Translated_Text: In the village appeared a tiger. / There appeared a tiger in the village.
Original_Orthography: 村子里出现了一只老虎。

Primary_Text: Nǐ bǎ háizi jiāo huài le.
Translated_Text: You have taught the kid in such a way that he has turned bad. / Your teaching has made the kid bad.
I saw a cow.
Comment: kànjiàn does not carry a strong denotion of result as its semantic focus is put on see, whose meaning is clear in itself, so it is usually impossible to fit in a BA alternation which denotes and therefore necessitates a strong resultative sense of the verb involved. For that reason, the BA alternation has an alternative name, i.e. disposal construction.

Translated_Text: The pirates sank the boat.
The water jar is filled. / The water jar is full.

Primary_Text: Wǒ bǎ tā kàn le yīxià.
Translated_Text: I gave her a look.
The meat is cut.

Primary_Text: Wǒ chī le tā sāngè píngguǒ.
Translated_Text: I ate three of her apples.
Comment: Some hold that this is SVO in nature because of the possession relationship between the latter two arguments.

Translated_Text: It's more difficult to cover up big cars.

Primary_Text: Nàgè píngguǒ bèi wǒ chī le.
Translated_Text: That apple was eaten by me. / I ate that apple.

Primary_Text: Shītǐ bèi jǐngchá yòng báibù gài qǐlái le.
Translated_Text: The dead body was covered with white cloth by the policeman.
Original_Orthography: 尸体被警察用白布盖起来了。

Translated_Text: A pot of rice is to serve ten prsons. / A pot of rice is for ten people to eat.
Comment: The ‘oblique’ object can also be a location. For example, wo chi shitang (lit. I eat cafeteria.) Only few highly frequently used verbs have such alternations. Another verb with the alternations is kao (examine), whose object could be the subject of the examination, a school or college the entrance exam is taken for, or an academic degree, the credit of the exam. etc.

Translated_Text: The policeman covered the dead body with white cloth.

Primary_Text: Wǒ bǎ nàgè píngguǒ chī le.
Translated_Text: I ate that apple.
Comment: The alternation is functionally a counterpart of 'The bread cuts easily' in English. However, -qilai is an inceptive aspect marker, which can be regarded as an applicative triggering a following AP, which is somewhat like a second predicate.

Primary_Text: Jìnkǒu níuròu zhǔ qǐlái gèng róngyì.
Translated_Text: It is easier to cook imported beef. / Imported beef is easier to cook.
Original_Orthography: 进口牛肉煮起来更容易。

Translated_Text: I wiped the table.

Primary_Text: Tā cóng wǒzhèlǐ názǒu le qián.
Translated_Text: She took away the money from me.

Primary_Text: Fàn bèi wǒ zhǔ hú le.
Translated_Text: The rice was burnt by me. / I cooked but burnt the rice.
This mountain is easy to climb. / It's easy to climb up the mountain.
This kind of handgun is convenient for carrying. / It is convenient to carry this kind of handgun.
Original_Orthography: 这种手枪携带起来方便。

Primary_Text: Wǒ yǐjīng bǎ húzi guā le.
Translated_Text: I have shaved my beard already.
The puppy was carried away by her.
The police are searching for the suspect.
He has carried the little dog here.

Primary_Text: Bǎ shū fàng zài zhuō shàng.
Translated_Text: Put the book on the desk.
Comment: The structure zài ... N-shàng functions as a circumpositionto modify the verb, fàng in this case. Besides shàng, other locative morphemes can also be used, like lǐ (inside) and xià (under).

Translated_Text: Dad pushed the table away.

Primary_Text: Dìdi bǎ tàidíxióng wán huài le.
Translated_Text: My younger brother played with the teddy bear and made it broken.

Primary_Text: Tā yǐjīng bǎ nánguā pí xiāo le.
Translated_Text: He has peeled the pumpkin.
I peeled the apple.
It's easy to make cars.
It is not easy to load this kind of truck.
Original_Orthography: 这种车子装起来很麻烦。

Primary_Text: Chē bèi wǒmen zào chūlái le.
Translated_Text: The car has been made by us.
We killed the enemy.
The car is made.
You frightened that kid.
The apple has been peeled.
I filled the water jar.
The enemy is killed.
It's not easy to hide big-sized kids.
Original_Orthography: 大个子孩子藏起来不容易。

Translated_Text: That kid is frightened.

Primary_Text: Zhèyàng de fángzi jiàn qǐlái bù róngyì.
Translated_Text: It's not easy to build this kind of house.
Original_Orthography: 这样的房子建起来不容易。

Translated_Text: The house has been built by us.
The house has been built.
The camera has been brought by me.
I have brought the camera.
The stick was boken by me.
The stick broke.

Primary_Text: Zhèzhǒng cáiliào mō qǐlái hěn shūfú.
Translated_Text: It is very comfortable to touch this kind of material. / This kind of material feels very good.
Original_Orthography: 这种材料摸起来很舒服。

Primary_Text: Píngmù bèi wǒ mō le yīxià.
Translated_Text: The screen was touched once by me.

Primary_Text: Wǒ bǎ píngmù mō le yīxià.
Translated_Text: I touched the screen once.
His eyes blinked once.
He blinked his eyes.
You have taught the kid in such a way that he has turned bad. / You have led the kid astray by improper teaching.
Comment: Usually neither objects In Mandarin ditransitive sentences involving the use of teach can be fronted as the subject of a relevant passive sentence. That is to say, jiao as used ditransitively does not permit BEI alternation.

Translated_Text: The kid is easy to teach.

Primary_Text: Zhèjiàn shì bèi lǎoshī gàosù le bàba.
Translated_Text: This matter was told to Dad by my teacher. / My teacher told Dad about this matter.
Original_Orthography: 这件事被老师告诉了爸爸。

Primary_Text: Wǒ bǎ zhèjiàn shì gàosù le tā.
Translated_Text: I told him about this matter.
The ticket was torn by him.
This kind of paper is easy to tear.

Primary_Text: Zhè chuán tài dà, chén qǐlái bù róngyì.
Translated_Text: It is difficult to sink the boat because it is too big. / This boat is too big and is difficult to sink.
Original_Orthography: 这船太大，沉起来不容易。

Primary_Text: Hǎidào chén le wǒmen shítiáo chuán.
Translated_Text: The pirates sank ten of our boats.
The boat was sunk by the pirates.
The pirates sank the boat.
The boat sank.
Ten persons share one basin of water for washing themselves.
A basin of water is for ten persons to wash themselves.

Primary_Text: Zhèzhǒng yīfu liàozi xǐ qǐlái róngyì.
Translated_Text: This kind of cloth material washes easily. / It is easy to wash this kind of cloth material.
Original_Orthography: 这种衣服料子洗起来容易。

Translated_Text: The clothes was washed by me.
I wahsed the clothes.

Primary_Text: Bèi tā kàn le yīyǎn, wǒ juéde hěn shūfú.
Translated_Text: I feel very comfortable because she gave me a look.
Original_Orthography: 被她看了一眼，我觉得很舒服。

Primary_Text: *Qí mótuōchē sǐ qǐlái kuài dé hěn.
Translated_Text: Riding motor cycle will kill the cyclist quickly.
Comment: This middle alternation-like use of si usually has a sense of humor. When a verb followed by the applicative qǐlái, it usually denotes a rather long process of the related acting, which contradicts with the quickness of the death caused by riding a motor cycle. This kind of use of the verb si is rather limited, while a more popular way of expression would be sǐ de gèng kuài (lit. die DE more/very quick) which means die more quickly or very quickly, or causing am immediate death. However, since this si is used not as a transitive verb, the how structure is not Middle alternation in nature.

Primary_Text: Tā bèi éguó xióng rèliè yōngbào.
Translated_Text: He was given a warm hug by the Russian bear. / He was hugged warmly by the Russian bear.
Ten persons are to eat the rice from one pot.

Primary_Text: Zhèzhòng shuǐguǒ chī qǐlái hěn róngyì.
Translated_Text: This kind of fruit is easy to eat. / This kind of fruit eats very fast.
Comment: The alternation is functionally a counterpart of The bread cuts easily in English. However, -qilai is an inceptive aspect marker, which can be regarded as an applicative triggering a following AP, which is somewhat like a second predicate.
Original_Orthography: 这种水果吃起来很容易。

Translated_Text: The table was wiped up by me.
This kind of cloth-brush wipes clean.

Primary_Text: Gǒu hěn xiōng,shuān qǐlái hěn kùnnán.
Translated_Text: It is very difficult to tie up the dog because it is very fierce.
The dog is to be tied up to the tree.
The tree is for one to tie up a dog.

Primary_Text: Gǒu bèi wǒ shuān qǐlái le.
Translated_Text: The dog bas been tied up by me.

Primary_Text: Wǒ bǎ gǒu shuān qǐlái le.
Translated_Text: I have tied (up) the dog.

Primary_Text: Zhèzhǒng qiānqíu tài zhòng, rēng qǐlái hěn máfán.
Translated_Text: This kind of lead ball is too heavy, so it is very troublesome to throw it. / This kind of lead ball is so heavy that it is very difficult to throw it.
Original_Orthography: 这种铅球太重，扔起来很麻烦。

Translated_Text: The trash was thrown away by Mom.
Mom threw away the trash.

Primary_Text: Wǒ názǒu le māma yīwànkuài qián.
Translated_Text: I took away ten thousand yuan from Mom.
Original_Orthography: 我拿走了妈妈一万块钱。

Translated_Text: The money was taken away by Mom.
Mom took away the money.
It is easier to steal from average households.
Original_Orthography: 小户人家偷起来容易些。

Primary_Text: Xiǎotōu tōule tājiā liǎngtóu níu, yīpǐ mǎ.
Translated_Text: A thief stole two cows and one horse from his family.
Comment: Some hold that this is a monotransitive construction in nature because of the possessive relationship between the two arguments following the verb tōu.
Original_Orthography: 小偷偷了他家两头牛,一匹马。

Translated_Text: The document was stolen by a thief.
A thief has stolen the document.
Ten persons are to sit on the same stool.
One stool is enough for ten persons to sit on.
Sitting in this chair is comfortable.

Primary_Text: Yǐzi yǐjīng bèi nǐ zuò le.
Translated_Text: You have already sat in the chair.

Primary_Text: Huìhuà zuòpǐn hái bèi tāmen zhǎnshì le yīfān.
Translated_Text: The paintings were shown by them.
Comment: When used in BEI construction, the verb is generally followed by a complement.
Original_Orthography: 绘画作品还被他们展示了一番。

Primary_Text: Tāmen hái bǎ huìhuà zuòpǐn zhǎnshì le yīfān.
Translated_Text: Additionally, they put up a show of the paintings.
Comment: When used in BA construction, the verb is generally followed by a complement.
Original_Orthography: 他们还把绘画作品展示了一番。

Primary_Text: Tāmen bǎ jūnjiàn mìngmíng wéi Wǔhànhào.
Translated_Text: They named the warship Wuhanhao.
Original_Orthography: 他们把军舰命名为武汉号。

Primary_Text: Tā cháo wǒ dà shēng jiàohǎn.
Translated_Text: He shouted at me in loud voice.

Primary_Text: Tāde húzi guā qǐlái hěn máfan.
Translated_Text: It is very difficult to shave his beard. / His beard is very difficult to shave.
Original_Orthography: 他的胡子刮起来很麻烦。

Translated_Text: This shaver shaves smoothly.
Original_Orthography: 这把剃须刀刮起来顺手。

Primary_Text: Húzi yǐjīng bèi wǒ guā le.
Translated_Text: The beard has been shaved by me.

Primary_Text: Wǒ zuótiān fā le yīfēng xìn gěi tā.
Translated_Text: I sent a letter to him yesterday.
Comment: The PP gěi tā (to him) can be moved pre-verbally, but that will cause ambiguity. Another possible interpretation is a beneficial one, when gěi tā is interpretated as for him. Therefore, a preverbal gěi tā may mean directional transfer just as its post-verbal version, and a beneficial act.
Original_Orthography: 我昨天发了一封信给他。

Primary_Text: Xìn zuótiān bèi wǒ fā gěi tā le.
Translated_Text: The letter was sent to him by me yesterday.

Primary_Text: Wǒ zuótiān fā le tā yīfēng xìn.
Translated_Text: I sent her a letter yesterday.

Primary_Text: Wǒ yǐjīng bǎ xìn fā le.
Translated_Text: I have already sent the letter.

Primary_Text: Jǐngchá zài dàlù shàng sōuxún xiányífàn.
Translated_Text: The police are searching for the suspect on the big road.
Comment: Mandarin structure 'zai...shang' (lit. on the top of...) functions as a circumposition.
Original_Orthography: 警察在大路上搜寻嫌疑犯。

Primary_Text: Yīgè háizi, zài mángmángrénhǎi dāngzhōng sōuxún qǐlái shì hěn kùnnán de.
Translated_Text: It is very difficult to search for such a kid from within such a huge crowd.
Comment: The Mandarin construction zai...dangzhong can be treated as a circumposition, and shi...de construction functions as am emphatic structure in which emphasis is laid on the element in between. In this case as the exmaple cited, it is kunnan (lit. difficult).
Original_Orthography: 一个孩子，在茫茫人海当中搜寻起来是很困难的。

Primary_Text: Hànyǔ de ràokǒulìng shuō qǐlái zuì máfan.
Translated_Text: Chinese tongue twisters are most difficult to say.
Original_Orthography: 汉语的绕口令说起来最麻烦。

Primary_Text: Zhègè dà yóutǒng gǔn qǐlái hěn fèilì.
Translated_Text: This big oil tank is very hard to roll.
Comment: All verbs that can enter Middle Construction should be transitive ones, so if roll is specified only as an intransitive verb in this dataset, as its Mandarin counterpart, gǔn cannot enter Middle Construction.
Original_Orthography: 这个大油桶滚起来很费力。

Translated_Text: The ball is rolling.
My younger brother is rolling the ball.
Comment: In Mandarin, zài as used in the zài +V(O) construction functions as a marker indicating present tense.

Primary_Text: Xiàngliàn zuìhòu háishì bèi fángdōng dédào le.
Translated_Text: The necklace finally was landed by the landlord. / The landlord got the necklace finally.
Original_Orthography: 项链最后还是被房东得到了。

Primary_Text: Zhèzhǒng huāpíng hǎokàn, dànshì fàngqǐlái hěn máfan.
Translated_Text: This kind of vase is nicelooking, but it is very difficul to put it (in a safe and steady place).
Original_Orthography: 这种花瓶好看，但是放起来很麻烦。

Translated_Text: The book is put on the desk.
Comment: The aspectual marker ZHE denotes a stative and durative meaning that the book is the sate of having beeen place on the desk. Without the marker, the sentence still makes sense, but with a different meaning, i.e. the desk is for placing books on it.

Primary_Text: Shū bèi fàng zài zhuō shàng.
Translated_Text: The book was put on the desk.
The big case is heavy to push.
The table was pushed aside by Dad.
Original_Orthography: 桌子被爸爸推到了一边。

Primary_Text: Yòng zhèzhǒng guànzi dào shuǐ, dào qǐlái hěn máfan.
Translated_Text: It is a big trouble pouring water from this kind of jar. / It is a big trouble pouring water into this kind of jar.
Original_Orthography: 用这种罐子倒水，倒起来很麻烦。

Primary_Text: Shuǐ bèi wǒ dào jìn wǎn lǐ le.
Translated_Text: The water has been poured into the bowl by me.

Primary_Text: Wǒ bǎ shuǐ dào jìn wǎn lǐ.
Translated_Text: I poured water into the bowl.

Primary_Text: Zhèzhǒng wánjù wán qǐlái hěn fèijìn.
Translated_Text: It is a big trouble playing with this kind of toy.
Original_Orthography: 这种的玩具玩起来很费劲。

Primary_Text: Tàidíxióng bèi dìdi wán huài le.
Translated_Text: The teddy bear was made broken by my younger brother who played with it.

Primary_Text: Zhèzhǒng huángguā xiāo qǐlái hěn bùróngyì.
Translated_Text: It is very hard to peel this kind of cucumber.
Original_Orthography: 这种黄瓜削起来很不容易。

Primary_Text: Zhèbǎ páozi xiāo qǐlái hěn shùnshǒu.
Translated_Text: This peelers peels easily.
Original_Orthography: 这把刨子削起来很顺手。

Primary_Text: Huángguā pí yǐjīng bèi tā xiāo le.
Translated_Text: The cucumber has been peeled by him.

Primary_Text: Zuótiān wǒliǎ guàng gōngyuán de shíhou bèi tā jìumā pèngjiàn le.
Translated_Text: Her aunt met us when we two were having a walk in the park yesterday.
Original_Orthography: 昨天我俩逛公园的时候被她舅妈碰见了。

Translated_Text: It is very uneasy to load this kind of goods.
Original_Orthography: 这种货物装起来很麻烦。

Translated_Text: The hay is to be loaded onto the truck. / The hay is loaded on the truck.
The truck is loaded with hay. / The truck is for loading hay.
Comment: The ambiguity arises mainly due to the absence of aspectual or tense marker. Please refer to other similar items, e.g. HIDE.

Translated_Text: The hay was loaded onto the truck.
The truck was loaded with hay.
Load the hay onto the truck.
An old granny lives in the forest.
In the forest lives an old granny.

Primary_Text: Bèi rén xǐhuān shì yījiàn xìngfú de shìqing.
Translated_Text: For one to be liked by others is something happy. / It is something happy for one to be liked by others.
Original_Orthography: 被人喜欢是一件幸福的事情。

Primary_Text: Nàjiàn shìqing zuìhòu bèi lǎoshī zhīdào le.
Translated_Text: The teacher finally knew it.
Original_Orthography: 那件事情最后被老师知道了。

Translated_Text: The tiger was killed by Wu Song.

Primary_Text: Wǔ Sōng bǎ lǎohǔ shā le.
Translated_Text: Wu Song killed the tiger.

Primary_Text: Zhèyàng de gùnzi dǎqǐlái bú shùnshǒu.
Translated_Text: It is not comfortable when hitting with this kind of stick. / It is not comfortable when one hits with this kind of stick.
Original_Orthography: 这样的棍子打起来不顺手。

Translated_Text: The elder brother was hit by the younger brother.
The elder brother hit the younger brother.
The ball is hidden in the cupboard. / The cupboard is for hiding balls.
The ball is hidden in the cupboard.
The ball has been hidden up by Mom.
Hide the money in a safe place.

Primary_Text: Zhènshàng hái bāngzhùle wǒmen hěnduō dàmǐ.
Translated_Text: The local township government also helped us by giving us much rice.
Comment: Mandarin bāngzhù is generally used as a monotransitive verb taking two arguments. This ditransitive use of the verb is only popular among dialect speakers probably because their identification of the consistency between the meaning of a double-object construction and the implications of 'help' (bāngzhù) which usually means giving things.
Original_Orthography: 镇上还帮助了我们很多大米。

Primary_Text: Wǒ rènwéi bāngzhù biéren hé bèi biéren bāngzhù dōu shì yīzhǒng xìngfú.
Translated_Text: I think both helping others and being helped by others are a kind of happiness.
Comment: Mandarin passive BEI construction generally carries a strong adverse flavor implying that some negative and undesirable effect has been caused to the subject. However, the BEI passive does not necessarily carry such an adverse flavor in present-day Mandarin usage, especially in such formal registers as government documents, news reports and science and technology writings.
Original_Orthography: 我认为帮助别人和被别人帮助都是一种幸福。

Translated_Text: Your words were beard by the teacher. / What you said was heard by the teacher.
This kind of wheat is easy to grind.
The soybean has been ground (ready) by my uncle.
My uncle has ground the soybean.
The pencil was given to Mom by me.
I gave the pencil to Mom.

Primary_Text: Xiǎo nǚháir xiàhu qǐlái róngyì de hěn.
Translated_Text: It is very easy to frighten a little girl.
Original_Orthography: 小女孩儿吓唬起来容易得很。

Primary_Text: Nàgè xiǎohái bèi nǐ xiàhuài le.
Translated_Text: That kid was frightened so much by you.

Primary_Text: Nǐ bǎ nàgè xiǎohái xiàhuài le.
Translated_Text: You have frightened that kid so much. / That kid was frightened so much by you.
The water fills up the pail. / The pail is full of water.
The pail is filled with water. / The pail is full with water.

Primary_Text: Shuǐtǒng bèi wǒmen zhuāngmǎn le shuǐ.
Translated_Text: The pail was filled with water by us.

Primary_Text: Wǒmen bǎ shuǐtǒng zhuāngmǎn le shuǐ.
Translated_Text: We filled the pail with water.
It is energy-saving to cut with this knife.

Primary_Text: Ròu yǐjīng bèi wǒ qiē hǎo le.
Translated_Text: I have cut the meat (and made it ready for cooking).
Comment: When used in BEI alternation, the verb qiē is usually followed by a complement.

Primary_Text: Tājiā dê zǔfén bèi rén wā le.
Translated_Text: His ancestral grave has been dug by someone.
Comment: When used in the BEI alternation, the verb wā is usually followed by a complement or at least an aspectual marker.

Translated_Text: It is very energy-consuming to dig through this kind of soil.
Original_Orthography: 这种泥土挖起来很费力气。

Primary_Text: Shēntǐ de zhègè bùfen pāidǎ qǐlái zuì máfan.
Translated_Text: It is least easy to beat this part of your body. / It is most uneasy to beat this part of human body.
Original_Orthography: 身体的这个部分拍打起来最麻烦。

Primary_Text: Bìngren de bèibù bèi tā zìjǐ pāidǎ huài le.
Translated_Text: The patient's back was hurt because of his own wrong beating of it.
Original_Orthography: 病人的背部被他自己拍打坏了。

Primary_Text: Bìngren bǎ zìjǐ de bèibù pāidǎ huài le.
Translated_Text: The patient beat his back in such a way that something has gone wrong with his back. / The patient hurt his own back by beating it in the wrong way.
Original_Orthography: 病人把自己的背部拍打坏了。

Translated_Text: He was starved by the enemy.
Comment: There must be an X element at the end of the sentence. The X may be an expression of duration/occurrence, resultative, etc.

Translated_Text: Lit. The enemy made him hungry. / The enemy starved him.
Comment: There must be an X element at the end of the sentence. The X may be an expression of duration/occurrence, resultative, etc.

Translated_Text: He remained hungry for three days. / He didn't eat anything for three days.
Comment: Mandarin adjectives can function as stative verbs, treated as a subgroup of verb. When followed by a perfecive marker (or aspectual marker), it is used as an intransitive verb.

Primary_Text: Yīzhī lǎohǔ chūxiàn zài cūnzi lǐ.
Translated_Text: A tiger appeared in the village.
Original_Orthography: 一只老虎出现在村子里。

Primary_Text: Xiàng zhèzhǒng dōngxī yàoqǐlái kě bùróngyì.
Translated_Text: It is very hard to ask for this kind of things.
Original_Orthography: 像这种东西要起来可不容易。

Translated_Text: Grandpa has asked for two rooms from the company.
Comment: This ditransitive use of the verb yao is more frequently used by dialect speakers.

Primary_Text: Fángzi yǐjīng bèi tā māma yào huíláile.
Translated_Text: The house has been asked for and taken back by his Mom.
Comment: When used in BEI alternation, the verb yào is usually followed by a complement.
Original_Orthography: 房子已经被她妈妈要回来了。

Primary_Text: Wǒ qù bǎ tā yào huílái.
Translated_Text: I will ask for it and get it back.
Comment: When used in BA alternation, the verb yào is predominantly followed by a complement.

Primary_Text: Zhèzhǒng shùxué wèntí xiǎngzhe ràng rén tóu téng.
Translated_Text: It is a headache for one to think about this kind of maths problem. / This kind of maths problem is so hard to think about that it causes headache to people.
Comment: To use another applicative -zhe instead of -qilai after the verb xiǎng is probably due to the need to avoid ambiguity. xiǎngqilai is ambiguous.
Original_Orthography: 这种数学问题想着让人头疼。

Primary_Text: Zhège wèntí bèi nǐ xiǎng fùzá le.
Translated_Text: The problem has been thought about in a complcated way. / You have thought about the problem in such a way that it is made two complicated.
Comment: When used in BEI alternation, the verb xiǎng is usually followed by a compliment.
Original_Orthography: 这个问题被你想复杂了。

Primary_Text: Nǐ bǎ zhège wèntí xiǎng fùzá le.
Translated_Text: You have taken the problem in a complicated way. / You thought about the problem in such a way that it is made too complicated.
Comment: When used in BA alternation, the verb xiǎng is usually is followed by a complement.
Original_Orthography: 你把这个问题想复杂了。

Primary_Text: Zhèzhǒng xiāngshuǐ wénqǐlái ràng wǒ tóuyūn.
Translated_Text: This type of perfume smells in such a way that it makes me feel dizzy.
Original_Orthography: 这种香水闻起来让我头晕。

Primary_Text: Wǒ gāng jìn fángjiān jìu bèi xiǎogǒu shàngshàngxiàxià wénle yībiàn.
Translated_Text: Right after I entered the room the little dog thoroughly smelled me once.
Comment: When used in BEI alternation, the verb wén is usually followed by an adverbial-like complement.
Original_Orthography: 我刚进房间就被小狗上上下下闻了一遍。

Primary_Text: Xiǎogǒu pǎojìnlái bǎ zhěnggè fángjiān wénle yībiàn.
Translated_Text: The little dog ran in and smelled the whole room once.
Comment: When used in BA alternation, wén is predominantly followed by a necessary adverbial-like complement.
Original_Orthography: 小狗跑进来把整个房间闻了一遍。

Primary_Text: Xìnghǎo nǐ méiyǒu bèi biéren kànjiàn.
Translated_Text: Luckily, you were not seen by other people.
Original_Orthography: 幸好你没有被别人看见。

Translated_Text: He is putting on his clothes. / He is dressing himself.
Comment: In English, the verb dress lexicalizes the meaning components of the object and the verb itself, i.e. clothes. However, in Chinese, the meaning components are expressed separately by two words, the verb chuān (which means put on) and yīfu (which means clothes).

Translated_Text: He tore the ticket.

Primary_Text: Xiányífàn yǐjīng bèi sōuxún le duōcì.
Translated_Text: The suspect has been searched for for many times.
Original_Orthography: 嫌疑犯已经被搜寻了多次。

Primary_Text: Huángdòu zǎo yǐjīng bèi jiùjiu mòhǎo le.
Translated_Text: The soybean has already been ground by my uncle.
Original_Orthography: 黄豆早已经被舅舅磨好了。

Translated_Text: Mom poured water into the pail.

Primary_Text: Píngguǒ yǐjīng bèi tā xiāo le (pí).
Translated_Text: The apple has been peeled by him.

Primary_Text: Lǎo shī zài tuī yīgè xiāngzǐ.
Translated_Text: The teacher is pushing a box.

Primary_Text: Zhuōzi yǐjīng bèi tā gài qǐlái le.
Translated_Text: The table has been covered by him.
Original_Orthography: 桌子已经被他盖起来了。

Translated_Text: Please cover the table.
He is covering the table.

Primary_Text: Yuánzǐdàn bèi tāmen zào chūlái le.
Translated_Text: An A-bomb has been made by them.
Original_Orthography: 原子弹被他们造出来了。

Translated_Text: I heard the gunshot.

Primary_Text: Tā zǒngshì bèi yīdàqún rén gēnzhe.
Translated_Text: He is always followed by a large crowd of people.
Original_Orthography: 他总是被一大群人跟着。

Primary_Text: Nà jǐgè zì yǐjīng bèi tā cādiào le.
Translated_Text: Those characters have already been wiped off by him.
Original_Orthography: 那几个字已经被他擦掉了。

Translated_Text: I went (to Beijing).

Primary_Text: Ròu yǐjīng bèi Lǎo Lǐ qiē le.
Translated_Text: The meat has been cut by Old Li.
Comment: When used in passive voice, the Mandarin counterpart 'qie' is normally followed by a complement indicating the result of the cutting.

Translated_Text: I cut meat with a knife.
The bridge has been built already.
The screen has been touched (by somebody).

Primary_Text: Yīngér de jiǎo bèi wǒ pāidǎ le jǐxià.
Translated_Text: The baby's foot was beaten several times by me.
Original_Orthography: 婴儿的脚被我拍打了几下。

Translated_Text: He is a hunter.
I saw that tiger.

Primary_Text: Tāmen bǎ nàzuò lǎofén wā le.
Translated_Text: They have dug up that old tomb.
Comment: When used in BA alternation, the verb wā is generally followed by a complement. In addition, wā as used in VO construction can also mean 'cause that product indicated by O to come out as a result of the action of digging'.

Translated_Text: I have cut the meat.
I cut the meat.

Primary_Text: Wǒ bǎ fàn zhǔ hǎo le.
Translated_Text: I have cooked the rice.
The house was burnt by them.
Comment: When used in BA and BEI constructions, shāo functions as a monotransitive verb, which runs against the the usage of burn specified in this dataset as an intransitive verb.

Primary_Text: Wǒ yòng shuǐ zhuāngmǎn le shuǐtǒng.
Translated_Text: I filled the pail with water.
Dad is shaving his beard.
The warship is named Wuhanhao.
The little girl is screaming again.

Primary_Text: Wǒ zuótiān gěi tā fā le yīfēng diànzǐyóujiàn.
Translated_Text: I sent an email to him yesterday.
Original_Orthography: 我昨天给他发了一封电子邮件。

Primary_Text: Huàjiā (xiàng wǒmen) zhǎnshì tā de zuòpǐn.
Translated_Text: The painter is showing his paintings (to us).
Original_Orthography: 画家（向我们）展示他的作品。

Translated_Text: The classmates sang loudly.

Primary_Text: Tā cāqù le zhuōzǐshàng de zì.
Translated_Text: She wiped the words off the table.
Comment: The Mandarin counterpart of 'wipe' is normally followed by a complement indicating the result of the action of wiping.

Translated_Text: Xiao Ma is running.

Primary_Text: Liú lǎoshī gēn Lǐ lǎoshī zài tánhuà.
Translated_Text: Mr Liu and Mr Li are talking.
Original_Orthography: 刘老师跟李老师在谈话。

Primary_Text: Gēge duì māma shuō ：“wǒ yě xiǎng qù”.
Translated_Text: My elder brother said to Mom, "I want to go, too".
Original_Orthography: 哥哥对妈妈说：“我也想去”。

Primary_Text: Lǎo Liú (cóng lǎobǎn nǎér) dédào le yīdài mǐ .
Translated_Text: Old Liu got a bag of rice (from his boss).
Original_Orthography: 老刘（从老板哪儿）得到了一袋米。

Translated_Text: It is raining.

Primary_Text: Tā tōu le Lǎo Lǐ de sāntóu niú.
Translated_Text: He stole three cows from Lao Li. / He stole Lao Li's three cows.
The ball is rolling on the ground.
He sat down (at my side).
Grandma sat on the sofa.

Primary_Text: Tā bǎ nà běn shū fàng zài shūjià shàng le.
Translated_Text: He put that book on the bookshelf.
Original_Orthography: 他把那本书放在书架上了。

Primary_Text: Wǒmen bǎ mǎ shuān zài shuānzhuāng shàng.
Translated_Text: We tied the horses to the hitching posts.

Primary_Text: Dìdi zài cāochǎng shàng wán (pí qiú).
Translated_Text: My younger brother is playing (ball) on the playground.

Primary_Text: Qǐng gěi wǒ xiāo liǎnggè píngguǒ.
Translated_Text: Please peel two apples for me.

Primary_Text: Zuótiān wǒ zài jīchǎng pèngjiàn le Xiǎo Lì.
Translated_Text: I met Xiao Li yesterday at the airport.
Original_Orthography: 昨天我在机场碰见了小丽。

Primary_Text: Gōngrén men wǎng kǎchē shàng zhuāng gàncǎo.
Translated_Text: The workers loaded hay onto the truck.
Comment: The Locative shàng here literally means on or on the top of and it is usually used like a suffix, following a noun indicating a place.
Original_Orthography: 工人们往卡车上装干草。

Translated_Text: Grandpa lives in Shanghai.
Comment: Often the PP can occur pre-verbally and post-verbally, with subtle semantic differences. Therefore, it is possible to say Yéye zài Shànghǎi jūzhù.

Translated_Text: I like Shanghai.

Primary_Text: Wǒ xiàgè yuè líkāi Běijīng (qù Shēnzhèn).
Translated_Text: I will leave Beijing (for Shenzhen) next month.
Original_Orthography: 我下个月离开北京（去深圳）。

Translated_Text: What are you hiding?
He jumps on the playground. / He is jumping on the playground.
You should help him.
Uncle ground the soybeans with a stone mill.
The little boy followed his father.
I feel cold.
The leaves fell.
Grandma is digging for potatoes.

Primary_Text: Nǐ píngshí zìjǐ zhǔ fàn ma?
Translated_Text: Do you ordinarily cook meals yourself?
Policemen may carry guns.
The workers are building a bridge.
The kid is laughing.
Comment: Literally, Mandarin does not have a simple word for LAUGH. The meaning of Xiao in Mandarin is highly generalized, including the meanings of English laugh, smile, giggle, chuckle, grin, etc. Mandarin precise counterpart of LAUGH is a compound da-xiao (lit. big-smile). The property of compound restricted its alternations.

Translated_Text: I know your name.

Primary_Text: Wǔ Sōng shā le yīzhī lǎohǔ.
Translated_Text: Wu Song killed a tiger.
He hit me with a stick.

Primary_Text: Wǒ gěi le tā yīxiē qián.
Translated_Text: I gave her some money.
He often frightens me.
I feel painful.
My younger sister is crying.

Primary_Text: Yéye gěi Xiǎomíng dàilái le yīzhī xiǎo báitù.
Translated_Text: Grandpa brought a little white rabbit to Little Ming.
Original_Orthography: 爷爷给小明带来了一只小白兔。

Translated_Text: The classmates are climbing the mountain.
The house is still burning.
Grandpa is coughing.
Dad broke the stick.
You can touch the screen.
They can make cars.
The water is boiling.
Little Li blinked at me.
My younger brother is beating the door of my room.
I am hungry.
Old Wang is very sad.
The ground (has) dried.
Comment: The counterpart of the ground is dry is 地是干的. However, this form is not frequent in Mandarin.

Translated_Text: Little Wang is ill today.

We have built the house.
Comment: In Mandarin, this alternation is acceptable to many native speakers, but it would be more acceptable to say burongyi jian (not easy to build).

I broke the stick.

Comment: In Mandarin, "zao" in relevant alternations often must go together with chulai (出来come out) indicating result.

Translated_Text: The son hugs his Mom.
The enemy starved him for three days.
Comment: There must be X at the end of the sentence. X may be an expression of duration/occurrence, resultative, etc.

Comment: Although the transitive usage of wè̩ also includes dead animates, the inchoative-causative alternation excludes a dead animate. Hence, while it is possible to say: ó we̩ òkú náà 'He bathed / washed the corpse', It is not correct to say: *òkú náà wè̩ 'The corpse bathed / washed'.

Comment: the vta boozih is arguably vai boozi + the causative 'cause to get on.' MAC states: In my dialect booz'haa almost always, if not ALWAYS connotes giving somebody a ride, a lift. It evokes the image of someone walking along a road and being given a lift or standing beside a road flagging down a car and being given a lift. So the example sentence here would sound rather comical to my community of speakers.

Mosquitoes eat human beings.
The boys followed the girls.
I helped the boys.
The man shaved (his beard).
The girl (prox.) was dressed by her mother (obv.).
His mother (obv.) washed the boy (prox.).
The men searched for the women.
The girl knew the boy.
The bear frightened the man.
The man feared the bear.
The bear smelled the boy.
The man saw the bear.
The boy saw the girl.
The woman hugged her little boy.
The boy ate the fruit.
This is a boat.
We talked about Arzuman-beg.

Primary_Text: Mi kʰičʰ vat χosecʰinkʰ yes yev dukʰ ajsor.
Translated_Text: We had a somewhat unhappy conversation today.
At noon they met at the agreed restaurant.

Primary_Text: Jeɾažštutʰun kar gujnzgujn lujser ein tʰartʰvum.
Translated_Text: There was music, and a flickering of variegated lanterns.

Primary_Text: Miajn petkʰ e hetevel voɾpeszi keɾn amboʁǯovin utvi.
Translated_Text: It is only necessary that the food be eaten completely.
Original_Orthography: Միայն պետք է հետևել, որպեսզի կերն ամբողջովին ուտվի:

Translated_Text: The man poured water into the glass.
Original_Orthography: Մարդը լցրեց բաժակը / բաժակ-ի մեջ ջուր:

Primary_Text: Uf enkʰan em utum, tɾakʰvum nstum em lsi.
Translated_Text: Oh, I eat so much, you'd hear how I crack apart.
Original_Orthography: Ուֆ էնքան եմ ուտում, տրաքվում նստում եմ լսի:

Primary_Text: U kʰaʁcʰə, amenazoɾ kʰaʁcʰə lapʰum eɾ meɾ neɾsə u dandaʁ mahacʰnum mez.
Translated_Text: And hunger was devouring our insides and slowly killing us.
Original_Orthography: Ու քաղցը, ամենազոր քաղցը լափում էր մեր ներսը ու դանդաղ մահացնում մեզ:

Translated_Text: The mother also cried.

Primary_Text: De jek u lva dɾa šoɾeɾə.
Translated_Text: Now come and wash this dress.
Original_Orthography: Դե եկ ու լվա դրա շորերը:

Translated_Text: They dressed up, shaved themselves and went to the wedding.

Primary_Text: ʒez msicʰ en steʁcel, dukʰ ekʰ ʒez iɾaɾicʰ steʁcel.
Translated_Text: You were made out of meat, you made yourselves from each other.
Original_Orthography: Ձեզ մսից են ստեղծել, դուք եք ձեզ իրարից ստեղծել:

Translated_Text: I blinked.

Primary_Text: Nstecʰa u varpet asi hognel es, inʒ tur bahə, kʰičʰ el jes pʰoɾem.
Translated_Text: I joined him and said: Master, you are tired, give me the spade, I will dig for a short while.
Original_Orthography: Մոտեցա ու` «Վարպե՛տ, — ասի, — հոգնել ես, ինձ տուր բահը, քիչ էլ ես փորեմ»:

Translated_Text: The master was digging a hole in the garden ...
And it was said: do not kill.
Comment: ‘say’: passive

Primary_Text: …jev jes kʰičʰ eɾ mnum bacʰakančʰei nɾan...
Translated_Text: ... and I hardly kept myself from shouting at him...
Original_Orthography: …եւ ես քիչ էր մնում բացականչեի նրան…

Primary_Text: Khavatas, Gɾigoɾi Pantelevičʰ, hencʰ voɾ na inʒ ajd asacʰ, vɾas paʁ kʰɾtinkʰ jekav.
Translated_Text: Would you believe this, G.P., the moment he told me that I was all covered with cold sweat.
Comment: speech: dative Addressee
Original_Orthography: Կհավատա՞ս, Գրիգորի Պանտելևիչ, հենց որ նա ինձ այդ ասաց, վրաս պաղ քրտինք եկավ:

Translated_Text: Tie the goat to a peg so it can not run away.
Comment: ‘attach’: ablative ‘locus of contact’

Primary_Text: Jes gndakə netecʰ patin, ajn het tʰrav jev ǯaɾdecʰ patuhanə.
Translated_Text: I throw a ball at the wall, it bounced and broke a window.
Comment: ‘throw’: caused contact
Original_Orthography: Ես գնդակը նետեց պատին, այն հետ թռավ և ջարդեց պատուհանը:

Translated_Text: The man poured water into the glass.
Original_Orthography: Մարդը լցրեց բաժակը / բաժակ-ի մեջ ջուր:

Translated_Text: Mom filled a bucket of water.

Primary_Text: Aɾagašaɾž «makʰɾičʰneɾə» haziv en hascʰnum hoʁmapaku vɾajicʰ makʰɾel tʰacʰ ʒjunə.
Translated_Text: The quick wipers hardly were in time to take the snow away from the windshield.
Comment: ‘wipe’: ablative Source/Possessor
Original_Orthography: Արագաշարժ «մաքրիչները» հազիվ են հասցնում հողմապակու վրայից մաքրել թաց ձյունը:

Primary_Text: Vaɾdann angoɾ nstecʰ calovi atʰori vɾa jev ʒerkʰov makʰɾecʰ čavati kʰɾtinkʰə.
Translated_Text: Vartan limply sank to a folding chair and wiped sweat off his front with his hand.
Comment: ‘wipe’: internal genitive Source/Possessor
Original_Orthography: Վարդանն անզոր նստեց ծալովի աթոռի վրա և ձեռքով մաքրեց ճակատի քրտինքը:

Translated_Text: I plucked an apple from a branch.
Comment: ‘pluck’: internal genitive

Primary_Text: Na inʒnicʰ ʒin mi oɾov vercʰɾecʰ.
Translated_Text: He borrowed my horse for one day.
Comment: caused motion (→ transfer): extended by Source
Original_Orthography: Նա ինձնից ձին մի օրով վերցրեց:

Primary_Text: Ajdpisov khascʰnenkʰ aveli šat ban stanal kjankʰicʰ.
Translated_Text: In that way we’ll manage to get more from life.
Comment: caused motion (→ transfer): extended by Source
Original_Orthography: Այդպիսով կհասցնենք ավելի շատ բան ստանալ կյանքից:

Primary_Text: Bajcʰ im kinə ajs caʁikə tvecʰ maɾdun.
Translated_Text: But my woman gave this flower to (another) man.
Comment: ‘give’: obligatory Beneficiary slot (Recipient/Goal)
Original_Orthography: Բայց իմ կինը ծաղիկը տվեց մարդուն:

Translated_Text: Send us the letters from there, back home.
Comment: ‘send’: extension by Beneficiary slot (Recipient/Goal)

Primary_Text: Na inʒ netecʰ banalineɾə jev vazecʰgnacʰ.
Translated_Text: He threw me the keys and ran away.
Comment: ‘throw’: optional Beneficiary slot (Recipient/Goal)
Original_Orthography: Նա ինձ նետեց բանալիները և վազեց-գնաց:

Primary_Text: Bakum ʒiapanə baɾʒum eɾ iɾeɾs, nanin pajusaki meǯ daɾsum eɾ gatʰa ev čanapaɾhi pašaɾə.
Translated_Text: In the courtyard, the coach was loading my luggage, and Mom was putting gata and food for the travel into a bag.
Comment: caused motion: extended by Goal
Original_Orthography: Բակում ձիապանը բարձում էր իրերս, նանին պայուսակի մեջ դարսում էր գաթա և ճանապարհի պաշարը:

Primary_Text: Hoʁatʰmbi takicʰ ǯɾeɾə gloɾvum ein χrovahujz ev aʁmkum vazum araǯ.
Translated_Text: From under the embankment the water was quickly running (=rolling), roaring, running forth.
Comment: caused motion: mediopassive
Original_Orthography: Հողաթմբի տակից ջրերը գլորվում էին խռովահույզ և աղմկում, վազում առաջ:

Primary_Text: Getakn anpʰutʰoɾen gloɾum eɾ iɾ ǯɾeɾə.
Translated_Text: The small river was carelessly rolling its water.
Comment: caused motion: primary
Original_Orthography: Գետակն անփութորեն գլորում Էր իր ջրերը:

Primary_Text: šat kaɾevoɾ e voɾ mardik sovoɾen lav filmeɾ najel.
Translated_Text: It is very important that people learn to watch good movies.
Comment: ‘look’: transitive version; the verb may not be the same as the dative verb 'look at', in terms of both coding properties and probably also semantics, and could have been isolated into a separate lexical entry; though it is not fully clear how to distinguish between the dative and the transitive frames in contexts where there is not Target present.
Original_Orthography: Շատ կարեւոր է, որ մարդիկ սովորեն լավ ֆիլմեր նայել:

Primary_Text: Jes maɾdkajin vogu hot em arnum.
Translated_Text: I can smell the smell of a human being.
Original_Orthography: Ես մարդկային ոգու հոտ եմ առնում:

Primary_Text: Angjal oɾə mi kin jekav u χndɾecʰ inʒ het tesnvel.
Translated_Text: The other day a woman came and asked me to meet (to see each other).
Comment: ‘see’: reciprocal mediopassive
Original_Orthography: Անցյալ օրը մի կին եկավ ու խնդրեց ինձ հետ տեսնվել...

Translated_Text: I see the land.
Comment: ‘see’: transitive

Translated_Text: (You) burnt me to ashes with your kisses, with your eyes.
Comment: instrumental extension: non-default instrument

Primary_Text: Mi angam tesa, voɾ mekə pʰajtov cecum e očʰχaɾin.
Translated_Text: One day she saw someone beating a ram with a stick.
Comment: focus on the instrument
Original_Orthography: Մի անգամ տեսա, որ մեկը փայտով ծեծում է ոչխարին:

Primary_Text: Na sksecʰ pʰoɾel hin bahov, voɾə mi ɾopeicʰ ǯaɾdvecʰ.
Translated_Text: He started digging with an old spade that broke in a minute.
Comment: explicit instrument
Original_Orthography: Նա սկսեց փորել հին բահով, որը մի րոպեից ջարդվեց:

Primary_Text: Du inkʰd kʰo geɾezmanə kpʰoɾes, isk heto jes kʰez ktʰaʁem.
Translated_Text: You will dig your own grave, and then I’ll burry you.
Comment: implicit instrument
Original_Orthography: Դու ինքդ քո գերեզմանը կփորես, իսկ հետո ես քեզ կթաղեմ:

Translated_Text: And he sang about love, and he sang about life.

Primary_Text: Jes tʰujn em uzum, asacʰ na.
Translated_Text: I want (to take) poison, he said.
Comment: ‘want’: direct object, but no mediopassive
Original_Orthography: – Ես թույն եմ ուզում, – ասաց նա:

Primary_Text: Bajcʰ kʰani voɾ jes hivand čʰem jev uzum em gnal, inʒ vočʰ mi bžišk čʰi ogni.
Translated_Text: But as I am not ill and want to leave, there is no doctor who can help me.
Comment: ‘help’: indirect affectedness
Original_Orthography: Բայց քանի որ ես հիվանդ չեմ և ուզում եմ գնալ, ինձ ոչ մի բժիշկ չի օգնի:

Translated_Text: I have never met such an idiot.

Primary_Text: Sɾi sarə šeʁbə dipav nɾa vzin.
Translated_Text: The cold blade of the sword touched his neck.
Comment: ‘touch’: a contact verb
Original_Orthography: Սրի սառը շեղբը դիպավ նրա վզին:

Translated_Text: Do not be afraid of the enemies, be afraid of your friends.
Comment: ‘fear’: extended by Stimulus/Cause

Primary_Text: ʒjunn ajnkʰan čeɾmak e, voɾ ačʰkʰeɾs cʰavum en aɾevicʰ.
Translated_Text: My eyes ache because of the sun, so white is the snow.
Comment: internal state: extended by Cause
Original_Orthography: Ձյունն այնքան ճերմակ է, որ աչքերս ցավում են արևից:

Translated_Text: Don’t laugh at my parents!
Comment: sound production: postpositional Target

Translated_Text: The parents had a fight with (yelled at) the teacher.
Comment: sound production: postpositional Target

Primary_Text: Cicaʁecʰnelə cicaʁecʰnum em, bajcʰ vočʰ vokʰ čʰi cicaʁum.
Translated_Text: I do (try to) make them laugh, only no one is laughing.
Original_Orthography: Ծիծաղեցնելը ծիծաղեցնում եմ, բայց ոչ ոք չի ծիծաղում:

Translated_Text: The princes started to laugh.

Primary_Text: Simonyanə ʒerkʰicʰ cʰac gcʰecʰ bažak-ə pʰlvecʰ ir atʰorin u heckltacʰ.
Translated_Text: Simonyan dropped the glass down off his hand, collapsed in his chair and sobbed.
Comment: ‘drop’: lexical causative for ‘fall’
Original_Orthography: Սիմոնյանը ձեռքից ցած գցեց բաժակը փլվեց իր աթոռին ու հեծկլտաց:

Translated_Text: The boy left.
Comment: ‘go’: unextended (‘leave’)

Primary_Text: Voɾpes patiž usucʰičʰə jeɾeχa-neɾin jeɾku kilometɾ vaz-ecʰɾecʰ.
Translated_Text: As a punishment, the teacher made the children do a two-kilometer run.
Original_Orthography: Որպես պատիժ ուսուցիչը երեխաներին երկու կիլոմետր վազեցրեց:

Primary_Text: Mi angam užeʁ anʒɾevum eɾ, arancʰ hovanocʰə pʰakelu baɾʒɾacʰa jeɾtʰuʁajin takʰsi.
Translated_Text: One day it rained strongly, and (I) got into a minibus without folding my umbrella.
Original_Orthography: Մի անգամ ուժեղ անձրեւում էր, առանց հովանոցը փակելու բարձրացա երթուղային տաքսի:

Primary_Text: Suɾ danakov amen inčʰ aveli aɾag kktɾes.
Translated_Text: You will cut it all faster with a sharp knife.
Comment: focussed instrument
Original_Orthography: Սուր դանակով ամեն ինչ ավելի արագ կկտրես:

Translated_Text: Cut the bread!
Comment: implicit instrument

Translated_Text: Tom sat on the fence.
Comment: posture verb: spatial extension by Place

Primary_Text: Gomšasajleɾə ginu takarneɾ ein beɾum kʰaʁakʰicʰ.
Translated_Text: Carts driven by bulls brought wine barrels from the town.
Comment: motion: spatial extension by Source
Original_Orthography: Գոմշասայլերը գինու տակառներ էին բերում քաղաքից:

Primary_Text: Isk χanə čʰi el štapum mtnel palat, baɾʒɾanum e aštaɾakneɾicʰ meki sanduʁkʰneɾov veɾ u hasnelov veɾǯinneɾin najum neɾkʰev.
Translated_Text: But the khan was not even in a hurry to enter the rooms, he goes up one of the stairs of the tower and, after achieving the last steps, looks down.
Comment: motion: spatial extension
Original_Orthography: Իսկ խանը չի էլ շտապում մտնել պալատ, բարձրանում է աշտարակներից մեկի սանդուղքներով վեր ու հասնելով վերջիններին՝ նայում ներքև:

Primary_Text: Jes ʒez tvecʰi meɾ astco astvacašunčʰə.
Translated_Text: I gave you our Lord’s Holy Script.
Comment: ‘give’: obligatory Beneficiary (Recipient) with ditransitive verbs
Original_Orthography: Ես ձեզ տվեցի մեր Աստծո Աստվածաշունչը:

Translated_Text: I plucked an apple from a tree.
Comment: ‘pluck’: internal genitive Source/Possessor

Translated_Text: I plucked an apple from a tree.
Comment: ‘pluck’: ablative Source/Possessor

Translated_Text: The girl stole (her) teacher’s book.
Comment: ‘steal’: internal genitive Source/Possessor

Translated_Text: He spat, turned around and left.
Comment: implicit object omission

Translated_Text: They met (each other).

Primary_Text: čʰem kaɾoʁ amusnanal nɾa het, asacʰi jes, tanə kin em tʰoʁel, na jerbekʰ apaharzan či ta.
Translated_Text: I can not marry her, I said, I have a wife at home, and she’ll never give me a divorce.
Comment: primary valency (gen+with)
Original_Orthography: — Չեմ կարող ամուսնանալ նրա հետ, — ասացի ես, — տանը կին եմ թողել, նա երբեք ապահարզան չի տա:

Primary_Text: Jetʰe menak apɾveɾ astvac jevajin čʰeɾ steʁci...
Translated_Text: If [one could] live alone, God wouldn’t have created Eve...
Comment: mediopassive from an intransitive verb
Original_Orthography: Եթե մենակ ապրվեր, աստված Եվային չէր ստեղծի...

Primary_Text: Haǯoɾd oɾə jes paɾsatikov mi agrav spanecʰi u gcʰecʰi Boʁaɾi araǯ.
Translated_Text: The next day I killed a crow with a catapult and threw it in front of Boghar.
Comment: ‘kill’: direct causation conveyed by a primary transitive
Original_Orthography: Հաջորդ օրը ես պարսատիկով մի ագռավ սպանեցի ու գցեցի Բողարի առաջ:

Primary_Text: Urišneɾin mahacʰnelə pakas hancʰankʰ e kʰan čʰmernelə.
Translated_Text: … to cause others to die is a less crime than not to die.
Comment: ‘die’: distant causation conveyed by morphological causativization
Original_Orthography: …ուրիշներին մահացնելը պակաս հանցանք է, քան չմեռնելը:

Primary_Text: Tanə šušanə geʁamikin macun eɾ utecʰnum.
Translated_Text: At home Shushanik was feeding little Gegham with yoghourt.
Comment: morphological causative of a transitive verb
Original_Orthography: Տանը Շուշանը Գեղամիկին մածուն էր ուտեցնում:

Primary_Text: Arnetneɾə lkʰum en χoɾtakvoʁ navə, burn hɾčvankʰov kančʰecʰ Aʁasin.
Translated_Text: The rats are deserting a sinking ship, exclaimed Aghasy in a passionate exultation.
Comment: ‘sink’: decausative mediopassive
Original_Orthography: Առնետները լքում են խորտակվող նավը, — բուռն հրճվանքով կանչեց Աղասին:

Primary_Text: Um e aχoɾželi χoɾtakel haɾazat aʁǯkan?
Translated_Text: Who would feel happy about drowning his own daughter?
Comment: ‘sink’: a primary transitive verb for 'sink' (intr)
Original_Orthography: Ու՞մ է ախորժելի խորտակել հարազատ աղջկան:

Primary_Text: Ajd oɾə Nelson Stepʰanjanə iɾ ʁekavaɾac χmbov χoɾtakecʰ tʰšnamu jeɾku pahakanav.
Translated_Text: This day Nelson Stepanian and the crew under his command sank two enemy patrol ships.
Comment: ‘sink’: a primary transitive verb for 'sink' (intr)
Original_Orthography: Այդ օրը Նելսոն Ստեփանյանը իր ղեկավարած խմբով խորտակեց թշնամու երկու պահականավ:

Translated_Text: ... that pipeline was buil somewhere in the end of 1990-s.
Comment: mediopassive: ‘passive’

Primary_Text: Uzena mi oɾum hazaɾ vočʰχaɾ moɾtʰel kta.
Translated_Text: [If] he’d wanted, he’d have a thousand sheep killed every day.
Comment: ‘give’: periphrastic causative
Original_Orthography: Ուզենա մի օրում հազար ոչխար մորթել կտա:

Primary_Text: Du siɾel es mekin, na uɾišin.
Translated_Text: You loved a girl, she loved someone else...
Comment: human DO: dative marking
Original_Orthography: Դու սիրել ես մեկին, նա` ուրիշին:

Primary_Text: Rubin siɾum eɾ miajn žoʁovɾdakan jeɾgeɾ.
Translated_Text: Rubi was only fond of folk songs.
Comment: inanimate DO: nominative marking
Original_Orthography: Ռուբին սիրում էր միայն ժողովրդական երգեր…
Translation_Other: Руби нравились только народные песни.

Primary_Text: Hetpateɾazmjan tasnamjakneɾi əntʰacʰkʰum ajd kapeɾə pʰastoɾen sarecʰvac ein.
Translated_Text: In the post-war decades these connections have almost stopped (lit. were frozen).
Comment: causative and mediopassive combined in one wordform
Original_Orthography: Հետ-պատերազմյան տասնամյակների ընթացքում այդ կապերը փաստորեն սառեցված էին:
Translation_Other: За послевоенные десятилетия эти связи фактически были заморожены.

Primary_Text: čʰe oɾ lav e čanačʰum moɾə, na amen inčʰ nkatum e, džvaɾ e nɾanicʰ oɾeve ban tʰakʰcʰnel.
Translated_Text: Doesn't the mother knowswell, she notices everything, it's difficult to keep something secret from her.
Original_Orthography: Չէ որ լավ է ճանաչում մորը, նա ամեն ինչ նկատում է, դժվար է նրանից որևէ բան թաքցնել:
Translation_Other: Ведь хорошо знает мать, она все замечает, трудно от нее что-то скрыть.

Primary_Text: Lriɾ, anzgam aʁǯik, t‘e čʰe kʰez ksovoɾecʰnem, tʰe um het goɾc unes.
Translated_Text: Silence, you brazen girl, lest I teach you a lesson who you're dealing with.
Original_Orthography: Լռի՛ր, անզգա՜մ աղջիկ, թե չէ քեզ կսովորեցնեմ, թե ում հետ գործ ունես:
Translation_Other: Молчи, бесстыжая девушка, а то я тебя научу, с кем ты имеешь дело.

Primary_Text: Isk loru maɾzi lusaʁbjuɾ gjuʁi šɾǯaka dašteɾum ajɾvel e 3 hektaɾ χot.
Translated_Text: And on the fields of the Lusaghbiur village of the Lori district, those that were the closest, three hectars of grass burnt away.
Comment: mediopassive: ‘decausative’
Original_Orthography: Իսկ Լոռու մարզի Լուսաղբյուր գյուղի շրջակա դաշտերում այրվել է 3 հեկտար խոտ:
Translation_Other: А на ближайших полях села Лусагбюр Лорийского региона сгорело 3 гектара травы.

Primary_Text: Cɾagɾi hamaʒajn gazamuʁ kkarucʰvi tʰe hajkakan, tʰe iɾanakan taɾackʰneɾum.
Translated_Text: According to the project the pipe will be built on both Armenian and Iranian territories.
Original_Orthography: Ծրագրի համաձայն՝ գազամուղ կկառուցվի թե՛ հայկական, թե՛ իրանական տարածքներում:
Translation_Other: Согласно проекту газопровод будет построен как на армянской, так и на иранской территориях.

Primary_Text: Jev aha ajdkʰan taɾbeɾ ajd bnavoɾutʰjunneɾə kapvel ein iɾaɾ.
Translated_Text: And two characters, so different from each other, were bound together.
Original_Orthography: Եվ ահա այդքան տարբեր այդ բնավորությունները կապվել էին իրար:
Translation_Other: И вот такие разные характеры связались друг с другом.

Primary_Text: Aɾamjanə kuzenaɾ inkʰn el gnal najel, bajcʰ culanum eɾ hagnvel.
Translated_Text: Aramian would go to see himself, but he didn't feel like dressing.
Original_Orthography: Արամյանը կուզենար ինքն էլ գնալ նայել, բայց ծուլանում էր հագնվել:
Translation_Other: Арамян сам бы пошел посмотрел, но ему было лень одеваться.

Translated_Text: I love this girl.
I want this girl.
My brother made a boat out of an oak-tree.
My brother made a boat out of an oak-tree.
The policeman yells.
My enemy is ill.
The water is boiling.
The women cooked the meat.
The boy heard the bear.
The boy heard the bear.
The old lady taught the girl a song.
The boy pushed the girl (into the water).
The woman is digging for potatoes.

Primary_Text: Kanajkʰ cecum ein hatikneɾə (sandov jev vaɾsandov).
Translated_Text: The women were grounding the seeds (with mortar and pestle).
Original_Orthography: Կանայք ծեծում էին հատիկները (սանդ-ով և վարսանդով):

Translated_Text: This man is a hunter.
The house is burning.
The child is playing (with the ball).
The man screamed.
The little girl laughed.
The boy left the village.
I blinked.
The boy peeled the bark off the stick.
The boy made the stick clean of the bark.
The boy peeled the bark off the stick.
The boy peeled the bark off the stick.
The boy peeled the bark off the stick.
The boy peeled the bark off the stick.
The man took the money from his friend.
The man cut his hair.
The man shaved his beard.

Primary_Text: Aʁǯikə mtacecʰ iɾ tatiki masin jeɾek.
Translated_Text: The girl thought about her grandmother yesterday.
Original_Orthography: Աղջիկը մտածեց իր տատիկի մասին երեկ:

Translated_Text: The bear smelled the boy.
The bear nuzzled the boy.
The mother hugged her little boy.
I tore up my clothes.
I’m cold.
The boat sank.
The ground is dry.
The ball is rolling.
The little girl was sad.
It rained.
It rained.
The boy was hungry.
The boy froze.
The man fell (to the ground).
The man fell (to the ground).
The man died.
The man died.
My arm hurts.
The boy appeared (on the road).
The boy sang (a song).
The boy lived in the village.
The boy went (from the village).
The child jumped (on the floor).
Comment: ‘jump’ extended by Place (locative prepositional phrase)

Translated_Text: The child ran (on the floor).
The child ran (on the floor).
The man sat on the floor.
The man sat (on the floor).
The man sat down (on the floor).
The man climbed (up) the hill.
The man coughed.
The man washed (himself).
The girl washed the child.
The girl dressed the child.
The man helped the girl.
The man followed the girl.
The man met the girl.
Comment: primary valency (dat)

Translated_Text: The man searched for the boy.
The man liked the boy.
The boy liked the man.
The boy feared the man.
The man frightened the boy.
The man looked at the boy.
The man saw the boy.
The man knew the boy.

Primary_Text: Maɾdə tʁaji het aʁǯka masin χosecʰ.
Translated_Text: The man talked to the boy about the girl.
Original_Orthography: Մարդը տղայի հետ աղջկա մասին խոսեց:

Translated_Text: The boy asked the man for money.
I plucked a flower.
The man told a story to the girl.
The man shouted to the girl.
The man shouted to the girl.
The man said nothing to the girl.
The girl called the boy a fool.
The man built the house out of stone.
The boy broke the window with the stone.
The boy killed the snake with the stick.
The boy beat the snake with the stick.
The boy hit the snake with the stick.
The boy touched the snake with the stick.
The boy cut the bread with the knife.
The girl wiped the dirt from the table.
The girl wiped the dirt from the table.
The girl tore the page from the book.
The girl tore the page from the book.
The girl tore the page from the book.
The girl hid the book from the teacher.
The girl stole the book from the teacher.
The girl got the book from the teacher.
The girl showed the book to the teacher.
The girl gave the book to the teacher.
The girl sent the book to school.
The girl sent the book to the teacher.
The girl carried the book to school.
The girl carried the book to the teacher.
The girl brought the book to the teacher.
The man put the book on the table.
The boy threw the stone into the window.
The man put the book on the table.
The man poured the water into the glass.
The man filled (his) glass with water.
The man tied the horse to the tree.
Comment: Both dative and nominative choices as DO marking are typically available to animate non-humans.

Translated_Text: The man loaded the hay on the cart.
The man filled the glass with water.
The man covered the child with the blanket.
The girl ate the bread.
Ok, it's done this way, too.
Translation_Other: Хорошо, это тоже так сделано.

Primary_Text: Tʰoneɾov ʒuk voɾsacʰvac e Kaɾčaʁbjuri, Sevani jev Noraduzi meǯ.
Translated_Text: Tons of fish were caught in Karchaghbyur, Sevan and Noraduz.
Comment: ‘catch/hunt’: passive formed from causative
Original_Orthography: Թոներով ձուկ որսացուած է Կարճաղբիւրի, Սեւանի եւ Նորադուզի մէջ:

Primary_Text: Sa inčʰ ban e? - Na baɾkutʰjanb kʰašecʰ latʰi cajɾicʰ.
Translated_Text: What is this? – He furiously pulled by the tip of the clothes.
Comment: contact verb: locus of contact
Original_Orthography: Սա՞ ինչ բան է, — նա բարկությամբ քաշեց լաթի ծայրից:
